Heya all,


	Since we've been on the topic of music a fair amount lately, I 
thought I'd ask this rather broad/tangential question:  
	What kind of music do we SFRavers listen to when we're 
not raving?  I imagine that our tastes must be pretty varied considering 
how eclectic and creative this group is... so humor me, please!  Name a 
favorite artist, album, label, etc. (preferably outside the electronic music 
genre, but not necessarily!)
	Heh, I'll go first: 
	
	-Tom Waits always and forever tops my list of genius musicians/
	songwriters--no one else's music moves me as much as his.
	-The Chieftains are the most damnably fine Irish folk group in 
	the world
	-Fugazi are the most genuine punk band in the universe (any other 
	SFRaver's going to see them play at the Troc this weekend?)		
	-Others include Philip Glass, David Byrne, Lou Reed, Peter 
	Gabriel... blah blah. 


	Just curious,



		His Majesty jon, The Burger King

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov  1 02:44:15 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA12529; Wed, 1 Nov 1995 02:44:15 -0800
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA12524; Wed, 1 Nov 1995 02:44:10 -0800
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id CAA17701 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 1 Nov 1995 02:44:02 -0800
Date: Wed, 1 Nov 1995 02:44:02 -0800
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199511011044.CAA17701@well.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: On the road again . . .
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Haven't posted for a while about what I've been up to, so here's the
October Travelogue . . .
 
I finished up my Seattle project in the early part of the month.  It was
quite an experience being there amid the Mariners hysteria.  Got my old
baseball blood stirring!  However, I didn't see any of the games, as
I detest the Kingdome.  Besides, I didn't have time, in fact, I didn't
even have time to go out at night, or visit the new Platinum Records
outlet on Pike right off of Broadway.  This is the new store started by
my friends at Platinum here in Portland -- Ali, Scott, Jeff, Brad.
Seattle finally has a real DJ store, selling both equipment and recordings
(vinyl and CD).  I can't say much about the Seattle scene because I haven't
been to any events there at all.  But like Portland, it seems to be a
dreary choice between bad, cheezy clubs and bad, icky warehouse parties
with occasionally good DJs.  Which explains why I was fortunate enough
to spend more time elsewhere this month.
 
On the 7th, I was kindly invited to spin at Freaky Friday at the "friendly
confines" of Komotion.  It was a little weird following the fast-trance
DJ and then being followed by the belly dancer and drummer (yes, that's
right!), but overall it was pretty fun and I got to break out my
"San Francisco vs. Detroit Sound Clash" set with the SF toonz on the
left turntable and the Motor City ones on the right side for a unique
kind of one-and-one set.  Worked pretty well too.  I was also lucky enough
to see DJ Stonie (that's Jake to all of us!) play live, he played trippy
house with the Cakewalk sequencer and some keyboards.
 
The next night was the house party at the new home of sfraves stalwarts
Cindy, John and Sho, and it definitely rocked!  I got in a little over
my head but with no adverse effects.  I want to thank Ozy for an especially
excellent set down there in the basement.  The beer was fine and the cookies
were a little tooo fine!  There was a great good feeling at this party and
I hope there'll be more.  Sort of like a scaled-down version of the Blue
Cube gatherings . . .
 
The following weekend, I took the plunge, emptied the piggy bank and went
to Detroit for the Metroplex 10th anniversary party.  This was a big deal
for them not only because of the honors for Juan Atkins and Metroplex, but
because they have full-on parties so rarely in Detroit.  Read this month's
Urb for a brief rundown of how many get busted there.  Except for Jeff
Mills,
who was booked solid in Germany and couldn't take off the weekend, just
about everyone from the Detroit underground was there to play or just be
around.  Things started Friday evening with a small gathering at a gallery
for a special, one-time-only-probably-never-again live performance by Juan,
Mike Banks of Underground Resistance and two of the members of Aux 88,
who've put out excellent tracks recently on Direct Beat.  They did three
early techno tunes ("No UFOs," "Technicolor" and "Clear") which me, being
the relative newbie, didn't really know, but have significant meaning for
the Detroit hometowners.
 
The main event was spread out over two nights at an old disco warehouse
place called the Warehouse just north of downtown.  Two rooms were used,
and the music just kept getting better and better.  It was hella competitive
among all the DJs, but all for a good purpose.  Many people liked Rob Hood
and Orlando's sets, but housey type-a-guy that I am, I fell totally for
the sets by Anthony Shakir and Stacey Pullen, who impressed me thoroughly
by taking a kind of not-into-it Saturday midnight crowd and *making* them
willingly pay attention to what he was playing, just through
excellent track selection and mixing.  The stellar set remained for the
end, as Derrick May provided two hours of absolute sonic mastery.  It was
one of those wonderful moments I just gave up all my critical tendencies
to total enjoyment.
 
This meant I missed my chance to hear Juan play jungle (among other things),
but I did hear his two previous sets, which covered the range from vocal
house to trance techno to minimal beats.  He's not a technician as a DJ,
instead the musicality of his approach stood out and I finally understood
the basis of how Jeno and others play their best stuff.  You couldn't ask
for a more low-key yet self-assured DJ and musician than Juan Atkins, he
simply defines "total class" pure and simple.
 
The crowd for this stellar event was loose and happy.  I saw no "attitude"
at all.  Given the infrequent gatherings in the area, I thought Friday was
a real warm-up night, it seemed like people just didn't get loose until
near the end, but Saturday things steamed right up and the vibe was as
thick as it ever gets.  The people there were sweet and fun and it was
really nice to feel that unspoiled vibe again.  It must be hard to be
in an area where events happen so infrequently, but they sure take
advantage when they can.
 
I'll have more to say about Detroit in an article I'm starting to write.
Needless to say, my experience at the Detroit Regional Music Conference
in 1994 and the Metroplex party this month have sent my musical context
into some kind of techno hyperspace!  I should mention special thanks
to Robert Smith and Mike Banks, who provided hospitality beyond measure
and an outlook that in many ways defines where I think our scene needs
to go.
 
I left my records at home for the Detroit trip, but they certainly went
along for Tribal Future the following weekend.  This was organized by
the Ameba gang, of which I am proud to consider myself at least an
honorary member and "visiting resident."  They hooked up with Pacific
and Wicked and pulled off an amazingly wonderful outdoor event in the
redwoods.  This was one I could not miss, since it was the same location
where we did Penelope's Web in June 1993 (a collaboration between Your
Sisters House and some sfravers, led by Bob Ramstad, who put time,
effort and not a little dough into making that one happen).
 
In addition to the fantastic location in the redwoods on the side of the
hills east of Willits, about three hours north of SF, this is basically the
perfect spot for an outdoor dance party, with a clearing perfectly
sized for music, an amazing garden, a cabin with a full kitchen, solar
power, congenial hosts . . . what a place.  It was bone-chillingly cold
toward morning but totally pleasant during the day (unlike '93, when it
was great at night and blazing during the day).  I can't even remember
everyone who played, but I got my turn on the good old Ameba turntables
and mixer PLUS the Wicked sound system around sunset, and had a fantastic
time.  The real standout set was by Polliwog, who, just as she did
in 1993, demolished us all with an outside-beyond-belief tripped out
junglistic Mr. Rogers/Nile Rodgers Cosmic DJ Whirligig set.  She's my
favorite DJ in the world and #2 isn't even close.  I want to thank
Diane Tabellija for the driving and the excellent company; it was a
treat to meet yet another old-time sfraver I somehow had never met.
If by some miracle or luck we can do another event at Walter's Raver
Camp in Willits :) by all means cancel all your other plans and show!
 
Which brings us at last to this past weekend culminating in a stellar
Friends & Family.  I wasn't much involved in this one, preferring instead
to take it easy and just enjoy it.  In part this was because I had a
little secret.  As you know, Bill Gates is my Evil Twin, we were born
as twin brothers in different families on the same day, October 28,
1955, which meant that Saturday was our 40th birthday.  He didn't invite
me to his party, so I didn't invite him to mine.  Instead, Friends &
Family from all over provided me the best possible birthday party of all
by not having it have anything to do with *that* and instead be totally
about what we've been developing so steadily this past couple of years --
a mean-motor-scooter of a party organization and crew that has actually
planned and carried out some of the most rad events on the planet, small
as they may be.  I mean, where else can you hear "Dear Prudence" and
gabber being played on the same turntables within half an hour of each
other?  The usual stellar playing pertained everywhere, of course, but
a couple of sets really stood out for me -- those by Felix and Minor,
neither of whom I'd heard play before.
 
I have to give special mention to 3A hisownbadself -- Ameba Astralmatrix
AndyJ -- who gave us a thundering world premiere of his live set.  The
fullness and power of the live sound he got out of those little old-
fashioned boxes was just amazing, even to these jaded ears, and the
mesh with the fantastic Burning Man mud-people video only brought it
to that much higher a level.  I don't think I've had the feeling of
that uplifting surge that happened during that set for a long long time,
maybe back to some of my earliest Dead shows.  I know Andrew was pleased
with how it turned out, but the genuinely ecstatic response from many
of us who were in that ole garage when it happened was the kicker.
There are plenty of things to improve on with the F&F parties (uh oh,
that means we might have to do more?!), but it's still the best place
to be and this one proved it again.  The sound, the ambient areas, the
amazing lights and video show, all of it.
 
I was hoping to make the last Sunset of the year but couldn't snag a ride,
so instead I hung out on Haight St. all day and ended up meeting several
friends, grabbing a couple of records, and having a generally fully
pleasant time of it.
 
Home is where the heart is.  I live in Portland, love it, won't leave it,
but San Francisco is my musical home.  There's so much more I could say
but that says it all.
 
Thanks everyone . . .
 
peace
 
phred

My computer tells me that on Wed, 1 Nov 1995, Jonathan Mark Logan shared:

> Heya all,
> 
> 
> 	Since we've been on the topic of music a fair amount lately, I 
> thought I'd ask this rather broad/tangential question:  
> 	What kind of music do we SFRavers listen to when we're 
> not raving?  I imagine that our tastes must be pretty varied considering 
> how eclectic and creative this group is... so humor me, please!  Name a 
> favorite artist, album, label, etc. (preferably outside the electronic music 
> genre, but not necessarily!)

	Most of my favorite music would be generally categorized as eighties 
pop; I love Blondie, The Smiths, Book Of Love, Cindy Lauper, New Order, 
etc, etc, ad nauseum.  A lot of this I consider to be dance music, although 
many ravers might not.
	When I go skiing, I like to listen to Enya, The Orb, and other ambient 
stuff, or classical music such as Tchaikovsky.
	I also love movie soundtrack music; some of my favorites are The 
Living Daylights (Pretenders, Aha, etc.), Star Wars (John Williams), 
Jesus Christ Superstar (Andrew Lloyd Webber/Tim Rice), Born On The Fourth Of 
July (John Williams, Edie Brickell, etc.)
	I have a definite soft spot for many artists generally considered to 
be easy listening or "adult contemporary" (I love that term, it makes it 
sound X-rated):  Billy Joel, Elton John, Chicago, etc.
	A few other groups that I like a lot that don't really fit into 
the above -- The Beatles, ABBA, Pink Floyd.
	Finally, I love zany novelty records by artists like Weird Al 
Yankovic and the stuff heard on the Dr. Demento show.  So go figure.

Cheers,
				*** Starchild ***

______________________________________________________________________________
"[Dancing is] a perpendicular expression of a horizontal desire."
							-George Bernard Shaw

here are some of my favorites:
Bob Marley, whose music makes always makes me smile slowly,
The Clash, who were the smartest punk band, esp. 'London Calling', which is 
  probably the best album I've ever heard,
The Velvet Underground--there's no one cooler than Lou Reed;
B.B. King (anything of his live); Prince; The Beatles;
James Brown (now THAT'S dance music); early Rolling Stones; and
of course the best band of all, U2, for having the most passion.

just my two cents,
Timothy

Here is a brief list of my favorites (okay maybe it isn't so brief, I 
kinda got carried away!):

for the non techno catergory:
Negativland -Escape from Noise is a classic
Sonic Youth- Sister and Bad Moon Rising are favorites.
Big Black- Songs about Fucking and Atomizer punk rock with a beat box 
Scratch Acid-Just Keep Eating and Beserker 
Non-when you need some noise to scare the neighbors
Jerky Boys, Basement Tapes, Sound effects records, Weird Al, spoken Word, 
comedy records, TV theme songs (Love Boat), the Chipmunks
Morton Subotnick, Steve Reich, Stockhausen, Tery Riley, Edgar Varese, 
Robert Ashley, Pauline Oliverios-great selection at the local library 
Illusion of Safety, Hafler Trio, Nurse With Wound, Nocturnal Emissions. Coil 
Jesus and Mary Chain-Psychocandy an all time favorite of feedback guitar 
dreamy pop
Twisted Sister-Play "Were not going to take it" at a party and watch the 
place get destroyed!
New Order-They bring back a lot of memories
Art Bell-Talk radio about ufo's, ouija boards, conspiracies etc...
My own personal audio recording of 2 Sasquatch engaged in intercourse.


and then my brief dance/techno list
808 State-Newbuild (If you can find it, buy it, the best acid house ever 
imho!), 
Aphex Twin (The king of the underground), U-Ziq (the prince), Reflective 
Records, Rephlex records, Ubik, Single Cell Orchestra
Holy Ghost, Spiral Tribe, Meat Beat Manifesto, RSW, Ritchie Hawtin, UR, 
Mantronix, Rising high records, R and S records, The Mover (PCP), 
Dimensional Holophonic Sound, Erik Van De Broek, Drexicya, FSOl, 
Locust/Autocreation/Mark Van Hoen, Pete Namlook/Fax, Mike Kandel/Exist 
Dance records, Paul Bishop, Freddie Fresh


Derek
                                
0--\___/--\___/---0    moses@teleport.com     0--\_______/--------0

At 1:44 AM 11/1/95, you wrote:

>        Since we've been on the topic of music a fair amount lately, I
>thought I'd ask this rather broad/tangential question:
>        What kind of music do we SFRavers listen to when we're
>not raving?

I guess I should preface this by saying I have fairly wide-ranging musical
tastes.  Whatever my mood is dictates what I feel like listening to I
guess.  Okay, I'd intended this to be short but I kept thinking of more and
more faves I had to list 8P

Pink Floyd - had to head this list.  I have like 14 of their albums, 1 ROIO, and
                a super-funky "The Royal Philharmonic presents Pink Floyd"
                album!!
so-called "Classic Rock" artists I also dig - Jimi Hendrix, Santana, the
                Beatles, Led Zep, the Velvet Underground, Janis Joplin, and the
                Stones.  And I'll even admit to owning (and liking!) the
                "Frampton Comes Alive!" album 8P
Alternative stuff - Beck, Blur, Spaceman 3 (esp Playing With Fire), Nirvana, the
                Charlatans UK, Medicine, Spiritualized (anyone else seeing them
                tonight @ Slim's?), and the Lords of Acid.  Oh, and U2.  I know,
                I know, they're not really "alternative" (whatever _that_ is)
                but "Zooropa" is pretty unique
Artists I can't really categorize - Laurie Anderson, the Art of Noise, MC 900ft
                Jesus, Paul Simon (Graceland)
Soundtracks I like to chill to - 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Big Chill (*great*
                motown tunes!), Little Buddha, and the Blues Bros.
Misc Artists - Ray Charles, REM, John Denver, Miles Davis (Bitches' Brew),
                Public Enemy, Willie Nelson, Johnny Cash, Tchaikovsky (1812
                Overture, Romeo and Juliet), Richard Wagner (The Ring Operas),
                Bob Marley, Mongo Santmaria, Vicente Fernandez, the Beastie
                Boys, and... <gasp!> Milli Vanilli.  I'm sorry!  If I admit that
                do I have to give my SFR laminate back?  Cuz I won't ;)

>                His Majesty jon, The Burger King

All hail jon!  Vive le Roi!  8)

Luv,
Manuel

>Xref: netcom.com clari.sfbay.general:4874 clari.sfbay.police:10517
>Path: netcom.com!looking!bass!e.news
>Comment: Subject mapped from all upper case
>From: C-bcn@clari.net (BCN / L.Peterson)
>Newsgroups: clari.sfbay.general,clari.sfbay.police
>Subject: Lawsuit Filed Against SF Police in New Year's Eve Raid
>Organization: Copyright 1995 by Bay City News
>Message-ID: <VraidU5OV147pp@clari.net>
>Lines: 45
>Date: Tue, 31 Oct 1995 13:50:25 PST
>ACategory: regional
>Slugword: RAID
>Threadword: raid
>Priority: daily
>ANPA: Wc: 522/0; Id: a0054; Src: bcn; Sel: bagm-; Adate: 10/31/95-147pp
>Approved: e.news@clari.net
>Note: BCN54                  -RAID LAWSUIT

  	  	
	SAN FRANCISCO (BCN)   	
	Attorneys for seven people arrested by San Francisco police at a 
raid of an AIDS fundraiser on New Year's Eve filed a federal civil 
lawsuit against the city and four police officers.  
	Attorney Nancy Clarence said the suit was filed because of the San 
Francisco Police Commission's failure to take action on an Office of 
Citizen Complaints report that sustained 28 charges of misconduct 
against 21 officers last August.  
	``We will not allow our rights to be stifled by a do-nothing Police 
Commission and our freedoms held hostage by mayoral electoral 
politics,'' she said at a news conference outside the Hall of Justice.  
	The lawsuit claims the four defendants led more than 70 other law 
enforcement officials in a raid of a benefit for gay artists with HIV 
or AIDS at 938 Harrison St. on Jan. 1.  Eleven people were arrested on 
charges of resisting arrest, drug posession and operating an illegal 
nightclub.  All charges were later dropped.  
	Police said the raid was conducted because the building is not 
permitted to house large gatherings, though organizers said police 
told them they did not need a permit for the event.  
	The suit names the City and County of San Francisco, Police Chief 
Anthony Ribera, Sgts. John Haggett, Stephen Bosshard and Edward Santos 
and officer Hoyt Wong as defendants.  
	Plaintiffs Larry Ackerman, 44; David  Bowman, 32; Donald 
Branchflower, 28; Joseph Cain, 39; Eric Shannonhouse, 18;  Graham 
Cruickshank, 27; and Eden Somberg, 22  ``suffered the most serious 
abuse'' of those arrested, Clarence said.  
	According to the suit, officers and agents from the State Alcohol 
Beverage Control Board arrested plaintiffs without a warrant or 
probable cause and subjected arrestees to physical brutality and 
homophobic slurs.  Clarence said the four defendants had the most 
serious complaints of brutality against them as well as ``long and 
disturbing'' records of past abuse.  
	Police Chief Anthony Ribera said in September that six of the 22 
officers named in the OCC report, including a captain and a 
lieutenant, would be assigned hearings before the Police Commission, 
which oversees the most severe misconduct cases.  
	OCC attorney Bruce Kapsack could not verify any connection between 
the officers awaiting commission hearings and those named in the 
lawsuit but admitted the process was taking an unusually long time.  
	``There is generally a pattern and this case is taking longer than 
usual,'' he said.  
	Clarence said the lawsuit will be pushed forward even if the 
commission disciplines the officers soon.  
  	   	
--

also some Frank Sinatra and Harry Connick Jr.  I am not too heavily

Date: Wed, 1 Nov 1995 09:44:01 -0800 (PST)
From: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: mo' music question
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9511010926.A29082-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I couldn't help but share my music tastes.  It's great to hear everyone's 
varied tastes, an expression of their personality.

I think I have fairly wide ranging tastes thay have certainly expanded in 
the last years.  The one constant is that I love music that's driving, 
that gives me emotion.  This started with 80's glam rock and heavy metal; 
my all-time favorite through high school was AC/DC (kill me, I was a 
product of peer pressure in a hicktown!!!! :)  Now I don't have to suffer 
through misogynistic lyrics and am blessed with a plethora of riot grrl 
bands like L7, Babes in Toyland, Seven Year Bitch, Hole, Bikini Kill, 
etc.  I love female artists, I suppose partly as a reaction to the male 
rock world, but also I find something different and unique about this 
kind of music. 

My other big passion right now is FUNK and SOUL.  James Brown rocks my 
world like no other artist (the best concert I've ever seen).  Maceo Parker, 
Fred Wesley, Bootsie Collins, George Clinton, Parliment, Aretha 
Franklin, Lyn Collins etc. etc.
(I reccomend the two CD's called JB's Funky People which have artists that 
recorded on his label and are awesome)  I also saw Maceo and Fred in concert
about a month ago.  Man, they played for 3 hours straight without a break 
and we never stopped moving our feets.


My other love is Latin folk music and rock including Inti Illimani (some 
of the most talented artists ever), Mercedes Sosa (seeing her in concert 
tonight), Los Fabulosos Cadillacs (Argentinian ska!), Sexual Democracia, 
etc. 

To finish up:  I LOOOVE the Talking Heads (surprisingly, one of the first 
punk bands), Liz Phair, the Breeders, R.E.M., Stereo MC's, Black 
Sabbath, English Beat, Dramarama, Cure, etc., etc.  My favorite 
local bands are the Broun Fellini's, Lawsuit, and the Fabulous Hedgehogs.

chau--kc

On the topic of music:

Has anyone ever heard of Ozric Tentacles???  They are partly electronic, 
partly insrtumental upbeat ambient music that hail from England.  My SO 
turned me on to them and they are really great.  I don't know a lot about 
them, but they are good, and have 2-3 albums out.  From what I understand 
they are played at raves in the U.K. (but I wouldn't know fer sher since 
I've never been!! :] )

xxoo,

remember the helicopter song)...lets see...I also love to study to 
mozarts requiem, bach, 102.1, in the mornings I like public supported 
radio kqed, I also love the beatles, mazzy star, 10000 maniacs, bob 
marley compilation disc one, robert johnson, i dont like the cure or 
depeche mode anymore, but I still occasionally pull out those nitzer ebb 
or front 242 from way back.

From: Tenderloin Waxx <twaxx@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Rave the vote 
To: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
cc: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>, twaxx@netcom.com,
        sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951101012943.27862C-100000@orion>

> > still can't believe you actually believe what you're saying... making
> > services that civic in nature only means you are pitting someone's motive
> > for profit directly against the provision of services... it should be
> > no surprise, then, that these private interests act in their own
> > interest rather than that of the public.  Why?  Because they'd make
> > less money if they didn't act in their own interests.  Also, note the
> > cosy (read corrupt) way in which contact oriented business opportunities
> > are doled out (pun intended), it's really true, "it's not what you know,
> > it's *who* you know".  Dude, get a grip, Ben Hom is not going to give you
> > anything unless you're in the "capital gains club"... read the writing on
> > the walls, business always acts in its own this interest, regardless of
> > negative effects on anyone else, at least in America... this is not the
> > way it must be, but it is most certainly the way it is...
> 
> Dear Waxx,
> 
> 	I'm not asking Ben Hom to "give" me anything.  I think that's 
> part of the difference between people like myself who are inclined to 
> vote for a candidate like him and people inclined to vote for one of the 
> more socialist candidates.  Too many people are looking for a handout at 
> someone else's expense.  Sure it may be for a good cause.  That's beside 
--------------------------

I didn't mean "give" as in give you money, I met give in terms of giving
good, honest and fair representation as mayor.  Noone's looking for a
handout, so don't even go down that silly road, that's not what I'm
talking about.  BTW, Ben Hom WILL give you something; if you're not rich
enough to be in the "capital gains club", he'll give you a foot in the
ass.  He'll disrespect the constitution, the rights of city citizens, and
the city charter in favor of giving handouts to his business friends.  If
you're worried about handouts, find out where the handouts exist; in the
privatization business sector, that's where!



> the point.  I don't have the right to ask government to tax you to pay 
> for my good cause any more than you have the right to ask them to tax me 
> to pay for yours.
---------------

Obviously, that's not what I'm talking about... read my above paragraph.




> 	The distinction you draw between private interests and public 
> interests is, to my mind, unnecessary.  It narrowly defines the situation 
> through a win/lose paradigm (i.e. if private interest wins, public 
> interest must lose, and vice versa).  Why not look for a win/win solution?
-------------------------

I think you need to address the corruption concerns Niels raised, as any
gains through privatization will be lost through the rampant corruption.
What's your answer to Niels scenario?  Please don't say it isn't a real
scenario, as it's going on around us right now, Jordan is up to his ass
in that kind of shit.  So if you have an answer for Niels concerns, then
and only then, will I take you seriously.  I would really like to hear
your solution for those problems, and if it's sane, then maybe there could
be a "win/win" solution, but not before those concerns are remedied.




> There are lots of examples of businesses and individuals turning a profit 
> by providing a valuable public service that people are willing to pay 
> for.  Because their profit depends on the public's belief in the benefits 
> of the product they offer, private enterprise has a built-in motive to 
> provide a certain level of quality.  Government-run programs lack this.  
---------------------

Most privatization efforts strongly protect the company providing the
service from any competitive pressure and customers rarely have any other
choice WRT where to get the products or services, rendering your point
completely useless.  Unfortunately, since the public has nowhere to go
other than to the privatization company (in whatever market), the company
isn't REALLY sensitive at all to their customers, since the customers
don't have a choice to buy from someone else anyway... again, please
tell me your solution, I'm incredulous that you don't understand this.




> They generally have a captive market for their products, and their 
> continued funding depends not on offering a profitable service (i.e. one 
> that is valuable to members of the public), but rather on the continued 
> existance of the problem the program is designed to solve.  If a 
> government agency solves the problem it was designed to deal with, it is 
> likely that it will lose funding or be discontinued.  So in government, 
> there is not only no incentive to give value to the public, there is an 
> incentive to do the opposite.
----------------

Because of the situation I outline in my previous paragraph, the company
gets the privatization contact is in exactly the same situation as the
government in your above description, and like the government, couldn't
care less about providing decent value, since the customer is captive.
Again, I'd like to hear your solution.



> 	This is why if you look around the world you will see that 
> countries where the standard of living is rapidly improving (Chile, Hong 
> Kong, etc.) are those that place few restrictions on private sector 
> economic activity and have low rates of taxation, minimizing government's 
> drain on the economy.
------------------------

What is the ratio of rich to poor in these countries?  Who is benefiting
from the "capital improvements"?  Many of these countries have no middle
class, and the richest %1-5 are the only ones to benefit.  America is
headed in this direction, is this what you want?



> 	Corruption in the handing out of contracts can be avoided by 
> making entire government agencies into independent corporations rather 
> than having existing companies bid to take on the services they provide.  
-----------------

I don't buy it.



> Existing companies would be allowed to compete with the newly private 
> agencies, and power is effectively dispersed and decentralized.
--------------------------

I want to see how you will insure that the consumer/public will benefit
from having choices between competitive providers of good and services.
I bet you can't do it, because with this plan, it can't be done.  Look at
P.G.&E. in San Francisco.  San Francisco could provide its own public power,
stabilizing our debt crisis and providing much lower rates to city users
of power.  However, this "privatized" market is structured so that P.G.&E.
contributes serious bank to city politicians, ensuring that they can
continue to charge inflated power rates to city dwellers.  Our rates here
are among the highest in the nation, and this is through a basically
privatized power market here in San Francisco.  In fact, P.G.&E. hasn't
even stuck to the fat contract they won, they haven't even fulfilled the
commitments they made even when they did get the contact to provide power
for their own profit.  Please explain your solution...




> 	 People in the United States are starting to realize the truth of
> what libertarians have been saying for years, which is why privatization
> is becoming increasingly popular -- it works.
----------------

Only for the top %1-5... please answer my above concerns, or this point
simply doesn't hold.




> 	Again, this needn't be seen as a victory for business, or the 
> right wing, or as a withdrawal of society's commitment to the poor and 
> disadvantaged.  True laissez-faire capitalism, as opposed to corporate 
> socialism and the misleading stories we learned in history about 19th 
> century robber barons, benefits society as a whole, the poor most of all.
-----------------

You are truly out there starchild, this is completely off the wall.  If
you can explain away my concerns I'll be amazed...


> 
> Cheers,
> 				*** Starchild ***
> 
---------------

-=jack=-

my faves:

  older stuff:

     pinkfloyd (remember when that's the way they spelled it?)
     grateful dead
     old alan parsons (i robot, etc)
     boc (old weird stuff)
     nillson (me and my arrow!)

  medium old stuff:
    
     pat metheney 
     john mclaughlin
     steve vai
     bob marley
     black uhuru
     ini kamoze
     yngwie malmstein
     the specials 

  new stuff:
     the orb
     william orbit
     banco de gaia
     primal scream
     happy mondays

basically, any blunt-induced or -listenable stuff ;)

Hi everybody,

sorry for the massive crosspost but I think this should be interesting
to at least some people everywhere.  Version 2.0 of DJ ONLINE starts
this Thursday at 6:30 Eastern.  If you weren't around earlier this
year when we did the first series, DJ ONLINE is a regular weekly thing
where DJs and musicians from the scene are invited onto VRAVE for you,
the people, to talk to them :)  If you don't know what vrave is, ask
your friends :) or try it yourself (telnet hyperreal.com 7283) any
time.  Anyway, DJ Online 2.0 starts this Thursday and will happen every
Thursday (except for holidays) at 6:30 pm Eastern until at least mid-
January.  Here's the (very tentative) schedule.  I think it will probably
be on channel two of vrave.

Nov  2 - KEOKI and SOULSLINGER
Nov  9 - DB and JOESKI
Nov 16 - JAMES CHRISTIAN, JASON JINX, MIKE DEARBORN and TERRY MULLAN
Nov 30 - DEEP DISH and SCOTT HENRY
Dec  7 - HEATHER HEART and ADAM X
Dec 14 - NIGEL RICHARDS and DJ ORION
Dec 21 - KIMBALL COLLINS
Coming in January - RITCHIE HAWTIN, JOHN ACQUAVIVA, PROTOTYPE 909, JOHN
SELWAY, SCOTT RICHMOND

If you have any questions, please e-mail me at speakman@biost.mskcc.org.
Please also mail me there if you (1) have any suggestions for people
we should invite onto DJ Online, or (2) live in/near Orlando or Detroit
and would like to host a DJ Online from there (you should be able to
figure out which ones :))

But please DON'T do a REPLY to this message unless you are ABSOLUTELY
CERTAIN it will go to just me and not to the huge list of mailing lists
in the Cc: line.  If you're not certain, please just mail me at the above
address.  Thanks!

John
speakman@biost.mskcc.org

For example, I posted about the excellent "melody maker" (UK) 3 CD
compilation "the serious roadtrip" bosnian children's charity CD  I
picked up a while back. It's probably the best $22.00 I ever spent on
new techno/trance/dub/rave music...

Normally, I wouldn't have bought it but the artist track looked like it
woulda creamed yer average IDM-list trainspotter's panties. SO I bought it.

At Reckless Records, I also saw, but didn't purchase:
	Peel Sessions of Planet Dog (??) -- comments?
	Some Eat Static import (not "Abduction" which I have).

So rather than spouting about how you actually have a secret soft spot
in your heart for Frank Sinatra, how about just posting some quickie
reviews of really outstanding CDs, Compilations, LPs, Tapes you've
recently purchased (give prices and location if ya can!).

Our Wallets and Our Ears Will Thank You For Your Dilligence!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov  1 13:34:16 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA01905; Wed, 1 Nov 1995 13:34:16 -0800
Received: from nature.Berkeley.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA01891; Wed, 1 Nov 1995 13:34:07 -0800
Received: (from davidk@localhost) by nature.Berkeley.EDU (8.7.1/8.7.1) id NAA22926; Wed, 1 Nov 1995 13:34:05 -0800 (PST)
Date: Wed, 1 Nov 1995 13:34:05 -0800 (PST)
From: David Kilimnik <davidk@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Bass-in-your-face-mobile
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951101131057.18678B-100000@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi-
	
	After a wonderful mad raver weekend featuring the 
stompy-FnF-sunset triple kaboom, my friend and I were finally feeling 
like ourselves again last night.   We decided to mosy on over to the 
castro to check out the festivities.  Decked out in our complementary 
costumes of circa 1990's urban street wear, we felt a little guilty about 
contributing to the forces that have turned the castro party a little 
sour.  Most people were not in costume...the drag queen contingent was 
very low..and the drunk idiot contingent was extremely high.   Anyway, we 
managed to push our way through the elbow-to-elbow crowd until we were 
reasonably close to the thundering sound system that was set up on market 
st above castro.   They were pumping what i guess would best be called 
happy house, the kind of music you'd hear leaking out of a castro st. bar 
or club.   I probably could have danced a little bit to these sounds, but 
it would have taken an amount of will power that i'm seldom capable 
of.   The soreness of our muscles, and the drunkenness of the dense 
crowd around us told us to leave pretty quickly.
	What we came across next was really more intriguing.  Parked at 
18th and church was a bus with some nice sounds emerging from it.   We 
decided to go check it out, and found the bus to contain a few roland 
synthesizers, and a pair of turntables, with someone spinning more 
progressive sounding music.   There were a few people dancing happily on 
the sidewalk to these pleasant beats.  This bus had a really nice 
sounding system, and the dj had nice taste in music.  I was wondering if 
anyone out there knows about this bus, or knows who is behind it.  It 
would be perfect at those outdoor renegade parties which get broken up,  
where people end up dancing to a mixed tape in someone's car stereo.  
	
	Did anyone else see the bass-bus, or was it just wishful-hallucinating?

	Wishing I could c/u tonight, -dave.

Uhh... hmmm.... this one is difficult for me to answer, but...

When I'm not listening to techno, I really get into:

Indie
-----------
o Love Battery
o Catherine Wheel
o Smashing Pumpkins
o Pixies
o The Breeders
o Pavement
o Wire
o Throwing Muses
o Belly
o His Name Is Alive

Noisy Guitars
-------------
o Swans
o Godflesh
o God
o Neurosis
o Hair & Skin Trading Co.
o Truman's Water
o Big Chief
o Superconductor
o Pain Teens
o Pitchblende

Dischord
--------
o Fugazi
o Minor Threat
o Lungfish
o Nation of Ulysses
o Jawbox
o Holy Rollers
o Slant 6

Melancholy Indie
----------------
o Red House Painters
o This Mortal Coil
o The 6ths
o Magnetic Fields
o Talk Talk
o Codeine
o American Music Club
o The Wedding Present
o Heatmiser
o Eliot Smith
o Orang

Shoegazer
---------
o My Bloody Valentine
o Swirlies
o Slowdive
o Mojave
o Pale Saints
o Chapterhouse
o Medicine

Experimental Industrial
-----------------------
o :zoviet-france:
o Lilith
o Coil
o Voice of Eye
o Bourbonnese Qualk
o Morthond
o Mental Destruction
o Paul Schutze
o Nurse With Wound
o Old Psychic TV
o Foetus
o Negativland

Twitchy Dance
-------------
o Meat Beat Manifesto
o Renegade Soundwave
o Art of Noise
o Cabaret Voltaire
o Intermix
o New Psychic TV
o Pop Will Eat Itself
o Wiseblood

Doom and Gloom
--------------
o Skinny Puppy
o Legendary Pink Dots
o Tear Garden
o Severed Heads
o Current :93.
o Dead Can Dance

Japanoise
---------
o Merzbow
o The Boredoms
o Futsushita
o Hijokaidan
o Gerogerigegege

Hip Hop
-------
o Public Enemy
o Paris
o Pharcyde
o Eric B & Rakim
o Beastie Boys
o old NWA

Country
-------
o Patsy Cline
o Hank Williams, Sr.
o Lyle Lovett
o Johnny Cash

Adolescent Power Chords
-----------------------
o Def Leppard
o Yes
o Aldo Nova
o Loverboy
o Foreigner

Avant-Garde
---------
o Krystof Penderecki
o Iannis Xenakkis
o Karlheinz Stockhausen
o Michael Nyman
o Philip Glass

Classical
---------
o Bach
o Mahler
o Tchaikovsky
o Shostakovich
o Vivaldi
o Chopin

Of course, what I'm into at any given moment is only a small subset of the
above, and I don't own recordings by all of them, but this is a pretty good
representation of the sort of music I like. There will always be more music
that I like and want than I can afford. Keep in mind, though, that for the
past few years (save the last two months), I've been buying almost nothing
but techno.

yrz,
ozy

Since we've (perhaps) moved onto recommending/reviewing albums, I'd have to 
plug Sabres of Paradise' _Haunted Dancehall_...
It's chock full of spooky textures and complex beats.  Not quite ambient, 
not really dancy, it's pure Sabres, once again defying classification.
And they never have cheesy computer graphics on their album covers!  
How's that for an innovation in the techno genre?


		    jon
		The Burger King

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Okay, I know it's a little late, but I thought I would add my two cents...

This was THE BEST event I have *ever* been to.  F&F has to have been the
in the "spirit of raving" an ideal-world party.

The only things that took away from this being *the* ultimate party (not in
general, just for me personally) was that I was spending quite a bit of
time running around all night making sure that all my first-time friends
were having the best experience possible. I was spending time with another
friend who came alone and was having a bad E trip. That was still pretty
much okay for me though, and not really a huge downer, just a distraction
from total concentration on celebration. The only thing bad was that I had
the misfortune of bumping into a few spooks that gave me some REALLY bad
vibes... :-( but the rest of you weren't affected by them the way they
affected me, and most likely you never even knew you saw them...

With regard to physical setup, etc. I think that the warehouse worked much
better than the last F&F due to the 90 degree rotation of the DJ area, the
added laser, lights, video, etc. And the posh outdoor ambient areas were
loads better than last time (and there were 2!) and the trailer decorated
with the branches made a totally special place.

The "first time" friends' minds were all TOTALLY blown, and they are ready
to do it again and again! One those friends sent me this:

"I want to thank you for being there with me. Now I understand."    !!!!! :-)

I feel that message is not meant for me, but it's for all of us that were
there in
celebration that night!

thanks!

 Hello SFRavers -
 Recently , Jon asked : 
> 
> 	What kind of music do we SFRavers listen to when we're 
> not raving?  I imagine that our tastes must be pretty varied considering 
> how eclectic and creative this group is... so humor me, please!  Name a 
> favorite artist, album, label, etc. (preferably outside the electronic music 
> genre, but not necessarily!)

 The way I answer this question is to reword it - "Which artists would I
buy a new recording of , without even knowing what the recording sounds like?"

 These are my instant buys ( not in any kind of priority ): 

 1. Siouxie and the Banshees ( proto-goth dark romantics ! )
 2. Hawkwind ( Space rock grunge/ambient )
 3. Most former members of Hawkwind ( Nick Turner , mostly )
 4. Chris and Cosey / CTI ( industrial pioneers )
 5. Bill Nelson ( former Be Bop Deluxe guitarist ) 
 6. Dead Can Dance
 7. Love and Rockets

 These are almost instant buys :

 1. Industrial ambient ( Zoviet France , Nocturnal Emissions , etc )
 1. Mickey Hart ( Grateful Dead drummer )
 2. Grateful Dead ( country rock/blues/jazz/folk/improv band )
 3. Bad Manners ( SKA!!! )

 Showing my age ...
                  Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov  1 18:45:19 1995

In-Reply-To: <199511012131.NAA07738@netcom15.netcom.com>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Jeno's first tape "House Reality" fit's any of my moods. Some of the best 
music ever made, lots of acid-house and variety, even Kraftwork, Meat Beat 
Manifesto, Renegade Soundwave and a couple dubby songs.

His other tapes "Bang the Drum", "Inside the Mind" & "We Are Phuture" are 
also realy realy good. I have yet to hear any tapes or sets come remotely 
close to achieving the kind of emotional expression as these have.

Actualy Future Sound of Londons "Accelerator" album is also brilliant.

-josh

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Nov  2 03:08:31 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id DAA06431; Thu, 2 Nov 1995 03:08:31 -0800
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id DAA06426; Thu, 2 Nov 1995 03:08:28 -0800
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id DAA08831; Thu, 2 Nov 1995 03:08:15 -0800
Date: Thu, 2 Nov 1995 03:08:15 -0800
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199511021108.DAA08831@well.com>
To: nwraves@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Masa gets thumbs-up!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In every issue of DJ Magazine from the UK, a guest DJ gets to review
a bunch of new releases.  It's far and away the best thing in the
magazine.  In the September 28 issue, Mr. C of the Shamen (who also
runs Plink Plonk, just to show he's not all Ebeneezer Cheeze :) hmas
this to say about Masa's "Drum":

    Now "Drum" really canes the dancefloor at high volume.  It's
    a superb bumpy tribal cut that builds slowly, becomes more
    trippy, intricate, and funky as it does so, then gaining an
    offbeat hip hop kinda rhythm later on; really psychedelic.
    They've [sic] pushed rhythmic percussion in a new direction
    for house music, and bumpy house DJs wbho like a techno feel
    could mix it forever.  "Basscharger" is a deeper dubby
    alternative for even darker tribalist moments.

I think that means he likes it :)  I played it at Tribal Future and
it's a top-shelf track (I also played two Plink Plonks in that set,
so that clinches it, right? -- and all this before getting the magazine).

It's quite a charge to read a review in one of these self-important
magazines about a record someone you know put out, especially if they
get it right :)

phred

Just a reminder that the elections are Tuesday.
I know people don't like us posting about politics on here, but I just got
a permit proposal rejected again today. If we get out and vote, we can hopefully
change things. If not, dancing will certainly be outlawed. So will loud music.

Its too late to register for this year's election but I believe it is still
possible to register in time for the runoff elections which will probably
be held. To register, pick up a form at the library or post office or the
Registrar of Voters Office
633 Folsom St, #109
San Francisco, CA 94101

If you live elsewhere, there are other local Registrar's offices.
Don't forget Alameda County's new decision to forbid all future all-night
events. I've heard rumors that there are board positions on the ballot.
Richmond dwellars: The Civic Center policy is still being debated: Use your
votes.

And for everyone: Please tell people to vote. Not just on the net, but one
on one. Promoters: Please mention it on your VM lines. If you live outside
of SF, call your friends there and remind them. Just get people talking.

Dancing can and will be outlawed.

Peace,
Colin

TIGGER: Keoki, who inspired you musically?
KEOKI: aldskfal89cxnq.2348ZSdm I AM A SUPERSTAR!!! a1340vQ#@%sad05mq2 =83zxz39
TIGGER: What do you have to say about the allegations of your misconduct at
TIGGER: various parties?
KEOKI: I AM A SUPERSTAR!!!  szlxv!$^QSD%^@*&Wcfm// q w4eo89gd=2980(*&%^&934

Sandra Maccarone, Weekly Reader's editor in chief, was traveling and could
not be reached for comment and no one else at the company could comment on
the study, Maccarone's office said. 
----------------

Yeah, this is the type of public service you will get out of most
privatized industries.  As you can see, not only do they propagandize
children (in this case), but they are so insensitive to their "customers",
that they not only don't provide the best value, they aren't even
available for comment.  With politicians, sooner or later, they're made
to answer inquiries, even though the inquiries often never amount to
any punitive or restorative action (although it did with Richard
Nixon and Bob Packwood).  In private industry, there's no requirement
to even answer an inquiry in the first place.

Starchild, would you please address these issues and explain how you
will handle them?

-=Jack=-

(This text composed by voice)

   Little Louie Vega and Wicked sounds like a good combo to me. On the
   techno tip, Frequency 8 is back that same night. Come/Unity was pretty
   solid last night - Garth was working the crowd with some funky stuff,
   mixing in some oldies and a slow groove in the middle. Friends and
   Family was amazing as usual, and even better than ever.

   Don't forget to VOTE on Tuesday, especially in San Francisco.  The
   mayor's race, the district attorney's race and the curfew proposition
   could all have effects on the scene.

Administrative Notes 

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.

Subject: Re: privatization hard at work 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Thu, 02 Nov 95 11:48:26 PST."
             <Pine.3.89.9511021120.A23518-0100000@netcom3>

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


In case you were all wondering what the heck Mr. Jack Hart is quacking
about, he was responding to a private note I sent to him and starchild
stating something like "see, this is what you can expect with
privatization".

The case involves one of those free educational readers distributed to
children because schools don't have enough money to buy their students
proper textbooks... So instead a shining knight of a company, RJR
Nabisco (RJ Reynolds Tobacco) steps in, and after people are blinded by
the twinkling of the thousand points of light, after people are so
thankful that the good will of US businesses will take care of the kids
that the "government" has forgotten about -- they gradually find out
that behind the apparent good will of the company was little more than
a successful attempt at direct-marketing cigarettes to school children!

This is pretty much a microcosm of what you can expect if the
libertarians get their way, and privatization becomes rampant. Nobody
in business does anything out of "pure good". Corporate good deeds, at
best, involve positive PR, and more typically, involve motives of
profit.

Also, Starchild made some comment that the failures that we've noted in
libertarianism and privatization stem from the fact that the examples
weren't cases of "pure privatization". Same argument could be made for
socialism/communism -- it would work great in an ideal world where
corruption, greed, and money aren't a problem. Unfortunately, all you
have to do is wake up, get out of bed, and go to work, then note  how
far things are from ideal.

Sorry if this is non-topical, but I wanted to clear some things up...

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Weekly Reader spread tobacco industry views, researchers say

Associated Press

SAN DIEGO -- School children who read the Weekly Reader 
between 1989 and  1994 were treated to an unhealthy dose of 
tobacco industry views on  smoking in articles that were often 
illustrated with Joe Camel,  researchers say.

At the time the articles appeared, the Weekly Reader was owned by 
the  largest shareholder in RJR Nabisco, Joe Camel's creator.

Joe Camel, a promotional cartoon character for Camel cigarettes, 
has been  widely criticized for appealing to children.

Scholastic News, a competing newsletter, was much more likely to 
include  health warnings and to give health advocates the last 
word, said the  authors of a study presented Monday at the annual 
meeting of the American  Public Health Association.

In October 1994, health advocates attacked the Weekly Reader over 
an  article for youngsters that discussed smokers' rights and the 
harm to the  industry from smoking restrictions. The article said 
nothing about  smoking as a cause of lung cancer and heart disease.

Following that uproar, researchers at the University of California, 
San  Francisco analyzed 34 articles from the Weekly Reader dealing 
with  smoking. For comparison, they analyzed 28 from another 
school newsletter,  Scholastic News, which is published by a 
family-owned company.

In the Weekly Reader, distributed to school children nationwide, 
68  percent of the articles included tobacco industry views and only 
38  percent carried a clear message against smoking. In Scholastic 
News, only  32 percent of articles included industry views and 79 
percent carried  anti-smoking warnings.

``Weekly Reader needs to change its editorial policy,'' said the  
principal researcher, Edith Balbach of the University of California, 
San  Francisco. ``They're certainly not helping kids not to smoke.''

The Weekly Reader is owned by K-III Communications, a unit of 
Kohlberg  Kravis Roberts, which was the largest shareholder of RJR 
Nabisco until  March, when it sold its interest in RJR.

Sandra Maccarone, Weekly Reader's editor in chief, was traveling 
and  could not be reached for comment and no one else at the 
company could  comment on the study, Maccarone's office said.

Balbach expressed particular concern over an article for sixth-
graders on  whether Joe Camel is encouraging kids to smoke. 
Research has shown that  Joe Camel is as familiar to children as 
Mickey Mouse, and that Camel  cigarettes have increased in 
popularity among teen-agers since the  campaign began.

The article appeared in an issue in which Joe Camel was on the 
cover  handing out ``Camel cash'' promotional coupons. Inside, 
the article  featured a reproduction of a Joe Camel billboard.

Next to the billboard was a reproduction of an RJR Tobacco poster  
advising children not to smoke. The Weekly Reader's caption said 
the  poster was intended to help children make the ``right 
decision'' about  smoking.

``You will note that doesn't indicate which is the right decision,''  
Balbach said.

Joe Camel appeared eight times in the Weekly Reader articles, she 
said.

``There were no negative markings on the photos, such as the 
international `no' symbol. In effect, they were not that different 
from actual ads,'' she said. 

Joe Camel appeared seven times in Scholastic News, but in three 
cases children were demonstrating against the character and the 
pictures had the international ``no'' symbol over them. In two 
other cases, Joe Camel appeared as part of stories on how the 
industry uses advertising to hide the dangers of smoking, Balbach 
said. 

----- End Included Message -----

Hi Everyone,

My boyfriend and I will be travelling in Spain (Madrid and Barcelona 
mostly) and Paris in December, and of course, we would like to check out 
"the scene" there. So who better to ask for tips than people on this 
list? If you know of any clubs, stores, cafes, underground-type places, 
etc. in any of those or other nearby locales, please let me know! We're also 
interested in jazz clubs (both traditional, for lack of a better word, and 
acid) and any other recommendations regarding places to visit, stay or eat -- 
we are trying to experience the culture more and do the touristy stuff less, 
so any advice on how to avoid the Pier 39s of Europe would be appreciated!
By the way, we won't have a car - we're planning to rely on our feet and 
public transit.

Thanks much.
:)
Kathryn 


P.S. I tried to send this yesterday, but it never showed up on the list 
(as far as I can tell anyway). Anyway, sorry if this is a duplicate message.

On Thu, 2 Nov 1995, Kathryn Ankrum wrote:

> 
> 
> Hi Everyone,
> 
> My boyfriend and I will be travelling in Spain (Madrid and Barcelona 

The biggest club in Barcelona is the Apolo ( Nou de la Rambla 113- 
Paralelo 61). Dj record stores (aka sources for flyers) are hard to find 
in Barcelona, there used to be one called Revolver Records, but I don't 
know if it is still around. There is one really good clothing/dj shop in the 
Barri Gothic, but I can't remember the name or where it is. The Bari-Gothic is 
home to many trendy shops, so if you walk around you should be able to 
find one, just listen for the bass. I can't really comment on the jazz 
scene in Spain, but you might find more in France, or even in some parts 
of Switzerland (Luzern and Zurich). Generally, I've noticed that the 
farther south in Europe you go, the more disco/happy euro-house the clubs 
are, and the farther north you go the more acid/hard techno you get. I 
guess you should look in the middle?

marc

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Nov  2 17:55:38 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA20298; Thu, 2 Nov 1995 17:55:38 -0800

	id RAA24313; Thu, 2 Nov 1995 17:55:51 -0800

Message-Id: <199511030155.RAA24313@ix2.ix.netcom.com>
From: scary@ix.netcom.com (Gary Burns )
Subject: Re: instead of musings on music, howbout musings on current purchases?
Cc: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Niels wrote: 

>So rather than spouting about how you actually have a secret soft spot
>in your heart for Frank Sinatra, how about just posting some quickie
>reviews of really outstanding CDs, Compilations, LPs, Tapes you've
>recently purchased (give prices and location if ya can!).

	I recently picked up Transmissions from Planet Dog - a sampler
	from the various bands that make up the Planet Dog label. Two
	CD's with a smattering of tunes from Eat Static, Banco de Gaia,
	Timeshard & Children of the Bong. The music is of the Trance/
	Techno genre, speed varies (although never that fast), and even
	though the featured artists follow a similar theme, they each
	have a distinct & recognisable sound.

	Some fine tracks throughout, most notably from Eat Static &
	that Banco fellow, although I'm less impressed with Timeshard
	& Children of the Bong (not bad, just not that good).

	If, like me, you own none of the contributors other CD's, this
	will serve as a good introduction - if you already own material 
	from these artists, maybe its not such a good bye.

	The revelation was Banco de Gaia, in particular Mafich Arabi, a 
	delicious, complex & original record. Unfortunately, I've been 
	unable to find any of his other CD's (I believe there's one 
	older one, and a new release out around now).
	
	-Gary

I'll add a little. Two CD's I got recently and really enjoy are the 
Rising High/Moonshine compilation "TranceFiction" and "leftism" by 
Leftfield. Trancefiction has some really good stuff here, especially 
Casper Pound and Sound Enforcer. Leftfield is just awesome to listen to.
All their well known songs (Original, Open Up, Song of Life, Release the 
Pressure) are here but in different mixes as well as songs I hadn't heard 
before. Everything on this one is excellent-lots of bass and tribal 
influences (Black Flute and African Left).
 
  Overall, while I listen to a lot of styles of music I haven't bought 
anything but techno/acid/house music for years. Except for some Didjerido 
music ala Stephen Kent.

  Another thing with the recent postings on confusion between Stareyes 
and Starchild I noticed there is a second Austin as well! So I'll include 
Tinsau in my signature while he uses Phunky.


       AAMMMMMDD
      A AM M MD D
     AAAAM   MD  D
    A   AM   MD   D        Austin
   A    AM   MDDDD         Tinsau

To reply...the transmission from planet dog was my firs tintroduction to 
that label about 2.5 months ago...since then I have bought the new album 
from all but timeshard...I especially love eat-static implant...a kick 
ass tune!!and children of the bong symbol 1...another cool alien type 
thing that is pretty freaky...
	the banco de gaia new album last train to 
llasha is awesome...I loved it the very first time that I put it on...
	The same goes for Children of the bong...the release Sirius 
Sounds is terrific, track 1 and three are especially classic...
	The eat static took a little more getting used to...it is faster 
and more in a club atmosphere than the rest...but after a few listenings 
it has definately grown on me.
	All in all I really like the sounds coming from this label. Nice 
to chill to.
all of these releases are excellent for various moods sitting around the 
house...not too much base to make you feel like you are at a club or party
or something.
-Hierophant

On Thu, 2 Nov 1995, Gary Burns wrote:

> Niels wrote: 
> 
> >So rather than spouting about how you actually have a secret soft spot
> >in your heart for Frank Sinatra, how about just posting some quickie
> >reviews of really outstanding CDs, Compilations, LPs, Tapes you've
> >recently purchased (give prices and location if ya can!).
> 
> 	I recently picked up Transmissions from Planet Dog - a sampler
> 	from the various bands that make up the Planet Dog label. Two
> 	CD's with a smattering of tunes from Eat Static, Banco de Gaia,
> 	Timeshard & Children of the Bong. The music is of the Trance/
> 	Techno genre, speed varies (although never that fast), and even
> 	though the featured artists follow a similar theme, they each
> 	have a distinct & recognisable sound.
> 
> 	Some fine tracks throughout, most notably from Eat Static &
> 	that Banco fellow, although I'm less impressed with Timeshard
> 	& Children of the Bong (not bad, just not that good).
> 
> 	If, like me, you own none of the contributors other CD's, this
> 	will serve as a good introduction - if you already own material 
> 	from these artists, maybe its not such a good bye.
> 
> 	The revelation was Banco de Gaia, in particular Mafich Arabi, a 
> 	delicious, complex & original record. Unfortunately, I've been 
> 	unable to find any of his other CD's (I believe there's one 
> 	older one, and a new release out around now).
> 	
> 	-Gary		
>

               If I could speak the way I wanted to with each and everyone
of you in the most personal intimate way, I'd want it to be.  If I could not
have all the fire that I have, I'd want it to be.  If I could constantly be
in a perfect state of Zen all the time, I'd also like it to be.  I know for
sure that when I'm at peace, the fire in me is calm.  My mouth, what a long
story.  My whole life saying the wrong thing, time after time.  If I could
count the number of people I've offended, put off, said the wrong thing to
time after time, it may take my soul perminatly out of cosmic working order.
It's  hard to apologize when you can't see what your doing  until after it's
done.  As wide as I try to open my eyes, I'm always over looking things.
I've never meant any bad Energy towards anyone and that seems to be the only
truth I know.  Sometimes I wish I could be more aware, cause once the damage
is done, it's to late.
I feel contradicting when I think of what Frequency 8 means and how I
sometimes act.  My goal is the Eighth Frequency, and trust me, everyday I'm
not on that level, and every person I come across with wrong Energy to, I
feel it.   I feel my biggest challange in life, calm the fire and just Be.
I geuss I'm honored by Life to have such an oppertunity; be in Zen or pay
the price.  It's not easy to actually have a sensitive soul under all this
mess of crazy Energy.  To every person I've made contact with on this
planet, and to those of you that I've met in the dream state, please know
that I'm under construction.   If I could find a way to take back every bit
of Energy that I've misplaced, misdirected, or malfunctioned with I would.
It seems only at that point would I be able to start fresh with everyone of
you and introduce myself again the way the Real me would like to.
So what is Frequency 8?  From my understanding there is a certain
consciouness that we can attain while on this planet.  The highest that we
are able to get to is the Eighth level of understanding.  This "level" is
determined by how in touch we are with ourselves emotionally, physically,
and spiritually.  Most people in our society are around a level of 2 to 3.
Buddah, Jesus, and Mosses attained the 8th level.  They were Enlightened
Beings with a direct connection to the One Energy source that surrounds us.
I feel that this music; trance, Goa, Cyber- whatever it is that we choose to
call it, comes from the 8th Frequency.  It is a sound vibration.  To me this
vibration would sound as if the Mothership were fifty feet over my head and
I was bowing down in awe.
It seems that some of us on this Planet have an instictual understanding for
this sound, we don't know exactly why, but it calls us.  I feel that this
vibration is commimg from the Eighth Frequeney and is bringing those of us
who respond to it together.
My whole vision of the number 8 came to me while studying in Jerusalem last
summer.  It was a sunny day and I was standing on top of a building over
looking the remains of the Holy Temple of Israel.  The number 8 hit me with
the power of lightening.  I had no idea what the significance of the number
meant.  It was months after I had gotten home, and the power of that
experence finally calmed, that an old Rabbi told me that 8 was the numer of
the Messiah.
Leaving Home Soon,
Michael Adam RobbinS (MARS)

Niels,

I knew this was going to be brought up by someone... :-)

No, they really are real.  If you check the credits I'm actually the 2nd
author on all this stuff and I can provide the internal Hubble archive ID
numbers for you to go and find the files for yourself.  Its just Murphy
giving us an interesting twist that the pictures happened to be taken on that
date.

you see our next pictures of the center of M8 - the Lagoon Nebula.

Hope this allays your fears.

Want to see some cool picures? Download the full size images accessible
from the following pages:
	http://www.stsci.edu/pubinfo/PR/95/44.html
	http://www.stsci.edu/pubinfo/Pictures.html

I'm not normally a sci.astro kinda geek, but CNN was on while I was working
and they had this news piece on the first pictures of the birthing of stars
and the picures looked pretty spectacular. So I typed the following into
the netcom unix prompt (cuz netscape's news interface blows, and rn/GNUS is
too slow):
	cd /usr/spool/news/sci/astro
	find . -type d -print
		##	found directory hubble
	cd hubble
	scan +. last:10
		##	found this article below...

But then again, I was beginning to think that perhaps these are just
pictures of turds that have been fixed up in Photoshop. Anybody know for
sure? If so, this April fools joke made it all the way to CNN...

excerpted from the text below:
| The picture was taken on April 1, 1995 with the Hubble Space Telescope 
| Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2.

Anybody know if these are real or just a belated April fools joke?

          NASA Headquarters, Washington, DC      
          (Phone: 202-358-1547)

          Fred Brown
          Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MD 
          (Phone: 301-286-5566)

          Ray Villard
          Space Telescope Science Institute, Baltimore, MD
          (Phone: 410-338-4514)

PRESS RELEASE NO.: STScI-PR95-44


  EMBRYONIC STARS EMERGE FROM INTERSTELLAR "EGGS"

Eerie, dramatic new pictures from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope 
show newborn stars emerging from "eggs"  -- not the barnyard variety -- 
but rather dense, compact pockets of interstellar gas called evaporating 
gaseous globules (EGGs).  Hubble found the "EGGs," appropriately 
enough, in the Eagle nebula, a nearby star-forming region 7,000 light-
years away in the constellation Serpens.

"For a long time astronomers have speculated about what processes 
control the sizes of stars -- about why stars are the sizes that they are," 
said Jeff Hester of Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ.  "Now in M16 
we seem to be watching at least one such process at work right in front 
of our eyes."

Striking pictures taken by Hester and co-investigators with Hubble's 
Wide Field and Planetary Camera  2 (WFPC2) resolve the EGGs at 
the tip of finger-like features protruding from monstrous columns of 
cold gas and dust in the Eagle nebula (also called M16 -- 16th object 
in the Messier catalog).  The columns -- dubbed "elephant trunks" -- 
protrude from the wall of a vast cloud of molecular hydrogen, like 
stalagmites rising above the floor of a cavern.  Inside the gaseous 
towers, which are light-years long, the interstellar gas is dense enough 
to collapse under its own weight, forming young stars that continue to
grow as they accumulate more and more mass from their surroundings.

Hubble gives a clear look at what happens as a torrent of ultraviolet 
light from nearby young, hot stars heats the gas along the surface of 
the pillars, "boiling it away" into interstellar space -- a process called 
"photoevaporation."  The Hubble pictures show photoevaporating gas 
as ghostly streamers flowing away from the columns.  But not all of 
the gas boils off at the same rate.  The EGGs, which are denser than 
their surroundings, are left behind after the gas around them is gone. 

"It's a bit like a wind storm in the desert," said Hester.  "As the wind 
blows away the lighter sand, heavier rocks buried in the sand are 
uncovered.  But in M16, instead of rocks, the ultraviolet light is 
uncovering the denser egg-like globules of gas that surround stars 
that were forming inside the gigantic gas columns."

Some EGGs appear as nothing but tiny bumps on the surface of the 
columns.  Others have been uncovered more completely, and now 
resemble "fingers" of gas protruding from the larger cloud. (The fingers 
are gas that has been protected from photoevaporation by the shadows 
of the EGGs).  Some EGGs have pinched off completely from the 
larger column from which they emerged, and now look like teardrops 
in space.

By stringing together these pictures of EGGs caught at different stages 
of being uncovered, Hester and his colleagues from the Wide Field and 
Planetary Camera Investigation Definition Team are getting an 
unprecedented look at what stars and their surroundings look like 
before they are truly stars.

"This is the first time that we have actually seen the process of forming 
stars being uncovered by photoevaporation," Hester emphasized.  "In 
some ways it seems more like archaeology than astronomy.  The 
ultraviolet light from nearby stars does the digging for us, and we study 
what is unearthed."

"In a few cases we can see the stars in the EGGs directly in the 
WFPC2 images," says Hester.  "As soon as the star in an EGG is 
exposed, the object looks something like an ice cream cone, with a 
newly uncovered star playing the role of the cherry on top."

Ultimately, photoevaporation inhibits the further growth of the 
embyronic stars by dispersing the cloud of gas they were "feeding" 
from.  "We believe that the stars in M16 were continuing to grow 
as more and more gas fell onto them, right up until the moment that 
they were cut off from that surrounding material by photoevaporation," 
said Hester.

This process is markedly different from the process that governs the 
sizes of stars forming in isolation.  Some astronomers believe that, 
left to its own devices, a star will continue to grow until it nears the 
point where nuclear fusion begins in its interior.  When this happens, 
the star begins to blow a strong "wind" that clears away the residual 
material.  Hubble has imaged this process in detail in so-called 
Herbig-Haro objects.

Hester also speculated that photoevaporation might actually inhibit 
the formation of planets around such stars.  It is not at all clear from 
the new data that the stars in M16 have reached the point where they 
have formed the disks that go on to become solar systems," said 
Hester, "and if these disks haven't formed yet, they never will." 

Hester plans to use Hubble's high resolution to probe other nearby 
star-forming regions to look for similar structures.  "Discoveries 
about the nature of the M16 EGGs might lead astronomers to rethink 
some of their ideas about the environments of stars forming in other 
regions, such as the Orion Nebula," he predicted.

                                * * * * * *

The Space Telescope Science Institute is operated by the Association 
of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. (AURA), for NASA, 
under contract with the Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MD.  
The Hubble Space Telescope is a project of international cooperation 
between NASA and the European Space Agency (ESA).
