PRC95-44c   M16 B&W Detail    gif/M16HaBW.gif     jpeg/M16HaBW.jpg

Higher resolution versions (300dpi JPEG) of the release photographs will 
be available temporarily in /pubinfo/hrtemp: 95-44a.jpg, 95-44b.jpg and 
95-44c.jpg.

GIF and JPEG images, captions and press release text are available via 
World Wide Web at URL http://www.stsci.edu/pubinfo/PR/95/44.html, 
or via links in http://www.stsci.edu/Latest.html and 
http://www.stsci.edu/pubinfo/Pictures.html.

Space Telescope Science Institute press release text and other information 
are available automatically by sending an Internet electronic mail message 
to listserv@stsci.edu.  In the body of the message (not the subject line) 
type the words "subscribe pio Name."  Don't use quotes or user/account 
names; i.e., someone named Jane Doe would type subscribe pio Jane Doe.  
The system will reply with a confirmation via e-mail of each subscription.  
E-mail will be received with new press releases.

FOR RELEASE: November 2, 1995
PHOTO NO.: STScI-PRC95-44a

             PILLARS OF CREATION IN A STAR-FORMING REGION
                 (Gas Pillars in M16 - Eagle Nebula)

Undersea corral?  Enchanted castles?  Space serpents?  These eerie, dark
pillar-like structures are actually columns of cool interstellar hydrogen 
gas and dust that are also incubators for new stars.  The pillars protrude 
from the interior wall of a dark molecular cloud like stalagmites from the 
floor of a cavern.  They are part of the "Eagle Nebula" (also called M16 -- 
the 16th object in Charles Messier's 18th century catalog of "fuzzy" objects 
that aren't comets), a nearby star-forming region 7,000 light-years away in 
the constellation Serpens. 

The pillars are in some ways akin to buttes in the desert, where basalt and 
other dense rock have protected a region from erosion, while the 
surrounding landscape has been worn away over millennia.  In this 
celestial case, it is especially dense clouds of molecular hydrogen gas 
(two atoms of hydrogen in each molecule) and dust that have survived 
longer than their surroundings in the face of a flood of ultraviolet light 
from hot, massive newborn stars (off the top edge of the picture).  This 
process is called "photoevaporation."  This ultraviolet light is also 
responsible for illuminating the convoluted surfaces of the columns and 
the ghostly streamers of gas boiling away from their surfaces, producing 
the dramatic visual effects that highlight the three-dimensional nature of 
the clouds. The tallest pillar (left) is about a light-year long from base to 
tip.

As the pillars themselves are slowly eroded away by the ultraviolet light, 
small globules of even denser gas buried within the pillars are uncovered.  
These globules have been dubbed "EGGs."  EGGs is an acronym for 
"Evaporating Gaseous Globules," but it is also a word that describes 
what these objects are.  Forming inside at least some of the EGGs are 
embryonic stars -- stars that abruptly stop growing when the EGGs are 
uncovered and they are separated from the larger reservoir of gas from
which they were drawing mass.   Eventually, the stars themselves emerge 
from the EGGs as the EGGs themselves succumb to photoevaporation.

The picture was taken on April 1, 1995 with the Hubble Space Telescope 
Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2.  The color image is constructed from 
three separate images taken in the light of emission from different types 
of atoms.  Red shows emission from singly-ionized sulfur atoms.  Green 
shows emission from hydrogen.  Blue shows light emitted by doubly-
ionized oxygen atoms.

Credit: Jeff Hester and Paul Scowen (Arizona State University), and NASA

Image files in GIF and JPEG format and captions may be accessed on 
Internet via anonymous ftp from ftp.stsci.edu in /pubinfo:

                                      GIF                      JPEG
PRC95-44a    M16 3 Pillars       gif/M16Full.gif          jpeg/M16Full.jpg

Higher resolution versions (300 dpi JPEG) of the release photographs will 
be available temporarily in /pubinfo/hrtemp: 95-44a.jpg, 95-44b.jpg and 
95-44c.jpg.  GIF and JPEG images, captions and press release text are 
available via World Wide Web at URL 
http://www.stsci.edu/pubinfo/PR95/44.html, 
or via links in http://www.stsci.edu/Latest.html and
http://www.stsci.edu/pubinfo/Pictures.html.

RELEASE DATE: November 2, 1995

PHOTO NO.: STScI-PRC95-44b

            STELLAR "EGGS" EMERGE FROM MOLECULAR CLOUD
                     (Star-Birth Clouds in M16)

This eerie, dark structure, resembling an imaginary sea serpent's head, 
is a column of cool molecular hydrogen gas (two atoms of hydrogen in 
each molecule) and dust that is an incubator for new stars.  The stars are
embedded inside finger-like protrusions extending from the top of the 
nebula.  Each "fingertip" is somewhat larger than our own solar system.

The pillar is slowly eroding away by the ultraviolet light from nearby 
hot stars, a process called "photoevaporation".  As it does, small globules 
of especially dense gas buried within the cloud is uncovered.  These 
globules have been dubbed "EGGs" -- an acronym for "Evaporating 
Gaseous Globules".  The shadows of the EGGs protect gas behind them, 
resulting in the finger-like structures at the top of the cloud.

Forming inside at least some of the EGGs are embryonic stars -- stars 
that abruptly stop growing when the EGGs are uncovered and they are 
separated from the larger reservoir of gas from which they were 
drawing mass.  Eventually the stars emerge, as the EGGs themselves 
succumb to photoevaporation.

The stellar EGGS are found, appropriately enough, in the "Eagle Nebula" 
(also called M16 -- the 16th object in Charles Messier's 18th century 
catalog of "fuzzy" permanent objects in the sky), a nearby star-forming 
region 7,000 light-years away in the constellation Serpens.

The picture was taken on April 1, 1995 with the Hubble Space Telescope 
Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2.  The color image is constructed from 
three separate images taken in the light of emission from different types of
atoms.  Red shows emission from singly-ionized sulfur atoms. Green 
shows emission from hydrogen.  Blue shows light emitted by doubly-
ionized oxygen atoms.

Credit: Jeff Hester and Paul Scowen (Arizona State University), and NASA

Image files in GIF and JPEG format and captions may be accessed on 
Internet via anonymous ftp from ftp.stsci.edu in /pubinfo:

                                     GIF                   JPEG
PRC95-44b    M16 1 Pillar        gif/M16WF2.gif      jpeg/M16WF2.jpg

Higher resolution versions (300 dpi JPEG) of the release photographs 
will be available temporarily in /pubinfo/hrtemp: 95-44a.jpg, 95-44b.jpg 
and 95-44c.jpg.  GIF and JPEG images, captions and press release text 
are available via World Wide Web at URL 
http://www.stsci.edu/pubinfo/PR95/44.html, or via links in
http://www.stsci.edu/Latest.html and 
http://www.stsci.edu/pubinfo/Pictures.html.

        
RELEASE DATE: November 2, 1995

PHOTO NO.: STScI-PRC95-44c

         STELLAR "EGGS" EMERGE FROM MOLECULAR CLOUD (CLOSEUP)
                  (Evaporating Globules in M16)

This eerie, dark structure, resembling an imaginary sea serpent's head, is 
a column of cool molecular hydrogen gas (two atoms of hydrogen in each 
molecule) and dust that is an incubator for new stars.  The stars are embedded 
inside finger-like protrusions extending from the top of the nebula.  Each 
"fingertip" is somewhat larger than our own solar system.

The pillar is slowly eroding away by the ultraviolet light from nearby hot 
stars, a process called "photoevaporation".  As it does, small globules of 
especially dense gas buried within the cloud are uncovered.  These globules 
have been dubbed "EGGs" -- an acronym for "Evaporating Gaseous Globules".  The 
shadows of the EGGs protect gas behind them, resulting in the finger-like 
structures at the top of the cloud. 

Forming inside at least some of the EGGs are embryonic stars -- stars that 
abruptly stop growing when the EGGs are uncovered and they are separated 
from the larger reservoir of gas from which they were drawing mass. Eventually, 
the stars emerge as the EGGs themselves succumb to photoevaporation.

The stellar EGGS are found, appropriately enough, in the "Eagle Nebula" (also 
called M16 -- the 16th object in Charles Messier's 18th century catalog of 
"fuzzy" permanent objects in the sky), a nearby star-forming region 7,000 
light-years away in the constellation Serpens.

The picture was taken on April 1, 1995 with the Hubble Space Telescope 
Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2.

FOR RELEASE: October 18, 1995
PHOTO NO.: STScI-PRC95-43


        HUBBLE DISCOVERS NEW CLASS OF GRAVITATIONAL LENS 
              FOR PROBING STRUCTURE OF THE COSMOS

These two objects represent a new distant class of quadruple, or
cross-shaped, gravitational lenses which might eventually provide
astronomers with a powerful new "magnifying glass" for probing a
variety of characteristics of the universe.

The two gravitational lenses were discovered in about 100 fields of sky
imaged by Hubble Space Telescope's Wide Field Planetary Camera 2.  The
first cross-shaped lens was discovered serendipitously by Eric
Ostrander while processing HST images for the Medium Deep Survey, a
Hubble key project led by Richard Griffiths.  A second fainter and
smaller lens was identified a few weeks later by Myungshin Im.  Each
configuration is in the form of four faint blue images situated
symmetrically around a much brighter red elliptical galaxy.  The
distinctive cross-like pattern around an elliptical galaxy makes them
unambiguous quadruple lens candidates, even before spectroscopic
observations, which are typically used to confirm lenses.

Hubble's high resolution allows astronomers to extend the search to
much fainter, and hence much farther lenses, than those few examples
ground-based telescopes have uncovered relatively nearby.  Hubble can
explore a larger volume of space which could provide enough examples of
this rare cross type of lensing to allow astronomers to address a
variety of fundamental cosmological questions.

A gravitational lens is produced by the enormous gravitational field of
a massive object which bends light to magnify, brighten and distort the
image of a more distant object.  Depending on the alignment between the
objects and the mass distribution of the foreground lens, the more
distant object can be smeared into arcs or split into pairs, triples,
or even quadruple images.

Credit: Kavan Ratnatunga (Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD)

        the abundance of space.

        me like family.

i turned 24 the night of F&F....  :)

i really liked DJ Carlos -- can he get the crowd hyped or what!  :)
supposedly Derrick Carter was to spin, but at 3AM, i had to go.

i felt outta place with no costume!

SUBJECT: TV report / Help

Last month I was in Dallas and had the opportunity to meet several
great people there, check out the scene, and even go to a genuine, fun
outdoor rave.

Anyway, I received a request from a good friend I met there to post this
to SFRaves.  Apparently a local TV station in Dallas has broadcast a very
negative and misleading report on raves (no, have not seen it so am
taking the below on faith).  Shows how lucky we are here!
 (While in Dallas I did get the chance to witness a "posse" of cops try to
  bust the rave I was at, and they really are as hick-like (cowboy hats and
  chewing tobacco and all) as portayed on the worst TV movie - eek!)

To: kxas@pic.net
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Concerning your report on raves -- KXAS
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com, TBOBSC@tevm2.nsc.com, jv@mcmann-tate.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear KXAS,

I was disturbed, but not suprised, to find out that your television station
aired a misleading and innacurate report on raving in the Dallas area.  I
was disturbed because raving (parties which involve repetitive beat music)
has been misunderstood since it's emergence in the underground culture of
America, I was not suprised, because most underground cultures are.

Like our parents, we are members of a generation that want to show future
generations how to love and respect one another; we will succeed where they
have failed.  When they began their quest to make the world a better place,
your brothers and sisters of the media hearlded them as drug touting
hippies.  And now, so many years later, you uphold the same
yellow-journalistic spin.  Your way of shaping the world is grounded on
making money, ours rests on the foundation that collectively, through love,
respect, music, dance and commitment to our cause, we can make a positive
impact on our society.  What contributions do you make toward a better
tomorrow?  And don't say "offering in-depth, fact filled journalism to the
people," for television media has become the potato chip for the couch
potato: greasy and full of crap.

But that's getting us off to a negative start.  Let me back up and defend
the rave scene in general:

Our scene is not about drugs!  Our scene is about movement.  Movement that
starts at the core of our soul and is drawn forth through music -- dance.
Movement that will afford a safer, more peaceful place to live for our
children (if we decide to have any) -- social consciousness.  And movement
to educate as many people as possible on how to treat eachother with
respect -- love.

Why did you take a camera undercover to an event that would have accepted
you openly?  I am certain you would find many happy people to talk to
upfront, with a camera and lights on.  Since you wouldn't find violence,
sex or other angles to spin your story with, I feel the true fear lies in
your inability to sell the story.  The veil of low-light, undercover camera
work is a nice tactic in guiling the viewer into thinking that the focus of
your story (the people involved) is trying to cover something up.  In this
case, were you to remove the veil your dedicated viewers would have found
people eager to tell you how much "the scene" has positively affected them.

Like all social movements, there are dark sides to raving.  You decided
that it was this dark side you would report on, thus marking the whole
movement seem to the mindless viewer as an untethered, drug crazed scene.
There are people who want to take advantage of a good thing.  There are
drug dealers and those who don't have the control to monitor their intake.
But let me say this, your focus on those people is why your story was
innacurate.  That's not what we're about.

Save your undercover video clips for insurance scams, police brutality
cover-ups, political scandals and other scenes where people actually have
something to hide.  We are proud of the love, unity and respect that we
offer one another and we encourage you to do a little more in-depth
reporting on the subject, instead of trying to further scare the likes of
Mom and Pop Couch Potato who, with gin and tonic in hand, believe every
word your plastic coated anchor people spew.

If I sound mad, I'm not.  I'm just disappointed in you.  That's alright
though, I'm sure with time, as we prove ourselves worthy of some positive
news coverage, you'll change your story fast enough.  That I have no doubt.

Most respectfully,


Tony Rotundo
Age:  28
College Educated
Professional

P.S.  While your crew was filming the story, did they notice that there was
just one long song playing the whole time?  The amazing talent and
dedication it takes to "spin" records, or rather, DJ, is worthy of ten
times the amount of coverage you gave to the only questionable part of our
scene.  But you know, we've come to expect cheap shots from you, for
without them your Ken and Barbi in front of the camera might actually have
to break a sweat.

You feed the couch potatos, while we teach their children to dance!

As in the early nineties raves were given a bad rap by the europiean
tabloids.  And as the age old adage rings true: "What we don't know, We
condem".  Although I'm in San Francisco And you're in Dallas, you condem me.

I rave (and have been for five years) at the age of 23.  I live a upright
social life as a salaried manager at a nationwide computer/electronics store.
 Unfortunatlly, the media, like yourselves, has forced this sub-culture into
a counter-culture.   Instigating and pitting us against our past generation
(ie parents) and the future generation (our children).  We have been
stigmatized and cast off as odd, drug using freaks.  You condem me.

It's funny how the same "dark side" of raves can be found at any niteclub,
concert, art & wine festival, or large social gathering.  Drug use and
intoxication.  However, If one were to take an accurate survey of raves to
these other events you possibly be suprised at how many events end in any
kind of violence.  I can say as a person (i.e. raver) that has been going to
events once a weekend for about 5 yrs. I've noticed that less than 6 raves I
attended ended with any kind of physical confrontation.  I doubt you can say
that with any of the other socialy accepted functions listed previously. 

Actually if one of your reporters were to go to a "Rave" she/he might be
suprised to notice the communal feeling with fellow ravers.  Many of us are
quite non-violent, yet, protective of our own. We have to be.  You caused
this...

I am not bitter.  I have no hate towards you, media.  However, It is sad to
see that since you dont understand us, we're evil.

But, we will still grow....

Foustus

"If enlightment is just a word, knowlage is a route to understanding words"

        "Portland raves?" (Nov  4,  4:31pm)
References: <951104163149_12839323@mail04.mail.aol.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: JohKir@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Portland raves?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You can get info on what's happening in Portland and the Northwest by
subscribing to nw-raves right here on hyperreal.

There are two or three big warehouse style events in Portland every
month these days.  Not my cuppa, but there ya go.

Brad Vachal's the organizer of Down & Out on Thursday nights at Up Front.

Saucebox on Broadway is just starting a Sunday night thing.  

Queer Night at La Luna is every Monday, probably the strongest weekly in
the Northwest now.

The rest is cheezy disco and pop-house, although some people like the
Panorama.

c ya
phred

the gardening club loves you all

        As you can see below over the last year, "the gardening club" has
brought you a contrast of Dj's and many different genres of music from
Psychedelic Funk to Disco to Techno, ambient and Jungle. All brought to you
in an environment based on communication and inhaling THC. Our music
programming has always been to ask Dj's to bring a set of music that they
have always wanted to play but never get a chance to.(every Dj has a set of
those weird tunes).

        Our Job is done you have been educated by "the gardening club."
        Repetitive music that all sounds the same does not have to be the
basis of  clubland.
        You have to experiment, to allow yourself to evolve!

Thanks to all these people:
Jonah Sharp(Spacetime Continuum), Mark Broom (UK),  Claire(Clear),
Pete Namlook,(Fax) Jon William's(natural), Thomas(wicked), Dj Bone(Detroit),
Kevin(Bulletproof), Spun, Dr Rockit(Clear), Phil Smart(Sabotage),
Velocette(Reflective),
Borealis(natural), Jesus and the Alien, Garth(Wicked), Tobin(Soundworks),
Mu-Ziq,
Derrick Carter(Classics), Mark Farina(Mushroom Jazz), Andrew Rawnsley(XLr8r),
Professor Smith(XLr8r), Markie(Wicked), Galen(Pacific), Matty SKYLAB(UK),
Dani & Charlotte(Butterfly), Jeno(Wicked), Dj Emma(DiY), Robbie Hardkiss,
Digs & Woosh(DiY),
 Gamal(Reflective), Marusha(Love Parade), Patrick Pulsinger(Cheap), DB(Smile),
John Howard, Suiki, Black dog(UK), Felix(Black Dimond), Dj Ace, Pascal
feos(Germany), Mune(Tokyo underground),Delux(UVC), Subtropic(Reflective),
Darren (tweekin)Polywog, Hyperdelic, Synergy, New Moon Cafe and all the
other  gardeners we have missed.
Plus our bestest bar leaners, who drank enough to keep the club open.
Barry(Primal), Billy(Reflective), Jason, Jonah,Sasha & Richard.

THIS MONDAY IS OUR LAST NIGHT AS A WEEKLY PARTY
November 6th

Special Guest TBA
Charles Uzzell Edward's(FAX)
Darkhorse(natural)

Thanks for your Support
See ya Around.
the gardening club
Don't let things get stale again, otherwise we will be back!
http://www.manmade.com
faxlabel@sirius.com
the gardening club will be back sporadically at certain events.

i read your reply to the news station.
you bring some good points, but in calling "them" names and teh such, we 
only stoop to their level. it creates opposition, before they think about 
what youre saying, they have already taken offence, and will tend to 
naturally cling to their beliefs that "raving pollutes the minds of young 
innoscent children with dangerous chemicals" rather than hearing what you 
have to say.
POSITIVE energy is easy to reitirate when everyone is loving, caring, 
concerned. but it is in the face of those who dont understand that we 
need to show our POSITIVITY the most, teh virtues of our scene.
other than that, i agree wit you, and thank you for taking the time to 
voice your feelings. Its a beautiful scene, and i hope you dont take 
offence to my comments.
smiles:) tom

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Nov  5 01:30:33 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA29680; Sun, 5 Nov 1995 01:30:33 -0800
Received: from uclink.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA29675; Sun, 5 Nov 1995 01:30:30 -0800
Received: by uclink.berkeley.edu (8.6.10/1.33(web)-OV4)
	id BAA07113; Sun, 5 Nov 1995 01:30:28 -0800
Date: Sun, 5 Nov 1995 01:30:27 -0800 (PST)
From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: my musical history...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9511050103.C27167-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

sorry I came onto the music topic so late, but...

here's a brief summary of my musical history (or "How I got into techno", 
by Seth Horvitz)

-4th grade Duran Duran
-5th grade I became a breakdancer, started listening to Run-DMC, UTFO, 
Grandmaster Flash, Egyptian Lover, etc.  Hey, when are thick shoe laces 
going to came back into style? 
-6th grade Prince and all associated projects (Morris Day & the Time, 
Appalonia, Vanity)
-7th grade Beastie Boys
-8th grade I started getting "alternative", and continued through high 
school (Depeche Mode, U2, the Cure, Smiths)
-12th grade I simultaneously became a 4AD addict (this is a record label, 
not a drug :) and a punk rocker
-College was the turning point for me.  I started branching out into 
weird experimental/industrial/goth rock, but soon discovered the magic of 
T99 and LA Style in combination with a certain hallucinogens.  I became 
fascinated with all forms of electronic music, and have continued to be 
since then.  I still listen to all kinds of music, but all of it somehow 
seems to GO with techno in a strange way.  I generally like all forms of 
music that were either inspired by, or somehow seem to work well in 
combination with psychedelics of any kind.  

Anyone else want to tell their "how I got into techno" story?  (as 
opposed to the "how I got into raves" story)

-Seth

Last night we went to a restaurant "RAW" and Conscious Labs was playing 
ambient toons while the chef served up totally raw (cold, uncooked, vegan) 
food.
It was super hip. Andrew got his soup and then his pizze, then a half an hour 
passed and I got my stuff (soaked , not cooked, rice among other things).
There were ravers there :] Expect to be there a while, but I swear we felt 
high when we left.             ...  on 9th near Lincoln

Message-ID: <Pine.OSF.3.91.951105134259.31090D-100000@pogonip.scs.unr.edu>

Precedence: bulk

   Saturday, November 4th - space children - Be Here Now

I have a little odd coincidence story to tell everyone, so bare with me.

A group of us were planning to drive from Reno to SF last night so one my 
friends could Experience San Francisco one last time before moving north.
Things didn't work out though, so we ended up in Barnes and Noble (a Reno 
bookstore) late last night. We were wandering around aimlessly when all 
of a sudden Jennifer pulled a blue book off the shelf in the New Age 
section and ran over to me.

The book was entitled _Remember: Be Here Now_

Both of us were more than a little spooked by this, especially when the 
first page she flipped open to WAS THE BUTTERFLY THEY USED FOR THE FLYER.

I bought the book; it's incredible. All of these thoughts on life from a 
very plur-aly, ravey, consciousness oriented Eastern philosophical slant. 
(If no one objects, I'm going to post things from it from time to time-- 
it is an INCREDIBLE book.)

Anyway, later we ran into a friend, and when we showed him the book and 
the flyer, his eyes got really big, and he said "You are supposed to be 
there. I've never seen anything like this. It's amazing the way the 
universe works. Even when you can't physically be where you're supposed 
to be, the energy of the universe always seems to draw related things 
into your life exactly when they're supposed to be there."

It cleared up a lot in my mind to hear this. Lately I've been frustrated 
by my geographical constraints. I had been wondering if my life situation
was causing some wierd form of chaos to invade my life and cause my growth
process to become stagnate. I realized then & there that no matter where
you go, no matter what you do, you are where you are supposed to be. And
that's all there is to it. :)

(About the book: There are no author credits given.
The front section was written by Dr. Richard Alpert, Ph.D, one of 
Timothy Leary's cohorts at Harvard during the LSD experiments) 

Hope your weekend was wonderful!
oh, and if anyone did go to this... what was it like? 

					lv, Alex


      Alexandra Crocket   |  "Reality is anything 
      alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with" 
	         -------PLUR-------





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Nov  5 16:10:25 1995

From: Foustus@aol.com
Received: by mail06.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id TAA03816 for Sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sun, 5 Nov 1995 19:09:48 -0500

Subject: Nights, music,styles, vibe and Yoda
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A warm greetings to all this fine morning...

So with all the festivities of the nyght I choose F-8 as my droppad, dancing
to some very intense sets.  I top off my Mao cap to the DJ's (in reverse
order): Cyr, Mystr-e, and MARS... They came up with some innovative tunes,
yet kept that common "trait" which keeps me coming back.  Unfortunatly I
didn't make it to hear the start-off DJ's nor thier sets.  

Dispite the chilly cold around 4 or 5ish the atmosphere was pretty chill.  I
actually got a kick out of the more clubby types that dropped by during cyr's
sets. I invade thier world @times too, so respect is given. Opening horizons,
that's what it's all about.

I do apologize for "bumpin'" into a few of yous or your friends.  One of the
DJ's did state that I have an "aggresive dance style". I dance how I dance,
all I can state is that thier are no enimies in the the floor of dancing.  So
apologies again are given.

As for Yoda, we'll chat later @ Degohba

Smiles-o-meter

Vibe:  9smiles (nice build up sets, with a few wrenches to cross up us happy
dancers)

Friendship Factor:  8.5smiles (Lot's o friends both old and new.)

Dancing space: 8smiles (I guess Im getting used to more spacious areas)

Tunes:  9smiles (Lotsa energy at this one, I believe it's the music in the
end to allow us to move the energy from one soul to another)

Overall 8.75 Smiles. All I can state is that It's going to be interesting to
see how much F-8 will improve after the winter.

In closing,
Everyone searces. Dj's search fo a better beat.  Phlosiphers search for
better words. (I search for a better spell-checker) Dancers search for a
better spin. Life is that adventure in searching.  Look hard. Look at others.
Look in yourself.  What do you search for?  One day, we may, or may not, ever
find it...
So,till then, enjoy your ventures...  

Spins,

Adam

"A true master has lived the slaves life"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Nov  5 17:27:42 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA24405; Sun, 5 Nov 1995 17:27:42 -0800
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA24395; Sun, 5 Nov 1995 17:27:39 -0800
Date: Sun, 5 Nov 1995 17:27:39 -0800 (PST)
From: Andrew Thomas <andy@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Subject: Be Here Now (SF)
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.951105162013.19497A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


This had to have been one of the most diverse parties I've been to in a
long time, something for almost everyone.  I debated whether or not to go
becuase of the steep cover ($20) but I'm really glad I went.  The crowd
was pretty young (some of the kids looked *really* young), I'm sure most
of the 21+ were at Wicked.  I got there around 11:00, some dj was spinning
some progressive house, I wasn't really into it but things really picked
up when Jonah went on after.  Wow, I've always liked Jonah's taste in
music but last night he was just incredible, his mixing has really
improved (although there were some wierd spots).  Lots of techo that you
just don't hear played that often, some of it was even a little funky.  J.
Saul Kane (Depth Charge)was on next, I was expecting him to be better
technically, a lot of his mixes were sketchy but his records made up for
it.  A mix of chuggy depth charge dub stuff, some IDM (he played a couple
u-ziq tracks and some other stuff I recognized but couldn't place), some
techno stompers and misc. electronic wierdness.  It was great.  DRC played
some decent hard trance, i was bored by her set at first but it really
picked up later, and the crowd was going nuts, I think her set probably
got the best reaction of the night.  DJ Dan was amazing as usual.  After
Dan was an impromptu jungle set by Goldie (in town opening for Bjork). 
Even though I'm not into jungle, it was interesting nonetheless.  Some of
the slower dub-style jungle was really cool, but the super fast snare
cracks get on my nerves quick.  I'm glad I got a chance to see him spin
though.  I'm pretty sure hardly anyone knew who he was, a lot of people
didn't know how to react to the music and subsequently the dance floor
started to clear out midway into his set.  I was hoping to catch a deep
house set by Mark Farina but after about 90 mins. of goldie someone else
came on (Graeme?).  Around 5:30 I decided to head out.  All in all, great
party, definitly worth the money... 

Anyone else go? 

Andy

++''++,,++''++,,++''++,,++''++,,++''++,,++''++,,++''++,,++''++,,++''++,,++

This is a petition to urge the French Government to stop nuclear tests.
If you agree with us, please add your name to the list above, and send
copies to your friends.

We will add up the lists that had come back to us, and send it to the
French Government.

If you happen to be the hundredth,two hundredth, three hundredth, and
so on, on the list, please send a copy of the mail back to the addresses
below, so that  we can keep track of this project.

If you have any comments please send mail to us.  And also, if you are
multi-lingual and have friends who may not understand English, please
translate this message and add it to the end of the mail.
Thank you very much.
 ******* addresses of the organizers: shimizu\femto.phys.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp
keshi\uticeaix1.icepp.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp <- please use this address

On Sun, 5 Nov 1995, Alexandra Crocket wrote:

>    Saturday, November 4th - space children - Be Here Now
> 
> I have a little odd coincidence story to tell everyone, so bare with me.
> 
> A group of us were planning to drive from Reno to SF last night so one my 
> friends could Experience San Francisco one last time before moving north.
> Things didn't work out though, so we ended up in Barnes and Noble (a Reno 
> bookstore) late last night. We were wandering around aimlessly when all 
> of a sudden Jennifer pulled a blue book off the shelf in the New Age 
> section and ran over to me.
> 
> The book was entitled _Remember: Be Here Now_
> 
> Both of us were more than a little spooked by this, especially when the 
> first page she flipped open to WAS THE BUTTERFLY THEY USED FOR THE FLYER.
> 
> I bought the book; it's incredible. All of these thoughts on life from a 
> very plur-aly, ravey, consciousness oriented Eastern philosophical slant. 
> (If no one objects, I'm going to post things from it from time to time-- 
> it is an INCREDIBLE book.)
> 
> Anyway, later we ran into a friend, and when we showed him the book and 
> the flyer, his eyes got really big, and he said "You are supposed to be 
> there. I've never seen anything like this. It's amazing the way the 
> universe works. Even when you can't physically be where you're supposed 
> to be, the energy of the universe always seems to draw related things 
> into your life exactly when they're supposed to be there."
> 
> It cleared up a lot in my mind to hear this. Lately I've been frustrated 
> by my geographical constraints. I had been wondering if my life situation
> was causing some wierd form of chaos to invade my life and cause my growth
> process to become stagnate. I realized then & there that no matter where
> you go, no matter what you do, you are where you are supposed to be. And
> that's all there is to it. :)
> 
> (About the book: There are no author credits given.
> The front section was written by Dr. Richard Alpert, Ph.D, one of 
> Timothy Leary's cohorts at Harvard during the LSD experiments)

>

 I'm going to show my age but Dr. Richard Alpert, Ph.D is also know
as Ram Dass the author of the original "Be Here Now" which came out in 
the late sixty's and was a tremendous Pop cultural phenomenon, it turned 
a tremendous number of "hippie" kids onto (eastern) spiritual ideas many for
the first time.  You might want to look up the original in the library 
and compare the two.

In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSI.3.91.951105233248.20920A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>

On Sun, 5 Nov 1995, Doug Zimmerman wrote:

> hey everyone,
> 
>   just wanted to see if anyone went to Wicked and had any comments on
> Little Louie Vega's set.  good bad, DEEP, cluby, etc.  
> 

Yeah I was there (doin the door as usual),
	If any of you went (who don't know me) I was the giant Black Man with
the guest list.  I must say that this party really kicked (much better 
than the last two :).  For me it's not a real wicked unless you can truly 
say at the end of the night "Shit, now THAT was Wicked".  This party lived
up to my expectations.  The line up was: Garth, Jeno, Lil Louie Vega, Thomas.
We had good numbers this time even though we are still at King street but
that should be changing hopefully after the first of the year, if anyone
knows where you can throw a more or less legal party for 800 with loud
music in SF (and have it be bust proof) let me know :) Anyways, I knew the
night would be good with many "old timer's" comming out like Cindy K,
and Rox. Not to mention a lot of "new faces", Wicked still amazes me as to
the diversity of the crowd, and tonight EVERYONE was in the house, New York
Homeboys to SF Muscleboys, with many Charms and Strange Attractors 
circulating through the crowd (who was that masked girl?, I don't know
but she left this silver nipple ring :) Any way garth started off with 
a typical Garth on the disco tip set, although this time he played pretty 
good stuff, Jeno moved in with a truly brillient Jeno set, I knew he 
would be goos as he always makes a good showing when the New York boys 
are in the house, I guess people are like terrirorial like dogs and have 
to "mark" their territory, still I found myself irresistably sliding into 
that Trance state which is always the indicator for me.  Next came Lil' Louie
Vega who is fully on the New York - Chicago House tip,  I must say that I was
not impressed with his performance as he came out the gate but after about
30 minutes he seemed to get on the wavelength of the crown and proceeded to
fuck it up! Maybe it was the inspiration that was dancing down in front of
him (JSL can I get a witness :) In any event he may have started out a 
little slow, but he eventually did lay a solid foundation from which he 
proceeded to "Build his house" and by the time he was done, he definitely
had a mansion standing.  Thomas straight back from England by way of New York
took the controls in his classic closing role and kept the crowd dancing
(and most importantly still in the house, he seems fresh from his travels
and ready to get down to some serious work.


Full Moon Rave is tonight. Come out because it might be the last one outdoors
until the spring.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NEXUS SYSTEMS/CYBERTRIBE-5 : Voice:(415)965-2384 
Editor/Instigator/Catalyst : Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>

	              RAVE: For a better tomorrow

		--PGP Public key available upon request--
     "If I can't trance, I don't want to be part of your revolution"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov  6 09:30:37 1995

	id JAA20773; Mon, 6 Nov 1995 09:30:22 -0800
Date: Mon, 6 Nov 1995 09:30:20 -0800 (PST)
From: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: nuff respect
To: vivian host <stareyes@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <v02130501acc12ca64662@[128.32.99.244]>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9511060930.B12380-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I went to Your Mama's on Saturday to hear star Eyes and was sadly 
disappointed when she wasn't there :[   However, I still got to hear (I 
think) Thad.  At least that's who the woman working there said it was.  The 
music was really cool and I love that cafe.  I highly encourage people to 
go to this cafe.  They have a lot of different DJ's every night, 
including trip-hop and house on various nights.  (they have a listing of 
the different DJ's)  I think the place may be hurting for customers 
because I have never been there and seen more than five other people.  

The cafe is set up with turn tables in the corner and couches and big 
chairs with rustic tables spread across the rooms.  There is a pool table 
and they serve both coffee and alcohol.  The walls are painted with 
really cool graffiti art.  I think the atmosphere is really 
chill and could be so much more if the place had a little more notoriety.

I highly reccomend this place to be checked out.  I'm pretty sure I'll be 
there next Saturday to here star Eyes and Thad spin.  :]

XXOO,
kc

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov  6 12:00:50 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA18809; Mon, 6 Nov 1995 12:00:50 -0800
Received: from netcom20.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA18803; Mon, 6 Nov 1995 12:00:46 -0800

From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Message-Id: <199511061922.LAA13214@netcom20.netcom.com>
Subject: Lil' Louie Destroys SF!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 6 Nov 1995 11:22:45 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1841      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is correct.  Lil' Louie dropped the serious bomb on SF Sunday 
morning at Wicked.  It was truly the mosty amazing set I've heard to 
date.  The mix was flawless, the mucis was so large, expansive, trippy, 
housey, trancey, and big, it was inbcredible.  There was no use of the 
useless crossfader, since Lil' Louie worked 3 faders and three decks with 
little problem!  He had perfect control over the music and where it was 
going.  He filled that room with such emotional content people literally 
went off (I know I did!).

Basically he has built a house, a really big one onto which proper folx 
would do well to build upon, and add to.  Incredible!  The energy was 
incredible, the people, for a Wicked, were really nice, and everyone got 
on the goodfoot.  Louie played some of the deepest HOUSE music I"ve 
heard, as only he can put it together.  When my man plays a 110bpm 
record, and the polyrhythms carry it up to 120, it shows how well he has 
mastery over his music.  He also brought so many acetates and first 
pressings, stuff you might never hear again, it was well worth the minro 
annoyances that happen at Townsend.

The Dr. was in, gave some lessons, dropped some bombs for good measure, 
and left everyone scrambling for their brain cells.  THE SHIT WAS ON!

SF is all about the groove!

Shouts & propers to:  The Black Man, DJ Loren & SO Tracy, DJ John Howard, 
Andrew (Yo man!  It was good seeing you out!  Look forward to your next 
show!),Yashoda, Rox, Sistah Barbara, & Micro (I hate big ass, sweaty, 
pushy, muscleboys at times too!), and all the people who bathed before 
they raved!

Also shouts to Wicked for bringing in talent from all over!  Nice one!!!

Peace,
John

P.S.  When asked "Hey man, what did you think about Lil' Louie?!" I 
replied, "Uhhh, yeah...." (my brain had been reorganized).  Out!

X-Sender: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3b4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Re: my musical history...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

funny, this sounds remarkably similar to my experiences...

>-4th grade Duran Duran
>-5th grade I became a breakdancer, started listening to Run-DMC, UTFO, 
>Grandmaster Flash, Egyptian Lover, etc.  Hey, when are thick shoe laces 
>going to came back into style? 

Pretty much the same here, but I was also really into New Wave music.

>-6th grade Prince and all associated projects (Morris Day & the Time, 
>Appalonia, Vanity)
>-7th grade Beastie Boys

I went through this odd easy-listening Cat Stevens/Elton John phase then.  I
know it was a strange time for it, but I was an odd kid.

>-8th grade I started getting "alternative", and continued through high 
>school (Depeche Mode, U2, the Cure, Smiths)

Definitely the same.  I was obsessed with the Smiths through the entirety of
High School.  I have this Smith's cap that one of my friends bought me my
Junior year, and I wore it for almost three years straight.  He said it was
the best money he'd ever spent.

>-12th grade I simultaneously became a 4AD addict (this is a record label, 
>not a drug :) and a punk rocker

My senior year I was still really into the Smiths, and I listened to Kate
Bush almost daily.  I've always listened to punk off and on, but it's never
been a lifestyle thing.  My 4AD affliction didn't start until college, but
it's still with me (as if you didn't know).  However, I have to disagree
with Seth.  It _is_ a drug.  

I'm not sure when I started listening to techno or house.  Actually, I
started listening to ambient first.  Come to think of it, I still listen to
ambient more than any other style in the spectrum of electronic music.  My
roommate last year had a copy of One A.D. (which is _excellent_, for those
of you who haven't heard it).  From there I started listening to Higher
Intelligence Agency, FSOL, picked up a great compilation called Wasted (a
collection of songs from the Volume samplers.  There's another one called
_Sharks Patrol These Waters_ (with many a 4AD band on it), but Wasted is the
one with the dance-oriented tracks on it), and from there I was pretty much
hooked.  I didn't really start listening to more upbeat stuff until I
started going to raves, but even now I don't own that much house or techno.
I'd say about 80% of my cd's are either bands on 4AD or ambient.  

Just so you know.

Peace & kibble,
Jake

I'd have to agree, I've been to a few other ones and it was pretty cold..People 
just have warmer clothes, tents, sleeping bag,(a fire if permitted of course). 
Most of the time I see people with warm clothes coming in to the party and in 
about 1/2 - 1 hour most of those clothes are off because they dancing alot. The 
cold air is somewhat good, and keeps you from over heating, key is drink alot of 
water and if you stop dancing for a while put on those clothes you took off or 
use the tent, sleeping bag thing until you go back out. This might be a good 
thing to do a survey on. If the DJ's and everyone else doesn't mind a little 
chill, I don't see why they can't be all year round, (of course the rain might 
be a bad thing for the equipment, but then again there is always tarps and 
things to use as cover at least for the DJ's and equipment. With everyone 
pitching in and bringing things to use to cover the sound system up with, 
everyone could have just as much of a good time there as any other time..IMHO. I 
think if I knew how to spin and had a sound system I would love to do it, Just 
seeing everyone, dancing, jumping up & down and just letting it go, Big Happy 
Smiling faces looking up reaching for the ran and loving every minute of it. 
Thought would be one hell of a sight to see. Just all the energy for seeing 
something like that happen would be overwhelming. Try to picture it and tell me 
you didn't get a big smile on your face, and say, "Yes, that would be awesome.

Tim (knucklehead) This is how I would feel.

NO ON L ...this is the curfew law for kids 18 and under....and you know

enacted maybe we could have some kid-ravers have some say in what is

yes on G this is going to improve the office of citizens 
complaints...right now as we can recall (say the new years bust thingy)

        Hi all 
Sorry for taking so long to respond back but I was without E-mail till today
(10 days!!).

Well what can I say.  SF is a crazzy place, a very intense city but it's
heart gives off a great vibe.  I quickly wrote up a top ten reasons to visit
San Francisco. (drumroll please)


Top Ten Reasons to Visit San Francisco
10. The  Hotel Californian:    
        No joke, that was the name of the hotel I stayed in.  OJ's prison
cell was larger               than my room!!  I expected Don Henley to be
walking around (get it, Hotel                 California, bad joke  ;-)
9. 70F Weather:
        I didn't realize how warm it was until I returned home to find the
air a brisk 40F.              BRRRR!!!  There would be no way you could have
an outdoor rave in British                 Columbia right now.     
8. Celebrities:
        I saw the brother of Robert Crumb (you know .. he wrote the original
Fritz the Cat         comics) walking down the street. Okay, Okay, I saw the
brother a celebrity!! 
7. The Scenes:
        Haight St, Berkeley, Telegraph Ave, Castro, etc, etc.  Great places
to hang out.  
6. Education:
        I learned about the Schmoo or Schwa as Amy calls it.  (I still can't
pronounce                 or spell it!!).  I learned that Burning Man did
not involve any human sacrafice to my         great relief (all that mud,
the writhing bodies, the fireworks, the fun). 
5. The Castro Halloween Party
        What a party!!!  SF should have a party like that once a month and
donate the               money to a good cause.
4. Wayne's Launch Pad
        One Word: groovey
3. FnF
        What a concept!!!  A gathering that had amble ambient space (2 in
fact!!), free              water and candy (with donation), neat little
cubby spaces, good music, etc.  Why         can't other promoters get their
shit together??
2. Ethan's Set
        Mindblowing...manic...insane...Can't talk...Have to dance....Have to
dance...
1. SF People
        Amy, Melanie, Tristan, Noel, Jon, Jake, for the company.
        Wayne, Vince, for the laminant.  
        Amy for the ride.
        Carolyn for the warm hugs.         
        And any others I forgot to thank for making my trip such an awesome
experience.      
        
John

wait are you serious...i know you're not...i dunno where Joe Normal gets
his perception...yeah he gets it from the million and one people that call
themselves ravers that can't go out without doing drugs...i haven't seen
the documentary either but im willing to bet he isnt wrong...that IS one of
the main facets of the rave scene and while doing drugs do not a raver make
they are certainly the main diet of almost everyone at "given club"....i am
going to take this opportunity to send a message out to all the people that
think they can't go out without an E or think it is going to somehow change
things....if you aren't going to a club for the music or the people than
why the hell are you there...also, I think the point of E is that you can
learn something from it (how to open up, be friendly, etc.) and carry that
over to your real life...just remember that taking an E is not a substitute
for being a truly nice person with a scintillating
personality...thanks...sorry i had to go off but im sick of seeing everyone
so fucking dependent on a dodgy white pill...
                                                **starEyes**

>Subject: 26 THOUGHTS TO GET YOU THROUGH THE DAY

>26 THOUGHTS TO GET YOU THROUGH THE DAY >
>     1 - Indecision is the key to flexibility.
>     2 - You cannot tell which way the train went by looking at the track.
>     3 - There is absolutely no substitute for a genuine lack of
>        preparation.
>     4 - Happiness is merely the remission of pain.
>     5 - Nostalgia isn't what it used to be.
>     6 - Sometimes too much drink is not enough.
>     7 - The facts, although interesting, are irrelevant.
>     8 - The careful application of terror is also a form of
>         communication.
>     9 - Someone who thinks logically is a nice contrast to the real
>         world.
>    10 - Things are more like they are today than they ever have been
>         before.
>    11 - Anything worth fighting for is worth fighting dirty for.
>    12 - Everything should be made as simple as possible, but no simpler.
>    13 - Friends may come and go, but enemies accumulate.
>    14 - I have seen the truth and it makes no sense.
>    15 - Suicide is the most sincere form of self-criticism.
>    16 - All things being equal, fat people use more soap.
>    17 - If you can smile when things go wrong, you have someone in mind
>         to blame.
>    18 - One-seventh of your life is spent on Monday.
>    19 - By the time you can make ends meet, they move the ends.
>    20 - Not one shred of evidence supports the notion that life is
>         serious.
>    21 - The more you run over a dead cat, the flatter it gets.
>    22 - There is always one more imbecile than you counted on.
>    23 - This is as bad as it can get, but don't bet on it.
>    24 - Never wrestle with a pig: You both get all dirty, and the pig
>          likes it.
>    25 - The trouble with life is, you're halfway through it before you
>         realize it's a 'do it yourself' thing.
>    26 - All problems can be resolved with the proper application of
>         high explosives.
>
>
>

>
>2. For those of you who had sent me back the lists, thank you very much
>   for participating in this. We will include your list in our list
>   which is to be sent to Mr. Chirac, but it will not appear as fast
>   as the signs made via WWW. We couldn't help it, but I think there
>   is noone who can manage more than 2000 mails per day. If you want to
>   have your name on the list faster, please try our WWW site. Don't
>   worry about duplications because it is rather easily eliminated by
>   using the sort program. And ofcourse before sending it to Mr. Chirac,
>   it will be very carefully checked.
>
>3. If you had distributed our chain letter to your friends, thank you
>   for your support, but please try to stop your friends from distributing
>   it further. And also, tell your friends about the WWW site, and
>   tell them to sign via WWW if they want their names on the list.
>   What you should do about the list you have: if you had not yet
>   sent the list back to me, please send it back with only the list
>   part with it. That means, please cut the banner and the sentences
>   away.
>
>4. About the chain letter: after distributing our first chain letter,
>   we have realized there were many problems in our chain letter,
>   and then, that using chain letter was inadequate from the begining.
>   We have sent our second chain letter to go after the first one,
>   since that was the only way we could think of to stop the first
>   one from spreading. However this is not working so well, and now
>   many sites around world is having unnecessarly high traffics
>   and are getting into troubles.
>   We deeply apologize for having started a chain letter. We hearby
>   declare that we will never ever start such thing and also never
>   distribute one when we recieve other chain letters, no matter
>   what the content may be.
>   If you see anywhere anyplace in the network about this chain
>   letter, please tell people that we have realized the inadequateness
>   of our method and trying our best to stop further distributions.
>
>5. If you had recieved our letter with only "Dear Sirs" on it,
>   we are very sorry about this. It comes from our poor knowlege
>   of English: in Japanese, we don't have differnt ways to call
>   to Men and Women. Those of you who had added "Dear Madames" or
>   changed it to "Dear people" and so on, thank you for your help.
>   To gather many peoples power was from the begining our scheme.
>
>6. We have already told all our story to our postmaster, and they
>   have understood us. So, it is no use complaining about us to
>   him. We are trying our best to stop what we have started.
>
>   Sincelery,
>
>   Yuichi Nishihara
>   Shimizu Seishi
>
> both Physics student at University of Tokyo.
>
>
>------- FORWARD, End of original message -------

THE FULL MOON COLLECTIVE PRESENTS:

Line-up: Monty, Mars, Minor, Gavin Hardkiss, morning ambient w/
Consciousness Labs, and some surprises.

Starts at 11 PM.  Call (415) 536-9453 for more details.

The party is happening outdoors, on the bay in San Francisco in the park at
the end of 24th & at Illinois Street.

Directions are as follows:

>From central San Francisco or SOMA area:
Take 3rd street south. Turn left on 24th street. Cross over Illinois street
and go to the end of the street.

>From south of San Francisco:
Take 101 north or 280 north to 280 north. Exit the Mariposa Street exit.
Turn right onto Mariposa Street. Turn right at 3rd street. Go down 3rd
street until 24th street. Turn left on 24th Street. Cross over Illinois
street and go to the end of the street.

Park, go towards the bay and follow the sound of the music.

Subject: Theremin
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.951107000337.7377B-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


In the paper, I saw that Steven Martin's documentary,  Theremin:An 
Electronic Odyssey is playing at Lumiere in San Francisco. If you a big 
fan of electronic music, I highly recommend this film. It's a documentary 
about Leon Theremin, the pioneer of electronic instrument. He is the 
inventor of the Theremin, which is an instrument that makes a weird 
eerie vibrating tone (the instrument was most notably used in sci-fi films 
such as "The Day the Earth Stood Still").
If you've ever been to the Exploratorium, there's a Theremin that you 
can play with in one of the sound booths. The film is about the inventor's 
life (which is very interesting!) and how he has influenced people such as 
Bob Moog and Brian Wilson (there are interviews of them in the film). 
Moog said in the film that he one of his main influences in buliding 
synths.

So glad to hear the DEEP shit goin' over so well in SF. I'm from NY
originally and always make the reliqious pilgramage to Sound Factory Bar on
Wed. for Louie and Frankie K. on Fri. when I'm back there. If you ever find
yourself in the vicinity go check one of these boys spinning solo for a
full night for 7 hours (count em', 7) straight on a sound system designed
just for them, with a large percentage of the music they spin produced by
themselves. With all due respect to the Wicked DJs and other house DJs on
the SF scene, these boys can seriously take them to school when there on
their home turf.

KEEP it DEEP
ek  =o)


>This is correct.  Lil' Louie dropped the serious bomb on SF Sunday
>morning at Wicked.  It was truly the mosty amazing set I've heard to
>date.  The mix was flawless, the mucis was so larg e, expansive, trippy,
>housey, trancey, and big, it was inbcredible.  There was no use of the
>useless crossfader, since Lil' Louie worked 3 faders and three decks with
>little problem!  He had perfect control over the music and where it was
>going.  He filled that room with such emotional content people literally
>went off (I know I did!).
>
>Basically he has built a house, a really big one onto which proper folx
>would do well to build upon, and add to.  Incredible!  The energy was
>incredible, the people, for a Wicked, were really nice, and everyone got
>on the goodfoot.  Louie played some of the deepest HOUSE music I"ve
>heard, as only he can put it together.  When my man plays a 110bpm
>record, and the polyrhythms carry it up to 120, it shows how well he has
>mastery over his music.  He also brought so many acetates and first
>pressings, stuff you might never hear again, it was well worth the minro
>annoyances that happen at Townsend.
>
>The Dr. was in, gave some lessons, dropped some bombs for good measure,
>and left everyone scrambling for their brain cells.  THE SHIT WAS ON!
>
>SF is all about the groove!
>
>Shouts & propers to:  The Black Man, DJ Loren & SO Tracy, DJ John Howard,
>Andrew (Yo man!  It was good seeing you out!  Look forward to your next
>show!),Yashoda, Rox, Sistah Barbara, & Micro (I hate big ass, sweaty,
>pushy, muscleboys at times too!), and all the people who bathed before
>they raved!
>
>Also shouts to Wicked for bringing in talent from all over!  Nice one!!!
>
>Peace,
>John
>
>P.S.  When asked "Hey man, what did you think about Lil' Louie?!" I
>replied, "Uhhh, yeah...." (my brain had been reorganized).  Out!

i am so incredibly blown away, though it is 4:30 am, i must write:

the communal full moon was at 24th and illinois, all decked out with 
candles, shrines, a huge mandala made of rocks and scraps, plus an 
awesome system...j and k, i believe...

phrank was playing when we got there, and then gavan hardkiss, who was 
playing all kinds of freaky, groovy sh*t, such as some really cool trippy 
trip hop stuff and lots of other goodies.  first time i've heard him play 
dance music and it was worth the drive and the momentary tensions of a 
night out. 

this party was defintely very Yin.  there was an ankh in the mandala, for 
instance.  

a proverb, said to be from china:  the moon is in the water and the lotus 
blossom is in the sky.

two cops showed up around 3:30 and said to shut it down, but now it's 
moved out to the berkeley marina.  monty and consciousness sound labs i 
believe are going to play still.

the music and the vibe harmonized perfectly as this party.  i feel 
fulfilled, thanks to the moon.

and also a little shiatsu, from g., recently moved back from japan.  i'm 
feeing mighty good right now...

see you later!

Ann

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Nov  7 09:03:08 1995

From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Message-Id: <199511071702.JAA06914@netcom20.netcom.com>
Subject: SF & NY & Other stylees...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 7 Nov 1995 09:02:19 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 5976      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The homey from NY was correct.  SF DJ's , as a whole have quite a bit to 
learn from the more senior members of NY's DJ community.  It's apparent 
every time a NY DJ comes to town.

Pierre, when he played @ Wicked, both times, created such mayhem it has 
yet to be equalled by ANY SF resident DJ.  Lil' Louie stomped so much 
butt this place is still shaking from his presence.  And Mark Farina is 
probably getting to the top of his game here in SF, still heads and 
shoulders above others.  I guess it all comes down to class and style, 
along with serious record buying habits.

The other thing brotha from NY pointed out is the serious shortness of 
sets that SF dj's tend to play.  I really don't like going out to hear a 
DJ for 2 hours, f*ck that crap.  1.5 hours is even less useful.  I want 
to hear a MINIMUM of a 3 hour set, or better yet 2 5 hour sets from 2 
DJ's.  This 4 DJ's in 10 hours (or worse at most parties), really stink 
IMHO.  First, the DJ usually starts getting into the set after a good 
30-45 minutes, others it takes longer.  But before you know it, it's the 
next DJ's turn.  Yuck!  Lil' Louie played for 3 hours, and IMHO that WAS 
NOT ENOUGH.  They shoulda let him close the place IMO!

I really dunno wassup with SF.  I've talked with P-Dog and some of the 
other veteran promoters about why the 3 to 4 DJ lineup.  The dog will 
usually only have 3 DJ's max at his parties, so at least he is trying.  
When I see a flyer for 5 or more, I know better than to waste my time 
geting into someones set, only to be replaced by completely different 
grooves right when I'm starting to get into it.  Screw it.  Sf should get 
a clue on this point.  People want to hear alot of music, but not 
necesaarily from alot of people.  I think it's coming though, rest 
assured.  There will be someone who does a real music experience, with 
good DJ's, spinning a minimum of 3-4 hour sets.  The days of 100 DJ's 
on one flyer have already started to wane, andnot a moment too soon.

Hell, I would love to hear any of the DJ's I really enjoy play for a few 
hours on 3 decks.  Most of the accomplished better known DJ's can do this 
with little effort.  I think however that laziness on the part of both 
promoters and DJ's has set in, and it'll be difficult to break.  Also 
people now have patterns of behavior that they're not willing to give 
up.  I do wonder if there was a party that had Just Lil' Louie alone, 
would people come and pay $15-$20 for JUST one DJ.  I think SF would be 
more than willing to accept 2 for that price, I doubt we're really ready 
for just 1 DJ doing a 7 hour set though.  There will still always be 
people who think more is better (DJ-wise).  I am NOT one of those people.

I think things are slowly changing though.  Velvet Shop often features 
just two DJ's.  Simply Done as well.  Not familiar with the lineup at 
other weeklies, but I hope they followe this trend.  I remeber Wicked's 
where only two of the boys would spin.  I do miss those days.

I hope SF DJ's and promoters get it, and stop flooding us with tons of 
DJ's with tons of music.  It's NOt the quantity, it's the quality that is 
the real barometer of excellence.  NY has once again shown SF how true 
this paradigm is.

Props to NY, I gotta, and I mean, GOTTA get there in 96!  Record 
shopping, some clubbing, and of course some good eating.

SF's got a ways to go yet, but it'll happen.

One other note I think contributes to SF's lack of, how shall we say, 
music quality: record production.

Let's face it, the majority of the people who come here from NY and other 
places are making the music they spin.  Yes, there are plenty of record 
companies here who are either established or starting up.  But what 
percentage of them actually have working gigging DJ's producing, and 
re-mixing material?  Not enough, rest assured.  And that is what gets 
me.  We have some really talented folx here in the city.  They spend 
plenty of time and money perfecting their craft, no doubt.  But you'd 
think with the mass of talent here that more of them would start at some 
point to get into the real ART of the music by CREATING thier own music.  
Don't get me wrong, I am well aware of the people who are DJ's making 
serious tunes (Tony & Doran, HardKiss, Dubtribe, Buck, Digit, EFX to name 
a few), but there are so many DJ's and so few of them have devoted the 
time to make anything other than that which can be made on the dance 
floor.  I think that's the main difference between Chicago, Detroit, & NY 
from SF.  The talent in these other places not only spin records, they 
make them too.  The amount of cross pollination between the artists in 
these locales is evident each time they visit.  Here in SF it's 
realtively few who take the time and effort.

I've heard it all from "Man, I want to perfect my form first...", or 
"..when it's time, it's time.  I've only been spinning for 4 years now 
and...", whatever.  Shit, I bought some Pierre Trax from 86-89.  Yeah, it 
was immature, but at least he was starting at a time when he was 
beginning to push up.  I think that music will go only so far as long as 
the DJ's involved are isolated from the music creation process.  It's 
much more than beats, it's much more than melody, it's much more than the 
parts that make people go yeah, versus people going YEAH!.  It seems 
people who create the music have a much better handle on how to control 
it (witness Vega & Pierre).  And until you learn how to control it, move 
it, manipulate it, all you're doing is putting 2 and 2 together to make 
4, with some minor variations.  That's the difference between SF & NY 
DJ's IMHO.  The more DJ's are involved with the creation of music, the 
better DJ's they will be, plain and simple.  You will only go so far just 
spinning records.

I've said quite enough...thanks for listening.

Peace to you all,
John

P.S.  Did I mention Lil' Louie dropped a bomb and built a house?  Well, 
he did!

Out.

> 
> >So glad to hear the DEEP shit goin' over so well in SF. I'm from NY
> >originally and always make the reliqious pilgramage to Sound Factory Bar on
> >Wed. for Louie and Frankie K. on Fri. when I'm back there. If you ever find
> >yourself in the vicinity go check one of these boys spinning solo for a
> >full night for 7 hours (count em', 7) straight on a sound system designed
> >just for them, with a large percentage of the music they spin produced by
> >themselves. With all due respect to the Wicked DJs and other house DJs on
> >the SF scene, these boys can seriously take them to school when there on
> >their home turf.
> >
> >KEEP it DEEP
> >ek  =o)
> >
> >

> 

Yeah man, I hae to agree.  Not taking away from any of the talent here, 
but SF can learn quite a bit from the process by seeing how other DJ's do 
the do.

I am fairly sick and tired of going out to hear 5 or more DJ's play for 
1.5 to 2 hours each.  It defeats the purpose of listening to music in the 
first place.  I wish that people would begin to throw parties with just 1 
or 2 DJ's spinning a minimum of 4-5 hour sets.  When I see 5 DJ's on a 
flyer, or announcement, I know that's not where I want to be.  I want a 
DJ to take me on his/her trip, but how can they do that if they only have 
2 hours.  Basically it doesn't happen.  And it certainly happens less as 
you become more mature with the music.  For instance, it was fine for me 
3 years ago to hear a DJ for 2 hours.  Now I want a minimum of a 3 hours 
set, otherwise, it's really not worth the effort to go out.  It takes a 
DJ 30-40 minutes to find their pocket.  Once thier in it, you're gonna 
let them go after 1 or 1.5 hhours?  Not.

I think the problem is laziness on both the parts of the promoter and the 
DJ's.  DJ; are now used to playing 2 hour sets max.  Some want more, but 
the promoter want to please people so he/she will book more talent.  They 
have set up a pattern here people are used to, that is the more DJ's the 
better.  People often feel as though they are not getting thier monies 
worhtwhen they are asked to spend $15-$20 for 1 or 2 DJ's.  The paradigm 
has been set and people are just follwing the simplest instinct.  to be 
fair, I do know that people are trying to change things by allowing no 
more than 3 DJ's (Stompy being one of the parties), or allowing DJ's to 
spin for more than the standard 2 hours (Wicked being the other).  But 
there are still people who want 100 DJ's in 10 hours.  Sick IMHO.

the other problem is  the people from out of town have a disticnt 
advantage over SF, they create thier own music.  Yeah, there are plenty 
of DJ's in SF who have/are producing (i.e creating) music.  But it falls 
far short when compared to the number of spinning DJ's overall.  Could be 
that SF is immature in this sense.  The real difference between someone 
who is considered good , like a Jeno or Markie, and a Lil' Louie Vega is 
a combo of years spinning and the fact that Louie or Pierre or Derrick 
create thier own music.  This is a great help to any working DJ.  You 
hear things completely differently when you spend time creating music as 
you would JUST spinning it.  That's the difference.

I wonder what Jeno, Markie, or even a talneted guy like Mark Farina 
starts to create music on thier own.  Could be devastating to hear, and 
maybe we'll hear these guys as well as others do 4 -7 hour sets as std 
operations, instead of the tiny 2-2.5 hour sets they normally do.  Their 
music will change radically as well.  Face it, the best DJ's are the ones 
who can not only spin & mix well, but who can also make the music they 
themselves would want to spin.  That's the difference between 
NY/Chicago/Detroit and SF.  In time though, I hope this will change.  
Until then, I'll stay home, make some music, spin a little, and wait for 
the next visitor from out of town to drop a house.

I LOVE house music!

Break the paradigm, support parties with 1 or 2 DJ's.  For this old 
house's sake.

Much peace,
John

P.S.  Did I metion Lil' Louie Vega dropped a bomb, and built a house?  
Well, he did!

Out.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Police BS
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On your way into The City bound FMR last night you had to pass a bunch of
illegally parked mobile homes and their occupants, replete with mangy,
skitish dogs, on 24th Street.

When the cops came at 4am or so, the first thing they said, and their basis
for shutting us down was:  "Don't you have any respect?  There are people
living 200 yards from here!"

I couldn't hold back.  "Excuse me, sir?  Is it legal to live in a trailer
200 yards from here."

Because of his enormous training in always telling the truth, Johnny Law
blurted, "No!"  But then, realizing the impact of what he was saying, he
copped (pun!) an attitude and came down on me with a classic
slamming-iron-bar-look and said, "Sir!"  As if to say, "Now we all know
that our reasons for shutting down this party are BS, but you're not going
to question them are you?"

Another classic example is that while the sound guys were packing up their
gear, thus showing that we understood the party was over, the cops started
talking to a random woman and while she was going on about this and that,
he was saying, "Are you in charge here?  If we could talk to the person in
charge then we could get somewhere."  Mind you packing is taking place,
because they had spoken to the people in charge.  He was blatently saying
that he didn't need to talk to this person, and that it was wasting his
time to talk to anyone not in charge (can you say "ATTITUDE!"?).  But when
he said, "Did you organize this party?" and she replied "Well, I've
organized parties just like this."  His partner nudged him and said,
"You're not gonna get anywhere with this group."  Classic.  At least one of
them had a sense of humor.

Later!

Tony

P.S.  The party was great.  Very cool.  And not too cold!



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Nov  7 15:34:39 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA28207; Tue, 7 Nov 1995 15:34:39 -0800
Received: from gw.steam.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA28182; Tue, 7 Nov 1995 15:34:31 -0800
Received: from well.com (phred@well.com [206.15.64.10]) by gw.steam.com (8.6.10/8.6.9) with ESMTP id OAA03955 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 7 Nov 1995 14:59:37 -0800
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id PAA00192; Tue, 7 Nov 1995 15:17:30 -0800
From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <9511071517.ZM190@well>
Date: Tue, 7 Nov 1995 15:17:29 -0800
In-Reply-To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
        "SF & NY & Other stylees..." (Nov  7,  9:02am)
References: <199511071702.JAA06914@netcom20.netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee), sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: SF & NY & Other stylees...
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Geez, John, you should hear what people who know the NY scene say when
they visit or move to SF.  There's much more going on here than there
as far as places to go and variety of dance music.  The Sound Factor
Bar has been CLOSED for months, got tha 411?  There are rumors it will
reopen.  Meanwhile, the Tunnel fell all over itself paying Junior 
Vasquez a princely if not kingly sum, plus who knows how many tens
of thousands of dollars to build him a special DJ *apartment* at the
club including a shower, small recording studio and room for all of
his assistants to do his chores while he's mixing.  yes he and Louie
and Frankie Knuckles and Pierre and all of them are the great ones,
they have what it takes to do 4, 8 or even 12 hours of spinning.  Not
everyone does or should even try.  

I'll agree about short sets, it may just be me but I'm a slow starter
and don't get going until 30 or 45 minutes in most times.  The hour-and-a-
quarter sets I've been getting this year are the cruelest slots for a DJ,
just long enough to start rolling and then you have to stop.  An hour and
a half is good, two is better and three is best.  Beyond that unless you
train like a marathoner it's awfully hard to keep up the momentum (plus
you have to start planning those 14-minute Wild Pitch tracks for the
bathroom breaks, heh!).  Even an hour is better than 75 minutes because
you know it has to be in, bang, boom, out.  

The biggest continuing problem for me in the scene has to do with the style
of music.  I know, I'm old fashioned and all that, but the tracks I've been
hearing and even buying the second half of this year just don't move me as
much.  Last night I put on one I bought this week I thought was pretty good,
a test pressing remix of G Spot's "Make That Move," versus a now-famous
but then-obscure 1993 track, "Moment of Truth" by Brian Transeau, Dubfire
and Sharam (long before they made it as Remixers of the Day like they are
now).  It wasn't funny, it wasn't even sad, it was kind of depressing.
The sound now is on the doleful, minor-key side in all genres (except some
jungle, oddly enough).  Production is flat, everything's starting to sound
samey even to me.  House always had the dark side, just listen to some of
Felix's early stuff.  I'm not going to say I'm going to stamp my little
feet and throw a fit until things get better, and maybe it's right to say
that progressive house had its day (as acieeed did) and there's no more
left to say . . . but I doubt it.  

The music is reflecting cultural shifts as much as creating them, and 
I see what we're going through now as a kind of retrenchment after tghe
optimism of the early 1990s, the fall of the Berlin Wall and the rise of
democracy in eastern Europe and Russia, and now we're dealing with the
aftermath worldwide.  We elected Clinton here and he is presiding over
the final decay of people-oriented politics in an age of cynicism, spite
and the alfuckingmighty dollar -- attitudes which are well entrenched in
what used to be an underground and devil-may-care music scene.  

You can't stand still ever, and I feel like my own musical horizons have
broadened considerably in the last couple of years, but yknow, even
though nobody played longer than 2 hours hardly ever in 1991-93 in SF,
I'll stand some of those sets up against anything the masters could throw
down not because they were technically as superb as what Junior or Pierre
or Mark Farina or Derrick nowadays can do, but because they were an
amazing fit to the times, the crowd, the feeling that change was in the
air.  But the scene was always built on a restless imagination and the
moving finger of fate has moved swiftly since then.  We're all getting
a little bit in a rut, if you ask me, including myself, and I think it
is important to keep probing the edges, make it uncomfortable from time
to time, risk something, try something you think won't work to see if
you can prove yourself wrong.  

I think John raised some really good issues in that rant and it's always
a good thing to shake the SF scene by its self-satisfied, jaded foundations,
but don't forget, THIS is where the greener grass is by the estimation of
almost any other place on the globe :)

peace

phred

     Ya' know, NY ain't all that a few of you are making it seem.  I admit,
NY is pretty phat, a lot of the old skool DJs still play out all the time at
the local parties (I.E. Frankie Bones, Adam X etc.) but still... the scene
there is definitely 2nd rate compared to SF.  The music quality is usually
excellent at the parties, but there are _NO_ promoters that are into it for
the fun, and for the good vibes, they are all just trying to make a buck.
 Half the time they even do things like put DJs names on flyers before
they've even tried to book them... I went to a party where the whole damn
flyer was based on Plastikman and he didn't even show up!  Trust me... the
scene here in SF is first class; great vibe, fantastic music, and a real
community...
          Hugs, Wurz

>
>In the paper, I saw that Steven Martin's documentary,  Theremin:An 
>Electronic Odyssey is playing at Lumiere in San Francisco. If you a big 
>fan of electronic music, I highly recommend this film. It's a documentary 
>about Leon Theremin, the pioneer of electronic instrument. He is the 
>inventor of the Theremin, which is an instrument that makes a weird 
>eerie vibrating tone (the instrument was most notably used in sci-fi films 
>such as "The Day the Earth Stood Still").

Speaking of Theremins (that's something you don't hear much), I saw one at
the Pere Ubu concert on the 1st.  Most of you have probably heard on before
in a recording and just not known it.  It looks like two triangular pieces
of metal attached to two separate posts that you move your hands around to
make different feedback-type sounds.  If you've ever heard something in a
song that sounds like guitar feedback but sounds a little to weird, that's
probably what it is.

Thereminally yours,
Jake
