Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Right said Phred, yo man wassup!  Hey, before I get to your meaty letter, I
want to let you know, as well as others who I voted for:

Achtenberg/Hallinan

Now with that over with....


>Geez, John, you should hear what people who know the NY scene say when
>they visit or move to SF.  There's much more going on here than there
>as far as places to go and variety of dance music.  The Sound Factor
>Bar has been CLOSED for months, got tha 411?  There are rumors it will
>reopen.  Meanwhile, the Tunnel fell all over itself paying Junior
>Vasquez a princely if not kingly sum, plus who knows how many tens
>of thousands of dollars to build him a special DJ *apartment* at the
>club including a shower, small recording studio and room for all of
>his assistants to do his chores while he's mixing.  yes he and Louie
>and Frankie Knuckles and Pierre and all of them are the great ones,
>they have what it takes to do 4, 8 or even 12 hours of spinning.  Not
>everyone does or should even try.

I was not talking about the scene Fred, I was adressing the music, the
style of mixing, and the sounds.  Sorry, out of town DJ's often fuck this
place to shreds.  That is not to say we do not have a cornucopia of talent
and music, but we have a dearth of the type of talent that is a Pierre,
Humpries, Vega, etc.  It will happen, but it hasn't yet.  I do think we are
on our way.  Time will tell.

Yes, I know about the Sound Factory in NY.  But that has nothing to do with
what I was talking about.  I was talking about the music, not the dance
culture there.

>
>I'll agree about short sets, it may just be me but I'm a slow starter
>and don't get going until 30 or 45 minutes in most times.  The hour-and-a-
>quarter sets I've been getting this year are the cruelest slots for a DJ,
>just long enough to start rolling and then you have to stop.  An hour and
>a half is good, two is better and three is best.  Beyond that unless you
>train like a marathoner it's awfully hard to keep up the momentum (plus
>you have to start planning those 14-minute Wild Pitch tracks for the
>bathroom breaks, heh!).  Even an hour is better than 75 minutes because
>you know it has to be in, bang, boom, out.

Right on!

>
>The biggest continuing problem for me in the scene has to do with the style
>of music.  I know, I'm old fashioned and all that, but the tracks I've been
>hearing and even buying the second half of this year just don't move me as
>much.  Last night I put on one I bought this week I thought was pretty good,
>a test pressing remix of G Spot's "Make That Move," versus a now-famous
>but then-obscure 1993 track, "Moment of Truth" by Brian Transeau, Dubfire
>and Sharam (long before they made it as Remixers of the Day like they are
>now).  It wasn't funny, it wasn't even sad, it was kind of depressing.
>The sound now is on the doleful, minor-key side in all genres (except some
>jungle, oddly enough).  Production is flat, everything's starting to sound
>samey even to me.  House always had the dark side, just listen to some of
>Felix's early stuff.  I'm not going to say I'm going to stamp my little
>feet and throw a fit until things get better, and maybe it's right to say
>that progressive house had its day (as acieeed did) and there's no more
>left to say . . . but I doubt it.

I agree 100% my brother, 100%!

>
>The music is reflecting cultural shifts as much as creating them, and
>I see what we're going through now as a kind of retrenchment after tghe
>optimism of the early 1990s, the fall of the Berlin Wall and the rise of
>democracy in eastern Europe and Russia, and now we're dealing with the
>aftermath worldwide.  We elected Clinton here and he is presiding over
>the final decay of people-oriented politics in an age of cynicism, spite
>and the alfuckingmighty dollar -- attitudes which are well entrenched in
>what used to be an underground and devil-may-care music scene.
>
>You can't stand still ever, and I feel like my own musical horizons have
>broadened considerably in the last couple of years, but yknow, even
>though nobody played longer than 2 hours hardly ever in 1991-93 in SF,
>I'll stand some of those sets up against anything the masters could throw
>down not because they were technically as superb as what Junior or Pierre
>or Mark Farina or Derrick nowadays can do, but because they were an
>amazing fit to the times, the crowd, the feeling that change was in the
>air.  But the scene was always built on a restless imagination and the
>moving finger of fate has moved swiftly since then.  We're all getting
>a little bit in a rut, if you ask me, including myself, and I think it
>is important to keep probing the edges, make it uncomfortable from time
>to time, risk something, try something you think won't work to see if
>you can prove yourself wrong.

Right on, thus the continual learnoing cycle we all could benefit from.
GeoffW pointed an article out to me that he read in jockey slut. Said
something to the effect that people should stop trying to build new
foundations, and stop groundbreaking.  Maybe it's time to build on what has
already been built.  So far things have been so disposable and there have
been so many new houses built, people feel the need to buid more.  When in
fact we should concentrate on how to take things to the next level, build
onto what has already been done, and additive process that consumes less,
but makes more.  Right now all that's being done is tract housing, nobody
has taken the time to even add additions to the houses they built.  Too
busy spending time building something totally different, and I think thats
where the rut lies IMHO.


>
>I think John raised some really good issues in that rant and it's always
>a good thing to shake the SF scene by its self-satisfied, jaded foundations,
>but don't forget, THIS is where the greener grass is by the estimation of
>almost any other place on the globe :)
>
>peace
>
>phred

I'll agree 100% AGAIN!!! :):):).  SF is rather special, I am priviledged to
live here with all these house music hoodlums, house mavens, and straight
up crackerjacks!  I do love it here, this is my home!  But I will never be
so arrogant as to say SF cannot learn lessons from other places and
peoples.  Stagnation is NOT an option.  Learning and diversity MUST
continue to flourish.

With that my man, much peace!,
John

Received: from DialupEudora by netcom7.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id UAA16430; Tue, 7 Nov 1995 20:59:19 -0800

X-Sender: jsl@localhost

To: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Re: SF & NY & Other stylees...
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

>I can't let this letter pass. I have my share of problems with San
>Francisco's scene, but they're diminishing all the time, and I think John's
>most recent posting betrays a few fairly serious misunderstandings of some
>of the factors at work in our scene.

Ok, but once again, I was talking about music, not the scene.  But please,
go on.

>
>First of all, I don't think SF's DJ posse has anything to learn from
>anybody, particularly New York. There are some incredible DJs from New York
>(like Keoki, har har), but they've gotten to where they are despite
>internecine, petty, and brutal scene warfare. Additionally, many of the DJs
>that John named in his letter come from NY's burgeoning club scene, and
>while people may dig the club scene, in most significant respects its
>attitude is completely antithetical to anything having to do with a "rave
>spirit."
>

To say that we have nothing to learn is to close your eyes to many
possibilites.  We ALL have something to learn.  Every one of us, despite
where we are from.  Learning never stops and we can all learn something
from those who visit our city, as well as learn from those who are here.


>Yes, some of the regular DJs in SF do tend to sound a little samey, but this
>town is packed to the rafters with skilled and talented DJs who never get
>the sort of exposure they deserve. I do think that SF's scene tends to be a
>bit inward-looking (it would be nice to see more out of town DJs at the big
>parties), but we're far from completely tapping our own potential. The fact
>that excellent DJs like Dutch still get the majority of their support from
>outside SF is mute support of this claim.

True enough.

>
>This touches on a related issue: the number of DJs on the bill. Hell, man,
>if I had my way, I'd be spinning every chance I got, for 8 hours at a
>stretch. I love spinning long sets, and just about every DJ I know feels the
>same way. It takes me a while to find my groove, but once I do, I want to
>ride it all the way home.

Good!

>Unfortunately, there _are_ a lot of DJs in San Francisco, and they all want
>opportunities to play. Since the DJs that get put on the bill are generally
>friends with the promoters, promoters have to walk a very thin line to keep
>all of their friends happy. When the promoters are DJs themselves (as they
>are with Friends & Family, Wicked, CDC, and our own, humble MaD) things get
>even more confused. Mixing's like a drug -- the more often you do it, the
>happier you are.

Another good point.

>
>Additionally, ravers play favorites. I know that there are parties that I
>have gone to only because one or two DJs I like are playing (yes, I do go to
>many parties without knowing anything about the DJs spinning -- to do
>anything but would be a sign of psychological death). Promoters know this,
>and bank on it. The more DJs they tack on the bill, the more likely they are
>to pull more people in. This reaches its (logically absurd) apotheosis in
>things like Cool World's parties.
>
>Even if the promoters are being true to the scene, all of these constraints
>make them walk a very tight line. I think they do rather well, despite the
>fact that I too would dig hearing certain DJs spin extended sets. OTOH,
>there are _lots_ of DJs that I'm glad I _don't_ have to hear for four hours
>at a stretch.

In agreement here as well.

>
>Regarding the lack of music-making DJs, open your eyes, man.

You did not read both of my posts then.  Whatever.  I cited ALL of the
people you did as well.  My eyes are wide open as my ears are as well.


> There are a ton
>of DJs making music in this town. The Hardkisses, the Reflective posse, the
>Visible crew, DubTribe -- the list goes on and on. The fact that most of
>these crews are far more visible outside San Francisco than within it is
>something of a mystery to me. Reflective is getting _large_ in the European
>community, and deservedly so, but you never hear dick about them here unless
>you hang out in SOMA a lot.
>
>The real reason DJs aren't making music more is because it costs real money
>that people don't have. I have a nice job, but I have a huge, vinyl-clad
>monkey riding on my back, and I have to keep feeding that monkey
>periodically to a) stay sane and b) keep growing as a DJ. I _want_ to start
>making music, but the gear is _not_ cheap.

Yes, I understand this as well.  But that is no excuse IMHO.  There are
plenty of people who have been able to scrape up ennough money to dupe
tapes, it just requires a bit more funds to go the next mile.

Fact is the "working" DJ's , when they manage their time and money
properly, can pout out a record.  It's been done before.


>
>There's a tone to your letter that I really don't like.

Sorry, can't please everyone.

> At least twice you
>make vague references to DJs being lazy or putting things off. Almost
>all of the DJs I've met since I've been in San Francisco are sincere,
>friendly people who obsess over their craft. They aren't lazy and they're
>all following their own muses, which is the only way to live and develop as
>an artist. Just because we aren't all cranking out tracks (and I dispute
>your claim that all of the DJs in Chicago and New York are cranking out
>music -- I think you'll find that it's a proportionally small number making
>music _anywhere_. There are a _lot_ of DJs in New York) doesn't mean that we
>don't care about what we're doing.

Geez.  What I said was the truth, what you said was the truth.  Fact is I
have talked to DJ's and gotten a variety of answers.  The bulk of them have
admitted dragging thier butts, while others have gone out and done
something.  Most WANT to do something, but get sidetracked.  I am well
aware of both poles of the argument.  Thus, Buck, Hardkiss, Tony, Etc.  I
am well aware of who is doing what in this city, and I don't need to go out
every weekend to know wassup.  Been there, done it, excelled at it, now I'm
waiting to hear thier stuff.  Time is on my side, they'll make music if
they want to.  And when they do, if it's good, I'll buy it.


>
>Where are all of the parties _you're_ throwing / spinning at and where's the
>music _you've_ made, John?

Where have you been since '92?
Check the SFRaves Archives.  See Vortex.  I don't like to toot my own horn,
so I won't.  Suffice it to say I've financed and thrown parties many times
in the city (6 to be precise).  All were anywhere between 400-500 person
digs.  It was all good, I had a good time, made plenty of lifelong friends,
got to know some folx.  It was all good.  Did my bit of promotion and work
for Preston and Martin as well.

As for the music I've made, cut my first records when I was 19 with a group
in Fla. called Noveau Riche, and very 80's thang, kinda Pat Benatarish
meets the b52's.   Did my share of demo shopping in England back in 83-86
for Aural X, another Fla. 80's thang group (Prince meets Duran Duran).
Invited by some A&R folx at RCA, Capitol, Beggars Banquet, to show my
wares.  Started 20Hz in 94, faltered, got back on my feet, and restarted
things.  Looking forward to working with a couple of people, one of which
is on the list, the others are works in progress.  I do what I say, and I
say what I do.

I would ask you the same question but it's moot, it doesn't matter.  I, as
many know hate critique without solutions.  I would be the LAST person to
get on this list, cite problems, and do nothing about it. Obnoxious at
times, yes, do nothing, NEVER. History should be your guide, read the
archives for any other elucidation you might require.

But since you asked:
Spun at :), CyberLab 7, Velvet Shop, as well as smaller house parties for
friends.  Come out with tapes about once a week, mostly for myself, but
hand them out to selected friends who want to know how my skills have been
getting.  So yeah, I've spun out, made music, and own a record company.

Oh yeah, I'm slated to spin at Butterfly with Charlotte (she asked me btw),
so you all are invited down (sorry it's 21+), but the music is good.  It's
always good to hear Charlotte, she's the bomb!

>Where are the labels you're helping start up
>and/or fund?

Check out http://www.twenty-hz.com
20Hz Records is mine.  Releases set for early '96.

>It's easy to armchair quarterback the scene when you're just a
>passive participant.

Your characterization is insulting and incorrect.
(People who know me know that usually I would have leveled someone for
trying my patience, but the moon is full and people are reacting to it.
Whatever.  Soemtimes people get me, other times they don't.  I'm the same
with others.  Such is life, but please go on.)

>It's a lot more difficult to be critical of people when
>you're actively engaged in the scene. I may not groove too hard on the tunes
>or mixing style of the Wicked crew, but I respect them mightily for doing
>things their way for as long as they have.

I also have respect for all those who do the do in SF, from Wicked to F&F,
I think people who know me know that about me.  As for being critical, I
try never to lose my objectivity.  If you're too wrapped up in it to see
that there is room for learning, then I would suggest that maybe you're too
close.  But that is my humble opinion.  You may well think otherwise.  I
respect that.

>Similarly, I don't particularly
>dig ambient music, but the Reflective crew have earned my admiration for the
>innovative way they run their business. And there are also a _ton_ of DJs
>who have complete control over their tunes and who can completely put me
>over the edge here in San Francisco.

As for control of music, ain't heard it like I did the other night.  Jeno
is a master, but rearely pushes the envelope these days, same can be said
of most of the other mosre seasoned DJ's.  Not to say they aren't good,
they just don't push up as hard as they used to IMHO.

And I doubt you would find too many DJ's here in SF think as highly of
themselves as you do.  Ask them do THEY think they are just as good as Lil'
Louie or Pierre, or Carter.  Many of the most well known DJ's aspire to be
at the level these guys are.  All you have to do is ask.  I would be
curious as to what you find out about how THEY feel about themselves.  Once
again, it's not to say they are not all good and talented, but face it, the
bigger boys from out of town are in a differnt league, you can hear it.
And any DJ who is working can hear it as well.  Any honest Dj would admit
it.  The good thing is, in time they will be in the same class as the
people they admire, but only through effort, recording and traveling will
they get to that point. It's a long road, no doubt.

As for putting me over the edge, that has not happened to me in quite a
while.  Jeno , Garth, Markie, Thomas, Josh, Tony, Buck, Noel, Ernie, James,
etc. have all put me over the edge.  Had religious experiences to most of
their music.  Been listening to them for YEARS.  Just waiting for them to
make the next step and move to the next level.  It does not mean that they
are not talented, they all are, I'm just waiting for them to make the next
step in each of their respective evolutions.  I look forward to their
changes and their future musical pursuits!

>
>I guess what chaps my butt is seeing you pull that old tired "grass is
>greener" argument out of the closet again.

You misunderstood what I said.  I said SF Dj's have something to learn from
NY DJ's.  I was talking about style.  You were not there for Vega's set so
you have no reference point from which to draw as it relates to WHY I said
what I said.  It's not that anyone is lacking, it's that there is plenty to
be learned.  Since you did not see the Dj's watching Louie do his do, you
assume that they have nothing to learn.  From what I heard from the bulk of
them, they were listening really hard , and observing a master at work.
Period.

>The set that Ethan pulled off at
>the last Friends & Family was the equal of anything I've heard anywhere by
>anybody at anytime, ever. I've heard my share of the world's DJs, and while
>there are people from outside of SF whom I would go a long distance out of
>my way to see (Derrick Carter and Jeff Mills being two examples), we have an
>astounding array of talent right here.

Didn't say we didn't have alot of talent here.  Did not degrade the talent
of the many DJ's here.  But let's face it, I do not think we have produced
a Pierre, Vega, Humpries, Rosario, etc.  Yes, we WILL produce our own
versions, but that will happen, no doubt in the future.  I look forward to
it!  The talent, as well as the drive is here.  Time will be the ultimate
judge IMHO.  And from those I talked to the future is quite bright.

>
>yrz,
>ozy
>

Just wanted to say that I had a great time at the Gateway Systems Full 
Moon party last night hanging out with my new housemate Minor Minor, who 
played a totally stormin' set, by the way.  It's too bad there weren't 
more people there to enjoy it! More people started to file in once the 
monday weeklies shut down (Mad + Gardening Club), and Gavin Hardkiss 
warmed them up with some slow trip-hoppy grooves.  He managed to 
gradually speed it up, turning the set into a tweaky ethereal acid stomp, 
which I really got into, despite the sketchy mixing.  Then, he whipped 
out Melissa Ethridge, and it was all downhill from there.  Oh well, his 
first 45 minutes or so were great, and we left before he finished.  Also, 
Brad from Consciousness Labs did a really good warmup set of dreamy 
ambient to begin the evening.  A great party overall, I just wish there 
had been more people to share it with!  

-Seth

YES! the beauty of it all is seeing so many people turned on to the same 
thing. i know the *high* you refer to. some people just exist with a 
higher vibration. our own energy tends to seek out those of a higher 
vibration, and when we meet, it brings teh vibration just a little higher 
thru exchanges in Energy. and insight. something just cliks, and i find 
myself talking about deep things with strangers, trusting them, and teh 
beauty of it is it doesnt only happen at raves, but *everywhere*.
we just need to open our hearts. and allow our minds to become servers of 
our hearts. it is just backwards teh other way around.

smiles:) tom

> >Regarding the lack of music-making DJs, open your eyes, man.
> 
> You did not read both of my posts then.  Whatever.  I cited ALL of the
> people you did as well.  My eyes are wide open as my ears are as well.
> 
> 
> > There are a ton
> >of DJs making music in this town. The Hardkisses, the Reflective posse, the
> >Visible crew, DubTribe -- the list goes on and on. The fact that most of
> >these crews are far more visible outside San Francisco than within it is
> >something of a mystery to me. Reflective is getting _large_ in the European
> >community, and deservedly so, but you never hear dick about them here unless
> >you hang out in SOMA a lot.
> >
> >The real reason DJs aren't making music more is because it costs real money
> >that people don't have. I have a nice job, but I have a huge, vinyl-clad
> >monkey riding on my back, and I have to keep feeding that monkey
> >periodically to a) stay sane and b) keep growing as a DJ. I _want_ to start
> >making music, but the gear is _not_ cheap.
> 
> Yes, I understand this as well.  But that is no excuse IMHO.  There are
> plenty of people who have been able to scrape up ennough money to dupe
> tapes, it just requires a bit more funds to go the next mile.

Since when does being able to mix a record constitute a being good 
musician.  I 
think they do relate to each other somewhat but you DEFINETLY do not need 
to know how to dj to produce good music including House and Techno.  
Personally I am glad a lot of dj's are not making tracks, especially the 
ones that do know how to work a crowd and are the Rave/House scene 
stars.  These are the guys that seem to produce the formula tracks you 
know the ones that rock the house (the mainstream houses), but do nothing to 
innovate or push the music to advance.  Admitedly their are some dj's 
that can dj and produce some great tracks (DJ Pierre was an excellent 
example) but not all of them.  The art of mixing is building and creating 
energy, or dropping it, fucking with it, suprising people etc between 2 or 
more tracks.  I find these tracks that try to do it themselves with the 
big drum rolls and then the booming kick drum then the break etc, are 
pretty fucking cheesey, which did rock the crowd when it was an original 
concept, but it is a total formula that many dj's tend to repeat when 
they release their own tracks  (DJ Icee, Josh Wink etc....).  Personally 
I would much rather hear more tracks by guys that are not normally 
associated with the house and techno scenes, stuff like what the Jack 
Officers (Butthole Surfers), and Elliot Sharp have done.  Sometimes when 
you are so immersed in a scence (like being a big time dj)  you tend to 
loose a lot of creativity and insight, and it takes someone to come in 
from a totally different angle to really come up with the fresh shit.


Derek  

> 
> Fact is the "working" DJ's , when they manage their time and money
> properly, can pout out a record.  It's been done before.
> 
> 
> >
> >There's a tone to your letter that I really don't like.
> 
> Sorry, can't please everyone.
> 
> > At least twice you
> >make vague references to DJs being lazy or putting things off. Almost
> >all of the DJs I've met since I've been in San Francisco are sincere,
> >friendly people who obsess over their craft. They aren't lazy and they're
> >all following their own muses, which is the only way to live and develop as
> >an artist. Just because we aren't all cranking out tracks (and I dispute
> >your claim that all of the DJs in Chicago and New York are cranking out
> >music -- I think you'll find that it's a proportionally small number making
> >music _anywhere_. There are a _lot_ of DJs in New York) doesn't mean that we
> >don't care about what we're doing.
> 
> Geez.  What I said was the truth, what you said was the truth.  Fact is I
> have talked to DJ's and gotten a variety of answers.  The bulk of them have
> admitted dragging thier butts, while others have gone out and done
> something.  Most WANT to do something, but get sidetracked.  I am well
> aware of both poles of the argument.  Thus, Buck, Hardkiss, Tony, Etc.  I
> am well aware of who is doing what in this city, and I don't need to go out
> every weekend to know wassup.  Been there, done it, excelled at it, now I'm
> waiting to hear thier stuff.  Time is on my side, they'll make music if
> they want to.  And when they do, if it's good, I'll buy it.
> 
> 
> >
> >Where are all of the parties _you're_ throwing / spinning at and where's the
> >music _you've_ made, John?
> 
> Where have you been since '92?
> Check the SFRaves Archives.  See Vortex.  I don't like to toot my own horn,
> so I won't.  Suffice it to say I've financed and thrown parties many times
> in the city (6 to be precise).  All were anywhere between 400-500 person
> digs.  It was all good, I had a good time, made plenty of lifelong friends,
> got to know some folx.  It was all good.  Did my bit of promotion and work
> for Preston and Martin as well.
> 
> As for the music I've made, cut my first records when I was 19 with a group
> in Fla. called Noveau Riche, and very 80's thang, kinda Pat Benatarish
> meets the b52's.   Did my share of demo shopping in England back in 83-86
> for Aural X, another Fla. 80's thang group (Prince meets Duran Duran).
> Invited by some A&R folx at RCA, Capitol, Beggars Banquet, to show my
> wares.  Started 20Hz in 94, faltered, got back on my feet, and restarted
> things.  Looking forward to working with a couple of people, one of which
> is on the list, the others are works in progress.  I do what I say, and I
> say what I do.
> 
> I would ask you the same question but it's moot, it doesn't matter.  I, as
> many know hate critique without solutions.  I would be the LAST person to
> get on this list, cite problems, and do nothing about it. Obnoxious at
> times, yes, do nothing, NEVER. History should be your guide, read the
> archives for any other elucidation you might require.
> 
> But since you asked:
> Spun at :), CyberLab 7, Velvet Shop, as well as smaller house parties for
> friends.  Come out with tapes about once a week, mostly for myself, but
> hand them out to selected friends who want to know how my skills have been
> getting.  So yeah, I've spun out, made music, and own a record company.
> 
> Oh yeah, I'm slated to spin at Butterfly with Charlotte (she asked me btw),
> so you all are invited down (sorry it's 21+), but the music is good.  It's
> always good to hear Charlotte, she's the bomb!
> 
> >Where are the labels you're helping start up
> >and/or fund?
> 
> Check out http://www.twenty-hz.com
> 20Hz Records is mine.  Releases set for early '96.
> 
> >It's easy to armchair quarterback the scene when you're just a
> >passive participant.
> 
> Your characterization is insulting and incorrect.
> (People who know me know that usually I would have leveled someone for
> trying my patience, but the moon is full and people are reacting to it.
> Whatever.  Soemtimes people get me, other times they don't.  I'm the same
> with others.  Such is life, but please go on.)
> 
> >It's a lot more difficult to be critical of people when
> >you're actively engaged in the scene. I may not groove too hard on the tunes
> >or mixing style of the Wicked crew, but I respect them mightily for doing
> >things their way for as long as they have.
> 
> I also have respect for all those who do the do in SF, from Wicked to F&F,
> I think people who know me know that about me.  As for being critical, I
> try never to lose my objectivity.  If you're too wrapped up in it to see
> that there is room for learning, then I would suggest that maybe you're too
> close.  But that is my humble opinion.  You may well think otherwise.  I
> respect that.
> 
> >Similarly, I don't particularly
> >dig ambient music, but the Reflective crew have earned my admiration for the
> >innovative way they run their business. And there are also a _ton_ of DJs
> >who have complete control over their tunes and who can completely put me
> >over the edge here in San Francisco.
> 
> As for control of music, ain't heard it like I did the other night.  Jeno
> is a master, but rearely pushes the envelope these days, same can be said
> of most of the other mosre seasoned DJ's.  Not to say they aren't good,
> they just don't push up as hard as they used to IMHO.
> 
> And I doubt you would find too many DJ's here in SF think as highly of
> themselves as you do.  Ask them do THEY think they are just as good as Lil'
> Louie or Pierre, or Carter.  Many of the most well known DJ's aspire to be
> at the level these guys are.  All you have to do is ask.  I would be
> curious as to what you find out about how THEY feel about themselves.  Once
> again, it's not to say they are not all good and talented, but face it, the
> bigger boys from out of town are in a differnt league, you can hear it.
> And any DJ who is working can hear it as well.  Any honest Dj would admit
> it.  The good thing is, in time they will be in the same class as the
> people they admire, but only through effort, recording and traveling will
> they get to that point. It's a long road, no doubt.
> 
> As for putting me over the edge, that has not happened to me in quite a
> while.  Jeno , Garth, Markie, Thomas, Josh, Tony, Buck, Noel, Ernie, James,
> etc. have all put me over the edge.  Had religious experiences to most of
> their music.  Been listening to them for YEARS.  Just waiting for them to
> make the next step and move to the next level.  It does not mean that they
> are not talented, they all are, I'm just waiting for them to make the next
> step in each of their respective evolutions.  I look forward to their
> changes and their future musical pursuits!
> 
> >
> >I guess what chaps my butt is seeing you pull that old tired "grass is
> >greener" argument out of the closet again.
> 
> You misunderstood what I said.  I said SF Dj's have something to learn from
> NY DJ's.  I was talking about style.  You were not there for Vega's set so
> you have no reference point from which to draw as it relates to WHY I said
> what I said.  It's not that anyone is lacking, it's that there is plenty to
> be learned.  Since you did not see the Dj's watching Louie do his do, you
> assume that they have nothing to learn.  From what I heard from the bulk of
> them, they were listening really hard , and observing a master at work.
> Period.
> 
> >The set that Ethan pulled off at
> >the last Friends & Family was the equal of anything I've heard anywhere by
> >anybody at anytime, ever. I've heard my share of the world's DJs, and while
> >there are people from outside of SF whom I would go a long distance out of
> >my way to see (Derrick Carter and Jeff Mills being two examples), we have an
> >astounding array of talent right here.
> 
> Didn't say we didn't have alot of talent here.  Did not degrade the talent
> of the many DJ's here.  But let's face it, I do not think we have produced
> a Pierre, Vega, Humpries, Rosario, etc.  Yes, we WILL produce our own
> versions, but that will happen, no doubt in the future.  I look forward to
> it!  The talent, as well as the drive is here.  Time will be the ultimate
> judge IMHO.  And from those I talked to the future is quite bright.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov  8 10:46:13 1995

	id KAA05523; Wed, 8 Nov 1995 10:45:15 -0800
Date: Wed, 8 Nov 1995 10:45:15 -0800
Message-Id: <v01530500acc633941a86@[199.35.142.161]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ekjazz@netcom.com (Eric Kalabacos)
Subject: SF vs. NY hoohah!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm the person who responded to John Lee's glowing review of Little Louie
with the comment about how Louie and some other DJs in NY can take the
Wicked DJs and others from SF to school when on their own turf - which I
guess is what touched off the round of knocks that my man took for agreeing
with me. (we don't know each other, BTW).

Unfortunately, my mailbox at my ISP got fucked up so I've lost the threads
and can't respond directly to comments made, but I have a couple of things
that I'd like to say in general.

First of all, it is no accident that, although I grew up in NY, I now live
in SF. I agree with you all that the SF vibe is unmatched in many ways (and
this extends well beyond the dance scene for me - i find the vibe superior
to NY personally in many, many respects).

What I don't understand is why it seems that when a sister or brother
expresses an opinion on this list that doesn't go with the "Rah! Rah! SF"
flow in all respects, that people seem to get so defensive about this
place.

If you read the original posts, you may have noticed that John and I both
began our comments by giving props to the SF DJs and saying that we had
respect for them. I think John also made it clear that he was just talking
about music and not about promoters, party-vibes, or anything else.

Again, this does not take away from the brilliant, beautiful people
contributing to the scene here (many of the people mentioned in defense of
SF- Jonah Sharp - Ethan Miller - Buck - and others - are deeply valued
personal friends). I think what they are all doing is great (and I have a
feeling John would agree). BTW, I saw Buck's dad Randy on Monday and he
told me Buck will be returning to SF in December to set up a studio here!!!

If those of you that slammed John are so thrilled with the SF scene, than
you should feel confident enough in it to accept positive comments about
people/music from elsewhere without being so freakin' defensive.

And, as far as vibe goes, remember that we in SF certainly don't hold any
kind of monopoly. Even at a "commercial" venue like the Sound Factory Bar
(I was last there in July) I have had incredible times participating on a
sweaty, throbbing dancefloor full of people with smiles, hugs, and friendly
words for a stranger).

Keep it goin' on y'all!!!

Peace out,
ek

From: Josh Bates <unknown@nexsys.net>

Subject: Positive Propaganda
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.951108124206.14186C-100000@nexsys.nexsys.net>

This was written by my brother. Please read.

Sisters and Brothers,

	DO YOU WANT TO GET HIGH? Try eating organic short grain brown rice
for seven days and convert those wonderful complex carbohydrates into
simple sugars by chewing each bite at least 50 to 100 times. We are living
in an age where the food we eat is produced as fast as we can grow it with
little or no consideration for the health and well being of the people
that consume it. Have you noticed massive quantities of chemicals
displayed on prepackaged food? These chemicals are responsible for keeping
us static. They manipulate our minds, making us feel confused and
frightened. Most Americans live in so much fear, you can feel it by
walking past them on the street. By eating food sold in major supermarkets
we are setting up the necessary criteria in our bodies for degenerative
disease to surface. The mass produced food doesn't have the organic wild
nutrients our bodies and minds crave to be happy and stress free, with
positive goals and the tools necessary to obtain them. 

	DO YOU WANT TO DANCE FOR THE REST OF YOUR LIFE? A major reason why
we live in fear is because we eat animals that DIE IN FEAR. Whence their
turn to be slaughtered on the conveyor, they know what's going to happen
to them because they can smell the stench of their comrade's blood. They
excrete mass amounts of adrenaline that shoot through their entire bodies
attempting to escape. This fear, along with all the chemicals that are
used to grow the feed for the animals, not to mention the chemicals fed to
them and applied to their bodies, get transferred directly to YOU. The
American mass consumer (you) is unaware that they are contributing to the
destruction of forests, and land that could be used to grow food for us.
90% of all grain grown in the U.S. is fed to livestock instead of humans.1
People are starving and we indulge ourselves eating chemical laden meat
and then buying products from the pharmaceutical companies to counteract
all the symptoms. Our bodies are trying to tell us that we are doing some
thing wrong.

	DO YOU WANT TO LIVE AS OUR ANCESTORS DID? Humans have been
surviving and evolving with staple grains for thousands of years; Asians
eat rice; Germans eat buckwheat and rye; Indians eat chapatis and lentils;
American Indians eat corn; Africans eat millet and amaranth; and Aztecs
eat quinoa. AMERICANS EAT CONVENIENCE. Try not eating ANY animal products
for a week or a month and see how it feels. We now have the knowledge and
power to eat only what our bodies need. Visit your local library and check
out books on Macrobiotics, Ayurveda, herbs, and sprouts. Get motivated for
a physical and spiritual transformation! Shop the health food store bulk
bins for quality organic grains and beans. We are lucky to be living in
the bay area where the ancient foods are easily accessible and
inexpensive. Give your body what it really needs and feel deeply
nourished. More and more people are eating this way so you will not be
alone. It is part of the solution to the world's problems and it begins
with you...
							love*love*love
1.Diet for a New America, John Robbins

I was trying to keep the purely political stuff on the list to a minimum, 
but since you guys apparantly feel the need to keep telling sfraves how 
nutty libertarianism & privatization are, I feel a brief word is in 
order, to wit:

If the government sponsored a rave, and people were coerced to 
participate, how much fun do you think it would be?

Anyone who would like to see my fuller response to Niels posting below can 
email me and I'll be happy to share it.

My computer tells me that on Thu, 2 Nov 1995, Niels P. Mayer shared:

> 
> In case you were all wondering what the heck Mr. Jack Hart is quacking
> about, he was responding to a private note I sent to him and starchild
> stating something like "see, this is what you can expect with
> privatization".
> 
> The case involves one of those free educational readers distributed to
> children because schools don't have enough money to buy their students
> proper textbooks... So instead a shining knight of a company, RJR
> Nabisco (RJ Reynolds Tobacco) steps in, and after people are blinded by
> the twinkling of the thousand points of light, after people are so
> thankful that the good will of US businesses will take care of the kids
> that the "government" has forgotten about -- they gradually find out
> that behind the apparent good will of the company was little more than
> a successful attempt at direct-marketing cigarettes to school children!
> 
> This is pretty much a microcosm of what you can expect if the
> libertarians get their way, and privatization becomes rampant. Nobody
> in business does anything out of "pure good". Corporate good deeds, at
> best, involve positive PR, and more typically, involve motives of
> profit.
> 
> Also, Starchild made some comment that the failures that we've noted in
> libertarianism and privatization stem from the fact that the examples
> weren't cases of "pure privatization". Same argument could be made for
> socialism/communism -- it would work great in an ideal world where
> corruption, greed, and money aren't a problem. Unfortunately, all you
> have to do is wake up, get out of bed, and go to work, then note  how
> far things are from ideal.
> 
> Sorry if this is non-topical, but I wanted to clear some things up...
> 
> --------------------------------------------------------------------
> Weekly Reader spread tobacco industry views, researchers say
> 
> Associated Press
> 
> SAN DIEGO -- School children who read the Weekly Reader 
> between 1989 and  1994 were treated to an unhealthy dose of 
> tobacco industry views on  smoking in articles that were often 
> illustrated with Joe Camel,  researchers say.
> 
> At the time the articles appeared, the Weekly Reader was owned by 
> the  largest shareholder in RJR Nabisco, Joe Camel's creator.
> 
> Joe Camel, a promotional cartoon character for Camel cigarettes, 
> has been  widely criticized for appealing to children.
> 
> Scholastic News, a competing newsletter, was much more likely to 
> include  health warnings and to give health advocates the last 
> word, said the  authors of a study presented Monday at the annual 
> meeting of the American  Public Health Association.
> 
> In October 1994, health advocates attacked the Weekly Reader over 
> an  article for youngsters that discussed smokers' rights and the 
> harm to the  industry from smoking restrictions. The article said 
> nothing about  smoking as a cause of lung cancer and heart disease.
> 
> Following that uproar, researchers at the University of California, 
> San  Francisco analyzed 34 articles from the Weekly Reader dealing 
> with  smoking. For comparison, they analyzed 28 from another 
> school newsletter,  Scholastic News, which is published by a 
> family-owned company.
> 
> In the Weekly Reader, distributed to school children nationwide, 
> 68  percent of the articles included tobacco industry views and only 
> 38  percent carried a clear message against smoking. In Scholastic 
> News, only  32 percent of articles included industry views and 79 
> percent carried  anti-smoking warnings.
> 
> ``Weekly Reader needs to change its editorial policy,'' said the  
> principal researcher, Edith Balbach of the University of California, 
> San  Francisco. ``They're certainly not helping kids not to smoke.''
> 
> The Weekly Reader is owned by K-III Communications, a unit of 
> Kohlberg  Kravis Roberts, which was the largest shareholder of RJR 
> Nabisco until  March, when it sold its interest in RJR.
> 
> Sandra Maccarone, Weekly Reader's editor in chief, was traveling 
> and  could not be reached for comment and no one else at the 
> company could  comment on the study, Maccarone's office said.
> 
> Balbach expressed particular concern over an article for sixth-
> graders on  whether Joe Camel is encouraging kids to smoke. 
> Research has shown that  Joe Camel is as familiar to children as 
> Mickey Mouse, and that Camel  cigarettes have increased in 
> popularity among teen-agers since the  campaign began.
> 
> The article appeared in an issue in which Joe Camel was on the 
> cover  handing out ``Camel cash'' promotional coupons. Inside, 
> the article  featured a reproduction of a Joe Camel billboard.
> 
> Next to the billboard was a reproduction of an RJR Tobacco poster  
> advising children not to smoke. The Weekly Reader's caption said 
> the  poster was intended to help children make the ``right 
> decision'' about  smoking.
> 
> ``You will note that doesn't indicate which is the right decision,''  
> Balbach said.
> 
> Joe Camel appeared eight times in the Weekly Reader articles, she 
> said.
> 
> ``There were no negative markings on the photos, such as the 
> international `no' symbol. In effect, they were not that different 
> from actual ads,'' she said. 
> 
> Joe Camel appeared seven times in Scholastic News, but in three 
> cases children were demonstrating against the character and the 
> pictures had the international ``no'' symbol over them. In two 
> other cases, Joe Camel appeared as part of stories on how the 
> industry uses advertising to hide the dangers of smoking, Balbach 
> said. 
> 
> ----- End Included Message -----
>

I love San Francisco!!!!!!! And I love the SF rave scene!!!

But you should see those NY and Baltimore kids dance! They are FUNKY. I used
to just watch people and think, "How the hell do they do that?"

Also on the E. Coast we had some rave promoters who were very dedicated to
bringing us DJ's from around the world. I got to hear people spin from
Germany, Belgium, England (of course), L.A., SF, Montreal, Philly, Boston,
Toronto, NY, DC and Baltimore! etc. etc. Here that is definately the
exception rather than the rule. We have our own little British Invasion, but
how often am I going to hear the same 4 or 5 people spin at every party I go
to? (Just start flaming me now!)

There also seem to be a lot of folks who don't want to pay more than $10 for
a party. I would definately spend $20 or more to hear some really talented
DJ's who never get to spin out here. I mean, if these people have to be FLOWN
around the world, that costs money and I will pay the money for a really
kickin' party. I guess I just have to figure out how to put on a rave myself
or stop saying all of this.

The bottom line for me is that SF has the best scene by far, but I miss some
of the very talented DJ's I used to hear.

>> all the symptoms. Our bodies are trying to tell us that we are doing some
>> thing wrong.
>> 
>> 	DO YOU WANT TO LIVE AS OUR ANCESTORS DID? Humans have been
>> surviving and evolving with staple grains for thousands of years; Asians
>> eat rice; Germans eat buckwheat and rye; Indians eat chapatis and lentils;
>> American Indians eat corn; Africans eat millet and amaranth; and Aztecs
>> eat quinoa. AMERICANS EAT CONVENIENCE. Try not eating ANY animal products
>> for a week or a month and see how it feels. We now have the knowledge and
>> power to eat only what our bodies need. Visit your local library and check
>> out books on Macrobiotics, Ayurveda, herbs, and sprouts. Get motivated for
>> a physical and spiritual transformation! Shop the health food store bulk
>> bins for quality organic grains and beans. We are lucky to be living in
>> the bay area where the ancient foods are easily accessible and
>> inexpensive. Give your body what it really needs and feel deeply
>> nourished. More and more people are eating this way so you will not be
>> alone. It is part of the solution to the world's problems and it begins
>> with you...
>> 							love*love*love
>> 1.Diet for a New America, John Robbins
>> 
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov  8 15:06:58 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA21603; Wed, 8 Nov 1995 15:06:58 -0800

             <Pine.SOL.3.91.951108132537.8838B-100000@orion> 
Date: Wed, 08 Nov 95 14:52:43 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Why are you always siding with big money and big interests? Have you
noticed that:

(1) there are industries around more moneyed than schoolchild journalism
(2) these industries spy a marketing channel and fund deployment into
    the marketing channel via profits from higher margin sale (typically
    the channel, but often, it is worth $$$/power owning your own
    "independent' channels just in case...
(3) they are better funded than an independent competitor that is genuinely
    interestied in K-12 publishing as an "art" and an avocation, not
    because it'll fatten their wallets.
(4) they use their funding to dominate the competitors, simply because they
    want to sell you something "between the lines"....
(5) eventually, they are the sole voice and they have their marketing channel

This is typically the way things work when it comes to privatizing
essential human needs like education. We believe the future role of
government in a true democracy is to ensure both financial and personal
democracy, given the added pressures and profit motives brought on by
communications and the media and a world where information is a
commodity/necessity.

"Freedom from being the victim of someone's profit motive" is nearly
synonymous with (or at least as important as) freedom of religion. If
we can chose, to ignore it, that's fine, if it gets shoved down our
throats when it comes to the basic needs of human existance (education,
healthcare) that's no good. And that's where you're proposing to wedge
"privatization".

We are getting rather tired of watching the repeated paroxysms of this
deathkultur. Until we can figure out a way to come up with a society
where money is not equal to power, your thousand points of light are
nothing but black holes!

If the libertarian is just as interested in cottage industries as they
are in corporate megaliths then s/he too would also take on the belief
that more profit is not better, more competition is not better,
bigger/more is not better. THe exaltation of dominator pleasure in your
system of "competition for the sake of profit" comes all over the back
of economic slavery, suffering, and poverty. All the while they think
they're casting pearl necklace to swine!

This is not an optimal systems solution, and  eventually, if we're
gonna all survive, we've gotta talk "systems!". Don't be duped by
"their" wild wild west political fairytale, because unless you're rich
enough that your money can work for you so that you don't have to,
you'll just be a servant to their system! Nice Nice, Very Nice....

PS: this message was channeled to me from a star suckling from the left
third nub of the M16 eagles nest nebula. I was listening to the new
Planet Dog "Quadruped V.1" compilation... :-)

Hey, Good post


Whenever I try to expain to people the true evil of the
profit-motive-driven system of America, and I get tired or frustrated I
just say one thing- Morality is unprofitible, thus since this country is
directed only in favor of profit all power structures (corporate and
governmental) and the power decisions they make, are inherently devoid of
moality.

 Hence we live in a "profit democracy" and only the dollar votes and not
the people (majority).  Privatization is one facet of this problem, people
have been manipulated by the media to belive that competition is good
(profitible) and thus it's o.k. to privatize services that are a right
i.e.health care and legal representation, so that only those with the most
money get the best care and stay out of jail! is that democracy? NO, it's
more like feudalism.  Soon we will have private police, Yosemite will be
managed by Disney(no joke heard it on NPR yesterday) GG Park will cost 10
bucks and muni will only service the most profitible areas... on and on,
untill taking a deep breath will be 25 cents.

	I've never really been one to get involved in the socio-
political discussions (most of which are pretty interesting) that
sometimes pop up on this list, but I just got one of those
overwhelming urges to chirp up on this privatization thread...
Yeah, it's easy to embrace conspiracy theories, and I know there's
a romantic appeal in bashing "big-moneyed" businesses, but 
privatization, done responsibly, has historically proven to
be OVERWHELMINGLY successful... and I think Niels is confusing
the traditional definition of privatization (i.e. when a government
relinquishes control of a utility or service to private companies,
a la telephone service, mail service, airline service) with
the idea of complete libertarianism, where elementary schools
would be named after Philip Morris.  Privatization leads to
competition, and competition leads to lower prices, and since
Niels says that he wants "freedom from being the victim of  
someone's profit motive", I'm sure he'd agree that lower
prices for consumers are a good thing.
I could ramble on endlessly on this subject and put you all
to sleep so I'll stop for now, I guess :)

dancing to the hum of the big, bad, unfeeling, capitalist era ;)
Timothy


sidewalk@uclink2
UC Berkeley
"Fax machines, advertisements, television, technology...bring it
 all on board!  There's plenty of room!"  --U2

>Privatization leads to competition, and competition leads to >lower prices,
and since Niels says that he wants "freedom >from being the victim of
someone's profit motive", I'm sure >he'd agree that lower prices for
consumers are a good thing.

Frankly, I don't agree that lower prices are always a good thing. I don't
want a 99c hamburger from McDonalds, if it means forests are being clear cut
to graze cattle. 

I don't want a pair of cheaper Reebok sneakers if the Indonesian women who
work in their factories are making $2.00 a day, and are being repressed by a
genocidal dictator who won't let them organize. 

I don't want cheaper produce if I will get sick from eating it, and the farm
workers who use these chemicals will get cancer and die. 

I don't want lower prices if it means that I have to shop at Wal-Mart. 

Some of us believe that the free market economy should not dictate what our
MORALS are. Everything does not stop with the almighty dollar. Perhaps I am
lucky to be middle-class enough to make decisions like these. And make them I
will! 

Call me a raving liberal, but I intend to use the brain God gave me to
question our $$$ driven society.

On Thu, 9 Nov 1995, Rob Jellinghaus wrote:

> Geoff wrote:
> >Hmm me thinks you got it a little backwards, most of the world is
> >near vegan simply because the cannot afford meat, Meat is the thing that
> >is expensive.
> 
> I have heard that much of the world's arable land is suitable only for
> grasses that can feed cattle but not humans.  If this is true, then many
> millions of people eat meat because that is the only way to get fed
> from the sparse vegetation at their disposal.
>

No the truth is many millions of people are living at some level
of starvation. while it is true that there are several "primative"
tribes that exist of diets primarily consisting of meat (most notably
the eskimos and upper mongolians) almost of of the peoples of warmer climates
exist on diets that are mostly made up of vegitation augmented by what
ever livestock they have domesticated or whatever they can hunt down.
There are no Safeways in the grasslands of Africa.

 
> This doesn't mean that rich countries (like the US) with access to 
> land suitable for growing human-edible veggies shouldn't move towards
> veganism... they should.  But it does mean that "No More Meat For
> Anyone, Globally!" ignores some realities.

	Indeed it does ignore several problems, but ask yourselves how many
	of you would continue to eat meat if you had to murder the
	animal yourselves instead of buying a carcass at the Lucky's?

> would be in a much better state if we lived in a society intolerant of
> meat eaters.

services will likely be announced before the party. Stay tuned.)

interested parties, which includes you, if you've received this
note. So please join us, and send a copy of this invitation to anyone
else you may know who would be interested in attending.

to improve them.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Only a couple of additional points.  The recording scene is starting
to break wide open on the West Coast.  The Third Floor crew went to the
UK, made tons of mediocre remixes and some good ones, and then threw
back Freshly Squeezed distributed through Strictly, which is an SF
label in all but physical location (Freshly, that is).  Doran went to
LA to hook up with Paul Grogan and start Rampant, which defines the
new sound of the west (along with the new Twitch releases) as much as
the various Third Floor labels and the peak era of Twitch remixes did
a couple of years ago.  DJ Lace is leading the charge with excellent
trancey acidey house trax from Vangroovey.  I've heard other good things
from LA (Vox Lumania and City of Angels, for example) and SF (Pound
America, Trip'n'Spin, Astral Matrix of course, La Casa and a special
tip to Reflective which in addition to being a major worldwide ambient
label, as noted, has started to put out *serious* junglistic stuff),
as well as a smattering from elsewhere (Mike Commander Mindfuck Kandel
up there in Heaven in the San Juan Islands, Jon Bishop from San Diego
and others like the Rezonate crew in Atherton (?!?!) are putting out
well worthwhile tracks).  As I mentioned recently, my Seattle friend
Masa's new one is causing major waves, even though he released it 
himself somehow it ended up in DJ Magazine's hands and got a very
positive review from Mr. C, who aside from his jokey Shamen rapmeister
facade is a very serious and innovative musicians (both for the Shamen
and as boss of the Plink Plonk label).  And there are quite a few more
I haven't mentioned.  So it's a bit unfair of me to paint everything
musical right now as bleak, our own region is a very hot spot at the
moment and it shows no signs of cooling.  

As for DJs and skills, it's part determination, part luck, part pure
musical genius and part determination (again).  I'm impressed over and
over again by how long it takes to really learn the ropes of DJing.
I've been rattling the train tracks for over two years now and it's
just starting to make serious sense to me.  Charlotte tells me she's
been spinning for six years, Spun for eight, Ernie Munson for 15.
Pierre, Frankie Knuckles, Junior Vasquez, Carl Cox, Laurent Guarnier,
Francois Kevorkian, Josh Wink, all the "name" DJs you can think of
(other than Tracy Lords of course :) :) have at least five and as much
as 20 years of serious every-day-do-it-hard experience learning, doing,
and doing it again and again.  

I knew the moment I got into the SF scene in late 1991 that some of our
DJs were going to get national reputations and perhaps beyond.  It takes
a very long time.  It's not always a desirable thing -- ask Dubtribe, who
toured the country hard three times and came back worn down.  I really
cheer when a friend like Carlos *finally* starts playing out of town and,
you know what, they LOVE him on the east coast because he really is damn
good.  Won't knock yer eyes out like Pierre, maybe, but he WILL knock
yer eyes out.  It's hard to see the effect when you've seen Carlos scratch
techno tracks like nobody else in the world, probably, and you have seen
him do it for years without giving it much of a thought.  I think people
get the same thrill watching that for the first time as I did with an
east coast DJ who's basically unknown out here but has my total respect
as a DJ and remixer, Frankie Feliciano, one of the unsung heros of NY
house.  When he played at Mark Ameba
s Friday night Brothers and Sisters a few months ago at 1015 Folsom, 
I was utterly amazed by his style, so opposite that of Carlos.  I mean,
Frankie just put the record down, spun it a few seconds to sync it up,
waited for his mix point, dropped it in and let it go.  That totally
low-key no-tricks approach totally suited his style, which was based on
a thoroughly well-selected set.  A sheer pleasure.  Carlos and many
others in the SF scene have or soon will have the ability to please
a crowd with their style as well as their selection, and then maybe
a few years from now we'll talk about them the same as with Pierre
and the other "names" who truly deserve their reputation.

Well, I can see I'm ranting again myself.  I think all DJs are fundamentally
DJ sluts (thus the name of the magazine Jockey Slut :), just like musicians
do we check out the style, the presentation, the selection that the other
DJs are doing and we always, always, always learn something from it.

So when John Lee sez, "Check out Louie Vega!" I know exactly what he means.
He dropped the bomb the way Stacey Pullen and Anthony Shakir and Derrick
May dropped it in Detroit last month, and they weren't headliners, just
playing their sets amid many other well known DJs.

c ya
phred

Well this responce just makes me sad.  I don't think it's inherently (sp)
wrong to eat meat or dairy.  It's the way this kind of food is harvested
now-a-days.  If you raise betsy with love and milk her yourself then there
is probably not much harm done in drinking the milk, and if you kill her for
her meat (although I couldn't do it) that's probably not that bad either.
There is no love or respect for the life of the animals that are killed in
todays "factories".  I am not trying to change your beliefs, but I'm sure
you would agree that it is important to be aware of the actions you take.  

Rick

On Wed, 8 Nov 1995 MsPhink@aol.com. wrote:
 
> Frankly, I don't agree that lower prices are always a good thing. I don't
> want a 99c hamburger from McDonalds, if it means forests are being clear cut
> to graze cattle. 
> 
> I don't want a pair of cheaper Reebok sneakers if the Indonesian women who
> work in their factories are making $2.00 a day, and are being repressed by a
> genocidal dictator who won't let them organize. 
> 
> I don't want cheaper produce if I will get sick from eating it, and the farm
> workers who use these chemicals will get cancer and die. 
> 
> I don't want lower prices if it means that I have to shop at Wal-Mart. 
> 
> Some of us believe that the free market economy should not dictate what our
> MORALS are. Everything does not stop with the almighty dollar. Perhaps I am
> lucky to be middle-class enough to make decisions like these. And make them I
> will! 
> 
> Call me a raving liberal, but I intend to use the brain God gave me to
> question our $$$ driven society. 
> 

	Yeah, of course I'll agree that the ethical practices of many
businesses (both large and small) are wrong, but in this society, as
consumers we have the choice to support or boycott businesses that we 
like or dislike (because of privatization, there's more than one choice).
If we dislike Reebok, then we can buy another brand instead.  But, because
I also believe, like you, that the free market economy should not dictate
morals, then we shouldn't judge the purchasing decisions of other citizens.
It seems like I'm in the minority here, though, so don't take my word for
it! :)  I'm probably snappy because it's midterms week... yuck

See you,
Timothy

Thanks, phred,

I can't tell you how much I appreciate intelligent, informed discussion of
music and DJs like this post. These types of posts (as well as descriptions
of peep's personal experiences at parties) are the reason I was attracted
to this list in the first place and continue to hang out and wade through
alot of off-topic mailbox-stuffing to get to the goodies. Much props to
everyone on the list that takes the time and effort to share their musical
knowledge and insight with us.

Thanks for the education!!!

peace,
ek

>Only a couple of additional points.  The recording scene is starting
>to break wide open on the West Coast.  The Third Floor crew went to the
>UK, made tons of mediocre remixes and some good ones, and then threw
>back Freshly Squeezed distributed through Strictly, which is an SF
>label in all but physical location (Freshly, that is).  Doran went to
>LA to hook up with Paul Grogan and start Rampant, which defines the
>new sound of the west (along with the new Twitch releases) as much as
>the various Third Floor labels and the peak era of Twitch remixes did
>a couple of years ago.  DJ Lace is leading the charge with excellent
>trancey acidey house trax from Vangroovey.  I've heard other good things
>from LA (Vox Lumania and City of Angels, for example) and SF (Pound
>America, Trip'n'Spin, Astral Matrix of course, La Casa and a special
>tip to Reflective which in addition to being a major worldwide ambient
>label, as noted, has started to put out *serious* junglistic stuff),
>as well as a smattering from elsewhere (Mike Commander Mindfuck Kandel
>up there in Heaven in the San Juan Islands, Jon Bishop from San Diego
>and others like the Rezonate crew in Atherton (?!?!) are putting out
>well worthwhile tracks).  As I mentioned recently, my Seattle friend
>Masa's new one is causing major waves, even though he released it
>himself somehow it ended up in DJ Magazine's hands and got a very
>positive review from Mr. C, who aside from his jokey Shamen rapmeister
>facade is a very serious and innovative musicians (both for the Shamen
>and as boss of the Plink Plonk label).  And there are quite a few more
>I haven't mentioned.  So it's a bit unfair of me to paint everything
>musical right now as bleak, our own region is a very hot spot at the
>moment and it shows no signs of cooling.
>
>As for DJs and skills, it's part determination, part luck, part pure
>musical genius and part determination (again).  I'm impressed over and
>over again by how long it takes to really learn the ropes of DJing.
>I've been rattling the train tracks for over two years now and it's
>just starting to make serious sense to me.  Charlotte tells me she's
>been spinning for six years, Spun for eight, Ernie Munson for 15.
>Pierre, Frankie Knuckles, Junior Vasquez, Carl Cox, Laurent Guarnier,
>Francois Kevorkian, Josh Wink, all the "name" DJs you can think of
>(other than Tracy Lords of course :) :) have at least five and as much
>as 20 years of serious every-day-do-it-hard experience learning, doing,
>and doing it again and again.
>
>I knew the moment I got into the SF scene in late 1991 that some of our
>DJs were going to get national reputations and perhaps beyond.  It takes
>a very long time.  It's not always a desirable thing -- ask Dubtribe, who
>toured the country hard three times and came back worn down.  I really
>cheer when a friend like Carlos *finally* starts playing out of town and,
>you know what, they LOVE him on the east coast because he really is damn
>good.  Won't knock yer eyes out like Pierre, maybe, but he WILL knock
>yer eyes out.  It's hard to see the effect when you've seen Carlos scratch
>techno tracks like nobody else in the world, probably, and you have seen
>him do it for years without giving it much of a thought.  I think people
>get the same thrill watching that for the first time as I did with an
>east coast DJ who's basically unknown out here but has my total respect
>as a DJ and remixer, Frankie Feliciano, one of the unsung heros of NY
>house.  When he played at Mark Ameba
>s Friday night Brothers and Sisters a few months ago at 1015 Folsom,
>I was utterly amazed by his style, so opposite that of Carlos.  I mean,
>Frankie just put the record down, spun it a few seconds to sync it up,
>waited for his mix point, dropped it in and let it go.  That totally
>low-key no-tricks approach totally suited his style, which was based on
>a thoroughly well-selected set.  A sheer pleasure.  Carlos and many
>others in the SF scene have or soon will have the ability to please
>a crowd with their style as well as their selection, and then maybe
>a few years from now we'll talk about them the same as with Pierre
>and the other "names" who truly deserve their reputation.
>
>Well, I can see I'm ranting again myself.  I think all DJs are fundamentally
>DJ sluts (thus the name of the magazine Jockey Slut :), just like musicians
>do we check out the style, the presentation, the selection that the other
>DJs are doing and we always, always, always learn something from it.
>
>So when John Lee sez, "Check out Louie Vega!" I know exactly what he means.
>He dropped the bomb the way Stacey Pullen and Anthony Shakir and Derrick
>May dropped it in Detroit last month, and they weren't headliners, just
>playing their sets amid many other well known DJs.
>
>c ya
>phred

Just last night on the "Real World IV." Yes I am a habitual 
watcher...They went to Africa and basically had the same feelings we did 
about all this...except they actually got a look at the indigenous people 
and having to kill animals right there in front of you and then shoving 
on the fire for dinner...etc  Interesting stuff...
just to link this with something I experience:
	when I have shroomed in the past I always get these primitive 
thoughts in my head about how I should move to the wilderness and live 
off the land, and I ponder how the world and my life would be way back 
when everybody had to live off the land...anybody else get these thoughts?

G

On Wed, 8 Nov 1995, Josh Bates wrote:

> 
> 
> On Wed, 8 Nov 1995 blkadder@value.net wrote:
> 
> > P.S. Would you move this discussion elsewhere? This is sf-raves, not 
> > alt.meat.eaters.are.evil.
> 
> Sure. I guess alt.drugs/sfraves isn't the place to discuss this, unless I 
> talk about the drugs they feed em'. Sorry for posting something out of 
> love NOT out of intolerance. Why don't we switch to one of the usual xtc 
> threads now & pretend everything is just great. And please no more of 
> those interesting threads like "privitization".
> 
> -josh

You are absolutely correct about your post as well as the privitization 
thread. They do not belong here. Please, please don't take this the wrong 
way. I am not saying that your points or valid or invalid(although I 
disagree with a few, which I will be happy to go into in PRIVATE e-mail.) 
Certain threads start out as being peripherally related to raving, and digress 
further away from being related to SF-Raves in any way, shape or form. 
When this happens we all end up with political manifestos and flame-wars 
filling our mail boxes. Trust me, I know, I have been involved in more 
than one. When you see a thread that you have started digressing, would 
you consider asking the participants to move it to private e-mail? There 
are a lot of very intelligent people on here, with a lot of good ideas 
that need discussing. The art is finding when these subjects are better 
discussed privately. For a refresher, I have included a portion of the 
welcome messages everyone receives when subscribing:


	Appropriate topics include: announcements of upcoming events;
reviews of previous shows/DJ's/new records, etc; discussion about
SF-related and rave- culture-related topics, like smart drinks;
discussion about rave-related stories on TV/in the newspaper, etc.
Ideally we should try and stay away from, "Hey, did you catch that
Orbital song on "Beverly Hills 90210" last week?"  stuff, or from
over-generalizing ourselves: "Can Depeche Mode be considered "techno"?
", etc. But, other than that, I want it to be pretty free form. The
list should _not_ be about rave scenes in other parts of the world; an
occasional post about a huge megaevent in LA or a monthly report on
the scene in other cities might be okay, but remember there was a
reason this is called SFRaves; if you want to start a mailing list for
your area, ask your sysadmin, as that was all I had to do. If that
fails, there's alt.raves, the USENET newsgroup, where you can post
just about anything you want.


                                            Thanks
                                              Black Adder

Here's a belated post on the Texas TV program:

Though I didn't see the program, I do know how anyone could get such a 
misguided perception about our scene.  

At almost every rave I have been to including FnF, Basics, and others I have 
witnessed drug use.  However I think people focus on this too 
much...drugs are used everywhere.  I can also say I have witnessed drug 
use at SF Giants and 49ers games, almost every concert I have ever been 
to including Pearl Jam on Saturday (which by the way was killer!) and 
elsewhere.  Anybody just walking into our scene for the first time is 
going to see this first before they really see our community and immediately 
start to form opinions about our drug use and our scene as a whole. they 
can't get past this part of our scene to see the wonderful and friendly 
people.

G

On Sat, 4 Nov 1995, eric wrote:

> get fucked up on "E" or whatever and die or get arrested ARE NOT RAVERS. For
> the life of me I can't figure out how they came to that conclusion.

On Wed, 8 Nov 1995 MsPhink@aol.com wrote:

Ditto

> I love San Francisco!!!!!!! And I love the SF rave scene!!!

Double Ditto, soory SF, but after being here a year, East Coast Club Kids
and wanna be's dance all over us. Does anyone remember Mary Egan, if so,
and if you ever saw her dance ya know what I mean. I can tell just by
looking at people dancing, if I see that East Coast sytle, I'll walk up
and I'll ask are you or have you spent some time on the East coast scene
and 90% of the time they will say yes. But please don't look for that 
sytle in the way I dance, you wouldn't find it, cause I can't seem to do 
steps or don't have the patience or effort for it. But you do look great 
out there when you do it, it's just so cool looking that it makes you get 
up and try.

> But you should see those NY and Baltimore kids dance! They are FUNKY. I
used > to just watch people and think, "How the hell do they do that?" 

Tripple Ditto, in one year in Gainesville, FL. @ a club called Simions;
yes Gainesville, I saw Peirre, Keoki, The Hardkisses, Detroit, New York,
German, French, English, Japanese...etc spin. Are we either that cheap,
ignorant, fearful, or just SF sho-ven-ists. 

	Please don't take offense I'm just tring to bring to your
awareness, that we are not da shit. Most people know me, and know just how
much I love this town, and that my love is based on much more than just a
great scene. A city the size of, with the pull & draw that SF has, a
wonderful city that I know it is, should be a leader rather than just a
passive participent. It seems like we are just content to not be in a
world mix(with the exception & ocassional visit from God(Goa Gill)), but
rather Techno isolationsit, with our input entering from the street level
rather than from the top down, or what i would consider optimal, an equal
mix of both. 

> Also on the E. Coast we had some rave promoters who were very dedicated to
> bringing us DJ's from around the world. I got to hear people spin from
> Germany, Belgium, England (of course), L.A., SF, Montreal, Philly, Boston,
> Toronto, NY, DC and Baltimore! etc. etc. Here that is definately the
> exception rather than the rule. We have our own little British Invasion, but
> how often am I going to hear the same 4 or 5 people spin at every party I go
> to? (Just start flaming me now!)
 
Of course and all things being consider, that this is just my subjective
opinion, which is based on my experience over the years, and is not by any
means the way it is, or the word of God.

> just to link this with something I experience:
> 	when I have shroomed in the past I always get these primitive 
> thoughts in my head about how I should move to the wilderness and live 
> off the land, and I ponder how the world and my life would be way back 
> when everybody had to live off the land...anybody else get these thoughts?

Not when I'm shrooming >%^)

But- I have relatives that farm for a living, and I've spent a little bit
of time at Zendik Farm in TX (a small tribe that supports themselves 
through farming and propaganda sales).

The Zendik's aren't particularly high-tech about their farming; they don't
greenhouse or solar-cone their own veggies and still get power off the grid.
Even considering this, though, I wouldn't describe them as overworked: 
having more than Dad and his two sons working means it's a lot easier to deal
with the billion little things that have to be done on a farm.  Of course,
they don't have a lot of spare cash, so there aren't a lot of consumer goods,
but the quality of life seems pretty good if free time and sociability is
more important than having tons of stuff.

I figure that if you have a bit more money to start and some hardcore people
you can be more self-sufficient and do less work -- wind/water power, solar-
cone year-round gardening, and super-efficient dwellings come to mind.  All
you have to find is some people willing to commit with you, which is the 
really hard part.  I mean, it's bad enough finding housemates that you don't
want to kill.

Of course, when I think of living off the land, I think of hunting and 
gathering.  Unfortunately, there are way too many humans covering the earth
for this to be practical anywhere that isn't totally unpleasant (the 
Amazonian rain forest, for instance).  The modern equivalent is technomadism,
where you can either do your job from anyplace or find a job anywhere.
Somehow, tho, typing on a laptop isn't as cool, and leaves unsolved the
problem of connection to the land.

// g

***WARNING:THE FOLLOWING IS OF A PRIMARILY PROMOTIONAL NATURE, IF YOU ARE
OFFENDED BY SUCH MATERIAL, PLEASE DELETE THIS MESSAGE NOW***

Below is a copy of the Tribal Funk Newsletter I mailed out today to our mailing
list.--Colin

		Tribal Funk
				November 8, 1995

Dear Family Members:
	Thank you to all of you who came out to Nothin' But Love. It was
an amazing night of music and dance. The house exploded with DJ Dan and Donald
Glaude on four turntables. But the people made it really special. So many
smiles! Thank you again.
	With summer behind us, we are getting things together to celebrate
Tribal Funk's Second Birthday on November 25th, 1995. DJ's for the evening
will be Utopia, DJ Dan, Tony, DJ Trance, Jeno, and Garth. Visuals will be
provided by Hyperdellic and Synergy. Hollywood Dog will be there with the
laser show. Mark Wayne (E.A.R. Sound System) will provide the sound system.
This party will be $15 before midnight, so please arrive early to make this
a special night.
	For location information please call (415) 905-4476 or (408) 291-3243.
	As we approach our birthday, we've looked back a little on where
we've gone. In the summer of 1993 the scene was a little bleak in San Francisco.
Because too many parties didn't deliver what they promised and the friendly
vibe seemed to be harder to find we wanted to try throwing a party ourselves
and see if we couldn't do better. Ever since then we've tried hard to throw
the best parties we possibly could.
	Now the scen in San Francisco is booming. Nearly all the parties
deliver what they advertise on their flyers. The friendly faces are out in
force every weekend now, too. Now we want to continue the process we tried
to start at Nothin' But Love: It is our goal to create a magical evening
where people arrive as strangers and leave as friends.
	We are putting all our energy into creating the best production 
possible, but we need you to bring an open heart and an open mind. Only you
can make love happen.

			Keep Smiling!

		   Tribal Funk Productions

At 06:13 AM 11/9/95 -0800, you wrote:
> [ to SFRaves ]

> Recently , in a message from Derek Oliver <moses@teleport.com>:

>> I would much rather hear more tracks by guys that are not normally

>> Officers (Butthole Surfers), and Elliot Sharp have done.  Sometimes when

> What! Butthole Surfers doing "rave" music!?! Great! 
>
> Can anyone do a short review of recent "Jack Officers" releases? When/what
>was their most recent release? 

There was only one release, called "Digital Dump," which came out in 89 or
so. Not really dance music per se, but quirky, BH'er-esque experiments in a
synth studio. Fucked up Drum loops, samples, and keyboard bits. Not for
amateurs or simple-groove fans. It is only Gibby and Jeff at the controls, I
believe.

eh


p.s. More electro, please.
