Anyone read the article in Mix Mag about Holland, raves, and drug use?  I
picked it up the other day.  They are against having a "War on Drugs" over
there.  They prefer other methods, one of which allows drug testing centers.
Users, and dealers can have there E tested to make shure how much is in it,
and it isn't something else.  
One group set up a booth at a rave out there, and several of the pills
tested were other things like speed.....Some officers showed up at the rave,
and visited the booth.  They were very much in support of the testing.
It is unfortunate such testing would be illegal here, but I wont get into
those politics.  I do recommend that those interested read the article.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Nov  9 13:23:21 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA16745; Thu, 9 Nov 1995 13:23:21 -0800

To: eric <ehill@best.com>

Subject: Drug use, not abuse
In-Reply-To: <199511042010.UAA23847@shellx.best.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951109123313.11068D-100000@orion>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



My computer tells me that on Sat, 4 Nov 1995, eric shared:

> What a misguided perception of our scene. I have no idea where Joe Normal
> gets the impression that all we do is drugs and party. I mean, I haven't
> seen this "documentary," but it's GOTTA be stupid and wrong no matter what.
> When are these people going to see that all those people who go to raves and
> get fucked up on "E" or whatever and die or get arrested ARE NOT RAVERS. For
> the life of me I can't figure out how they came to that conclusion.
> 
> eh

	I'm not sure I'm comfortable with the spirit of Eric's sarcasm 
here, it seems to imply that negative media portrayals of our scene are 
OK, but I think he does touch on an important issue.  If we try to 
dissociate ourselves from drug use at parties, we will look like the 
worst kind of pretenders to anyone with the least bit of familiarity with 
our scene.
	When we try to play down the importance of drugs to the rave scene, 
we buy into the media's premise, and that of mainstream society, that all 
use of illegal drugs is bad.  This is bullshit.  Legal drugs like alcohol 
and tobacco are more harmful than illegal drugs like pot and exstasy, and 
if we won't stand up and tell the truth about this, who will?
	While the music and even more importantly the vibe at raves may be 
most important to those of us who go to the parties, its fair to say that 
in general this will not be the case of the media.  When the media comes, 
they will tend to pay a disproportionate amount of attention to drugs and 
sex.  Instead of trying to fight them, which is futile in the long run, 
let's use the media spotlight to educate the public on the positive 
aspects of sexuality and mind-altering substances.
	We need to make the distinction here between drug use and drug 
abuse.  To the media right now, they are the same -- any use whatsoever 
constitutes abuse, if the substance is illegal.
	Unfortunately, what's legal and illegal in this country has 
little to do with what is right and what is wrong.  Frankly, I don't care 
if what I do is legal or not, although obviously I care about getting 
busted by those who do.  I only care if what I do is right, i.e. if I am 
being a good person and respecting others -- call it a PLURal lifestyle.
	I will say this, and that is that in my nearly four years of 
going to raves, I don't recall ever seeing any elementary school age kids 
on drugs, and this is coming from someone who doesn't necessarily have a 
problem with kids that age smoking a little dope -- so run that on your 
evening newscast, KXAS.

PLURally yours,
				*** Starchild ***
_____________________________________________________________________________
"The press has anointed itself, by default but not reluctantly, as the 
gatekeeper of public morality..."
				-Edwin Yoder, USA Today, 8/7/91

>	While the music and even more importantly the vibe at raves may be 
>most important to those of us who go to the parties, its fair to say that 
>in general this will not be the case of the media.  When the media comes,

I agree with this somewhat, but I think the problem I have with taking this
attitude is that raves are about more than drugs and sex, and the public is
going to get a really negative image of raves with the way things are
portrayed now.  I mean, you only see the good in a situation if you want to
see.  And if you try to show the media the good side of drugs, they're just
going to twist it around and make it look bad.  It's really not that tough.
I'm sure the rave in Texas they went to was one I would enjoy going to, but
if I saw the tv broadcast later on I might be surprised at the way it looked.

Jake

>private sector's power gets so great that it interfere's with the publics
>intrests.  Hence the massive corporate control of "our" government
>(i.e.PAC'S).  In other words try to support your local small buisness when
>you can.
>
Maybe the small business is an aspiring tyrant...

So how are you going to deal with that power? One way is to try to forcibly
deprive the big monster of some of it's functions that it has developed
without problem all this time that no one has said anything. Another way is
to decrease your need for their product, thereby eliminating the power they
have over your life, and preserving everyone else's freedom of choice.

eh

>
>Mark
>

	id TAA27513; Thu, 9 Nov 1995 19:32:31 -0800
Date: Thu, 9 Nov 1995 19:32:31 -0800
Message-Id: <199511100332.TAA27513@ix4.ix.netcom.com>
From: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin )
Subject: Re: that pesky ol' evil private sector
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com.It.seems.that.the.republicans.would.have.us.believe.that.we.need.to
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

deregulate.  We need to promote free enterprise and capatalism.  We 
must get the goverement out of business.  Let the market run itself.  
We are a capatalist nation aren't we???  

Fuck that.  History shows that industry and business will do whatever 
they can to maximize profits.  Think of England during its Industrial 
revolution.  The number of people who died from one health problem or 
another due to lack of regulation is uncountable.  Without regulation 
business will dump waste into our water, our air, our land, and our 
bellies.  The profits are privitized to the industry and the cost of 
pollution would be commonized by the people paying with sickness and 
death.  When clean up is finally absolutely necessary we will pay once 
more for it.  

This is a form of communism disguised as capatalism.  Fortunately we 
have regulations such as the clean water act and we have the EPA (for 
what its worth).  Unfortuately we have a republican congress and may 
soon have a republican president.  This can be very bad for the concept 
of regulation.  We may not see the end of regulation but a weakening of 
it seems imminent.  

love chris

p.s. the solution to all political problems is the removal of the 
concepts of ownership and leadership.  The best goverment is no 
goverment at all.  But this means the removal of the concepts.  We as a 
species must evolve to a higher state of understanding.  Untill we stop 
competing with each other these ideals are impossible.  But a small 
group has been emerging at a rapid rate since the 1960's.  It is 
possible that the number is growing in the form of a J curve.  The 
revolution is taking place as we speak and the battle is being fought 
peacefully at raves and other gatherings.  rEvolution.

   Stompy and Vision are the big players this weekend. I made the rounds
   last night and found a groovy scene at Cafe Mars (cosmic lounge),
   nice jazzy stuff in a loungy atmosphere. Roots was going strong with
   the Black Diamond upstairs; upstairs featured some weird funky toons
   and Emma spun a great set as the evening's guest star.
   
   Thanks to everyone who's been sending updates and positive feedback.
   See you next week!

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

     All this talk reminds me of a Mr. Terrence McKenna's theory about the
coming profound change in the universe.  I won't go into it deeply, but the
increase of novel things has been growing at an exponential rate, and what I
beleive is at the heart of it is the new ideas that are being expressed by
the growing number of people being talked about.  If you want to check out
Terrence McKenna's theory of the Eschaton (the point where the amount of
novelty is the highest, where a great intergalactic change happens) can be
found at his web site... the URL is http://www.levity.com/eschaton/.  It's
very informative... you should all check it out.
            Hugs, Wurz

>---------- Forwarded message ----------
>Date: Thu, 9 Nov 1995 12:52:56 -0600 (CST)
>From: Edward M Wesp <edwesp@csd.uwm.edu>
>To: ecl.grad@alpha1.csd.uwm.edu
>Subject: Stelarc: Live on the Web
>
>
>CHECK THIS OUT TOMORROW (FRIDAY NOV. 10TH).
>LIVE!!!  INTERNATIONALLY ON THE WORLD WIDE WEB!
>
>The URL: http://www.telepolis.lu/live/stelarc
>
>
>The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee's Center for Twentieth Century Studies 
>will be the only US participant.  See below.  We are on the Web live at
11:00am 
>(Central).
>
>Below is the program for the event.  Enjoy.
>
>		See you on the Web, 
>
>		Kathleen Woodward, Carol Tennessen, and Nigel Rothfels
>
>FRACTAL FLESH
>
>SPLIT BODY : VOLTAGE-IN / VOLTAGE-OUT
>
>AN INTERNET BODY UPLOAD PERFORMANCE
>
>http://www.telepolis.lu/live/stelarc  
>
>
>
>STELARC
>
>
>
>Six remote sites will access and activate the body in Luxembourg using
>modem-linked MACs to a Multiple Muscle Stimulation system.  PictureTel -
>ISDN connections provide visual feedback.  People in Paris, Amsterdam,
>Hamburg, Helsinki, Vienna, Milwaukee and Toronto will choreograph the
>body's movements at TELEPOLIS, interactively participating and
>constructing the performance, which will be uploaded to the Internet. The
>Web site will allow monitoring and updating of the visual events between
>the the remote sites and Luxemburg. 
>
>
>
>With the Third Hand attached, it becomes a split body - on the LHS <left
>hand side> voltage in, generates involuntary limb motion; on the RHS
><right hand side> voltage out (using electrodes on the abdominal and leg
>muscles) actuates the robotic Third Hand.  Sensors on the arms, head and
>left leg allow the body to become the video switcher, and video mixer,
>structurally connecting motion with image.  Involuntary motions from the
>body will also generate sampled body signals and sounds. 
>
>
>
>Performance Schedule
>
>
>
>Friday November 10, 1995    
>
>18.00   Center for 20th Century Studies, Univ. of Wisconson at Milwaukee, USA, 
>
>	Kathleen Woodward, Director
>
>	Site coordinator:  Nigel Rothfels	
>
>19.00	TELEPOLIS  exhibition audience
>
>20.00	DOORS of PERCEPTION, Amsterdam, Netherlands
>
>	Josephine Grieve and Geke van Dijk, site coordinators
>
>21.00	TELEPOLIS exhibition audience
>

>
>

Subject: Re: privatization hard at work 
In-Reply-To: <951108201225_16847253@mail06.mail.aol.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951110045231.7585A-100000@orion>

On Wed, 8 Nov 1995 MsPhink@aol.com wrote:

> >Privatization leads to competition, and competition leads to >lower prices,
> and since Niels says that he wants "freedom >from being the victim of
> someone's profit motive", I'm sure >he'd agree that lower prices for
> consumers are a good thing.
> 
> Frankly, I don't agree that lower prices are always a good thing. I don't
> want a 99c hamburger from McDonalds, if it means forests are being clear cut
> to graze cattle. 
> 
> I don't want a pair of cheaper Reebok sneakers if the Indonesian women who
> work in their factories are making $2.00 a day, and are being repressed by a
> genocidal dictator who won't let them organize. 
> 
> I don't want cheaper produce if I will get sick from eating it, and the farm
> workers who use these chemicals will get cancer and die. 
> 
> I don't want lower prices if it means that I have to shop at Wal-Mart. 
> 
> Some of us believe that the free market economy should not dictate what our
> MORALS are. Everything does not stop with the almighty dollar. Perhaps I am
> lucky to be middle-class enough to make decisions like these. And make them I
> will! 
> 
> Call me a raving liberal, but I intend to use the brain God gave me to
> question our $$$ driven society. 
> 
In a free market there are multiple service providers, and you have these 
choices.  When government, through taxation and regulation, eliminates 
competition, it eliminates choices, and you could find yourself eating at 
McDonalds because the mom & pop restaurant owners had to shut down when 
they couldn't afford to keep paying their property taxes.  In countries 
that have followed the route of economic freedom, the standard of living 
has gone up, and you're unlikely to find anyone making as little as $2.00 
a day.  

Please, question our dollar-driven society all you want, just don't 
continue to play the money-grabbing game by voting for higher taxes and 
more government.  This won't make anyone less greedy, quite the contrary, 
because there will be less wealth to go around, and it will be harder to 
get by.

A word to the wise,
				*** Starchild ***

or Lenny or try Recod Time at +1 810 775-1550 and talk to Mike Huckaby or
Brian Gillespie, or try Seventh City distribution at +1 313 963-4737.

Phuture stuff) I'd try Gramophone in Chicago, which I don't have a number
for. Try Chicago information at +1 312 555-1212

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Nov 10 12:58:08 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA07228; Fri, 10 Nov 1995 12:58:08 -0800
Received: from mail02.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA07070; Fri, 10 Nov 1995 12:56:45 -0800
From: Disssolve@aol.com
Received: by mail02.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id PAA11960; Fri, 10 Nov 1995 15:54:11 -0500
Date: Fri, 10 Nov 1995 15:54:11 -0500
Message-ID: <951110151335_103230189@mail02.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: TGrenager@aol.com, SGrenager@aol.com, kchance@haverford.com,
        ezeamer@denitqm.ecte.uswc.uswest.com
Subject: ten suns exploding
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


after a two week vacation that flew by as if on mercury's ankle-wings, i'm
back from the east coast. and i return with an astronomical heap of gratitude
for the beautiful, cohesive rave-community we have here in the bay area. ten
suns exploding  in the same spot at once couldn't be more intense than the
joy i feel about the fact that i'm a part of several  thriving  communities
of artists, spiritual seekers, all-night dancers, moon-howlers, sun-screamers
and other freaks. 

it's about power, my lovelies. it's about getting clean, wholesome power, or
should i say it's about sharing the stuff. going reductionist for a moment,
the search for power is the primal activity of life. plants tan in the sun
drink with their toes and that's all they need to do to get their power,
which they impart to cows, vegetarians, and other herbivores. of course, we
crave all kinds of power, just as we should. black beans and rice, with some
chopped tomato, onion and cilantro, a drizzle of olive oil and some minced
garlic and crushed black pepper and sea salt, as wholesome it might be,
doesn't fill us completely. so we set off in search of other forms of power,
often without thinking about what we're doing. i go to a party not really
thinking about why i'm going, but once i'm there, and i'm dancing, and i'm
being danced, and i'm suddenly surging with power power Power, and suddenly
i'm so juiced that i'm leaking lightning out of my  ears. suddenly i realize
why i'm here, what brought me here: the search for good, clean power. 

that's why i rant and rave. that's why i dance. that's why i struggle with my
art: to express this power, the power of this power. i'm not talking about
neitzsche's superman power. we don't have to rush into a phone booth to
unleash this power.  i'm talking about the stuff the bubbles straight up from
the center of the human heart. 

have i lost you?    

i'm lost myself. delightfully so. my point is this: it's great to be back. i
missed throbbing with you, and i'm so glad that i live where i live that i
could just, um, blow apart.

surging, 
dSiHssAoLvOeM   

"too much sanity is insane. it is insane to accept things as they are and not
as they should be."
                                                       - cervantes 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Nov 10 12:59:47 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA07321; Fri, 10 Nov 1995 12:59:47 -0800
Received: from netcom14.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA07316; Fri, 10 Nov 1995 12:59:44 -0800
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom14.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id MAA15124; Fri, 10 Nov 1995 12:58:06 -0800
Date: Fri, 10 Nov 1995 12:58:06 -0800
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Message-Id: <v01510102acc8d7175c3a@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Re: privatization hard at work
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>In a free market there are multiple service providers, and you have these
>choices.  When government, through taxation and regulation, eliminates
>competition, it eliminates choices, and you could find yourself eating at
>McDonalds because the mom & pop restaurant owners had to shut down when
>they couldn't afford to keep paying their property taxes.  In countries
>that have followed the route of economic freedom, the standard of living
>has gone up, and you're unlikely to find anyone making as little as $2.00
>a day.
>
>Please, question our dollar-driven society all you want, just don't
>continue to play the money-grabbing game by voting for higher taxes and
>more government.  This won't make anyone less greedy, quite the contrary,
>because there will be less wealth to go around, and it will be harder to
>get by.
>
>A word to the wise,
>                                *** Starchild ***

Boy, talk about laissez faire capitalism!  Fact is there are very few
choices in a so-called "free market".  In a capitalist system, especizally
our, the so-called choices are at the expense of someone somewhere, who had
to make something for us to consume because the alternative would've been
starvation.

Please get real, and don't try to oversimplify what is really going on
here:  a money/power grab by the very rich, which controls those who are
not part of that clique and the world as a whole suffers.  Note that you
said the standard of living increases.  I would suggest doing some
research.  Wherever our form of money creation (usually done thru the IMF),
we have created wider gaps between the poor and rich in said countries.  We
have also allowed dictatorships to flourish in said countries.  People
really have few choices in the countries that manufacture our goods, and
due to the fact labor is cheap many jobs are exported to said countries
putting OUR citizens out of work.

Just the facts sir, just the facts.

What does this have to do with parties/dance culture/raves?  I dunno, I
just thought I'd throw my considerable opinion in ;) (chuckles!).

Let's face it, if Sri Lanka were to throw $3 or even $1 raves, would you
go?  I think that's the real question here!

Much laughter and peace,
John

At 3:54 PM 11/10/95, Disssolve@aol.com wrote:
>after a two week vacation that flew by as if on mercury's ankle-wings, i'm
>back from the east coast. and i return with an astronomical heap of gratitude
>for the beautiful, cohesive rave-community we have here in the bay area. ten
>suns exploding  in the same spot at once couldn't be more intense than the
>joy i feel about the fact that i'm a part of several  thriving  communities
>of artists, spiritual seekers, all-night dancers, moon-howlers, sun-screamers
>and other freaks.
>
>it's about power, my lovelies. it's about getting clean, wholesome power, or
>should i say it's about sharing the stuff. going reductionist for a moment,
>the search for power is the primal activity of life. plants tan in the sun
>drink with their toes and that's all they need to do to get their power,
>which they impart to cows, vegetarians, and other herbivores. of course, we
>crave all kinds of power, just as we should. black beans and rice, with some
>chopped tomato, onion and cilantro, a drizzle of olive oil and some minced
>garlic and crushed black pepper and sea salt, as wholesome it might be,
>doesn't fill us completely. so we set off in search of other forms of power,
>often without thinking about what we're doing. i go to a party not really
>thinking about why i'm going, but once i'm there, and i'm dancing, and i'm
>being danced, and i'm suddenly surging with power power Power, and suddenly
>i'm so juiced that i'm leaking lightning out of my  ears. suddenly i realize
>why i'm here, what brought me here: the search for good, clean power.
>
>that's why i rant and rave. that's why i dance. that's why i struggle with my
>art: to express this power, the power of this power. i'm not talking about
>neitzsche's superman power. we don't have to rush into a phone booth to
>unleash this power.  i'm talking about the stuff the bubbles straight up from
>the center of the human heart.
>
>have i lost you?
>
>i'm lost myself. delightfully so. my point is this: it's great to be back. i
>missed throbbing with you, and i'm so glad that i live where i live that i
>could just, um, blow apart.
>
>surging,
>dSiHssAoLvOeM
>
>"too much sanity is insane. it is insane to accept things as they are and not
>as they should be."
>                                                       - cervantes


******************************************************************************

David Ginsberg
ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu
Student of Philosophy and Cognitive Science
University of California at Berkeley

is true) does not mean that the standard of living does not
increase. (I believe that the stnadard of living has increased.. for
-everyone-, on average.)
Given choices
A) Starvation
B) Exploitation

	I'd choose (B) any day. Granted, exploitation sucks, but it is
much better than starvation.


> have also allowed dictatorships to flourish in said countries.  People

	"We"? Speak for yourself john. I have never "allowed" a
dictatorship for flourish.

> really have few choices in the countries that manufacture our goods, and
> due to the fact labor is cheap many jobs are exported to said countries
> putting OUR citizens out of work.

in the US. Granted, it's selfish, but I live in the US, and I want the
people living near me to not be exploitied. If most of the
exploitation happens outside the US, then that's better than it
happening in the US.

>> not part of that clique and the world as a whole suffers.  Note that you
>> said the standard of living increases.  I would suggest doing some
>> research.  Wherever our form of money creation (usually done thru the IMF),
>> we have created wider gaps between the poor and rich in said countries.  We
>
>        Non sequiter. Just because the gap increases (which I beleive
>is true) does not mean that the standard of living does not
>increase. (I believe that the stnadard of living has increased.. for
>-everyone-, on average.)
>Given choices
>A) Starvation
>B) Exploitation
>
>        I'd choose (B) any day. Granted, exploitation sucks, but it is
>much better than starvation.

Pretty sad state humanity is at these days if these are the only two
choices.  Wouldn't you say? Fact is, when you create such a disparity there
will always be someone skimming off the top, usually doing the least.
Thats why at first you see great economic proseptiy followed by massive
shrinkages.  There is only one class that fluctuates in the positive during
this time, the very rich.  Everyone else is expanding (as in a rising
poverty level, like we have here), or a shrinking of the middle class (the
phenom of the 80's, lotsa folx made $$$, but plenty went belly up).

This is all econmoics mumbo jumbo.  I vote to take this non-rave related
stuff off the list.

please....

>
>
>> have also allowed dictatorships to flourish in said countries.  People
>
>        "We"? Speak for yourself john. I have never "allowed" a
>dictatorship for flourish.

If at any time between now and WWII you bought something, or caused taxes
to be generated by commerce, you gave the funding (taxes) to a
country/regime whatever that has funded dictatorships, funded death squads,
and other nicities.  Of course, if you've never done any business in the US
at all this wouldn't apply.

>
>> really have few choices in the countries that manufacture our goods, and
>> due to the fact labor is cheap many jobs are exported to said countries
>> putting OUR citizens out of work.
>
>        I'd rather have people outside the US be exploited than people
>in the US. Granted, it's selfish, but I live in the US, and I want the
>people living near me to not be exploitied. If most of the
>exploitation happens outside the US, then that's better than it
>happening in the US.
>

In other words "It's ok to have 20% of our children starving as long as we
can get cheap goods."  Exploiting anyone comes back to bite you in the ass
where it hurts, and its bite is directed at the people least capable of
defending themselves.  The alternative you failed to mention is creating
another paradigm, so that nobody suffers.  Fairness, equity, & respect.  We
shouldn't allow people to exploit others, especially for profit.

>>
>> Just the facts sir, just the facts.
>>
>> What does this have to do with parties/dance culture/raves?  I dunno, I
>> just thought I'd throw my considerable opinion in ;) (chuckles!).
>>
>> Let's face it, if Sri Lanka were to throw $3 or even $1 raves, would you

>
>        I have never heard of a national government throwing a rave. I
>think I might go just because of the novelty of the idea of a national
>governenemt throwing a rave.
>

And here, he just doesn't get the joke.

Reading is fundamental.

Hi everyone-
I am making an attempt to rid our list of that pesky  "privatization hard at
work" thread. It's not that I don't have anything else to say on the subject,
or that someone has shut me up with an irrefutable argument! I always have
plenty to say! :-)

This is after all, sfraves not sfspewingpoliticaldiscussions. If the people
who are interested in this discussion would care to e-mail me, (at
Msphink@aol.com, for now) I could compile a list of all us krazy
revolutionary types who would like to over throw the government (oops, just
kidding if the FBI is reading) and we could just argue amongst ourselves. I
hope I will meet all of you at a rave some day, I would like to give everyone
a *big* hug for encouraging me to think and to grow as a person. I am not
some "don't worry, be happy" kinda gal. And hey, you can still be a happy
little raver while kicking some knowledge around! 

For the record, I don't think that I or anyone else has been claiming
corporations are "evil" or the private sector is "bad." Just examining what
their role is in our lives and how we would change that, if indeed it is
possible.

Love you all, Ms. Phink

anybody know more about this??

|                        "STUMBLING TOWARD ECSTASY"
|
|        In the United States, a public park designed to make people
|trip might attract lawsuits, but Japan's Site of Reversible Destiny has
|attracted 50,000 visitors since it opened last month. Despite the fact
|that two people broke their legs in the first two days of operation,
|conceptual artise Shusaku Arakawa's park is popular with visitors and
|art critics alike. For the publicly funded $12M project, Arakawa and
|wife Madeline Gins designed a grassy crater the size of a baseball
|field studded with steep paths, hollows and mazelike houses to provide
|a certain artistic disorientation. "You can experience an environment
|with the ignorance and innocence of a newborn baby," explains a park
|official. For visitors who don't want to digress too far, rubber soles
|shoes are recomended, and helmets can be borrowed at the gate.

Hey everyone,

More deep shit, but I couldn't find the above newsgroup, so you'll have to
hear me out.  ;)

After reading the 13 moon stuff Ameba was handing out a while back, I
stumbled across a book by Jose Arguelles (the 13 moon guy) called "The Mayan
Factor - Path Beyond Technology". 

Lots of cool stuff on the Maya, but I've been particularly moved by the
following passage:

Pg. 54  

        "But resonance - what is it? Everybody talks about it -
electricians, physicists, musicians and healers. But what is resonance,
*really*? Resonance means the quality of sounding again. To resonate is to
reverberate. Reverberation implies give and take, the definition of
communication which is always simultaneous and between at last two agents.
Any communication implies an exchange of information. People talk about the
"information age", but what is information? From the perspective of resonant
harmonics, information is the form-vehicle of qualities of energy passing
between two agents or parties. As a sounding again, resonance *is* information."

        "The essence of information, then, is not its content, but its
resonance. This is why feeling or sensing things is so important. To sense
the resonance of incoming information co-creates a resonant field. If we try
to conceptualize experience before we have actually resonated with the
experience, the field is off or even broken. If the field is broken, it
means the Kuxan Suum (the galactic life threads or fibers which connect both
the individual and the planet, through the sun, to the galactic core) is
obscured at the solar plexus - in a word, we've stopped feeling things and
our own resonance has been damped!"

        "When people speak of resonance, they also speak of frequencies and
tones. Frequency refers to rate of vibration. As everybody knows, there are
higher and lower rates of vibration, while all vibration is pulsation of
waves. A frequency held for but a single wave cylce, otherwise known as a
beat, becomes a tone. A tone then, is any sustained frequency, whose level
determines which of our sense organs may be affected. In other words, touch
has its tones, perfume is a tome of the sense field 'smell'; even 'mind'
experiences its high frequency sensory tones."

        "Inclusive of all the sense-fields, harmony is the sychroinization
of two or more tones. The skill in sychronizing tones and synthesizing sense
fields is an art as much as it is a science. The practice of science yields
opportunites unthought of from a materialistic perspective, which, for
instance, leads one to think that flying is the air-borne passage of a
physical body between two points. But what is flying to the sense-fields of
the passenger in the airplane? The coarse, vibratory shudder of jet engines,
the odor of jet fuel, and a microwave meal. What if flying is, instead, a
capacity to identify conciousness with resonance and ride the frequencies of
different levels of reality?" 


Eh?

I had to read it a couple of times myself. Basially, the Maya were so keyed
in that they could astrally (sp?) project themselves to various realities,
even connecting with the resonance of the glactic core! 

If your on the same frequency with the galactic core, then...perpetual
balance and understanding? 

I've found that certain vibrations with our music (whatever genre you
prefer) can create resonances (or is it the other way around? I get
confused) that allow gateways to different realities. These realities help
gain perspective as to "our true nature".  

Combine the Mayan mind with Josh's vegan diet and you have.....

Blast off! Galactic Core or Bust!

Then again, I could just be crazy, but I'm finding more and more that crazy
is a nice place to be.

Don't know if Ameba still has 13 moon stuff, but I'm sure they can tell you
more if your interested.

later...

Jonas


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Nov 11 12:15:54 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA06039; Sat, 11 Nov 1995 12:15:54 -0800
Received: from netcom21.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA06029; Sat, 11 Nov 1995 12:15:43 -0800
Received: from localhost by netcom21.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id MAA21051; Sat, 11 Nov 1995 12:14:14 -0800
Message-Id: <199511112014.MAA21051@netcom21.netcom.com>
To: SCRUTON@joyce.dnet.hac.com,
        "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: yeah but on the other hand (re pesky ol' private sector)
Date: Sat, 11 Nov 95 12:14:10 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com:
>  i really don't think anyone on the list would be able to afford a 
>    computer (or their company/school/access provider couldn't) if
>     it weren't for a little bit o' greed and moneymaking desire
>      which lead to innovations and mass production
>
> just like modern-day gizmos ain't all good, they ain't all bad, niether

It's too bad that we can't get access to a Lisp Machine or an
Amiga/Toaster or a NeXT, or a Beta VCR (or in a few years, an SGI
workstation) because they've been competed out of the industry by other
companies. In other words, yeah, you may have this wonderful piece of
technology that you and everybody else can now use for cheap, but is
your Pentium box running Windows 95 that you were "forced" to buy going
to help you do your job better, when what you really wanted was a
macintosh? Freedom implies choice -- where are our choices?

Over and over again, we see a situation where the "winners" weren't
really technically better or anything, just better funded, more
popular, better advertised, or more politically expedient, or just
plain lucky ... We talk about competition being good because it winnows
out the weak and sickly ... There's too many instances where
competition has killed viable (or even potentially superior)
alternatives, giving the public little or no choice in the goods they
are to purchase. Some competition is good, but the kind of
monopoly-oriented competition we have nowadays ensures that the
consumer loses, the cottage industry loses, and that the powerful
survive regardless of whether they are the source of any "greater
good". You can talk social darwinism and survival of the fittest all
you want, but realize that what is happening isn't survival of the
fittest, just like when pollution causes algae to bloom abundantly in
the ocean (red tide) killing all the fish -- it doesn't mean that
"algae" is better than "fish" just that something primitive, stupid and
ubiquitous consumed all the resources that would allow the fish to
survive.

Typically "competition" is not a system of giving choice to the
consumer because the winning corporate game plan is to stifle any
competition before the consumer is allowed to make a choice in the
first place. To me this is just more dead fish, but some think this is
a way of life...

Every time I enter the hallowed halls of biz-ness, the prevailing
attitude is "it's not good enough that we succeed, but we must also
ensure everybody else's failure as well". When you hear the mantra-like
repetition of terms like "market domination", "thrust", "vertical
insertion" etc, it becomes pretty clear that the human need to commit
murder, rape, mayhem, and warfare has been sanitized behind gentler
non-warlike terms like profit, domination, mortgages, loans, mergers,
acquisitions, bankrupcy and foreclosures (usually in that order)...

So I wonder how people can talk about PLUR and all that crap and still
believe that the so called "free market", dominator system we have now
has anything to do with a PLUR-like outlook. Just because war, hate,
discord, and disrespect (the forces of anti-PLUR) have been civilized
behind a respectable facade of business and "competition" doesn't mean
that it's right...

--------------------

PS: Actually, the reason why we can afford computers today is through
nationally funded programs (aka socialism in a way) that allowed a few
folks to take the long view towards where we needed to go
technologically, taking on projects that "pure business" would have
declined due to lack of immediate return on investment. Although often
these programs are typically  combination of private and public sector
operations, they can be seen as "incubators" of new ideas that would
have been stillborn had they been forced to compete in a purely free
market.

You see, US business is too fixated on reaping guaranteed short-term
profits in the 6-12 month range and would never have invested money in
something as outlandish as research on integrated circuits fabrication
in the mid 60's... fact is you can indirectly thank the US GOVERNMENT 
(particularly ARPA and NASA) for helping put that Pentium box on your
desk, and that easy to use internet connection, and your web browser,
etc. Private industry joined in for the profits once they realized that
it was a safe and sure bet, because US industry is fundamentally
conservative and anti-innovation.

If you don't believe me. Take a look at what happens to the stock of  a
private corporation when it annouces that it is cutting back it's R&D
operations -- the stock goes up! ANd when a company annouces it is
starting up an R&D organization or beginning research in some new and
unproven field -- the stock goes down! The public wants it's investment
back in 6 months, not 5 years, and business plans and innovation is
shaped accordingly.

=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

formation while tripping, at least not without laughing. 
I read the book "LSD and the American Dream" which was really good, but I
forget who the author was.

Also, Paul Leary (butthole's guitar player) produced the two most recent
Meat Puppets albums, "too high to die" and "no joke", and plays some guitar
on the most recent (no joke).

Even more bizarre, (not that Paul producing them is bizarre), the current
Meat Puppets single "scum" was remixed by none other than Vapor Space.  I
heard some of it over the phone, so couldn't get a good listen.  Because the
pups are friends of mine, and because I've been egging them on for years
to do any kind of dance oriented music (they've been happy to comply off
the record, but nothing was ever released) and because before this nothing
has ever made it to vinyl (they're not exactly known as a dance floor act),
I would dearly love to get my hands on 2 12" singles of "scum" by
Meat Puppets/Vapor Space, so if any of you ever see it, would you be so
kind as to snatch up 2 copies?   I hereby swear that I'll buy them
from you immediately (well, I'm not easily extorted, but I'm assuming
none of you would be so unkind!).  I've looked around at a couple places,
without any luck, but I would really love to get a copy of that track
even if it sucks, although from what I heard on the phone, it was pretty
SF sounding house/etc., and sounded pretty decent.  Anyway, the comment
about the butthole surfers reminded me of yet another bizarre house
intersection...

Josh, I would like to take this moment to thank you, deeply, honestly and
from the bottom of my heart for discussing these issues.  I urge you to
resist those who attempt to silence you; no, it wouldn't be right to have
all discussion on the list center around politics, but to avoid it as was
suggested is cultural suicide.  Unfortunately, remaining uninvolved and
uninterested in these issues is exactly what has brought us to this sad
state we were discussing.  Only thinking and speaking about it will lead
us to a solution that will last for generations; I honestly believe without
fundamental change we have only a few generations left.  So if people aren't
interested, let them delete, but don't let them shut your mouth, you are
engaged in necessary, responsible and in the long run, rave-related
behavior; I don't want to attempt to blindly dance upon a burnt out cinder,
and although that's obviously a dramatic exaggeration (we hope), you
get my point!

"I want to get down, I want to party hearty,
 I want to get down, with the defunkt!"

-=J=-

I couldn't disagree more.  Politics is inherently related to raving and
ravers will suffer the consequences of being politically uninvolved.

Furthermore, I resent being asked to hide this discussion which would
prevent people who might want to get involved from having the chance.

What I would prefer would be to change the subject line so that those who
don't want to hear/read/etc. about these subjects can easily delete or
filter out these messages.  When you start trying to dictate what is
or isn't appropriate (yes, I've read the "sfraves manifesto" many times),
I believe you have overstepped your bounds as obviously enough people
were interested that the volume of messages on these subjects was fairly
high.

Precedence: bulk


> I couldn't disagree more.  Politics is inherently related to raving and
> ravers will suffer the consequences of being politically uninvolved.

I have heard the same tired argument from the Zippies. 

The one thing that is always been great about the scene is that it 
welcomed people from all different backgrounds, political spectrums, 
and lifestyles. There was no "agenda." This is all, sadly, changing. 
There is an accepted mindset forming. As this mutates, it drives away the 
people that were originally drawn to it because of the lack of 
requirements to be accepted.

So now "ravers" have a political agenda. So, what, we now vote a 
party line? Someone tells us what to vote for because it is the "ravey" 
thing to do? If I don't, am I out of the club?

> 
> Furthermore, I resent being asked to hide this discussion which would
> prevent people who might want to get involved from having the chance.

Look, there is no conspiracy to silence you. Hell, I wasn't even talking 
to you, so I don't know where you have anything to resent.

Sometimes I wonder why I put so much time into certain posts, like the 
one you are replying about. It's obvious that you payed little attention to 
it. If you had , you would have seen that I had asked that when people see 
that their posts are digressing from being related to the purpose of this 
mailing list, that they take it to private e-mail. I did not ask that no 
one ever post anything not directly rave-related. 

People want to get involved politically, that's cool. Try ba.politics. 
That is what it is there for. Throw your ideas up against a proportionate 
amount of people that are of differing opinions. Otherwise all you have 
is a big circle jerk, and your arguments crumble under serious oppostion.

> 
> What I would prefer would be to change the subject line so that those who
> don't want to hear/read/etc. about these subjects can easily delete or
> filter out these messages.  When you start trying to dictate what is
> or isn't appropriate (yes, I've read the "sfraves manifesto" many times),
> I believe you have overstepped your bounds as obviously enough people
> were interested that the volume of messages on these subjects was fairly
> high.

I am not trying to dictate anything. I am just asking that others follow 
the stated intent of this mailing list, as I try to. 

Failing all else, putting "not rave related" or something would at least 
be a gesture.

> "De de Funkt, yeah,
>  De de Funkt, yeah!"
> 
> -=jack=-
> 
> (This text composed by voice)
> 
> 
> 
> 
> > For a refresher, I have included a portion of the 
> > welcome messages everyone receives when subscribing:
> -------------
> oh please, how tired...

Yeah, imagine that, posting the stated intent of the mailing list. How 
tired of me. 

I'm tired. Tired of people that have probably been on the Internet for a 
week, and don't have clue one about ettiqute. They don't understand the 
concept of USENET, and the intended scope of mailing lists. See, there is 
thing called USENET, which is composed of thousands upon thousands of 
newsgroups. Oddly enough, the newsgroups are named after the subject to 
be discussed. Even more odd, people actually expect you to talk about 
things relevant to the subject of the newsgroup, as stated in the FAQ or 
the description of the newsgroup. People talking about unrelated subjects are 
considered RUDE. Extrapolate for mailing lists. 

In the final analysis, there are only two things that matter to me:

1) The people

2) The music

Fuck politics.... I just wanna dance...

                                            Black Adder

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Nov 11 22:31:46 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA16844; Sat, 11 Nov 1995 22:31:46 -0800
Received: from violet.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA16837; Sat, 11 Nov 1995 22:31:43 -0800
From: trose@violet.berkeley.edu
Received: by violet.berkeley.edu (8.7.1/1.33r)
	id WAA01617; Sat, 11 Nov 1995 22:05:53 -0800
Date: Sat, 11 Nov 1995 22:05:52 -0800 (PST)
Subject: emergent culture...?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9511112100.A29127-0100000@violet.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everybody,
	Boy arent these flame wars fun...I wish you guys could do it 
privately!
	phew, i just finished writing this, it turned out longer than I 
expected, and I still feel like I need to write a book to fully explore 
this idea...but at least these unfinished ideas can be seeds to explore 
further thought...enjoy!

	Anyway...you may remember my post about a month ago when I first 
introduced myself to everyone here. At the end I started rambling about 
my ideas on emergent culture and such, and one of the main problems I was 
experiencing were actually finding signs of this in our society. Because 
it is so easy to merge your perception of reality with your expectations 
of reality. The objective world to me is in serious question. At least in 
respect to ever being able to truly understand what is going on around 
you. But that is almost off to another topic altogether. 
	After my last post on this idea I took a few weeks toi think it 
over and my working conclusion has been that there is not enough evidence 
to really notice if something new is happening or if it is just the same 
ol sh*t in a different package. It is hard evidence that I am looking for 
here, not idealistic wishes and wants and dreams...this all is very 
related to the recent string on capitalism on this mailing list. it is 
true that many people are jilted and bitter about the society that we 
live in. And it is true that many people see the problems as well as the 
benefits and the progress that mankind has made in our history. But I 
feel that it is possible (once again I am looking for evidence) that we 
are reaching a critical junction in the evolution of humankind.
	As far as I can see from my bubble of reality I have these 
evidence of the positive global trends. The internet, global communication, 
expanding awareness.
	Expanding understanding worldwide of cultures.
	 In speaking with a friend he talked to me 
about platos maybe aristotles(I think) progression of the soul. The first 
step is the love of flesh, raw animal attraction, then comes love for the 
soul, and finally comes love for beauty itself in its pure form. I 
skipped a few steps as a result of my poor memory but...you get the idea. 

What my insight has been is to look at the evolution of how culture 
expresses itself as a result of the type of music we listen to as a 
popular culture. It is these songs I take to be signs of where we are 
at as a culture and as a way to communicate our feelings and relate to 
eachother on a large scale. Take a look at the progression of 
music in the last 50 years or so in the western culture at least.
	At first we had songs like "rock around the clock". These types 
of songs are very base and talk about very little that is of the human 
experience.  In terms of Platos progression, this level of the 
progression of the collective soul is very young. Unable to talk about or 
express anything deep or about what is going on inside of the soul.
	Over a little bit of time however, more and more songs evolved and the 
next stage I see evolving is the love song stage. This level I see as the 
first step to get into the collective soul. Those ideas that we can all 
relate to, that the song can be played at the supermarket or whatever and 
almost every person can relate. At the same time, this level is not very 
risky in the sense that to express love or these types of feelings is the 
least scary in terms of opening yourself to another human beeing.
	The sixties comes a time of rebellion and rebirth of ideas about 
how things are to be done. Bringing to mind another relevant analogy of 
growht to maturity of a human being.
	And now in popular culture we can see songs like green day 
talking about paranoia, I m a loser baby etc. What strikes me is that it 
is the first time that it is okay now to talk and sing and express to the 
world that you have faults, you are human. And to talk to the popular 
culture about the darker sides of being human.
	I see the rave culture as the last or pre last stage, at least an 
idea of what the last stage of growth and maturity may be like, if we 
make it there as a culture intact. My criticism of the rave culture as it 
stands is that so many people are using drugs to experience the love 
of beauty for itself ideology.
		What worries me is that my writing still seems to have 
this ideological coloring to it, fitting what I see to what I want to 
see. But, alas...as John Searle says "this doesnt mean you give up...get 
to work!" (ha ha hi dave!)

-Hierophant		

   "Searching for that elusive objective truth"

>> I couldn't disagree more.  Politics is inherently related to raving and
>> ravers will suffer the consequences of being politically uninvolved.
>
>I have heard the same tired argument from the Zippies.
>
>The one thing that is always been great about the scene is that it
>welcomed people from all different backgrounds, political spectrums,
>and lifestyles. There was no "agenda." This is all, sadly, changing.
>There is an accepted mindset forming. As this mutates, it drives away the
>people that were originally drawn to it because of the lack of
>requirements to be accepted.
>
>So now "ravers" have a political agenda. So, what, we now vote a
>party line? Someone tells us what to vote for because it is the "ravey"
>thing to do? If I don't, am I out of the club?
>

The real problem is with curfews, 18+ parties, permits for peacful
gatherings, police harassment, I could go on.  Due to teh LACK of political
involvment (something I said we needed years ago BTW), ravers are stuck
with the same venues, no/few 18+ venues, and consistent police harassment.
Sorry Blckadder, lack of political involvment , especially here is SF,
means certain detah.  SF means politics.  I see no reason why serious
political debate cannot be held on SFR's.  And if it drives theapolitical
away, one can only wonder WHY people moved to the most political city in
the world in the first place.

I do agree that after a while it tends to lose it's focus (witness the
privatization thread), but I think they still have relevancy to the group
IMO.

>>
>> Furthermore, I resent being asked to hide this discussion which would
>> prevent people who might want to get involved from having the chance.
>
>Look, there is no conspiracy to silence you. Hell, I wasn't even talking
>to you, so I don't know where you have anything to resent.

Nice PLUR huh?

>
>Sometimes I wonder why I put so much time into certain posts, like the
>one you are replying about. It's obvious that you payed little attention to
>it. If you had , you would have seen that I had asked that when people see
>that their posts are digressing from being related to the purpose of this
>mailing list, that they take it to private e-mail. I did not ask that no
>one ever post anything not directly rave-related.

The mailing lsit is about communication.  What I find disturbing is the
"Rave religion" nonesnese that makes this list such a bore.  If you're not
hyping SF, if you're not hyping PLUR, if you're not hyping parties, both
directly and specifically, then it is only a matter of time before someone
comes out of the woodwork to announce "Hey, isn't this off-topic, where are
the parties?, Where are the good vibes?".

Whatever, I think there's room for all interests.  Ifinite Diversity in
Infinite Combinations.  Yeah, all for 19.95 too!


>
>People want to get involved politically, that's cool. Try ba.politics.
>That is what it is there for. Throw your ideas up against a proportionate
>amount of people that are of differing opinions. Otherwise all you have
>is a big circle jerk, and your arguments crumble under serious oppostion.
>

Why not the list?  I guess if it ain't about rave religion, or rave
philosphy it out of place.  And yet we stil hear the calls of pople talking
about police harassment, parties getting shut down, people being
mistreated, etc.  In SF, you cannot sepearte politics from anything.
Sorry, just the way it is (Hell, when you have the most apolitical people
IMO , Bike MEssengers, send a message to the city each last friday of the
month by blcoking traffics with 5000 bikes, it just goes to show you how
apolitical anyone is in this city!).  I LOVE THIS PLACE!

>>

created that make that term nostalgic if anything IMO.

all in all this was an excellent thingie. There were lots of people, but 
lots of space for everyone.  A laser or two, some film loops and yes, the 
whistles!

musically it was all there for me.  fast slow funky spacey housey all 
over the place.  Anyone ever notice this phenomena:  DJ has the energy at 
a high level, people are goin' off, and then brings the level down a few 
notches to let people recoop.  But lots of times I'm not ready to come 
down.  Ever been there?  

Well last night it was exactly the opposite.  Level is high... people are 
digging in, and then it just continues... and continues... and WHEW this 
walrus has JUST GOT TO STOP lest I lose a lung!

> good". You can talk social darwinism and survival of the fittest all
> you want, but realize that what is happening isn't survival of the
> fittest, just like when pollution causes algae to bloom abundantly in
> the ocean (red tide) killing all the fish -- it doesn't mean that
> "algae" is better than "fish" just that something primitive, stupid and
> ubiquitous consumed all the resources that would allow the fish to
> survive.

	Just because algae isn't 'better' doesn't mean it isn't more
'fit'.  Survival of the fittest does seem to hold true, but fittest
does not mean 'best.' ms-windows does well not because it is good, but
all the factors which make it do well lead to the fact that is ends up
being the fittest, and thus does well.

	All your points make good sense, and I think my quarrel with
this point is mostly semantics.

	My question: why do you need to assign a label to yourself?
The only label I 'really' assign myself, is "sameer".  (I may at times
say 'i am an sfraver', or 'i am a cypherpunk', but that is merely an
abbreviation of the longer form 'i go to raves in sf and i'm subbed to
the e-list' or 'i do stuff to promote the use of cryptography to
protect privacy')

> 
>

> am better off alone with my thoughts. 
> 
> So I pose these questions to ALL OF YOU:
>

> What does "raving" mean to you, in your life?

On Sat, 11 Nov 1995 blkadder@value.net wrote:

> 
> > I couldn't disagree more.  Politics is inherently related to raving and
> > ravers will suffer the consequences of being politically uninvolved.
> 
> I have heard the same tired argument from the Zippies. 
> 
> The one thing that is always been great about the scene is that it 
> welcomed people from all different backgrounds, political spectrums, 
> and lifestyles. There was no "agenda." This is all, sadly, changing. 
> There is an accepted mindset forming. As this mutates, it drives away the 
> people that were originally drawn to it because of the lack of 
> requirements to be accepted.
> 
> So now "ravers" have a political agenda. So, what, we now vote a 
> party line? Someone tells us what to vote for because it is the "ravey" 
> thing to do? If I don't, am I out of the club?
> 
> > 
> > Furthermore, I resent being asked to hide this discussion which would
> > prevent people who might want to get involved from having the chance.
> 
> Look, there is no conspiracy to silence you. Hell, I wasn't even talking 
> to you, so I don't know where you have anything to resent.
> 
> Sometimes I wonder why I put so much time into certain posts, like the 
> one you are replying about. It's obvious that you payed little attention to 
> it. If you had , you would have seen that I had asked that when people see 
> that their posts are digressing from being related to the purpose of this 
> mailing list, that they take it to private e-mail. I did not ask that no 
> one ever post anything not directly rave-related. 
> 
> People want to get involved politically, that's cool. Try ba.politics. 
> That is what it is there for. Throw your ideas up against a proportionate 
> amount of people that are of differing opinions. Otherwise all you have 
> is a big circle jerk, and your arguments crumble under serious oppostion.
> 
> > 
> > What I would prefer would be to change the subject line so that those who
> > don't want to hear/read/etc. about these subjects can easily delete or
> > filter out these messages.  When you start trying to dictate what is
> > or isn't appropriate (yes, I've read the "sfraves manifesto" many times),
> > I believe you have overstepped your bounds as obviously enough people
> > were interested that the volume of messages on these subjects was fairly
> > high.

> I am not trying to dictate anything. I am just asking that others follow 
> the stated intent of this mailing list, as I try to.

> be a gesture.

> I'm tired. Tired of people that have probably been on the Internet for a 
> week, and don't have clue one about ettiqute. They don't understand the 
> concept of USENET, and the intended scope of mailing lists. See, there is 
> thing called USENET, which is composed of thousands upon thousands of 
> newsgroups. Oddly enough, the newsgroups are named after the subject to 
> be discussed. Even more odd, people actually expect you to talk about 
> things relevant to the subject of the newsgroup, as stated in the FAQ or 
> the description of the newsgroup. People talking about unrelated subjects are 
> considered RUDE. Extrapolate for mailing lists. 
>

> 2) The music

On Sat, 11 Nov 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com:
> >  i really don't think anyone on the list would be able to afford a 
> >    computer (or their company/school/access provider couldn't) if
> >     it weren't for a little bit o' greed and moneymaking desire
> >      which lead to innovations and mass production
> >
> > just like modern-day gizmos ain't all good, they ain't all bad, niether
> 
> It's too bad that we can't get access to a Lisp Machine or an
> Amiga/Toaster or a NeXT, or a Beta VCR (or in a few years, an SGI
> workstation) because they've been competed out of the industry by other
> companies. In other words, yeah, you may have this wonderful piece of
> technology that you and everybody else can now use for cheap, but is
> your Pentium box running Windows 95 that you were "forced" to buy going
> to help you do your job better, when what you really wanted was a
> macintosh? Freedom implies choice -- where are our choices?
> 
> Over and over again, we see a situation where the "winners" weren't
> really technically better or anything, just better funded, more
> popular, better advertised, or more politically expedient, or just
> plain lucky ... We talk about competition being good because it winnows
> out the weak and sickly ... There's too many instances where
> competition has killed viable (or even potentially superior)
> alternatives, giving the public little or no choice in the goods they
> are to purchase. Some competition is good, but the kind of
> monopoly-oriented competition we have nowadays ensures that the
> consumer loses, the cottage industry loses, and that the powerful
> survive regardless of whether they are the source of any "greater
> good". You can talk social darwinism and survival of the fittest all
> you want, but realize that what is happening isn't survival of the
> fittest, just like when pollution causes algae to bloom abundantly in
> the ocean (red tide) killing all the fish -- it doesn't mean that
> "algae" is better than "fish" just that something primitive, stupid and
> ubiquitous consumed all the resources that would allow the fish to
> survive.
> 
> Typically "competition" is not a system of giving choice to the
> consumer because the winning corporate game plan is to stifle any
> competition before the consumer is allowed to make a choice in the
> first place. To me this is just more dead fish, but some think this is
> a way of life...
> 
> Every time I enter the hallowed halls of biz-ness, the prevailing
> attitude is "it's not good enough that we succeed, but we must also
> ensure everybody else's failure as well". When you hear the mantra-like
> repetition of terms like "market domination", "thrust", "vertical
> insertion" etc, it becomes pretty clear that the human need to commit
> murder, rape, mayhem, and warfare has been sanitized behind gentler
> non-warlike terms like profit, domination, mortgages, loans, mergers,
> acquisitions, bankrupcy and foreclosures (usually in that order)...
> 
> So I wonder how people can talk about PLUR and all that crap and still
> believe that the so called "free market", dominator system we have now
> has anything to do with a PLUR-like outlook. Just because war, hate,
> discord, and disrespect (the forces of anti-PLUR) have been civilized
> behind a respectable facade of business and "competition" doesn't mean
> that it's right...
> 
> --------------------
> 
> PS: Actually, the reason why we can afford computers today is through
> nationally funded programs (aka socialism in a way) that allowed a few
> folks to take the long view towards where we needed to go
> technologically, taking on projects that "pure business" would have
> declined due to lack of immediate return on investment. Although often
> these programs are typically  combination of private and public sector
> operations, they can be seen as "incubators" of new ideas that would
> have been stillborn had they been forced to compete in a purely free
> market.
> 
> You see, US business is too fixated on reaping guaranteed short-term
> profits in the 6-12 month range and would never have invested money in
> something as outlandish as research on integrated circuits fabrication
> in the mid 60's... fact is you can indirectly thank the US GOVERNMENT 
> (particularly ARPA and NASA) for helping put that Pentium box on your
> desk, and that easy to use internet connection, and your web browser,
> etc. Private industry joined in for the profits once they realized that
> it was a safe and sure bet, because US industry is fundamentally
> conservative and anti-innovation.
> 
> If you don't believe me. Take a look at what happens to the stock of  a
> private corporation when it annouces that it is cutting back it's R&D
> operations -- the stock goes up! ANd when a company annouces it is
> starting up an R&D organization or beginning research in some new and
> unproven field -- the stock goes down! The public wants it's investment
> back in 6 months, not 5 years, and business plans and innovation is
> shaped accordingly.
> 
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
> =  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>

On Sun, 12 Nov 1995, John S. Lee wrote:

> >> I couldn't disagree more.  Politics is inherently related to raving and
> >> ravers will suffer the consequences of being politically uninvolved.
> >
> >I have heard the same tired argument from the Zippies.
> >
> >The one thing that is always been great about the scene is that it
> >welcomed people from all different backgrounds, political spectrums,
> >and lifestyles. There was no "agenda." This is all, sadly, changing.
> >There is an accepted mindset forming. As this mutates, it drives away the
> >people that were originally drawn to it because of the lack of
> >requirements to be accepted.
> >
> >So now "ravers" have a political agenda. So, what, we now vote a
> >party line? Someone tells us what to vote for because it is the "ravey"
> >thing to do? If I don't, am I out of the club?
> >
> 
> The real problem is with curfews, 18+ parties, permits for peacful
> gatherings, police harassment, I could go on.  Due to teh LACK of political
> involvment (something I said we needed years ago BTW), ravers are stuck
> with the same venues, no/few 18+ venues, and consistent police harassment.
> Sorry Blckadder, lack of political involvment , especially here is SF,
> means certain detah.  SF means politics.  I see no reason why serious
> political debate cannot be held on SFR's.  And if it drives theapolitical
> away, one can only wonder WHY people moved to the most political city in
> the world in the first place.
> 
> I do agree that after a while it tends to lose it's focus (witness the
> privatization thread), but I think they still have relevancy to the group
> IMO.

I realized that I made a very important omission in my comments about 
politics not belonging here. There points you raise above are most valid. 
They affect our ability to do what we do(dance) and do have a place being 
discussed IMO. What I was referring to was the privatization thread, which 
started out being related, and digressed further and further away from 
anything relevant. I apologize for not giving the context in which I was 
referring to political discussions.

> >>

Agreed, conditionally. I don't think that you have to be hyping all of

John S. Lee:
> Whatever, I think there's room for all interests.  Ifinite Diversity in
> Infinite Combinations.  

When this subject came up a couple of years ago, it inspired me to write
something that I then decided not to post.  Here it is, only slightly 
modified.  :) for the humor-impaired.  - Lee

------

You're on the dance floor at a party called Infinite Diversity.  The 
person in front of you is very drunk and keeps banging into you.  You step 
back and someone grabs your shoulder and shakes it, his jaw twitching
uncontrollably as he shouts "Hey man, d'ya know where I can score some
crystal?"  You are about to answer him but the person behind you starts to
blare a whistle into your ear. You try to move away but the shirtless drunk 
turns with his arms raised and thrusts a sopping hairy armpit into your face.
face.  "WOO!  WOO!" he screams while jumping up and down.  You look over to 
one of the projection screens to see the image of a flower fade into that 
of a human vivisection.  "Cool, man." say a bunch of sullen cyberpunks all
dressed in black.  They go back to talking among themselves and you decide
that maybe you should just focus on dancing.  But then the music abruptly 
changes from techno to slow reggae and someone blows smoke in your face.
A few feet away a little kid is pounding out a loud percussion solo on a
drum kit, completely out of time with the music.  You move closer to have
a look but there are a lot of people standing around a group of circle
dancers so you can't get through.  The music changes again, this time to
some kind of thrash metal song  and a mosh pit starts to form.  A 
firecracker goes off by your head, and a boot comes crushing down on your
sneakered foot.  Before you can say "ouch" a skinhead screams "Out of the
way, faggot!"  None of this bothers you.  As an openminded raver, you are 
very happy to be in the middle of such diversity.

- leg of eel

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Sun, 12 Nov 1995 16:45:38 -0800

From: ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu (David Ginsberg)
Subject: Re: emergent culture...?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm afraid this is hopelessly long too, but here are some thoughts...

As I see it, the search for objective truth is what the dominant paradigm
is all about and has been for 400 years.  It's this way of being in the
world which has lead to the problems with exploitation talked about in that
downer 'privatization' thread.  I'd like to suggest that the emerging
culture, as I find it in raves and the internet (two aspects of the
emerging culture with which I am familiar), embodies a recognition that
such a search is mere folly, that what we really have is an indefinite
number of perspectives on the world and that the primary grounding for any
of them is to be found in the experiences of those who hold them and the
communities they form.

I believe the closest we can come to 'objective truth' is some sort of
intersubjective agreement, perhaps bolstered by apparent convergence from
various ways of knowing, such as religion, the sciences and other forms of
culture.  There are those (i.e. Franscisco Varela, Fritzof Capra, and the
Dalai Lama) who see convergence between paradigms in Western science and
Eastern contemplative traditions.  I don't know if they're right, but if
they are this indicates that through either meditation or scientific
exploration we arrive at the same 'truths' which is interesting at the very
least.  (I use truth here in a subjective, or at best intersubjective sense
of the word.)

Perhaps there are a number of emerging cultures, it seems to me to be this
way.  I find the rave culture growing and finding its voice, but even
within this culture there are differences and not everyone is in it for
peace, love & joy.  There are plenty of parties thrown by people who simply
want to make money like any other promoter.  Perhaps then (to use
simplifying but I think appropriate imagery) our culture is fragmenting,
and what the emerging 'culture' is resembles a fractal, with ever-changing,
ever more complex structure which moves us farther and farther away from a
single, unified objective truth yet closer and closer to our own diverse,
personal truths.  Which is not to say that there is nothing which connects
us, for as each of us finds our own path and truly lives life fully and
openly we all share the experience of human being, from childhood to old
age, and these experiences bind us together.

Maybe, if these speculations are close to correct, the variety of choices
will empower each of us to select a way of being in the world which is
fullfilling to us.  And as more and more people choose to be part of
sub-cultures which are nurturing and fullfillling (or at least I hope this
is how it turns out), these sub-cultures will grow and flourish.

I think we each have the power to change the dominant culture by the way we
engage others.  If we refuse to be part of the exploitation and continue to
send each other 'virtual flowers' and share sunsets and smiles with
like-minded souls, then as we make our way through the rest of our days we
can share our smiles and sunshine with others we encounter, brightening
their days and maybe even causing chain reactions.  Its like the butterfly
flapping its wings in Tokyo and causing it to rain in New York, and the
power we have to effect changes like this puts an immense responsibility on
each of us to be in the right frame of mind and to always treat others with
respect, compassion and joy.  It isn't always easy (at least for me),
especially when the person you're dealing with shows a complete lack of
respect etc., but it helps me just knowing that there are others struggling
along with me, and that our numbers are growing...

Namaste

David

"When I die, I want to go peacefully in my sleep like my grandfather, not
screaming in terror like the passengers in his car"

Received: (from krok@localhost) by uclink2.berkeley.edu (8.6.12/8.6.12) id RAA13285; Sun, 12 Nov 1995 17:49:42 -0800

From: Kyung Rok Lee <krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu>

Subject: Re: What is Raving?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9511121715.B24427-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


>Given the current climate here, I am at a crossroads. I am trying to decide
>if I even wish to consider myself a "raver," whatever that means, or if I
>am better off alone with my thoughts.
>
>So I pose these questions to ALL OF YOU:
>
>What is the definiton of a "raver?"

On Sun, 12 Nov 1995, John S. Lee wrote:

> P.S.  I still despise the term raver, it's like calling someone a Negro
> (for black), or Indian (for Native American).  To me it's a term that has
> outlived its usefulness. New paradigms must be created, and have been
> created that make that term nostalgic if anything IMO.

actually, i think a different analogy is in order.  imo, the label "raver" 
is more analagous to "mod", "goth", "punk", or all the other musically 
defined identities which i associate with a certain time in life, namely 
jr. high and high school.  this is when folks seek a unified "identity", 
and are compelled to latch on to either a musical scene or a particular group.  
this isn't inherently bad, but it denies a lot of our partial identities,
as well as makes us less tolerant of others with whom we may share these 
partial and unfixed identities.  this sort of identification is useful, 
perhaps for some even necessary at the time, but this should be thought of as 
a stage in our process of maturing and learning to get along.  racial/ethnic 
labels (eg. "negro", "oriental", etc) are of a different nature because they 
involve a process of naming w/in a context of differential and "unjust" power 
relations, wherein the party in power is privaleged with the power to 
name (maim, claim, etc.).  look, we as contemporary human beings are a lot of 
things.  those of us, for example, who have trouble learning should not be 
labeled "a retard" because human beings are much more than their intelligence.
this "retard" (btw, fuck damon wayans for for doing "handi-man") may be a 
kind person, a lover of...etc.  let us not limit people by minimizing 
and objectifying them.  truth is relational, so the answer to the question 
"am i a raver?" will be contingent upon who's doing the asking, and how they 
are doing it, and whether you even call these events "raves".  personally, i 
feel that i have to describe these parties as "rave-like" to get the point 
across to certain individuals who might think i like dancing drunk and 
chanting "whoomp there it is!" if i simply tell them i like to go out and 
dance.  on the other hand, simply saying "rave-like" will bring a lot of 
unnecessary knee-jerk associations.  don't rely on soundbytes.  take the 
time.    

-rok

ps. "i _participate_ in the underground dance culture".

Subject: what's a raver?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9511121957.A29012-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk



	Black Adder posed the question, 'what's your definition of 
	a raver?' earlier, and I think I might have found a clue as
	to what the answer is.  The word raver is a noun derived
	from a verb, which means the definition will come from that
	verb--so a raver is "one who raves."  Painfully simple--
	maybe too simple--but I think there's a lesson tucked
	underneath the grammar.  If you go to raves, then you *are*
        a raver. You can't escape this, you can't really deny it,
	so rather than trying to shed the label, embrace it!
	So wear it on your lapel with as many other labels as you
	can fit--be a raver, a student, a writer, a friend, a teacher,
	a mystic, a hacker, an artist, a runner, and as many other
	things as you can--be everything! 
	   
	[at this point Timothy has a semi-psychic moment as he runs to
	 his cd collection, rifles through the albums excitedly,
         and hopes he can find the perfect quote which has just jumped
	 to the front of his memory...yessss! and here it is: ]

	"Come on you raver, you seer of visions, come on you painter,
	 you piper, you prisoner, and shine!"    
						-Pink Floyd's R. Waters

	See all you guys at Gateway next week,
	Timothy

____________________________________________________________________	
sidewalk@uclink2
UC Berkeley
P.S. immediately go out and buy the new Passengers album, called 
"Original Soundtracks 1". The Passengers are Brian Eno and U2, and
it's a full hour of smile-inducing ambient and dance music, mostly
instrumental and most excellent. Bye.

>as for teh others, i see massive change, but as you say our want to see 
>something may color our view, i wont go into it.
>smiles:) tom

This is what I've come up with, though.  The world is a very subjective
place, and sometimes (in fact, I'd say most times), what you want to see
affects your actions, which does bring about positive change.  I mean, what
is the truth of any situation?  What you see probably won't be exactly what
I see.  To be more concrete, think about a situation in your life where the
result of your positive thought on it affected the situation positively.
Isn't this a "colored view" of the situation?  Sure, but it helps good
things to happen.  

Rambling in the face of a 10-page research paper :(,
Jake
