        Lunar0242@aol.com
Subject: Re: What is Raving?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is in response to BlackAdders' question,:

"What is a raver?"

>From my standpoint:

The word "Raver" is indeed a label.  And as much as everyone dislikes labels
they will alwys continue.  If the term Raver were to disappear and say a new
term (example: Ranter, PLURbody or something) were to surface then yes, the
term raver falls in the category of "black" for afro american, "indian" for
native american et al... It becomes slang, and slang is always outdated and
updated.

However, Raver (to me) is also a stamp of a subcultural (and possibly
counter-cultural) facet of our society. And to accept the Label of raver is
to accept positive and negative connotations to it.  Ravers can be called
ones who "are members and particapents of dancing @ underground parties". But
it is also known that raver may (or may not) partake of illegal substances as
well as get into general mischief (ie. trespassing, loitering, noise
pollution ect.).  Ravers are also known to be very sincere & outgoing to
other ravers. This is the concept of PLUR. To the outsider of this subculture
this concept could be percieved like the "free love" antics not unlike the
hippie communes of the sixties. 
Another good point someone stated to me is that ravers "feel" the music not
just listen to it. Catching the vibe and communing with the music to gain
higher states of being...

As I stated in my letter to KLAX that our society, in it's competitiveness
(sp?) cannot understand these concepts.  And what society dosen't understand,
it condems.  So "Raver" is a negative term.  Not many people like to be
associated with negativity so we call raves: events, gatherings, massives
ect...

Yet, our generation witnessed the gay pride revoution and the term gay has
come into acceptance by a portion of the society at large. There are still
negative terms and lables homosexuals which I believe we all know (so I need
not list them here) and gay was one of them.  The homosexual community has
changed the term gay so it is accepted in public.

I hope the same rings true to the term Raver.  I am a raver.  I accept the
poitive and negative connotations to it as well.  I tell people that I rave,
and introduce people to the scene by my ways.  Granted I get ome really weird
reactions from my assertions of my lifestyle, from suprise to disgust:

"you rave?  Wow I thought that went out like in 92 or something"

I am proud of who I am and what I stand for...


(And I like dancing like a frenzied mongoose too)

Spins,
Adam

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Nov 12 20:45:23 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA22349; Sun, 12 Nov 1995 20:45:23 -0800

	id AA26623; Sun, 12 Nov 95 20:44:45 -0800
Date: Sun, 12 Nov 95 20:44:45 -0800
From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
Message-Id: <9511130444.AA26623@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: "ravers" and Vision
Cc: swoosh@cats.UCSC.EDU
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I guess I have several things to say;

Firstly, I appreciate Lee's story... It is a beautiful example
of what I consider to be a "raver."  Although the term raver is very
much like one of those classifications we latch onto to feel a part of
something, like mods, punks, whatever...  for me personally the term
meant something entirely unbounded, unlike what these other group
names meant to me when I was learning the names of things.  I saw
being a raver meaning an eternal search for freedom, finding the will
to be free of all the diversity which so often threatens our ego,
realizing that it is through this same threatening diversity that
we find our life and all the beauty that surrounds us.  I think that
this is an idea that I cannot outgrow, lest I give up on the concept itself.
People will always enter your life and not understand your words, but
when you find the strength to keep using your words and say them back
to these people with a smile, you begin to really fully understand their
and your meaning.  

Two years ago or so I remember a big switch from calling the dance underground
raves to calling them parties.  Raves have all the stigmatism and 
misunderstood meanings, I was told.  I remember being given a flyer
that said in big bold letters, "I am a raver and proud."  That's when
I decided that people will call these things whatever the hell they want,
I will call them raves.  I will call myself a raver and realize that
the meaning behind these words is chaos and change itself.
In the end, I'm the only one who really has to understand.
In a like manner, when I started to really listen to funky music
and realized it's power it was called house music.  One day, I started
hearing people talk about techno music, and I thought, that's funny,
it's just house music.  I realize there are certain differences, but
again, for me personally, all those differences lie in a spectrum
of house music... that's what I first heard, and that word is the word
I choose for this music's meaning.

and of course, this all relates to the Vision, and the need to have
undeterring faith in your vision.  These words are part of my vision,
and I will not change them or my vision will crumble.  Truth requires
a solid meaning and a neverending patience...  and it cannot help but
to come.  
Vision was a great party.  Just as it was 3 years ago when I was
in a airplane hangar with 5000 people, dancing like hell, realizing
what the word raver meant at another Vision, way back when.  
neverending patience... and I will continue to dance at Visions until
my bones break and I realize that my dancing had little to do with those
weary bones in the first place.

Which brings me to the last subject, the year 2012.
History will end when we realize that through the strength of our will
and vision we create reality.  Nonlinear time is just a state of mind
where meaning can see through fear itself, and true freedom is obtained.
"He's stark raving mad, I tell you."  Well, in your eyes.  In his eyes,
he is free.  and that freedom is the road to nonlinearity.  And for those
unconstrained modes of consciousness, the worlds and times of infinite
diversity are the playground of will, the heaven for the unified soul.
This is the form I seek with my definition of being a raver.
I am a raver and proud.
I am alive and free.

-john.

http://www.he.net/~swoosh

hola!  while we're on the subject of politics and parties...

SFPD Chief Ribera is scheduled to be announcing the names of the officers 
who will be disciplined for actions in the New Years Eve Raid this 
Wednesday at the Police Commission meeting.  so far, he's been quite 
evasive...he quoted to the press in sept. that he'd be sending 6 officers 
to the commission based on the OCC (office of citizens complaints) 
report; now he "doesn't know how many yet"/won't tell.  in addition, it 
has been, oh, ab out 11 MONTHS since the raid and the SFPDand Police 
Commision have yet to take action....

so... ACtion for Police Accountability is encouraging anyone who can to 
be at this weds' Police Comm. meeting at 850 Bryant, 4th Floor (or is it 
5th?), 5:30 on.  it ain't gonna be exciting, but it'll be a chance to (a) 
make public comments, (b) watch pseudo democracy in action! and (c) put 
pressure on the Commission by our very presence and interest.

ALSO, we (APA, people from the New Years Eve Raid, anyone else whose 
interested) are going to be organizing a demonstration/hopefully a boom 
box party(!) for Wednesday, Nov. 29, around 4:30 or 5:00 (more info 
later) outside the Southern Police Station (850 Bryant).  i'd like this 
to be a "party on the steps of the police station cuz they're crackin' 
down everywhere else" kind of thang, demanding that the officers in the 
raid be punished, etc.  the meeting to organize the demo will be monday, 
nov. 20 at 50 Fell Street, Room 110,f rom 7-9pm.  

i am looking into borrowing a radio transmitter so we can have some 
musick there, but if anyone has one please let me know.  (i thought about 
a sound system (!) but the steps of the cop shop seems a little too risky 
(sigh - maybe another time.)

please let me know if you're interested but can't make the meeting.  
will post more info when i have it.  

take care,
monicat

p.s. if you want any more info about the new years raid or anything, 
please email me.

From: tic-tac@psychoactive.com (Joe Rice)
Subject: Vision
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

When Martin was taking a straw poll as to the wisdom of doing Vision at the
Sound Factory I told him it wouldn't work - too many Sound Factory regulars
would gum up the vibe.

Fortunately I was wrong.

More people there than I've ever seen at the Sound Factory and the asshole
quotient, while not as low as at most undegrounds, wasn't bad at all.

I got there while Ethan was rocking large in the back room - more than one
person commented on the F&F type vibe in there as opposed to the clubbier
vibe in the main room. Dutch followed Ethan and was a bit aggressive for
me, so I checked out Tony in the main room. He blew away many of my friends
- I thought he was good, but not as spectacular as I've heard him before.
Josh followed in the main room with some serious SF style house and Garth
followed him, switching from the other room to fill in for an absent Paul
Johnson, who missed his flight.

Returning to the back room (via an interlude in the coat check area; _the_
place to chill and hang out at the SF), I found Galen about to go on, and
spent the next three hours (time I'd planned to spend napping) grooving to
the best set I've heard from him since some of the '94 Sunsets. Seriously
chunky acid house.

I heard Jeno ripped it up in the main room - he's rumored to have even
dropped a breakbeat. He did not, however, smile. Jon Howard finished up the
party (which still had a least 400 people at 7am) and was playing some nice
house when I left.

Overall a great party - a true rave.

Joe

P.S.  I still despise the term raver, it's like calling someone a Negro
(for black), or Indian (for Native American).  To me it's a term that has
outlived its usefulness. New paradigms must be created, and have been
created that make that term nostalgic if anything IMO.

From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Re: Vision
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I planned to go to Vision, but I had a few problems with it:

First, the *rediculous* price ($20) was not on any flyer and even the night
of the party was not on the info line. You had to go to the map point on
Townsend or to the Sound Factory to find out how much the night's fleecing
would be. Of course, if you're afraid to put the party cost on your info
line, you're probably already aware that you're screwing your party goers.

Also, the simple notion that it was at the Sound Factory had me doubting. I
don't really go there if possible to avoid the crowd that calls that place
home.

Once there, the security guard gautlet at the side entrance to the Sound
Factory was an instant vibe-killer.

And at the box office, the fact that a group of 5 of us showed up at 2:45am
and they insisted that we all pay $20 each was, in my opinion, not in the
'spirit' of and party I could have fun at.

   The message was clear: The number one interest of this promoter
                          was getting our cash. Thanks, Rodger.

So, we went with the rule that any party that costs $20, even at 3am is
most likely not worth it. Not even the rock stars at Wicked charge more
than $15 for their parties, and that's about the high end of what many will
pay for a bunch of home town SF DJ's who tend to play the same old sets
over and over.

No offense to Ethan or Galen (who area some of my favorites and was the
reason I wanted to go), but most of the other DJ's billed are, at this
point, in my opinion, way too overexposed here in SF. For instance, I have
to actually go out of my way to find a party that *doesn't* have Garth,
Jeno, or Tony playing.

Please fly in some talent from somewhere else if you expect to earn the $20
you want for a party or price your party more in line with what you are
selling.

John:
>Firstly, I appreciate Lee's story... It is a beautiful example
>of what I consider to be a "raver."

Perhaps so, but part of what I was trying to show was how absurd it can
be to actually *be* the manifestation of such an ideal.  As long as we
exist in this reality (the shared one defined by our current physical
state) ideals such as total acceptance, PLUR, absolute freedom, etc.
will be concepts that we can strive towards, but never fully realize.

>and of course, this all relates to the Vision, and the need to have
>undeterring faith in your vision.

Why not have multiple visions?  Visions of the perfect party, an
ideal government, spiritual bliss, amazing sex, most powerful weapon,
stupidest joke... 

>These words are part of my vision,
>and I will not change them or my vision will crumble.

Why can't a vision change or grow?  Isn't it rather idealistic to
believe that we can come up with a set of perfect ideals to believe in?

>Truth requires
>a solid meaning and a neverending patience...

There are many who would say that truth is relative and non-absolute.
But even *that* cannot be absolutely true!  

I have found that embracing "Truth" requires the acceptance of
neverending doubt and uncertainty...I think :)

>Which brings me to the last subject, the year 2012.

I have to say that it kinda bums me out that history is predicted
to end after this year, since 2012 is the year I become eligible for
retirement with full pension from this fucking job!

>"He's stark raving mad, I tell you."  Well, in your eyes.  In his eyes,
>he is free.  and that freedom is the road to nonlinearity.  And for those
>unconstrained modes of consciousness, the worlds and times of infinite
>diversity are the playground of will, the heaven for the unified soul.

I think there are times when we can transcend the limits of our
current reality and come very close to experiencing our ideals.  
It sometimes happens when I trance out on the dance floor. 

> This is the form I seek with my definition of being a raver.

Me, too.  At times.  But I don't expect it to be an integral part of
everyone else's world.  But perhaps our visions exist as extensions
of the reality we all share, even if unseen or unaccepted by those
who claim to "disagree".

Lee

of a multitude of 
	FLORA and FAUNA
and a balanced eco-{logical,nomic} system rather than 
	FLOATIN' and BLOATIN'  
carcases of dead animals and memes
	DECOMPOSIN' in a sea of SLIME!

That's the point -- it's green and it floats in space quite spectacularly!

thursday@uclink.berkeley.edu (Thursday):
> 12 days later, but typing fast...  Sorry to further prolong this thread,

> a little of yourself with me 8)  However, in re to Niels post, I'll try and
> post quickie reviews.  But I'm glad we all got the chance to tell of our
> Sinatra softspot ;)  Peace


Ok, fine.. I recently purchased Dr. John's "Afterglow" because I just
like the new orleans acoustic piano stylee, jazz, and Dr. John. The
combination of modern recording techniques, production by Tommy LiPuma
(Miles Davis, Natalie Cole, Streisand ...) big-band arrangements, and
modern remakes of "late golden age jazz", meant a fine treat for these
ears that still likes the sound and expressiveness of real analogue
instruments -- drums, horns, acounstic piano, etc played through a good
natural-sounding soundsystem. 

Overall, a nice selection of "tradititional" and original numbers with
a modern twist of taste; an "homage" to tunes performed by BB King,
Charles Brown, Nat King Cole, Louis Jordan, Duke Ellington...

NP: (again!) The new Planet Dog "Quadruped V.1" compilation with
selections by "Optic Eye", "Zuvuya", "Active Loop Zone", "Children of
the Bong".

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 13 11:43:19 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA05379; Mon, 13 Nov 1995 11:43:19 -0800
Received: from emout06.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA05373; Mon, 13 Nov 1995 11:43:16 -0800
From: MsPhink@aol.com
Received: by emout06.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id OAA28793 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 13 Nov 1995 14:42:46 -0500
Date: Mon, 13 Nov 1995 14:42:46 -0500
Message-ID: <951113144245_21142545@emout06.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: C'mon people, love one another!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi everyone!
This is a message of positive energy & love!
I am posting this message not in response to any one person, but in response
to the general welfare of sfraves.

Some of us have been asking ourselves "What is a raver?" I guess I would call
myself a raver; even though it is a label it serves a purpose, which is to
unite us all under the flag of RAVE. 

I would like to think that there is something out there which we have all
felt at a rave. It's not just the dancing or the music in themselves
(although these are very important elements!) What I am talking about is the
feeling of being interconnected with everyone in the room, the feeling of a
really good vibe, the feeling of love that you have at a really good party. I
would like to suggest that we try to carry over these feelings into the rest
of our lives, and especially onto this list! 

I have noticed what seems to be true of many "ravers" is that we tend to be
more tolerant of other people, since many of us have had experiences of true
love with the whole universe. This brings me to my thoughts of the political
discussions of sfraves. 

Obviously, there are some of us who would like to discuss politics, and some
who do not. Some people would like to discuss other things than just parties
and drugs. I have a suggestion for those of you who do not. You may have
noticed when you get an e-mail, there is a SUBJECT attatched to it, which
hopefully explains a little of what the e-mail is about. If it seems to be a
political message, you could always delete the damn thing instead of reading
it. You may be thinking to yourself, "Why should I put up with these type of
discussions on sfraves?" The answer to that is: Because you are a raver, you
WILL be tolerant of your fellow ravers. And if you can't do that, I suggest
you find another place where you truly belong. 

Really people, there is no need for name-calling. Telling other people that
they are *rude* or their messages are *boring* or that they don't belong on
sfraves, really serves no purpose than to divide us. I would like to think
that we could all get together at a party and actually have fun, instead of
someone thinking, "Oh, there's that asshole who posted the message I didn't
like....."

You may be thinking the answer to this dilemma is that we will never post
another message of a political nature on sfraves. Quite honestly, I don't
think that is going to happen. You can disagree with something that someone
has written, but try not to resort to hurting their feelings or making them
feel stupid. What purpose does that really serve? Can we try being NICE to
each other? Or at least civil?

This message has been brought to you by: 
Someone who cares. 


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 13 12:00:19 1995

On Mon, 13 Nov 1995, Wayne D. Correia wrote:

> 
> I planned to go to Vision, but I had a few problems with it:
> 
> First, the *rediculous* price ($20) was not on any flyer and even the night
> of the party was not on the info line. You had to go to the map point on
> Townsend or to the Sound Factory to find out how much the night's fleecing
> would be. Of course, if you're afraid to put the party cost on your info
> line, you're probably already aware that you're screwing your party goers.
> 
> Also, the simple notion that it was at the Sound Factory had me doubting. I
> don't really go there if possible to avoid the crowd that calls that place
> home.
> 
> Once there, the security guard gautlet at the side entrance to the Sound
> Factory was an instant vibe-killer.
> 
> And at the box office, the fact that a group of 5 of us showed up at 2:45am
> and they insisted that we all pay $20 each was, in my opinion, not in the
> 'spirit' of and party I could have fun at.
> 
>    The message was clear: The number one interest of this promoter
>                           was getting our cash. Thanks, Rodger.
> 
> So, we went with the rule that any party that costs $20, even at 3am is
> most likely not worth it. Not even the rock stars at Wicked charge more
> than $15 for their parties, and that's about the high end of what many will
> pay for a bunch of home town SF DJ's who tend to play the same old sets
> over and over.
> 
> No offense to Ethan or Galen (who area some of my favorites and was the
> reason I wanted to go), but most of the other DJ's billed are, at this
> point, in my opinion, way too overexposed here in SF. For instance, I have
> to actually go out of my way to find a party that *doesn't* have Garth,
> Jeno, or Tony playing.
> 
> Please fly in some talent from somewhere else if you expect to earn the $20
> you want for a party or price your party more in line with what you are
> selling.
> 
> 
>

From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
Message-Id: <9511132043.AA06427@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Subject: Re: "ravers" and Vision
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 13 Nov 1995 12:43:46 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 4693      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> >Firstly, I appreciate Lee's story... It is a beautiful example
> >of what I consider to be a "raver."
> 
> Perhaps so, but part of what I was trying to show was how absurd it can
> be to actually *be* the manifestation of such an ideal.  As long as we
> exist in this reality (the shared one defined by our current physical
> state) ideals such as total acceptance, PLUR, absolute freedom, etc.
> will be concepts that we can strive towards, but never fully realize.
> 
well, yes of course... I guess the point is just that we, "the raver"
or whatever we want to call this ideal must confront all these things
in order to continue beleiving in the ideal.  There are the absurd
examples, but then other times when everything pays for itself and
we can feel some sort of growth of this ideal in ourselves.

> >and of course, this all relates to the Vision, and the need to have
> >undeterring faith in your vision.
> 
> Why not have multiple visions?  Visions of the perfect party, an
> ideal government, spiritual bliss, amazing sex, most powerful weapon,
> stupidest joke... 
> 
yeah but again... The Vision is the ideal, the realization of infinite diversity. 
Within that are the truths we want to create and seek out...
visions of what we decide to be real and where to proceed from there...
This is not static, it must always evolve to keep its life,
but at the same time, no particular state of truth will come to be
with absolute faith in that particular truth, that vision.

> >These words are part of my vision,
> >and I will not change them or my vision will crumble.
> 
> Why can't a vision change or grow?  Isn't it rather idealistic to
> believe that we can come up with a set of perfect ideals to believe in?

well... your right. but the set of all ideals, that idea that every
ideal must change and grow sort'f brings the idea of growth full circle.
We can be idealistic when we respect every ideal, and of course this is just 
a philosophical truth rather than anything anyone will actually ever reach.
that doesn't mean we can't beleive in or understand it.

> 
> >Truth requires
> >a solid meaning and a neverending patience...
> 
> There are many who would say that truth is relative and non-absolute.
> But even *that* cannot be absolutely true!  
> 
If you can see your own truth, your particular vision, that's enough
to make it real.  It is relative and subjective, but in the end,
you're the one who has the final say in the matter.

> I have found that embracing "Truth" requires the acceptance of
> neverending doubt and uncertainty...I think :)
> 
yep... It's the same as the Vision versus a vision, the Ideal versus
an ideal... I think we're just saying the same thing, each with our
own words.  Everyone understands truth, they just have a different 
word for it.

> >Which brings me to the last subject, the year 2012.
> 
> I have to say that it kinda bums me out that history is predicted
> to end after this year, since 2012 is the year I become eligible for
> retirement with full pension from this fucking job!

Well, I think that 2012 is a relative thing.  Terrance Mckenna might
realize nonlinear consciousness in it's entirety on this date... I might
not realize it until 2050.  I might die before I realize it.  I might dream
tonight of a million possible realities, and wake up tommorow
with my aching back and a full day of work ahead of me.
That's the funny thing about nonlinear reality... the beholder of the 
meaning is the only one who can see through it all.
> 
> >"He's stark raving mad, I tell you."  Well, in your eyes.  In his eyes,
> >he is free.  and that freedom is the road to nonlinearity.  And for those
> >unconstrained modes of consciousness, the worlds and times of infinite
> >diversity are the playground of will, the heaven for the unified soul.
> 
> I think there are times when we can transcend the limits of our
> current reality and come very close to experiencing our ideals.  
> It sometimes happens when I trance out on the dance floor. 
> 
and sometimes it happens when we first notice that flower growing
through the sidewalk in front of our house, or when we see someone
or ourself doing exactly what it is that we think should be done.

I think it happens every moment we realize that we are alive.

> > This is the form I seek with my definition of being a raver.
> 
all in all, I think the important thing to realize is that
there is a singular componant within each one of us, life.
And it comes in a billion flavors, but every one of those
flavors must be respected to understand the infinite within us.
That is how we will continue to be alive.

anyway... 
Have a good week...

-john.
http://www.he.net/~swoosh

At 3:30 PM 11/7/95, Cynthia Lopez wrote:
>most of this theory originated in the EARLY 1900's with the fundamental
>destruction of then-current newtonian understandings of physics by
>einstein's general and special theories of relativity, which really served
>mostly to validate the discoveries by many other physicists that matter IS
>energy and the fundamental building blocks of matter (quanta) are simply
>"tendencies to exist" governed by no other will than their own.
>peace&positivity,
>greg-n-cindy
>house archives

        Along this topic, i was thinking about relativity theory and the
spacetime continuum (not the one that makes music though ;) and came to a
realization that spacetime is a unified thing that exists everywhen and
everywhere. Our day to day 'slice' of spacetime that we percieve is often
just the same thing as a mouse eatin' its way through some Swiss Cheese and
so because we percieve different things in a linear order we think that
'time is passing' when in fact it's us that is doing the 'moving.'  I was
thinking about this last weekend at a party in Baltimore as Mixmaster
morris was playing and thought "Right 'now' there is a rave where Mixmaster
Morris is playing and always will be and always has been and i'm LOVING it
but my ontological self is being drawn to different parts of the block of
that spacetime cheese block"
        So, next time you're out at a party (or anywhere in life) and are
not having such a good time, think 'back' to a time when you were in utter
bliss because, relatively, that place/time isn't that far away.
        peace,
                brad

    >> ecto@citenet.net >> ecto@magnet.ca >> http://www.magnet.ca/~ecto >>
========================\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/======================

Dear All & Martin(Communion);

	Cheers to, and a very sincere personal thanks to Martin, for
throwing & in his words "a great fuckin party." Me & my German friend Ulrike 
loved it a lot, for she danced the entire night away, this old man was worn 
out much before that. 

	Special thanks, & recognition to Martin for making the price of
admission $11.00 before 11 o'clock, if you see him thank him in person
yourself, if it moves you to. I feel that when a promoter, who was been
able to deliever, & packem in, for much more a costly event, who doesn't
have to, then throws a party with special pricing should be given special
thanks. (Flame Retartent ON). This should not lessen or in anyway take
away from the love, admiration, & dedication we have for people like Ethan
Miller & Co(Friend's & Family), Claire & Co(Lite), Greg Sandler &
Co(Harmony), Ann L. & Co(New Moon), Geoff W. & Co(Full Moon), The Marin
Posse Who Do Frequency 8(Where House is Just Something You Live In), All
Da Beautiful People @ Cyberlab 7, our Cloud Factory Friends in the South
Bay, and all the others I'm being either to ignorant or to high to
remember, for these people, my friends, & yours go above & behond "THE
CAUSE", to make sure that their parties are either free, run close to
cost, or unforturately end up losing money. 

	I didn't have any doubt that the Sound Factory is and was a great
place to have a party/rave, that's what it's designed for, though thank
god Ethan brought his sound system for the back room. Ethan's set was
great, and so was John Howard's, but who was the person who came on after
Ethan? It was also great to see so many of SF's finest DJ's, like Joe Rice
& John Carel there, not spinning however; but just having a great time
dancing, and listening to their friends spin. 

	I just hope, & I know that the ravers of SF sent a message to the
Sound Factory Management, that we will support a nice club venue that
supports us, but not a rich man's disco, with milatent security. 

	Having worked some of Martin's events it's good to see that he
uses his own security people each & everytime he has an event. I met each
one of them and they all seem very nice. Keep in mind I've worked security
twice at an event, and hated having to be the heavy, it's a sucky job,
having to enforce the rules, and to be there and have to make public
decisions that are often not popular. 

	Thanks again Martin, for everything, Peace, Love, & Happy Holiday's
to you & yours = >.

PS MARTIN, It's almost 2000AD isn't time Communion got an E-Mail Address :).

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET

Yeah, your right on.  In fact at the really good parties, (with the right
DJ and possibly enhancements :) you can experence a glimpse of Eternity.
Eternity is a point out of time, it just exist; in fact, the good parties
all lead us there.

It's the gateway to the place that Rip Van Winkle and some of his 
english predecessors found themselves in when they went to party
with old Gwen Ap Nudth (the king of the faieries) under neath Glastonbury
Tor.  Now THAT was some hardcore ravin! Go into a party, do some serious
partyin with the faiery folk (and believe me that DO know how to party!)
doze off, and wake up 20 years later!

These parties are only for the "True Ravers" however because everyone else
around you will be too old or dead, but hey, your are still 20 years younger
than everybody else so if you were'nt so dosed that you didn't forget
to pick up the flyer for the NEXT party, you could literally Rave through
out history. (or at least to the end of it at 2012 :)

Subject: Re: Vision
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, after reading about a few of you upset ravers out there, I have a few
comments to make.  First of all, my friends and I went to Vision, and we
thought it was truly a remarkable party.  It really shouldn't matter who the
DJ's are, as long as the music is alive, the beat is going, the vibe is
strong, and that everyone is having a good time.  Personally, we go to the
parties where the Wicked crew is at because they seem to always bring out the
togetherness, happiness, and plain old having a good time feeling in us all.
Yea, $20 is a little on the expensive side, but at least it's for a good
cause.  I can't even express how much everyone was like a family in the main
room, especially between 6:00-9:00 am.  When we all gathered hands, formed a
circle, then rushed to the middle, it was such a rush of energy.   Everyone
was all smiles (well, almost everyone), and though many were exhausted, the
music kept many dancing.  Tony, Garth, Jeno, and John Howard definitely kept
the evening alive and strong.
One of the only ways to make a party good is to go with a positive attitude.
 Don't worry about the price, don't worry about the security guards (at least
try to do any business AWAY from them), smile, hug people, DANCE, and have a
great time!

Dear All;

	The season tis almost upon us, sorry but someone had to be the 
first, Anyway, I've been communicating with many a raver, and many of us 
are going to be here in the Bay Area rather than returning home, to our 
families for all sorts of various reasons, I'm one such person.

	I have a lot of time on my hands, as many of you know :), so as 
my Christmas gift to the sfraves community I would like to offer my time 
and by internet account as the point of contact for a raver Thanksgiving & 
X-Mas away from home, Please send in your ideas, of how you would like to 
spend the holidays with your friends. The simpler the idea, the better 
chance of it happening, so that no one of us has to spend the holidays 
alone. 

	Happy Holidays & Wishes of Much Joy to you, yours & our planet
over this Holiday Season.

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=iso-8859-1
Content-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951113224119.2749D@pluto>

                                  New Show

                               November 1995

A site has been secured and SRL will be staging a large scale self-produced
performance in the Bay Area sometime during Thanksgiving Weekend. This will
be SRL's "Crime Wave" show, and will revolve around the many humorous
aspects of violent human interaction. This will be the first large scale SRL
performance since the May 1994 show, A Calculated Forecast Of Ultimate Doom.
We have waited to announce this date until we were fairly certain that the
arrangements for the site location were finalized. However, exact
notification of the time of day and location will not be released until
necessary. To avoid regulatory difficulties, arrangements will be sneakier
than usual. This will also apply to how we will be notifying the public.
Expect something unusual.

Announcement of an Internet based MBONE and CU-SeeMe broadcast will be
forthcoming. Stay tuned to this site for the latest information.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

                             Current Information

                              31 October 1995

There will be no pre-sale tickets. Instead, ticketing will be handled the
day of the show at the entrance to the show site. Tickets will be $10.

The location will be more specific as the show date approaches. However,
actual show location will not be released until the day of the show. When
that occurs it will be available via this WWW site and a telephone number
that will be made public later.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

                                   Notice

By nature SRL shows must happen without much warning to avoid alerting
various official personal. For that reason we ask that you check back to
this site which will be the first on-line resource to announce any SRL show.
This site will provide as many specifics as allowable for each upcoming
show.

Please check back as we are closing in on several show possibilities one of
which may be in your area. For those of you non-local, live video and audio
will be broadcast onto the MBONE and to various CU-SeeMe reflector sites.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                                   [Image]
                                    SRL
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

---------------------------------3187012411025--

hello all-
after reading the message i am responding to, i was surprised to not yet see
numerous responses.  well, here goes-

I AGREE!  please take some responsibility for what you read and choose to
not read.  if it doesn't interest you, delete it.  that's what i choose to
do for most of the political messages.  if you like it, read it.  if you
don't like a strain that has been developing, ignore it, as i have a few
times.  i veer away from totalitarian open-mindedness, but SFRAVES is a
place that open-mindedness can truly occur.  so, to quote "someone who
cares"  "Because you are a raver, you WILL be tolerant of your fellow ravers."
that's my piece, and if you do not care to read this, feel free to delete
it, as i would rather have you delete my message and take responsibility
rather than passively reading everything that flashes across your screen-

peace, love, and a little bitterness- (but still A LOT OF LOVE!)

matt


matthew d. p. k. lanier
vox 415-666-5659

peace behind us, peace around us, let all around us be peace."

From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Short review of Vision
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was quite surprised that Vision was going to be at the Sound Factory,
but after I get there,   I find out that the venue was remodeled and
a new air conditioner was installed and it was quite cool and I was
able to find a lot of smoke free places to dance.

I stayed in the small room and danced to Ethan's entire set.   WOW!!
he WENT OFF big time.    Dutch followed with similar BPM's and continued
with the high level goa trace...   I also danced his set,   other than for
short stretch breaks.   Galen finally went on,  and quickly brought the
BPM's down a few levels (he did it in just two songs) to finish up in
the small room.

After that,  went to the big room,  and even that was tolerable temperature
wise.    I had a harder time finding a smoke free place to dance,   but
I found a few spots and continued until I had to get back to a meeting
in Mill Valley.

The big surprise was the 18+ age limit.   NO ALCOHOL and had thus contributed
to a vibe that only Martin O' Brian could pull off.

Jolly good show,  Martin...  How many others went?   Saw a lot of SFRavers
there,  so it couldn't have been THAT bad...   Way to go Ethan,  your
music really did a great job in enhancing my state of mind...  It's
about time we get the higher BPM's.

Crunchman

In article <Pine.BSD/.3.91.951111210638.7936B-100000@value.net>,
blkadder@value.net wrote:
> 
> Given the current climate here, I am at a crossroads. I am trying to decide 
> if I even wish to consider myself a "raver," whatever that means, or if I 
> am better off alone with my thoughts.

Hmm, so is the real question, "Should Black Adder call himself a raver, and
should he continue to associate himself with the sf-raves community?"

If that is the real question, then I must state emphatically "YES" as I
would be sad if he left.  Call me selfish.

> What is the definiton of a "raver?"

RAVER - Rabid Alien Virus Eating Reality

It's common knowledge that techno comes from space aliens using the great
pyramids as psychic energy transmiters.  So far it has only taken over those
of us with weak, pliable minds, but the aliens powers are growing and soon
even the great Oral Roberts will be overcome.

> What does "raving" mean to you, in your life? 

Well, in no particular order, Black Adder, Ray Gun, Foustus, Cyr, Amy, Geoff
White, Lee Fogel, Peter Fogel, Milton, Ricki, Brian Darkness, Carol, Karen,
Kathrine, Rebecca, Mars, Myster E, REN, Theta Blip, Xris, Helena, Pilot
Girl, Peter Wolf, Kristal, Vivian, Ethan, Judge, Mike, Bryce, Greg, Cindy,
Chris, Ian, Diane, Newt King, Rok, Brian, Phred, Anthrax, Greg, Minuk,
Vince, Wayne, Jonas, and a whole bunch of others I'm not remembering because
its too late at night and my mind doesn't keep good lists.  I'd also like to
add to that list anyone I've ever shared water with, fire with, air with,
earth with, pictures with, smiles with, and hugs with.

If it weren't for raving, I would never have met most of these people, and
those I could have met, probably wouldn't be such good friends.  The first
SF Raver I ever met was Lee Fogel, and he gave me such a big hug I can still
feel it.

It's gotten progressively better since then.

- PT

I think email leads to action.  The history iof this list, and the 
actions of its membership is proof of this fact.  F&F is proof enough.  
People got tired of the same ol-same-ol and created thier own space, and 
own 'thing'.  All of this happened, at least in part, due to serious, 
often rabid debate.  Now F&F is all about doing, and it shows (at least 
in commentary of others, I have yet to go, but may one day).

So I never devaluate the positive effects of conversation.  I just don't 
like people who maon and groan and do nothing to alter their own reality.

Peace,
John

Hey there, all my fellow listies,

I've been pondering over the idea of going to London for the summer to live
and work.  It's something I've wanted to do for a while and I think I'll
finally have the opportunity.  What I'd like help with is my living
situation.  I guess I could search for a house over there and find someone
to sublet here, but I was hoping I could make it easier.  If anyone here
knows someone in London who might be interested in house swapping for the
summer, please let me know.  Also, is there any kind of rave list for that
area?  I thought I could pose the same question there if such a thing exists.

No problem there Joe,  *I* stand corrected.  Haven't talked to Martin,
mano-a-mano in quite a while.  Say hi to him at parties and all, know he's
well, but am not in on his plans, especially the most recent.  So thanks
for schooling me on the more recent history.

Just a side:
I don't like being the know-it-all-historian, and I really try to curb my
corrections, that's why I tried to let you know I wasn't being all
piss-ant-wise about the happs @ Martin's parties.  It's often a delicate
balancing act I think I've improved over time.  The one thing I hate about
the net is people who go out of their way to correct others on even the
most minor infraction.  I really despise people who dabble in the
unimportant minutae of being absolutley correct at all times.  Life's too
short to be right all the time ;)!

Much peace,
John

	Nothing in this Book is True but it's Exactly as Things are.


It'll explain EVERYTHING, really ;}

The end of history has to do with some time travel experiments,
the Greys have done a couple on their own, and a couple with our
"government" the most notable one being the philidelphia experiment,
since these experiments create strange relativistic singularities
they are really dificult to control and to understand, at 2012
they finally get it right and can move forward and backward at will.
when you have this capability then you literraly rewrite history, but
there really isn't any "history" any more since one can go to a 
prvious time in "the present", in fact if you go back and fuck with some
thing you just spawn off another worm hole (sorta like copy-on-write,
page fault algorithms for you Operating Systems buffs #:@)


You might find this interesting

2012

1987

1962

Each of these time periods are about 25 years apart.

1962 saw the first rumbling of the "flower children" here in SF
1987 saw the Harmonic Convergence and the second "summer of love" in the 
UK (Acied!)

2012 ??? Well Liam, (Jeno's son will be 19 years old ) 

Many of you youngins will be around fourty, I will be 55 (around
will penna's age currently)


Just think, when we get this time machine thing happening, we can all go back
and relive the best parties through out history, not only that, but we can
bring our grandkids and show them that grand-pa REALLY knew how to party in
his day :)

Gone MAD and Got Trancy 
 
 After missing out on Vision last weekend, I felt the need for some serious 
trance-portation music. So , despite the necessity of getting in to work at
8PM Tuesday morning , I drove from Sunnyvale up to S.F. to catch Ethan and
Joe Rice and Monty at the Bahia Restaurant. I arrived there a little after 10 
PM , at the same time SFRaver and F&F video projection master Mike Clay 
was parking his truck nearby . 
 
 I've never been to this restaurant before ,but my wife has eaten there and 
gave it a positive rating. The decor is South American tropical - I think the
ethnicity of the cuisine is Brazilian. The last of the eating patrons were 
watching the arriving ravers with some curiosity - of course , the acid trance 
that Ethan was spinning probably gave them a surprise as well ; not exactly 
dinner music !
 
 A nice wooden dance floor , about 25' X 40' . It finally started filling up 
at about 11:15PM. I was glad for the increasing crowd - at the beginning,
there seemed to be a small group of guys who seemed to be showing off/
teaching their dance moves to each other ( floor spins , etc ) , and they were 
taking up a lot of floor space. The back wall is mirrored , giving a wider 
feeling to the dancing area ; it was kind of amusing to catch glimpses of these 
guys as they monitored themselves in the mirrors . 
 
 Not that I've worth watching as I'm dancing - I'm of the "stagger rythmically
and symetrically and wiggle your arms about" school of dancing when it comes
to techno/house ( or most other schools of music, come to think of it ).  
Anyway , I got to do a lot of whatever it is I do on dancefloors - it was 
great! I was only able to stay for Ethan's set and some of Monty's set , so I 
got in as much dancing as possible until my legs started to feel like logs. 
 
 I've never heard Monty spin before , but I liked what I heard . I don't 
recall seeing his name before, but that may just be me. He's a black guy about 
6'1" , maybe late twenties. I'd go to hear him again.
 
 ------------
 
MAD!
 The next time I have trance/dance withdrawal symptoms , I'll know where to
go! 
 
  Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS - It was nice to meet another SFRaver in person - Rick Riffle . I'm 
     glad that I asked for his name twice - I was able to remember it!

Received: from netcom15.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id HAA17033; Wed, 15 Nov 1995 07:13:46 -0800

From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)

Subject: "Rave Goggles" review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 15 Nov 1995 07:12:18 -0800 (PST)
Cc: MaryP76944@aol.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1148      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


 By the way , I finally got to try out my new "rave goggles" again - athletic 
goggles with prescription  lenses. There's a flaw with using it that can be
considered a feature under the right circumstances. The damn things fog
up a bit too easily. I've even tried to put some of that anti-fog gel on it,
but that didn't seem to help. I think it sits a bit too closely to my face.

 If I really want to see something at the other end of the room/warehouse/
field/beach , it's inconvienent. On the other hand , it does aid in 
establishing an introspective mood , and sometimes what's there to see isn't
all that interesting!

 It is a different experience dancing with them - I must have been semi-
concioussly worried about my glasses falling off all this time - I was able
to relax just that little bit more. Also , like any different pair of glasses
than what one usually wears , the field of view and perspective is somewhat
out of whack - kind of like what the world looks like when A is starting
to kick in.

 I'll have to tinker with the frame a bit , try to get more air circulating 
behind the frame.  

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

On Wed, 15 Nov 1995, Jonathan Mark Logan wrote:

> Are there any Autechre fans out there?  If so, do any of you know when 
> their latest album is due out?  It was released in the UK last 
> week.  I want it NOW.  I want instant gratification NOW. NOWNOWNOWNOW

I picked it up on vinyl at Soundworks friday ($14.99), they had the cd as
well.  I'm sure Mod Lang and Rasputins has it now too.  If you're willing
to wait a couple of weeks you can pick it up domestic on WaxTraX/TVT. 

My first impression after a couple listens is that it's good, but not as
amazing as some others have made it out to be IMO.  It might take a while
to grow on me though... 

While we're talking about music I'd also like to add the new Mille Plateux
comp. "Electric Ladyland" and the Journey's by DJ Coldcut cd to the list
of recomendations.  Both are excellent. 

Andy

>On Wed, 15 Nov 1995 SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com wrote:

>> ummm, why do the greys or grays need our help to make a time machine?
>> 
>> do they have a hard time making stone knives and bearskins?

>> Dave Scruton

>Who said they need our help? Maybe we need theirs :)

I have read that the Greys removed emotion from thier species through
genetic manipulation.  Then eventually they realized they needed emotion to
evolve, or thier species will become extinct.  That's where we come in.
They need our help to understand emotion, and to integrate it back into
thier species.  So maybe emotion is a key to understanding time, and without
it, time cannot be manipulated.  True...untrue...I don't know, I just work here.

Rick  

Obsfraves,

I went to "Root of Consciousness" last Saturday, or was it Friday, I don't
remember.  It was beautiful.  The space was incredible.  It was some sort of
auditorium at a youth facility I believe.  The dance floor was way cool,
kinda springy.  The visiuals were great, including lasers.  Everyone was
ultra nice.  The guys at the map point were too.  Instead of frisking you as
you walk in the door, there was a guy with a bundle of sage incense who
would wave it up and down and around your body and blow the smoke toward you
to clear your aura...to clear negative energy.  I stayed in the ambient room
most of the time, but I danced a little to Carlos, and he went off.  He
really knows how to move a crowd.  He kept changing styles of music, but it
totally flowed.  He really worked everyone.  His energy is incredible, and
he scratchs like a mad-man.  The ambient room was really nice as well.
There was a live band that played all night.  Instuments were
everywhere...they had alot of shit.  Tons-o-analogue gear.
nnnneeeeeerrrrrrroooooouuuuuwwwwwwwwrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrreeeeeeiiiiiiiiiiiiizzzzz
z.  With a cool little red laser doing neat things on the wall.  I spend 75%
of my time in there.  They had a nice padded floor using those excersize
matt, like the gymnastics dept. had in school.  Everyone was totally
sprawled out, way cool.  Then, get this, they had a healing room, with lots
of people doing various kinds of energy/body work, Reki, charkra balancing,
massage, tarot, past life regretion.  There were about 15 to 20 different
things to choose form.  I tried the charkra balancing and was completely
blown away, infact when I was finished with that, I realized that that was
the real reason why I went to the rave in the first place.  The crowd was
kinda young, but the whole rave seemed young and fresh and new.  I had a
really good time.  I would recommend going if they do something again.

Rick

Just thought I'd throw that out there.

Dear Diane;

	What's going on hon?, sorry I'm clueless, but I care about the
people on this list cause they care about me. I don't know what's going
on, but also don't have to know the details to offer my support to YOU.
All that's important is that you hurt, that's all I need to sense. I'm
sorry that life is having it's way with you, I know all to well just how
it feels, and how spent & alone it can leave you. 

	Try and remember Diane, that we all shine, no matter what a court
might say about us, or anyone else for that matter. I often refer to human
beings as orginal works of art, masterpieces; cause like orginal art,
their wonderfully unique, with no two pieces being the same, and in a
sense, priceless; because they can't be exactly replaced. 

	Like those masterpieces their will never be another person like
you, or me, try & remember that love for yourself & humanity & keep it
close to you, always.  Everything will work out in the end, and I have no 
doubt you will always & continue to get what you need, and sometimes get 
what you want. So please accept some virtual flowers, a virtual hug, a 
virtual kiss, and an offer of my time & my telephone ear if ya care to 
talk, and also the virtual stuff until I can see you in person & give it 
to ya for real. See ya sunshine!!!!! = )

Please also except these Cowboy Junkie Lyrics as some comfort:

Taken From To Live Is To Fly; off of Black Eyed Man

Days up & down they come
lke rain on a conga drum
forget most, remember some
but don't turn none away.
Everything is not enough
nothing is too much to bear
where you been is good & gone
all you keep's the getting there.
To live is to fly low & high
so shake the dust off your wings
& the sleep out of your eyes

Were with ya Diane, and you are A STRONG CAPABLE WOMYN

> I have read that the Greys removed emotion from thier species through
> genetic manipulation.  Then eventually they realized they needed emotion to
> evolve, or thier species will become extinct.  That's where we come in.
> They need our help to understand emotion, and to integrate it back into
> thier species.  So maybe emotion is a key to understanding time, and without
> it, time cannot be manipulated.  True...untrue...I don't know, I just work here.
> 
> Rick  
> 
> Obsfraves,
> 
> I went to "Root of Consciousness" last Saturday, or was it Friday, I don't
> remember.  It was beautiful.  The space was incredible.  It was some sort of
> auditorium at a youth facility I believe.  The dance floor was way cool,
> kinda springy.  The visiuals were great, including lasers.  Everyone was
> ultra nice.  The guys at the map point were too.  Instead of frisking you as
> you walk in the door, there was a guy with a bundle of sage incense who
> would wave it up and down and around your body and blow the smoke toward you
> to clear your aura...to clear negative energy.  I stayed in the ambient room
> most of the time, but I danced a little to Carlos, and he went off.  He
> really knows how to move a crowd.  He kept changing styles of music, but it
> totally flowed.  He really worked everyone.  His energy is incredible, and
> he scratchs like a mad-man.  The ambient room was really nice as well.
> There was a live band that played all night.  Instuments were
> everywhere...they had alot of shit.  Tons-o-analogue gear.
> nnnneeeeeerrrrrrroooooouuuuuwwwwwwwwrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrreeeeeeiiiiiiiiiiiiizzzzz
> z.  With a cool little red laser doing neat things on the wall.  I spend 75%
> of my time in there.  They had a nice padded floor using those excersize
> matt, like the gymnastics dept. had in school.  Everyone was totally
> sprawled out, way cool.  Then, get this, they had a healing room, with lots
> of people doing various kinds of energy/body work, Reki, charkra balancing,
> massage, tarot, past life regretion.  There were about 15 to 20 different
> things to choose form.  I tried the charkra balancing and was completely
> blown away, infact when I was finished with that, I realized that that was
> the real reason why I went to the rave in the first place.  The crowd was
> kinda young, but the whole rave seemed young and fresh and new.  I had a
> really good time.  I would recommend going if they do something again.
> 
> Rick
> 
>

Precedence: bulk

Hello-

	Checked out Roots last night...Doc Martin tore it up for at least 
2 and a half hours...great to see such a variety of house music woven 
together with such skill.  
	Upstairs was a chill dancefloor with the warm sounds of trip-hop 
vibrating people's bones.   I struck up a conversation with a guy from 
London who had been in L.A. for two weeks, and San Francisco for only 
four days.   He said "This is a great party.  You couldn't find anything 
like this in London...and it blows the shit out of anything in L.A."   I 
tried to find the words to tell him how much fun our scene is, but words 
can only say so much.  No doubt there are great parties in London and 
L.A. as well, but it's nice to be reminded of just how lucky we are.
	Does anyone know which DJ's played when upstairs?  Thanks, -dave.

Subject: something you might want to know...
Date: Thu, 16 Nov 95 12:24:54 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


i have no idea of the copyright status of this snippet that was
forwarded to me... please remove my name if you're planning on saving
this information or passing it on. thankx.

------- Forwarded Message

from "micromedex"...

"Several assays can be used to detect delta(9)-THC metabolites
in urine.  Radioimmunoassay, enzyme immunoassay, thin-layer
chromatography (TLC), high performance liquid chromatography
(HPLC) and gas chromatography/mass spectometry (GC/MS) are some
of methods used (Mayer et al, 1987).  A new test, the
TDX(R)(Abbott) Cannabinol assay utilizing florescence
polarization has been introduced in Sweeden (Karlsson and Strom,
1988).  Radioimmunoassay and enzyme immunoassay, introduced in
1981, are the most widely used screening procedures.
Enzyme-mediated immunotechnique, EMIT(R)(Syva), is the one used
by most laboratories (Mayer et al, 1987). The EMIT procedure measures the
activity of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase.  In the absence of
delta(9)-THC metabolites, the enzyme is deactivated by an
antibody and the test is negative.  If delta(9)-THC metabolites
are present, the antibody binds to them, leaving the enzyme free
to react and produce a positive test (Mayer et al, 1987).

 Because the antibody used can cross-react with other urinary
substances (Karlson and Strom, 1988).  Addition of chemicals
such as salt, vinegar, bleach, or detergent to positive-testing
urine will result in a negative result.  Supervision of urine
collection, and follow-up testing of positive samples are
necessary with EMIT.  The advantage of EMIT is it is easy to use
and inexpensive (Mayer et al, 1987). Two EMIT(R) systems are commercially
available.  The EMIT-st(R (single test) system can detect cannabinoid
metabolites at
concentrations of 200 ng/mL with greater than 95% confidence;
the minimum detection level is 100 ng/mL but at less than 95%
probability.  The EMIT-st(R) is a portable, compact system
suitable for use in physicians' offices and small laboratories.
The EMIT-dau(R) (drugs of abuse in urine) is a more extensive
system used in high volume laboratories that is capable of
detecting concentrations of 50 ng/mL at a 95% probability and
20 ng/mL about 50% of the time.  The dau system reagents are
also available with a 100 ng/mL cutoff instead of 20 ng/mL to
decrease the probability of a positive urine result due to
passive inhalation of  marijuana  (Schwartz & Hawks, 1985).  There
are no false negatives.  Three percent of all test results or 5%
of all positive results with EMIT-dau(R) were found to be false
positive (Mayer et al, 1987).  EMIT-st(R) is designed to
identify only recent and heavy  marijuana  use and is much less
sensitive than EMIT-dau(R). Pharm Chem Laboratories reported that frequent
smoking of a single high-quality  marijuana  cigarette by a casual user results
in metabolites that can be detected in the urine for 3 to 10
days using the EMIT(R) 100 ng cutoff, and more frequent use can
lead to a positive  urinalysis  for 3-4 weeks.  Very heavy chronic
smokers may have detectable concentrations for greater than 4
weeks.  The longest reported detection time is 11 weeks in a
patient (using the 20 ng/mL EMIT(R) test) after abstaining from
marijuana  smoking.  The patient had a history of smoking 7 to 10
cigarettes/day for 7 years (Sedgwick, 1985). The TDX(R) system is precise and
reliable but much slower when a  large number of samples must be run.
The reagent cost is higher for the TDX(R) (Karlsson and Strom, 1988).
Because both the TDX(R) and the EMIT  give preliminary results
only, positive results need to be confirmed by TLC (detection
limit 50 ng/mL) or HPLC (detection 25 ng/mL) or GC/MS (detects 5
to 10 ng/mL).  In the study by Mayer et al (1987), HPLC, when
used for confirmation yielded a false fortune rate of 2% due to
interference, GC/MS was 100% accurate.  These three tests are
tedious and expensive, and therefore, are not appropriate for
screening.

Preliminary testing for the presence of delta(9)-THC and its
metabolites in urine can be done with EMIT(R) cannabinoid assay,
TDX(R) cannabinoid assay, or radioimmune assay.  EMIT is fast,
easy and less expensive than TDX(R), while TDX is more precise
the results can be confirmed when necessary with TLC, HPLC or
GC/MS.  A combination of EMIT-dau(R) and GC/MS gives complete
accuracy in detection of  marijuana  abuse.  Urine testing does
not determine intoxication because urine levels are not
correlated to psychopharmacological response.  Passive
absorption of THC appears unlikely to produce positive test
results.

D.  ADULTERANT-LABORATORY INTERFERENCE
   1.  Urinary levels fluctuate from day to day.  Adulterants may cause
false-negatives (acidic or alkaline adulteration or extreme dilution of the
urine), therefore urine pH and specific gravity should also be assessed
(Schwartz & Hawks, 1985).
   2.  Ingestion of 3000 mg of ascorbic acid, 1560 mg of golden seal root, and
750 mL of cranberry juice did not interfere with EMIT testing of urine for
cannabinoids. Levels were reduced but still detectable (Schwartz & Bogema,
1988).
   3.  The addition of Visine (R) eye drops in concentrations of 20 to 100 mL
per liter of urine resulted in false negative urine assays for cannabinoids
using the EMIT and TDx assays.  This effect was more evident when glass
specimen containers were used.
    a.  Studies with various components of Visine (R) showed the benzalkonium
chloride to be primarily responsible, although the borate buffer had some
effect (Pearson et al, 1989).
   4.  False negative results were seen in cannabinoid EMIT assays with the
adulterants sodium hypochlorite, Joy (R) liquid dish detergent, and sodium
 chloride.  The amount of sodium chloride needed to produce this effect
(greater  than 50 g/L) would preclude its practical use.
    a.  When the same adulterants were tested with an RIA assay or the Abbott
TDx assay, no false negatives were seen, but false positives occurred with the
Joy (R) detergent (Warner, 1989)."

------- End of Forwarded Message

My computer tells me that on Sat, 11 Nov 1995, Tenderloin Waxx shared:

> Sure. I guess alt.drugs/sfraves isn't the place to discuss this, unless I
> talk about the drugs they feed em'. Sorry for posting something out of
> love NOT out of intolerance. Why don't we switch to one of the usual xtc
> threads now & pretend everything is just great. And please no more of
> those interesting threads like "privitization". 
> --------------
> 
> Josh, I would like to take this moment to thank you, deeply, honestly and
> from the bottom of my heart for discussing these issues.  I urge you to
> resist those who attempt to silence you; no, it wouldn't be right to have
> all discussion on the list center around politics, but to avoid it as was
> suggested is cultural suicide.  Unfortunately, remaining uninvolved and
> uninterested in these issues is exactly what has brought us to this sad
> state we were discussing.  Only thinking and speaking about it will lead
> us to a solution that will last for generations; I honestly believe without
> fundamental change we have only a few generations left.  So if people aren't
> interested, let them delete, but don't let them shut your mouth, you are
> engaged in necessary, responsible and in the long run, rave-related
> behavior; I don't want to attempt to blindly dance upon a burnt out cinder,
> and although that's obviously a dramatic exaggeration (we hope), you
> get my point!
> 
> "I want to get down, I want to party hearty,
>  I want to get down, with the defunkt!"
> 
> -=J=-

	Waxx and I may have our disagreements, but I think he and Josh 
are right.  I don't blame anyone for not being interested in politics or 
philosophy, but on the other hand I believe if more ravers understood how 
much these things affect our scene by determining the social climate it 
takes place in, they might take more of an interest.  Remember, in many 
countries of the world, you would not be able to throw a rave at all.  
And to the people living there, it no doubt seems normal and 
unobjectionable, because they haven't experienced what they could have 
with a little more freedom.  I think the same is true for us.  Clearly 
there is a balance to be reached, I don't want the sfraves list to be 
inundated with political stuff any more than any of you, but I do feel 
its important to look at the bigger picture.  

Yours in liberty,
				*** Starchild ***

		-Marite & Francois Girbaud radio ad, 1993 (?)

heres a personal communication i thought i'd post to you guys at sfr.
On Thu, 16 Nov 1995, Jose Talavera wrote:

> Hey dude,
> 
>         What do you think about the reductionist theory of the mind-brain,
> where the mind-brain (and thus consciousness) can be reduced to the purely
> physical?  Your whole neural poem made me think of this.  Some dude was
> talking to me about a study he's doing in psychology where he's modeling
> the connections between neurons (or something) to see how thought occurs.
> Mind blowing shit, no doubt.
> 
> Strange days are coming......
> Smileyz;)  Jose
> there is a *soul* i think in each body, right? reincarnation, and the 
bit. but yes ive considered it, but think, if what the brain can 
perscieve were to be like the color green, then we can alter our state of 
consciousness with, say, LSD, and see teh next color, purple, red, or 
whatever, depending on the chemical. then think for a bit about the light 
outside teh electromagnetic spectrum, i mean the waves, outside teh 
possibility of perscieving through infinite numbers of chemicals, but 
then perhaps reality is just consciousness anyway, and like quantum 
physics states, nothing exists untill it is perscieved. get that. there 
were no atoms until someone found one.
but the energy of the universe is maleable into infinite set of forms, as 
many as your consciousness can have teh fancy to create or imagine. the 
bottom line, my friend, is *UNTAPPED POTENTIAL* and that is, imperically, 
our destination from the beginning.
dream out loud!
smiles:) tom
consider the random probability of the dendancy to exist, when speaking 
of matter. and how our *expectations*, and those of teh experimenters had 
a direct influence over where these tendencies to exist would manifest. 
*our* expectations. do you understand teh implificatiopns of these results.

perhaps teh government is well aware of this, having scientists work like 
mad for truth, so they can twist it into power.
*fuck politics*
but they have given us something. like acid into the hands of ken kesey. 
OOPS! and teh 60's happen.
my friend, we have the power as well, to think, to create. although some 
forms of this are illegal. why.?
"because they're afraid that there is more to reality than they have 
confronted, that there are doors ... and they dont want us to go in  
there either, because if we do, we might learn something they dont know, 
and that makes us a little out of their control."
more smiles:) tom
(subscribe to sfraves, they have some cool discussions there. i'll email 
you with how to do it, or find it under http://www.hyperreal.com)

	Once again I have to keep my impetuous fingers from typing an 
inapropriately long response to this non-rave related post.  I'll just 
share a couple brief quotes:

"...the power system continues only as long as *individuals* try to get 
something for nothing.  The day when a majority of individuals declares 
or acts as if it wants nothing from government, declares that it will 
look after its own welfare and interests, then on that day the power 
elites are doomed."
	-Antony Sutton, author of "The Best Enemy Money Can Buy"

Politically Unpopular Hugs & Smooches,

My computer tells me that on Wed, 8 Nov 1995, Mark Piercy shared:

> Hey, Good post
> 
> 
> Whenever I try to expain to people the true evil of the
> profit-motive-driven system of America, and I get tired or frustrated I
> just say one thing- Morality is unprofitible, thus since this country is
> directed only in favor of profit all power structures (corporate and
> governmental) and the power decisions they make, are inherently devoid of
> moality.
> 
>  Hence we live in a "profit democracy" and only the dollar votes and not
> the people (majority).  Privatization is one facet of this problem, people
> have been manipulated by the media to belive that competition is good
> (profitible) and thus it's o.k. to privatize services that are a right
> i.e.health care and legal representation, so that only those with the most
> money get the best care and stay out of jail! is that democracy? NO, it's
> more like feudalism.  Soon we will have private police, Yosemite will be
> managed by Disney(no joke heard it on NPR yesterday) GG Park will cost 10
> bucks and muni will only service the most profitible areas... on and on,
> untill taking a deep breath will be 25 cents. 
> 
> 
> >
> Why are you always siding with big money and big interests? Have you
> >noticed that:
> >
> >(1) there are industries around more moneyed than schoolchild journalism
> >(2) these industries spy a marketing channel and fund deployment into
> >    the marketing channel via profits from higher margin sale (typically
> >    the channel, but often, it is worth $$$/power owning your own
> >    "independent' channels just in case...
> >(3) they are better funded than an independent competitor that is genuinely
> >    interestied in K-12 publishing as an "art" and an avocation, not
> >    because it'll fatten their wallets.
> >(4) they use their funding to dominate the competitors, simply because they
> >    want to sell you something "between the lines"....
> >(5) eventually, they are the sole voice and they have their marketing channel
> >
> >This is typically the way things work when it comes to privatizing
> >essential human needs like education. We believe the future role of
> >government in a true democracy is to ensure both financial and personal
> >democracy, given the added pressures and profit motives brought on by
> >communications and the media and a world where information is a
> >commodity/necessity.
> >
> >"Freedom from being the victim of someone's profit motive" is nearly
> >synonymous with (or at least as important as) freedom of religion. If
> >we can chose, to ignore it, that's fine, if it gets shoved down our
> >throats when it comes to the basic needs of human existance (education,
> >healthcare) that's no good. And that's where you're proposing to wedge
> >"privatization".
> >
> >We are getting rather tired of watching the repeated paroxysms of this
> >deathkultur. Until we can figure out a way to come up with a society
> >where money is not equal to power, your thousand points of light are
> >nothing but black holes!
> >
> >If the libertarian is just as interested in cottage industries as they
> >are in corporate megaliths then s/he too would also take on the belief
> >that more profit is not better, more competition is not better,
> >bigger/more is not better. THe exaltation of dominator pleasure in your
> >system of "competition for the sake of profit" comes all over the back
> >of economic slavery, suffering, and poverty. All the while they think
> >they're casting pearl necklace to swine!
> >
> >This is not an optimal systems solution, and  eventually, if we're
> >gonna all survive, we've gotta talk "systems!". Don't be duped by
> >"their" wild wild west political fairytale, because unless you're rich
> >enough that your money can work for you so that you don't have to,
> >you'll just be a servant to their system! Nice Nice, Very Nice....

	This isn't a rave or a rave-type party particularly, but my 
girlfriend is having a party at her parents' place in Danville this 
Saturday evening.  
	It is sort of for the San Francisco State University Outdoor 
Adventure Kids club.  This is a student group she started to take inner 
city kids on hikes and stuff; the party was planned as a chance for 
people to get to know each other.  Everyone is welcome though, you don't 
have to go to State or be involved with the club.
	Jaime didn't want to have a full-blown rave because of concerns 
about noise and neighbors, but I don't think she'd be opposed to someone 
spinning, especially ambient, if the volume is low.  If you're 
interested, let me know.  You won't be paid, but then you don't have to be a 
superstar DJ or anything, just have a desire to play for a crowd.
	During the day on Saturday we're having a hike on nearby Mount 
Diablo, followed by the party in the evening.
	Her folks' place is really beautiful, it looks like a castle on a 
hill.  There's a big courtyard outside, which we'll be using for the 
party, and anyone who wants to sleep over outdoors is welcome to bring a 
sleeping bag, tent, etc.
	For more info, leave a message on my voicemail at (415) 270-7887.

Cheers,
				*** Starchild ***

       90.1 Stanford

       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)

       90.1 (Stanford)

       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)

       90.3 (SF)

       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills

       KMEL.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

> 	Waxx and I may have our disagreements, but I think he and Josh 
> are right.  I don't blame anyone for not being interested in politics or 
> philosophy, but on the other hand I believe if more ravers understood how 
> much these things affect our scene by determining the social climate it 
> takes place in, they might take more of an interest.  Remember, in many 
> countries of the world, you would not be able to throw a rave at all.  
> And to the people living there, it no doubt seems normal and 
> unobjectionable, because they haven't experienced what they could have 
> with a little more freedom.  I think the same is true for us.  Clearly 
> there is a balance to be reached, I don't want the sfraves list to be 
> inundated with political stuff any more than any of you, but I do feel 
> its important to look at the bigger picture.  
> 
> Yours in liberty,
> 				*** Starchild ***

Nicely put, thank you!
