        gregm@well.com, rdriffle@ucdavis.edu, wshartle@eos.ncsu.edu,
        sfraves@hyperreal.com, throb@netcom.netcom.com, keiper@itsa.ucsf.edu,
        peterf@ix.netcom.com, mayer@netcom.com, 74230.370@adoc.xerox.com
Subject: Thanks for the support!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     You know, I had a real difficult time getting myself to ask for a hug 
     yesterday and I'm really glad I did.  I kinda felt like I was washing 
     my laundry in public and that showing my neediness was a weakness.  
     But I endured yesterday and the sun rises and thanks to all of your 
     warm wishes and support, I'm feeling alot better.  I'm especially 
     warmed by people who don't know me on the list but posted anyway.  It 
     showed me that to be associated with sfraves or even being a raver, 
     people KNOW the difference between showing, sharing, and feeling love. 
      
     Posting to the group and other friends helped me realize once again, 
     that we're in this world...this reality...together (and I didn't have 
     to use music and dance or even trance to get me to this point!).  
     Though my perspective is still jaded w/the court system, I have to 
     take a more Eastern approach to thinking that karma will take care of 
     things, and that my son knew what he would encounter for the first 24 
     years of his life even before coming into this world, _and_ that 
     there's a reason for everything.
     
     For those who don't know what I'm going through, it's a custody case 
     for my 9 year-old son and a restraining order for an abusive 
     ex-husband.  Problems started this Summer when my ex fell off the 
     wagon, lost his job, his apartment, became homeless, and had my son 
     sleeping in a local public park on his custody days.  I filed for 
     temporary full custody and that was upheld until we sent our son off 
     to England in August.  The mediator yesterday addressed my ex's desire 
     for full custody and berated me for not being emotionally supportive 
     enough!  So much for keeping a chin up juggling too many hats of work, 
     and all.  I guess I'm just too restrained (except for when it comes to 
     dancing :)
     
     Thanks again for all of your kind words, thoughts, and love.  I've got 
     court at 9am tomorrow and I'm gonna make the best of it.  And if I'm 
     into escapism, maybe you'll even see me out this weekend since I won't 
     have my son.
     
     Love,
     Diane
     
     
                    ---------------------------------------
     Here is a test to find out whether your mission on earth is finished:  
        If you're alive, it isn't (Richar Bach, Illusions)
     
      


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Nov 16 18:10:25 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA26168; Thu, 16 Nov 1995 18:10:25 -0800
Received: from orion.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA26163; Thu, 16 Nov 1995 18:10:19 -0800
Received: (from star@localhost) by orion.sfsu.edu (8.7.1/8.7.1) id SAA05513; Thu, 16 Nov 1995 18:10:05 -0800 (PST)
Date: Thu, 16 Nov 1995 18:10:02 -0800 (PST)
From: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: star@orion
To: SanFranDiscoRaves! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
cc: star@sfsu.edu
Subject: Appropriateness of Non-Rave Postings
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951116174739.4888H-100000@orion>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	I just posted a message on this issue, and thought of something 
else I should have included.  
	I don't know how much time the rest of you spend in front of the 
computer, but if you're like me, you try to at least skim every posting 
to sfraves.  I think that having at least a core group of people who look 
at every post is essential to having some kind of community, some kind of 
common dialogue here, and I want to be a part of this dialogue, because I 
love raves and I'm still excited by what we have going on.
	The downside of this is that unless I want my eyes to glaze over 
as I develop carpal tunnel and I start sleeping with my mouse 
(cyber-bestiality?), it doesn't leave a lot of time to read and post to 
other lists, such as ba.politics.
	So while Black Adder's advice to take the political postings to 
an appropriate group has merit, the fact is that for many of us, sfraves 
is the only list we have time to follow, and personally I consider it bad 
nettiquite to post to lists that you don't follow or don't plan to 
follow, unless it's a specific item of interest.
	If sfraves is the only list that I and others have time to truly 
follow, either we (A) post things that are only peripherally rave-related 
from time to time, or (B) there is a whole dimension of life that we 
never get to discuss with others on the net.
	I think that as a community, we benefit from having as broad a 
range of discussion and interaction as possible.  I suspect that the 
interests of members of the community will be discussed in rough 
proportion to the amount of interest in the topic, without the neccessity 
of anyone being discouraged from posting on a topic.  But use your own 
judgement.  
	If I post the minutes from Libertarian Party functions daily in 
excrutiating length and detail, clearly I deserve to be slapped silly 
with a wet noodle and placed directly in front of a speaker at an event 
DJ'd by Traci Lords.

Love & Laughter,
				*** Starchild ***

   -NY State Senator James Donovan, speaking in favor of capitol punishment.

Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9511161810.D3561-0100000@violet.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

After writing a longer than I expected reply I decided that I must warn 
you that this is not purely rave related...but have hope! there is 
information at the end that is more directly rave related!;>


Hmm,
	This reminds me of a class I am taking called mind and brain, 
nuerophysiology and computers. These are the types of issues we talk 
about. My take on this is that I want to believe the physicalist camp and 
figure out how the mind can be found from looking at the brain...what is 
the connection? 
There is some fascinating research being done with results 
that show how as brains we can only know of our world what we create. The 
quick explanation is that for the example when you breathe a smell and 
the first  place the signal goes is a "bulb" the bulb recieves 80% of its 
information from prior knowledge (the cortex) and only 20% as input from 
the world. So the intuition is to say that what you percieve as the world 
is 80% influenced by your own mind, preconceptions, etc. Which is very 
related to the idea of ever being able to understand the world purely 
objectively. For now the only things which I see as being even close to 
purely objective is mathematical constructs.
	Boy this is really a ramble! Sorry about this, rave related 
information will come at the end!

> >         What do you think about the reductionist theory of the mind-brain,
> > where the mind-brain (and thus consciousness) can be reduced to the purely
> > physical?  Your whole neural poem made me think of this.  Some dude was
> > talking to me about a study he's doing in psychology where he's modeling
> > the connections between neurons (or something) to see how thought occurs.
> > Mind blowing shit, no doubt.
> > 
> > Strange days are coming......
> > Smileyz;)  Jose

> > there is a *soul* i think in each body, right? reincarnation, and the 

this is the point in the discussion where we divide up into religious camps!

> perscieve were to be like the color green, then we can alter our state of 
> consciousness with, say, LSD, and see teh next color, purple, red, or 
> whatever, depending on the chemical. 

the really interesting question here is...do you have the same experience 
of "red" or any other perception that I do? (seriously putting into 
question the dream of objectivism!)

> then perhaps reality is just consciousness anyway, and like quantum 
> physics states, nothing exists untill it is perscieved. get that. there 
> were no atoms until someone found one.

I would have to take issue with this point here, If there were 
no consciousness to appreciate the universe, then it would probably just 
be a prettylonely place, but it would still exist... although this can 
not be proven...a fun mind experiment to play is to try to find any 
unobjectable truth which can show that anything in the world actually 
exists besides yourself. How do you KNOW that everythiung you see  and 
understand is not merely inside your imagination?
	How I feel on this issue is that there is an objective world out 
there,one that is independant of my or your existance, it is just the 
problem of being a mind that I can not see what it 
<really> is but just my interpretation of it. My model of reality is that 
from the objective world we lay down our models as words and ideas over 
the world. in some places the fit is good (like how we can predict 
planetary motion) and in other places it is a bad fit. But in all cases 
we are just lifting and creating meaning from the world.

> but the energy of the universe is maleable into infinite set of forms, as 
> many as your consciousness can have teh fancy to create or imagine. the 
> bottom line, my friend, is *UNTAPPED POTENTIAL* and that is, imperically, 
> our destination from the beginning.
> dream out loud!

Right on!!

> consider the random probability of the dendancy to exist, when speaking 
> of matter. and how our *expectations*, and those of teh experimenters had 
> a direct influence over where these tendencies to exist would manifest. 
> *our* expectations. do you understand teh implificatiopns of these results.

once again a result of our inability to see the world objectively. And a 
testament to positive thinking and positive ideals-----> to project and 
these into the world.
 > 
> perhaps teh government is well aware of this, having scientists work like 
> mad for truth, so they can twist it into power.
> *fuck politics*

just my personal opinion...but not every politician is evil and greedy... 
they are human beings too, and to objectify them too much is to let 
yourself become unatached from your fellow and the problems that we all 
face as a  society

Wow, now that I have rambled on... you all have a better idea of my 
personal ideology...boy this is fun! 

Now that I have said all this here is the rave related stuff!! I just 
bought the new goa gil cd an dit is awesome!! I highly recomend it!!

thats all for today folks... bye!

trose (aka hierophant)

hello all-
i, being a psych/bio/chemistry/physics student, have some opinions on this
wonderful subject.  i shall vox them now:

i do not use the word mind.  i do not use the word soul.  i do not use the
word life.  i do not use the word death.  all of these words are no longer
in my vocabulary, after i realized the wonderfulness of physicality.

my physical being, your physical being, all physical beings, are capable of
the most wonderful actions and non-actions.  our heart heats.  our liver
converts glucogen into glucose.  our lungs breathe.  our brain interprets
and stores sensory information.  all of these are physical processes,
processes that are observable, physically, chemically, and biologically.
these processes are equal in their interdependance, our brain having it's
own function distinct from the heart and lungs, but neither more nor less
important, regardless of what our rational upbringing tells us about the
pre-eminence of cousciousness.

because these processes are observable and documentable does not make them
bad, nor does it make them less important that the "higher" processes that
we so talk about on SFRAVES.  For me, documentable physicality explains all
that i observe and experience.  it explains why i breathe and metabolize,
why i love my girlfriend, why my heart continues to beat after the drugs i
have put into my body, why i experience wonderful feelings of oneness at
raves and other gatherings, why my liver does the funny things that it does,
why i believe in one and no God, why i can feel such an intense connection
when at a rave or when reading a post SFRAVES, etc.

In Matt language, everything is explainable in terms of physical organisms,
the set of which we are all members.  I do not subscribe to a particular
spirituality that attempts to explain consciousness in terms a higher good,
higher connecting principle, collective unconsciousness, or any thing non
physical, because, for me, my body, your body, and all bodies are the
highest good just as they are.  That does not say that you shouldn't be
spiritual, for that is your language.  i just wish to put a physical
translation to the raver ethic/PLUR out there for the physically minded,
like me.

i love you all for getting to the end of this rambling post!!!!

peace, love, and rambles

matt


matthew d. p. k. lanier
vox 415-666-5659

"Peace within us, peace over us, peace under our feet.
peace behind us, peace around us, let all around us be peace."
     - David Haas

	A poetry teacher of mine once told us to nurture "fruitful 
juxtaposition" in our poems.  I discovered a bit of fruitful 
juxtaposition at the Blondie's Pizza on Powell Street near Market.
	Near the counter is some lettering that says $1.89/lb.  Directly 
to the left, someone affixed a sticker with the words BEATS AND CONCIOUS 
KNOWLEDGE.  So sometimes when I go in to order a slice, I also ask for a 
couple pounds of beats and concious knowledge.  I know a good deal when I 
see one!

Twinkle twinkle,
				*** Starchild ***

> modified.  :) for the humor-impaired.  - Lee

> You're on the dance floor at a party called Infinite Diversity.  The 
> person in front of you is very drunk and keeps banging into you.  You step 
> back and someone grabs your shoulder and shakes it, his jaw twitching
> uncontrollably as he shouts "Hey man, d'ya know where I can score some
> crystal?"  You are about to answer him but the person behind you starts to
> blare a whistle into your ear. You try to move away but the shirtless drunk 
> turns with his arms raised and thrusts a sopping hairy armpit into your face.
> face.  "WOO!  WOO!" he screams while jumping up and down.  You look over to 
> one of the projection screens to see the image of a flower fade into that 
> of a human vivisection.  "Cool, man." say a bunch of sullen cyberpunks all
> dressed in black.  They go back to talking among themselves and you decide
> that maybe you should just focus on dancing.  But then the music abruptly 
> changes from techno to slow reggae and someone blows smoke in your face.
> A few feet away a little kid is pounding out a loud percussion solo on a
> drum kit, completely out of time with the music.  You move closer to have
> a look but there are a lot of people standing around a group of circle
> dancers so you can't get through.  The music changes again, this time to
> some kind of thrash metal song  and a mosh pit starts to form.  A 
> firecracker goes off by your head, and a boot comes crushing down on your
> sneakered foot.  Before you can say "ouch" a skinhead screams "Out of the
> way, faggot!"  None of this bothers you.  As an openminded raver, you are 
> very happy to be in the middle of such diversity.
> 
> - leg of eel

Date: Fri, 17 Nov 1995 03:12:18 -0800 (PST)
From: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: star@orion
To: David Ginsberg <ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: emergent culture...?
In-Reply-To: <v02130501accc3a4cc1b9@[128.32.192.224]>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951117020704.22404C-100000@orion>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

My computer tells me that on Sun, 12 Nov 1995, David Ginsberg shared (in 
part):

> Perhaps then (to use
> simplifying but I think appropriate imagery) our culture is fragmenting,
> and what the emerging 'culture' is resembles a fractal, with ever-changing,
> ever more complex structure which moves us farther and farther away from a
> single, unified objective truth yet closer and closer to our own diverse,
> personal truths.  

Or maybe the single, objective truth is complex, and difficult to see, so 
that in striving for a consensus on the nature of things, it becomes 
easier to accept the idea of multiple truths, even if this does not 
really make too much sense -- unless we redefine truth as meaning "personal 
perception", in which case it makes perfect sense, but leaves us with no 
common vision to aspire to.

While my personal perception of a party as being fun may actually help 
make it fun for others there if this perception is reflected in my 
behavior, unfortunately our perceptions are not always able to change 
reality in this manner, and so fall short of real, objective truth.  You 
can perceive yourself as Wile E. Coyote all you want, it's not going to 
change the fact that if your friend drops an ACME piano on you from a 5th 
floor window, you're not going to get up and walk away from it.

I think we have become so concious about valuing everyone's opinion that 
we are sometimes reluctant to say any idea is wrong, for fear that we 
will be making a value judgement on the person expressing the idea.  
Saying an idea is wrong isn't necessarily passing judgement on anyone.  
Most of us, including myself, need to work on divorcing our egos from our 
belief systems, and removing the chips from our shoulders.

My head is aching from all these deep thoughts, I better quit now.

			     *** Starchild ***

question."
		-Alice in Wonderland, Chapter V (Lewis Carroll)

Hey, thought everyone should at least read this. For all you AOL people out 
here. There is one part I think is kind of funny, They say this program hads 
bugs, that, if it was ran from any drive other then C:...it would delete 
itself. That doesn't sound like a bug to me, sounds like a feature. One that 
wants the hard drive and forgets the floppies disks. It also sounds like a real 
poorly made Virus, but still a virus. Anyway, just want everyone to beware, and 
always use a virus scan when D/L files online.

Tim (knucklehead)  Hope this hasn't been sent before.

______________________________ Forward Header __________________________________
Subject: G-03: AOLGOLD Trojan Alert Bulletin
Author:  mauvais@ocelot.llnl.gov at hwsmtplink
Date:    11/17/95 12:20 AM


             __________________________________________________________
     
                       The U.S. Department of Energy
                    Computer Incident Advisory Capability
                           ___  __ __    _     ___
                          /       |     /_\   /
                          \___  __|__  /   \  \___
             __________________________________________________________
     
                             INFORMATION BULLETIN
     
       AOLGOLD Trojan Program
     
November 16, 1995 1300 PST                                          Number G-03 
_______________________________________________________________________________
     
     
PROBLEM:        A trojan program is being distributed around America
  Online and other networks called AOLGOLD.ZIP.
PLATFORM: DOS-based PCs
DAMAGE:         When the INSTALL.EXE program is executed, most files on the
  users C: drive are deleted.
SOLUTION:       See the description below 
_______________________________________________________________________________
     
VULNERABILITY   
ASSESSMENT:     Users who download the AOLGOLD.ZIP or INSTALL.EXE trojaned
  programs, unpack, and execute them may destroy files on their 
  DOS C: drive.
_______________________________________________________________________________
     
    Information on the AOLGOLD Trojan Program
     
AOLGOLD Trojan
==============
     
The AOLGOLD Trojan program was recently discovered on America Online (AOL). 
Notice about the Trojan has been circulated to all America Online 
subscribers.  Notice about the Trojan and a copy of the Trojan program were 
supplied to CIAC by Doug Bigelow, who is on the staff of America Online.
     
Apparently, an e-mail message is being circulated that contains an attached 
archive file named AOLGOLD.ZIP.  A README file that is in the archive 
describes it as a new and improved interface for the AOL online service. 
Note that there is no such program as AOLGOLD.  Also, simply reading an 
e-mail message or even downloading an included file will not do damage to 
your machine.  You must execute (or run) the downloaded file to release 
the Trojan and have it cause damage.
     
If you unzip the archive, you get two files: INSTALL.EXE and README.TXT. 
The README.TXT file again describes AOLGOLD as a new and improved interface
to the AOL online service.  The INSTALL.EXE program is a self-extracting ZIP 
archive.  When you run the install program, it extracts 18 files onto your 
hard drive:
     
MACROS.DRV
VIDEO.DRV
INSTALL.BAT
ADRIVE.RPT
SUSPEND.DRV
ANNOY.COM
MACRO.COM
SP-NET.COM
SP-WIN.COM
MEMBRINF.COM
DEVICE.COM
TEXTMAP.COM
HOST.COM
REP.COM
EMS2EXT.SYS
EMS.COM
EMS.SYS
README.TXT
     
The file list includes another README.TXT file. If you examine the new 
README.TXT file, it starts out with "Ever wanted the Powers of a Guide" and 
continues with some crude language.  The README.TXT file indicates that the 
included program is a guide program that can be used to kick other people 
off of AOL.
     
If you stop at this point and do nothing but examine the unzipped files 
with the TYPE command, your machine will not be damaged.  The following 
three files contain the Trojan program:
     
MACROS.DRV
VIDEO.DRV
INSTALL.BAT
     
The rest of the files included in the archive appear to have been grabbed 
at random to simply fill up the archive and make it look official.
     
The Trojan program is started by running the INSTALL.BAT file.  The 
INSTALL.BAT file is a simple batch file that renames the VIDEO.DRV file to 
VIRUS.BAT and then runs it.  VIDEO.DRV is an amateurish DOS batch file that 
starts deleting the contents of several critical directories on your C: 
drive, including:
     
c:\
c:\dos
c:\windows
c:\windows\system
c:\qemm
c:\stacker
c:\norton
     
It also deletes the contents of several other directories, including those 
for several online services and games, such as:
     
c:\aol20
c:\prodigy
c:\aol25
c:\mmp169
c:\cserve
c:\doom
c:\wolf3d
     
When the batch file completes, it prints a crude message on the screen and 
attempts to run a program named DoomDay.EXE.  Bugs in the batch file prevent 
the DOOMDAY.EXE program from running.  Other bugs in the file cause it to 
delete itself if it is run from any drive but the C: drive.  The programming 
style and bugs in the batch file indicates that the Trojan writer appears
to have little programming experience.
     
RECOVERY:
- ---------
     
**WARNING** Do not copy any files onto your hard disk before trying to 
recover your hard drive.
     
The files are deleted with the DOS del command, and can be recovered with 
the DOS undelete command.  The files are still on your disk, only the 
directory entries have been removed.  If you copy any new files onto your 
hard disk, they will likely be written over the deleted files, making it 
impossible to recover the deleted files.
     
If you have delete protection installed on your system, recovery will be 
relatively easy.  If not, the DOS undelete command can be used, but you will 
have to supply the first letter of each file name as it is recovered.  In 
many cases, you will probably want to restore the directories by 
reinstalling them from the original installation disks, but do that last. 
You must recover any unreplaceable files first using undelete and then 
replace any others by copying or reinstalling them from the distribution 
disks.
     
To recover the system:
     
1. Boot the system with a clean, locked floppy containing the recovery 
program for the recovery files you have installed, or the DOS UNDELETE.EXE 
program if you do not have recovery files installed.
     
2. Type the VIRUS.BAT file to get a list of the directories the Trojan 
tried to delete. Ignore any directories that don't exist on your machine.
     
3. Run the recovery program and recover your files. You may have to help it 
find the recovery files, such as MIRROR, which will be in the root 
directory. You may have to recover the MIRROR file first and then use it to 
recover the other files.
     
If you are using only the DOS undelete command, type:
     
   undelete directory
     
where directory is the name of the directory to examine. To undelete the 
files in the dos directory, use:
     
   undelete c:\dos
     
The undelete program will present you with a list of deleted files with the 
first letter replaced with a question mark. Without delete protection, you 
will have to supply this letter in order to undelete the file.
     
4. After you have restored as many files as you want or can using the 
UNDELETE command, replace any others by reinstalling them using the 
original installation disks.
     
The Operations staff at America Online has released the following 
bulletin to their users:
     
- --BEGIN MESSAGE--
     
Dear Member:
     
As you know, we strive to keep you informed on various issues regarding 
online safety.
     
We want to take this opportunity to remind you about potential computer 
viruses and Trojan horses and how to protect your computer.  First, a virus 
is a program that is designed to spread and usually attaches itself to a 
program with the goal of spreading to other computers.  A Trojan horse is a 
program that is intended to corrupt your computer but has to be activated 
before it can be executed.  For example, a Trojan horse can be distributed as 
an attached file to an email but the file has to be downloaded and executed 
before harm is done.
     
If you receive email from unknown senders with an attached file, it is a good 
rule of thumb not to download the files.  In addition, if you ever receive a 
file in email you believe could cause problems, please forward it immediately 
to TOSEMAIL1, and explain your concerns to our Terms of Service staff.
     
We have received recent inquiries regarding a Trojan horse that is sent as an 
attached file in an email message entitled "AOLGOLD" and "Install.exe". It is 
important to understand that no virus or Trojan horse can be passed along by 
simply reading email.  However, we strongly urge that if you receive email 
with an attached file with this name not to download it.
     
Due to the private nature of electronic mail, we cannot scan files in email 
for viruses as we do with files in public areas of the service.
     
We have never had an occurrence of a virus or Trojan horse being spread 
through simply reading email.  In order for one to spread to your computer, 
you would have to proactively select the attached file and download it to 
your hard drive.  It is therefore advisable never to download attached files 
from an unknown sender.
     
AOL incorporates virus protection throughout the service and scans all posted 
software, text, and sound files in public areas. We also offer our members 
the Virus Information Center on AOL where you'll find information about the 
latest virus or Trojan horse, along with updates to all the popular 
commercial, shareware, and freeware anti-virus tools.  Keyword: VIRUS.
     
Thank you for taking an active role in maintaining a safe online environment.
     
Sincerely, 
AOL Operations Staff
     
- --END MESSAGE--
     
_______________________________________________________________________________
     
CIAC wishes to thank the staff of America Online, especially Mr. Don Bigelow 
for
their assistance in providing the information necessary to prepare this 
bulletin.
_______________________________________________________________________________
     
CIAC, the Computer Incident Advisory Capability, is the computer security 
incident response team for the U.S. Department of Energy. CIAC is located at 
the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, California. CIAC is 
also a founding member of FIRST, the Forum of Incident Response and Security 
Teams, a global organization established to foster cooperation and 
coordination among computer security teams worldwide.

I just thought, even running virus scan on files might not do the trick. When 
there batch files involved..That says rename (ie..file.sys to file.bat..) then 
tells it to run that batch file which is to delete this directory or that 
directory. Those usually can not be detected because they are just text most of 
the time. So point is, if you unzip a file and see a batch file, view the batch 
files before running them. That way you can hopefully prevent some of the virus 
programs that are made of just batch files. 

Tim (knucklehead)

>Your studies in physics should tell you that the definition of
>"physical" is rather tenuous.  Of course, if you want to use your
>own definitions, that's fine with me.  Just don't expect to be
>understood.

WOW, LEE-
watch the personal mud-slinging, for it has no place here ( of that might
just be my paranoia :)   )

>Exactly what is a thought?

thought is a physical process, in that it is documentable and observable in
terms of neural function.  yes, it's observed in terms of probabilities, but
still observable.  i am just arguing against this language that seems to be
developing that ignores physicality, or at least seems to downgrade in for
the sake of using spiritual words, such as transcendence, consciousness,
etc.  i believe that we, as a whole, are getting further and further away
from the scientific explainations and biological processes that are the root
cause of our existence.  all that we experience at a rave is a product of
our brains, their wonderful power to project what they have learned upon
actual experience, and the fact that, through phermones, etc, they can
interact in largely covert ways.  those are all observable, biological
processes, and our understnaidng of them needs to be cemented in that fact,
that we are biological creatures who go through chemical processes.  i
think, on the whole, we have forgotten that, and because of that, our
theories on the existence of the world, world consciousness, music,
psychology, sexuality, and other subjects are veering further and further
away from scientific observations that we purport, as ravers, to be
approaching.  just like freud is criticized for spouting at the mouth
without much scientific evidence, i see many such postings on SFRAVES.  i do
not disparage the use of such a language, being a catholic myself and being
very spiritual.  but my spirituality is rooted in physicality, my
physicality, my body, which, through linking up with other bodies, can
achieve things only dreamed about.  but we are still bodies, and just that!!!!!

so, that is my soap-box for the day.

ya'll have fun

peace, love, and bodies

matt

> Well, try going through and reading some of the newsgroups sometime. For a 
> start try something like alt.security. Look at all the absolute crap, and 
> compare the signal to noise ratio to say, 5 years ago. Oh yeah, and don't 
> forget all the worthless spammers. It might give you an indication of

Yep:  it's headed for the world.  Or rather, the world is headed for 
USENET.  Time was, only a few technogeeks knew how to use this stuff, 
and they all knew about netiquette.  Now the rest of the world is 
coming on board, and it's time to adapt or die.

I use much much much better newsreading and email software now than I 
did back then.  I can read many more newsgroups much more quickly, 
even with all the fluff and spam.  And I'm really glad that all these 
new folks are on the net, even if lots of them are relatively 
clueless.

Five years ago, sfraves itself wasn't nearly as hopping as it is now. 
Growth has its good side and its bad side.  I prefer to go with the 
flow and learn to surf more efficiently, since all the newbies are as 
entitled to this net--and to the ability to say what's on their 
mind--as you or I were back in the day.
Rob Jellinghaus     robj@unreal.com     http://www.best.com/~robj

If I had a crystal ball, it says to me that things will continue to 
degenerate, and eventually people will call for moderation of all 
newsgroups because a) 90% of the posts no longer have anything to do with 
the subject of the newsgroup, and b) No one has the self-control to 
moderate themselves. So someone will have to do it for them. What a sad 
day that will be, when censorship is required because a bunch of 
clueless gits can't figure out that the name of the newsgroup is 
supposed to have a lot to do with the subject(s) discussed.

As an alternate time-line, everyone will join 

A) Microsoft Network
B) AOL
C) E-world

(*SHUDDER*) 

> I use much much much better newsreading and email software now than I 
> did back then.  I can read many more newsgroups much more quickly, 
> even with all the fluff and spam.  And I'm really glad that all these 
> new folks are on the net, even if lots of them are relatively 
> clueless.

Well I guess that makes one of us. I don't have a problem with people 
that are new to the Internet. That is how I make my living. What I have a 
problem with is people that get indignant when you explain to them that 
they are doing something that is considered rude. 

> Five years ago, sfraves itself wasn't nearly as hopping as it is now. 
> Growth has its good side and its bad side.  I prefer to go with the 
> flow and learn to surf more efficiently, since all the newbies are as 
> entitled to this net--and to the ability to say what's on their 
> mind--as you or I were back in the day.
> Rob Jellinghaus     robj@unreal.com     http://www.best.com/~robj

Yup. It would just be nice if these people would post to a forum:

A) Appropriate for what ever is on there mind
B) Where anyone gave a damn about what they are saying.

                                         Black Adder

P.S. No flames about off-subject posts please. I am just following the 
     new consensus rule here that seems to state we all can talk about 
     totally unrelated subjects here.

> Well, try going through and reading some of the newsgroups sometime. For a 
> start try something like alt.security. Look at all the absolute crap, and 
> compare the signal to noise ratio to say, 5 years ago. Oh yeah, and don't 
> forget all the worthless spammers. It might give you an indication of 
> where the USENET is headed. 

	I remember, shortly before the light bulb was invented, when people were 
bitching that they couldn't read a full global usenet feed anymore due to all 
the "newbies".  Since then (1982 or so) the collapse has been pretty much 
constantly predicted, as a feed went thru the 1 and 10 MB levels.

	Usenet and mailing lists remain one of the most bandwidth-efficient and 
easily filtered mediums around (if not the most).  This is why the sky, although 
always falling, never hits.  The comparison to CB radio really doesn't work.

	Eudora is free.  Unix equivalents exist (usually bundled). The 
point-and-click technology has been around since the "laurel" agent for the 
Alto (1979)...  I'm sure everyone can find what they need to easily ignore what 
they don't want to see, even if its mailx, pine, elm or mh...  and if you want 
to get really fancy you can set author, subject and/or text filters on many 
systems, which put different kinds of mail in different mailboxes (although I 
will admit that the UI's on most filterers suck)...

	Technology over tyranny -- thats what I say.

Andrew

Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

Good arguments both sides but it doesn't need to be a big deal...

Two quick options...

1. Eveyone follow the guideline of adding "Non-Rave" to the subject line of
posts not directly related. Then  SIMPLY sort your incoming mail and trash
those pesky non-rave related ones if you don't like them or just don't have
time. (are sort options that rare, difficult, or time consuming?)

2. Start up a second list called SFRavesCommunity or some such name and have
it for all the stuff that's not directly rave related but is related to our
community and the way we live (I'd definetly subscribe).

I know there are possible problems with both these suggestions but I also
know there must be some simple solution that will work for most of us...

peace,
martin

Message-Id: <9511172051.AA04979@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Subject: Re: consciousness/evolution
To: lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.EDU (Matthew D. P. K. Lanier)
Date: Fri, 17 Nov 1995 12:51:04 -0800 (PST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199511171651.IAA00617@taz.hyperreal.com> from "Matthew D. P. K. Lanier" at Nov 17, 95 08:48:12 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3282      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> >Exactly what is a thought?
> 
> thought is a physical process, in that it is documentable and observable in
> terms of neural function.  yes, it's observed in terms of probabilities, but
> still observable.  i am just arguing against this language that seems to be
> developing that ignores physicality, or at least seems to downgrade in for
> the sake of using spiritual words, such as transcendence, consciousness,
> etc.  i believe that we, as a whole, are getting further and further away
> from the scientific explainations and biological processes that are the root
> cause of our existence.  all that we experience at a rave is a product of
> our brains, their wonderful power to project what they have learned upon

Is consciousness the epiphenomenon of physicality,
or is physicality the epiphenomenon of consciousness...

I think that given all we know and have learned these last 400 years
exploring the material world of newtonian mechanics says pretty clearly
that we cannot understand thought as a physical process at all.  We are
no closer to understanding ourselves than we were then... wait, understanding
our non physical selves.  oh yeah, that doesn't really exist.
Sure, we can develop mind expanding drugs, and suck out tumors from our
body, and cure sickness, and drive really fast, and zip the zapiddy techno
zoodad... but in the end, has anything really changed?  Do people love
more or dance harder?  I just think that an entirely physical universe
discredits so many aspects of life (does that even really exist?) that
I find it hard to use as my answer of the truth.  I think that it's
dangerous not to use words that don't have physicality as the root 
cause of existance.  It discredits life, love, hate, any transcendant
idea.  and maybe from the perspective of a perfect material universe
it doesn't matter that these ideas are discredited... but how then
will meaning ever truly be known?  as an epiphenomenon of a machine?
The problem with an infinate machine is that it has no meaning, unless
there is a transcendant order.  I think that order is the root of
free will, the beholder of meaning, the spark of our life itself.
Some people like to call such an idea god, or just our consciousness,
some settle on just the word infinite itself... a mathematical relation
in a mechanical universe...  but I think the point is that somehow or other
we will always be confronted with our thoughts, meanings, feelings,
transcendant ideas... and unless we give them direct credit, rather
than definitions of epiphenomena, we will never truly understand them.  

anyway... I find it funny that I decided long ago that the universe
was a perfect system, deterministic to the end, with free will as an
illusion, and a funny accident that I should find myself here to consider
it at all... and then I went on to learn all the rules and relations,
the beauty of physics, and more physics, and more... and now, one month
before I graduate I've completely changed my mind on the whole thing.
The world is a very funny, beautiful thing... and I'm sorry if 
funny and beauty just don't really exist... just delusion found in the
midst of chaos.  I prefer to think that they are fundamental qualities
of our existance.

I hope the weekend treats you well,
-john.

Date: Fri, 17 Nov 95 13:56:15 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


In addition to prefacing subject lines with stuff like BSP, "Non Rave"
or whatever perhaps we can preface all meta discussions with meta:,
since these are the one's i'm least interested in hearing. I wonder if
anybody else feels like meta-discussions often take up more bandwidth
with more boring bullshit than non-germane (and I ain't talkin' Jackson!)
posts.

Furthermore, we should allow free combinations of prefaces so that we
can determine the stage of conversational development, just how ripe
and stanky the verbiage has become (e.g. like a fine cheddar,runny 
brie, gruyere, or parmesan). For example, a message with a title like
this
 META: ANAL-RETENTIVE: NO!-FUCK-YOU: FUCK-YOU!: NON-RAVE: have a nice day.
would be a definite 'd' for most people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

On Fri, 17 Nov 1995, Andrew Knutsen wrote:

> 	I remember, shortly before the light bulb was invented, when people were 
> bitching that they couldn't read a full global usenet feed anymore due to all 
> the "newbies".  Since then (1982 or so) the collapse has been pretty much 
> constantly predicted, as a feed went thru the 1 and 10 MB levels.

I never predicted a collapse. I don't see a collapse forthcoming. What I 
see is moderation due to the lack of self-moderation that is becoming 
rampant.

> 	Eudora is free.  Unix equivalents exist (usually bundled). The 
> point-and-click technology has been around since the "laurel" agent for the 
> Alto (1979)...  I'm sure everyone can find what they need to easily ignore what 
> they don't want to see, even if its mailx, pine, elm or mh...  and if you want 
> to get really fancy you can set author, subject and/or text filters on many 
> systems, which put different kinds of mail in different mailboxes (although I 
> will admit that the UI's on most filterers suck)...
> 

Great, so now we can all filter out shit that should have never been 
posted. Which of course is almost impossible to do. How do you know what 
to filter? How do you know that a line that is filtered isn't contained 
in a larger text that may be relevant? Filters, other than someone 
putting "Not XXXXXX related" or filtering mail from particular persons, 
are not very viable. Why should anyone have to jump through hoops to filter 
things that are irrelevant? Instead of being upset about people posting 
inapproriately, people get upset because they think someone is one is 
trying to rob them of their right to free speech. 


> 	Technology over tyranny -- thats what I say.

Why is it so difficult for people to figure out this is not about some 
tyrannical power-trip? "Because people get upset because I post whatever 
I want wherever I want, they are trying to censor me!" What a bunch of 
absolute, unmitigated CRAP. 

Ever hear the definition of free speech that stated that you have the 
unabridged right to say what you want where you want, except for example, 
you couldn't yell "FIRE!" in a crowded theater?

Altering this a bit for use as an analogy, say that you are in that same 
theater trying to watch that great movie. Except that the person in the 
next row and their friend next to you are talking loudly, preventing you 
from hearing most of the movie. There is no law against them talking in 
the theater. But does this mean that you should have to move down so you 
can fully hear the movie, because the shmucks are too inconsiderate of 
others to realize that there are people trying to watch the movie? If you 
ask them to shut up, are you now stifling them, trying to interfere with 
their right to free speech, when all you are trying to do is watch the 
movie? 


                                        Black Adder

If people are going to whine and complain that they cant simply hit 
delete if the subject line says non-rave then we should switch to idea 2. 
my main argument for this is that we are a community here and we are 
friends her, I dont run  around campus to the political science 
departments anytime I want to find someone to taslk about politics with, 
I usually turn to my friends. And this is why I would like to have 
suggestion 2 as an alternative to simply putting non-rave in the header 
(much simpler) and just encourage people to folloe the rule...also maybe 
certain peopl;e dont think that politics or consciousness ides are rave 
related but to me they are very much related to the scene, and to the 
sense of cummunity i get from being on thisd list, if all we talked about 
are how party x is and wht dj played what then i feel like we would be 
skipping a huge part of what the scenen really means to alot of us, like
the ideas we have while dancing, how politics may affect us etc...

-Trose (aka hierophant)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Nov 17 15:16:04 1995

Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA07618; Fri, 17 Nov 1995 15:15:54 -0800
Received: from [128.32.192.224] (ch051.Chance.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.192.224]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id PAA24131; Fri, 17 Nov 1995 15:15:31 -0800
Date: Fri, 17 Nov 1995 15:15:31 -0800
Message-Id: <v02130501acd253b9f871@[128.32.192.224]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
To: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
From: ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu (David Ginsberg)
Subject: Re: emergent culture...? NON-RAVE
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 3:12 AM 11/17/95, Starchild wrote:
>My computer tells me that on Sun, 12 Nov 1995, David Ginsberg shared (in
>part):
>
>> Perhaps then (to use
>> simplifying but I think appropriate imagery) our culture is fragmenting,
>> and what the emerging 'culture' is resembles a fractal, with ever-changing,
>> ever more complex structure which moves us farther and farther away from a
>> single, unified objective truth yet closer and closer to our own diverse,
>> personal truths.
>
>Or maybe the single, objective truth is complex, and difficult to see, so
>that in striving for a consensus on the nature of things, it becomes
>easier to accept the idea of multiple truths, even if this does not
>really make too much sense -- unless we redefine truth as meaning "personal
>perception", in which case it makes perfect sense, but leaves us with no
>common vision to aspire to.
>
>While my personal perception of a party as being fun may actually help
>make it fun for others there if this perception is reflected in my
>behavior, unfortunately our perceptions are not always able to change
>reality in this manner, and so fall short of real, objective truth.  You
>can perceive yourself as Wile E. Coyote all you want, it's not going to
>change the fact that if your friend drops an ACME piano on you from a 5th
>floor window, you're not going to get up and walk away from it.
>
There are some problems with the belief in a single objective truth.  For
example, some species of birds, and bees and other animals, have four or
more dimensions in their color space (they have 4 types of receptors where
we have 3).  This doesn't just mean that they see more or brighter colors
than we do.  We can't even imagine what they do see, but we can use
Einstein's imaginative way of conceiving 4 dimensions and give colors a
4th, temporal dimension (i.e. they flash on and off or somthing) as a way
to understand what this may mean.  Now, from an objective point of view,
which way of perceiving  the world is right?  Ours?  Theirs?  Yours?  Mine?
Hmmm.  It's not as easy as a saturday morning cartoon.  There are an
infinite number of degrees here, and while some things may occur in a
determinate fashion, there are just as many which are indeterminate.  Any
view comes from a particular perspective, and is therefore partial and
incomplete.  To speak of some sort of absolute objectivity, a 'God's-eye
view' or whatever is to speak of a view from nowhere, and I can't
comprehend what that could possibly mean.

Embrace the chaos - it is the embodiment of freedom!

>I think we have become so concious about valuing everyone's opinion that
>we are sometimes reluctant to say any idea is wrong, for fear that we
>will be making a value judgement on the person expressing the idea.
>Saying an idea is wrong isn't necessarily passing judgement on anyone.
>Most of us, including myself, need to work on divorcing our egos from our
>belief systems, and removing the chips from our shoulders.
>
We also long so dearly for an absolute ground for our beliefs  (why?
insecurity maybe) that we actually fool ourselves into believing such a
thing exist.  I think this is the far more common problem in our culture
(Western culture, not rave culture).  I understand your desire to find an
absolute Truth...I think we'd all like that.  But I think the more you
search (I've done alot...30 years now) the more you come to see that there
simply isn't anything absolute, and truth starts with you and your own
experiences, and is probably statistical and analog rather than binary and
determinate.

>My head is aching from all these deep thoughts, I better quit now.
>
>                             *** Starchild ***

Take two Xperin, drink plenty of liquids, and call me in the morning...

David


****************************************************************************

David Ginsberg
ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu
Student of Philosophy and Cognitive Science
University of California at Berkeley

****************************************************************************

Precedence: bulk

> But I think the more you
> search (I've done alot...30 years now) the more you come to see that there
> simply isn't anything absolute, and truth starts with you and your own
> experiences, and is probably statistical and analog rather than binary and
> determinate.

	I agree with this to a certain extent...  like when I see someone 
telling a tripper that they really can fly off the building, if they just 
*believe*.  Its hasn't worked yet, and I think the objective reality of gravity 
is sufficiently well proven that it should be taken as fact by *everyone*.  I 
don't want to invade your beliefs, but if I see you considering a jump, I'll 
seriously consider trying to talk you out of it rather than consider it an 
experiment in indeterminate reality.  (That is, if I'm not tripping too hard 
too, in which case I hope I'll let you do the experiment instead of me :-).

	There are other somewhat rave-related situations too...  like believing 
your soul will power you when you've dehydrated dancing...  belief in objective 
reality has done our medical sciences well, much to all our benefit.

Andrew

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Nov 17 17:54:36 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA20669; Fri, 17 Nov 1995 17:54:36 -0800

We're giving out evaluation/teaser copies of our multimedia authoring
environment for creating HTML 2.0 pages. There's much work to be done
on the WYSIWYG editing part of this application, and we're working on
an all new version now. However, current public release of WWWeasel is
quite useful if you want to grab media, links, text annotations, etc.
and incorporate them into new or existing documents, then publish them
to our experimental Web server. You can also use WWWeasel to edit your
existing HTML pages in structure mode (sort of like an outliner), and
use our DTD-based parser to evaluate how closely your HTML corresponds
to the HTML 2.0 specification. WWWeasel includes built in facilities
for capturing media via drag-and-drop from the SGI IndigoMagic desktop,
live video camera snapshots and mpeg movies (SGI), screen snapshot,
file/URL browser and audio recording/playback (all unix platforms).

	See http://www.eit.com/software/wwweasel for more information
	and a link to a registration forms allowing you to download
	the software (for free).

Sometime early next year (??), I hope to release WWWeasel II which is a
complete reimplementation of the editing part supporting true
netscape-like WYSIWYG presentation/editing, and a much faster
implementation. We'll also be supporting some of the more commonly used
HTML 3.0 tags, as well as some netscape extensions (centering,
background color/tile, text color, floating images), and it'll be
extensible to support creating your favorite HTML constructs as
"macros", "dynamic macros" (e.g. fetch information from a database or
programmatic query) etc. The extension language is WINTERP extended
with a C and Winterp-Lisp object oriented programming support for
manipulating HTML at a very high level (see 
http://www.eit.com/software/winterp).

!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!
!   Niels Mayer ..... mayer@eit.com   ! http://www.eit.com/~mayer           !

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA04847; Sat, 18 Nov 1995 14:30:40 -0800
Received: from netcom22.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA04830; Sat, 18 Nov 1995 14:30:34 -0800

	id OAA14788; Sat, 18 Nov 1995 14:29:06 -0800
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Message-Id: <199511182229.OAA14788@netcom22.netcom.com>
Subject: Chrysalis Review ( one guy's opinions )
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 18 Nov 1995 14:29:06 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3263      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Chrysalis Review:

 After getting the directions at the hard-to-get-to/hard-to-leave map point , 
I drove to the site , which was in an industrial part of Oakland. A group of us
wandered about on the sidewalk, fustrated at being able to hear the music
but not get in - no open door!

 I finally located some of the event organizers - including Ethan Miller - at 
a door around the corner . I had walked past it just before they opened up
for admissions.

 Chrysalis was in a nice clean warehouse . Curtains were hung along the 
length of the building , and the area on the right was the dancefloor and main
chill area. The other side was basically unused except for a port-a-sans and 
bathroom area - a nice large space for zooming around in if the dancefloor
density was too high. Actually , the tickets sold by the map point technique 
kept the attendance down to a comfortable density on the dancefloor all night.

 As I walked in , Galen was spinning , doing his usual great job. I like his 
taste in music. The sound was coming out of four speaker stacks set at the 
corners of the dancefloor. With the exception of the occasional problems 
with turntables and distortion , the sound was good all night.

 Visuals were provided by two video projections of computer graphics and 
fantasy film clips ; there were also some well-placed strobe lights , lasers 
and intellibeams. 

 There were three other rooms , about the size of bedrooms. Two were set up
with speakers for  ambient/jungle music provided by DJs and some live
musicians ( can someone else who was there identify who all the musicians 
and DJs were ? I know Seth for sure ). Also , two of the rooms had massage
tables set one ( one belonging and being operated by Brian Darkness ). These
rooms got filled up fast , so I missed a lot of the live music performances.

 I had a great time! My personal best moment happened when I was dancing
to the sound of the conga drummers who were set up next to one of speaker 
stacks. The combination of the aural mix of the techno music and the conga
drummers , with the visual stimulation of a wicked overhead strobe light,
just put me into another intense immediate state of conciousness for a few
sweet brief irreplaceble seconds. 

 The rest of Chrysalis was nice too! I had a lot of SFRavers greet me - I think
my "rave goggles" help to identify me. ( Note to the folks I met last night -
as the accuracy of my hearing , and the lighting , wasn't too good last night,
please say hello to me again in future events if it seems like I don't recognize
you! ). Non-SFRavers came up and complimented me on my red eyewear during
the night ,so I guess I'll be wearing them quite often - I even found a solution
to the fogging problem. I always suspected that the frames were designed for
someone with a larger nose. I tested this by rolling up a rave flyer and putting
it behind the nose bridge - no more fog! I think I'll build that area up with
something more comfortable than folded cardboard.
 
 Many compliments to the Gateway Sound System folks and all their fellow
travelers that helped to put Chrysalis together. Great RAVE!  

 ( I hope the sound system problems get fixed )

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
( It's almost 3PM - I'm going to bed ! )

      expected to be made by approx Nov. 30, 1995.

        President Bill Clinton
        1600 Pennslyvania Ave. NW
        Washington DC  20500
        fax (202)456-2461
        email president@whitehouse.gov
        voice (202)456-1111
White House Comments Line hrs: 6:00 am - 2:00 pm PST

There are many reasons to veto the Budget Resolution,
including that it allows the Arctic National Wildlife
Refuge to be opened to oil drillers. These private
companies will build roads, rigs and pipelines in our
nation's public Refuge, driving the carabou off their
birthing grounds. A 20,000 year cycle of life will
be lost forever. And the Gwich'in people have their
survival at stake, for their way of life and very
existence depend on the caribou. Please urge President
Clinton to veto the Budget Resolution  - a veto will
save the Refuge and the Gwich'in people's future.

good to be back!

Hello and good morning all-

I just composed a letter about this and then accedently deleted it so here
goes another....

Well I guess you all know about Kundalini - the whole WC police squad showing
up for this "little" gattering.  I have always had phun at Kundalini untill
last night. I got there around 2 so I didn't end up losing my 20 buck but I
feel for all those confused, ripped off, spun, dissapointed ravers leaving
the place.  You gotta know that the party is going to be busted when you book
a 350 ppl max space next to a bart station and expect 800 or more people to
be happy till dawn.  Well my night went from down-to-earth to outerspace
because DJ Sausee invited a post-Kundalin-break-up party  at his house.
  I had a great time, Sausee is great and he can really rock th house.  He
had over hundred people show up and put on a phat house party in his
bassment.  It was hot - sticky - groovy and beautyful.  The people were
great, vibe was excelent, and man did I dance my ass off today (er yesterday,
both).  Sausee was first in the first room and then came Carlos.  He cut his
records up and left them on the floor to melt.  Great sounds I heard from
him.  I don't remember who was in the other room -Dreamer? but aroung 6.30?
we brought the set up stairs to dance outside to the sunrise :) Dreamer and
Pat allan switched back-and-fortha and Sausee and Dreamer closed out.  Great
party   -just don't drink too much water-  I hope I might have met any of you
there - I met alot o strangers today and now have alot more friends.  Around
9 we left and went to a friends house to keep spinnin' and groovin'.  I
needed to rest so i am writing this before I crash.  Kundalini didn' bring me
down today and I hope you all found something exciting to do this weekend.
Happy Thanks Givin' all and to all a good night

333333333333333333333
L-    Austin  - 

http://www.geopage.com/SunsetStrip/1907/
333333333333333333333

Dear All;

	Very initially briefly; @ the Crysalis rave map point one of 
Gateway's dearest contributors, while a shotgun pointed at him was robbed 
of Crysalis ticket money. Also while cleaing up, another one of our 
dearest was put in a choak hold & robbed at gun point outside the warehouse, 
less than 10 yards away from everyone else inside. 

	Watch your people at your map points, never have more than $50.00 
on anyone person @ anyone time, do not break or make change for large 
bills either, other suggestions should follow. Does anyone have an old 
drop style safe lieing around?

	I don't mean to say I told you so, but I warned about a more 
organized effort to do just this type of robbery, MONTHS AGO. We could 
have had 2 of our friends dead right know, thank god we don't. WE ARE 
VULDERABLE, PLEASE BE CAREFUL.

	   Peace, Love & Happy Holidays From Across Cyberspace

On Sun, 19 Nov 1995, Jose Talavera wrote:


> 
>         I'm real fucked  uuup right  now, so excuse my bad grammar.  You
> know, dancing is communication on a level  much closer to what IS.  I found
> that out tonight.  It's  profoundly intimate and sexual as well...
> You  know what I'm saying?  Anyways, keeep the   house cool over
> there on the West Side of the 
*SNIP*
 
dancing is my spiritual release, always. you know some of the trance here 
is designed specificaly with the idea of how music affects teh body. it 
is the new evolution in *our culture*. SF is a focal point of some 
interesting?intense energy. were spoiled out here, spoiled rotten, its 
said by many who visit the scene. but its all teh people working together 
on this one, not just leaving it up to *big* promoters who always 
consider their pockets first.(well, its a big consideration, not *all* 
are dirty rotten theives, dont mean to stereotype)
anyways, everyone gets involved, from bringing some fruit to share in the 
morning, to spinning mad trance and teh like, to smiling and spreading a 
positive vibe, to lugging heavy equipment to the beach under a full moon, 
building a fire, giving a hug, crazy laser shows and visuals (and taking 
little or no $ home after teh event - thats teh big one)
*dancing* is communication with the higher energies that arent that much 
higher if one is conscious?aware. (of everyone, of themselves) teh love 
and energy flow naturally from that moment of mystical transcendence. 
(which isnt some big spiritual idea, but a down to earth feeling 
many have experienced, im sure, its that point during the night when 
something clicks, and everybody throws their hands in the air, teh music 
is extra clear, and so is everything. its that moment that is talked 
about after, but its hard to find vocabulary enough to describe it...   
you just *feel* it.) 
"were dancing the design of our new culture." - someone i cant remember.

I aggree with Brian's comments, and wanted to share my own:


	There appears to be a developing problem at parties...   Root of 
conscious, and Chrysalis  both had their map points robbed forcefully, by 
men wielding guns.  These men, or friends of theirs, showed up at 
Chrysalis, came inside, and talked with some of the kids (including 
myself) trying to obtain as much knowledge as possible.  
	Being the friendly raver that I am, gave this man some love, 
sensing that his energy was FUCKED...  He pushed me for more info, but 
eventually I had to break off the conversation to continue taking down my 
lighting gear.  He appeared strange, but almost friendly.  It was obvious 
that he was on some kind of speedy drug (coke, meth, crack) jittery, 
running around, talking too much.  He was tweaked, but intelligent in a 
very scary way.  
	There were many reports of cars getting broken into that night, 
and a couple muggings at gun point (myself included).  I imagine he 
targeted me because he knew I was working, and knew I'd get paid...  

	This is a word of warning...  

	ravers:	stick together,    !strength in numbers!

	promoters:	up your security budget.  especially at map 
points, and around parking areas.  

	It feels like they will continue, they're probably making good money.

	It's really too bad that the governmental powers that be, kick us 
out of legitimate spaces, forcing events to take place with 
in-appropriate security.   Subsequently putting the attendees in 
potential danger.  

	Love ya all.

	e

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Wow.  I'm glad someone mentioned this.  I think I met one of the people 
you mentioned was at Chrysalis.  I immediately noticed his 
confrontational (and scary) attitude when he responded extremely 
defensively to a friendly comment I made about his shirt.  I got away 
from him as quickly as possible. 
	I couldn't get him out of my mind as I tried to dance the 
encounter away, so I decided to go back to him and talk things out.  
The experience really freaked me out and very nearly ruined what had 
otherwise been an awesome night.  I figured confronting my fear of him 
would be the best thing to do.  
	He invited me to sit down with him in the chill room--a somewhat 
friendly gesture.  He then proceeded to talk at me (not to me) in an extremely 
agitated tone, gesticulating wildly, saying that he was on parole, that 
drug laws are fucked up, that raves were a lot like the cocaine circles 
he used to be a part of (??), that most ravers are full of shit, that 
most people are full of shit, that the school I go to is rascist, that drug 
laws are fucked up, that the government can't stop people from committing 
murder because its a part of the natural cycle of selection (??--I'm 
paraphrasing here).  Mind you, at this point, I was just nodding agreement 
and mumbling "uhuh", waiting for an appropriate time to get up and leave.  
He was talking so loudly that he was noticeably perturbing the people around 
him.  
	At some point in his monologue, this guy offered me a hit off of what I 
believe was a (???) crack pipe (???).  At that point I knew pretty 
decisively that I should not be dealing with this fellow.  Whether what 
he offered me was indeed crack, I don't know (I didn't want to ask), but 
I agree with LMNT's comment--this guy was definitely on something that 
you don't see or want at a rave.  
	In addition, I'm really sorry that some much bad shit happened at 
Chrysalis and to the great people who threw the party.  

	Any comments?  Questions?  I'm purposely omitting this guy's 
description because I don't intend to be accusing or impugning anyone 
here--I just wanted to tell my story.



	thanks,



			BK-jon

>
>Chrysalis Review:

> There were three other rooms , about the size of bedrooms. Two were set up
>with speakers for  ambient/jungle music provided by DJs and some live
>musicians ( can someone else who was there identify who all the musicians 
>and DJs were ? I know Seth for sure ). Also , two of the rooms had massage
>tables set one ( one belonging and being operated by Brian Darkness ). These
>rooms got filled up fast , so I missed a lot of the live music performances.

That was Consciousness Lab Ambient Sound Research doing the live stuff and
dj'ing.  I think there was atleast one other dj there, but I'm not sure who.
C-Lab is a collective of dj's and musicians that includes many people.
Ambient is the main style you will hear from C-Lab, but occasionally you
will hear others like trip hop, jungle, etc.

Rick

        Well it was my 21st b-day this weekend and this being the infamous

people outside and then two minutes later a fight breaks out(@ a
Rave?!)well i being well informed, we'll go to AD,no problem...on to san

go home..no big deal(it's hard for me to get depressed anymore) then today

X-Sender: handi@taz.hyperreal.com
To: sfraves@squishy.com
Subject: Raves from an eskimo's perspective (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.951119215228.4089C-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>

Date: Sun, 19 Nov 1995 04:37:25 -0500 (EST)
From: Sealion@cris.com
Subject: Raves from an eskimo's perspective (fwd)

This is really cool..

> 
>    Waqaa (pronounced wok'-ah) to all those on the rave net.  Waqaa,
> in case you're wondering, is hello in my native language Yupik and
> Yupik is the language of the central Eskimos of Alaska.  I am one of
> those Eskimos and I am currently attending school at Loyola
> University of Chicago.  My purpose of this posting is to let everyone
> know of my existence in hopes to make a lot of new friends through
> the system and also to share with you my experience (spiritual) with
> raving.
>    Back in my hometown, Bethel, Alaska, which is located 400 miles
> directly west of Anchorage, I held very strong ties to my culture. 
> The only part of my culture (also a very big part) that I lack of is
> the ability to speak my language fluently.  Other than that I hunt,
> fish, dance, and take part in many other cultural events.  
>    Eskimo dancing is the greatest event that I have ever gotten into.
> I take so much pride in dancing to songs that my grandparents have
> danced and sang, and their grandparents, and their grandparents
> before them.  Not only is it the pride, but the extreme spiritual
> feeling I receive from it.  Hearing the drumbeats and the voices of
> the elders singing in unison would bring me to such a euphoric state
> that I could not be taken down by anything.  At dance practice while
> everyone would take a break from dancing, I'd remain kneeling in
> anticipation, with my dance fans in my hand, for the next song to
> begin.  At dance festivals when a member of the audience yelled,
> "pumyaa" (pronounced bum-e-yaw and meaning encore) I would gladly
> repeat the dance with all the energy I had left, to please the
> audience, myself, and my people.  I have so much love and spiritual
> closeness to Eskimo dancing, however, since I've been here, I've not
> been able to take part in it.  In fact, the last time I was in Alaska
> was in June '95, and the next time I'll be back will be in May '96,
> so I've been completely taken away from all parts of my culture.
>    While trying to find something exciting and fun to do at Loyola, I
> failed at it when going to frat parties only to see the "high and
> mighty" fraternity brothers slam beers down as fast as they could.  I
> then started going to parties at De Paul where they had a lot of
> dancing to hip-hop, old skool, and reggae, but as soon as the house
> music came on, I'd find myself meandering off to the sides and
> standing against the wall, because I couldn't quite do all the "name"
> dance moves (you know what I mean by "name": "running man", "Roger
> Rabbit", "Butterfly", "Tootsie Roll").  Finally, the opportunity
> arose for me to attend a rave.  My friends told me not to expect much
> because it was free and on extremely short notice, but that didn't
> phase me one bit.
>    The feeling was strange.  I didn't know what it was, because it
> had been such a long time since I felt that same way, and it was only
> while I was eskimo dancing that I felt it.  When looking on the floor
> at all the other people, I noticed that none of them were doing those
> "name" dance moves and also that everybody was dancing by themselves,
> facing towards the source of the music.  After sitting against the
> wall for a few minutes, I closed my eyes and started moving my head,
> much like I do when I'm about to Eskimo dance.  Then the beat from
> the music was taken away.  I opened my eyes and looked on the dance
> floor noticing that the people dancing appeared to be gliding on the
> floor.  Their movements were so smooth; once again much like Eskimo
> dancing.  I stood up and walked over to the dance floor in the
> attempts to emulate the movements of everyone else, and only a few
> seconds after I started dancing did the beat drop back in and when it
> came back in, it hit me H-A-R-D!  By hard I mean that the music
> hypnotized me.  My attempts to dance like those surrounding me were
> no more. I wasn't able to think, or try to choreograph my movements.
> Everything that came out of my body, came out because I experienced
> the same feeling that all of you (or at least most of you) feel when
> you go to raves; that spiritual feeling received by the entire aura
> around you.
>    I immediately told my oldest brother about it and he replied
> saying that he felt the exact same way, when he went to his first
> party. What is it about raves that is so spiritual. . . here's my
> theory:  In the U.S. are many types of people of different ethnic
> backgrounds, however, not all of these people take part in their own
> culture, or have much knowledge on it.  How can they? If your history
> comes from Germany, France, Zimbabwe, Afghanistan, or where ever, but
> neither you, your parents, or grandparents were born their, then your
> culture really is American.  And by being an American we have the
> right to create anything we wish to be included in our culture; after
> all, this country really had no culture (at least to the Europeans,
> it didn't, who took the land from the natives who lived here before,
> but I don't want to get into that now) and so we must build our own. 
> Raving is part of the American culture, much like Eskimo dancing is
> part of my native culture.  It is something that unites people, and
> brings them to a higher level of mind-spirituality.  It is something
> that I'm glad I found while here in Chicago.  I feel complete now
> because I have found the other half of me, the African-American, or
> should I just say American half (My father is Eskimo my mother is
> African American)?  I have a long journey through life, and when I
> lived in Alaska I promised to myself and my people, that I will be
> dancing until the day that I die.  Now, I can tell all of you, that
> I'll be raving for a long time (not until I die; I probably won't be
> as energetic, but certainly for a large portion of my life).
>    I'm glad to have announced this to all of you, and I want you all
> to realize that raving has touched a great many of people, including
> Eskimos.  I'm looking forward to hearing from many of you.  Also, if
> you have any questions about Eskimos (no I don't live in an igloo,
> and I've never seen one, and the Alaska Natives never lived in them)
> or Alaska in general, then you're more than welcome to ask me and
> I'll try to answer them as well as I possibly can.  Quyana Caknek!
> 
> Torin "Seal" Kuiggpak Jacobs
> 
>

I remember after many, many hours of crackin' on (over 24 to say the
least), I would come home and cool my brain to that channel!  The videos
are a complete trip, the rhythms, and of course that near atonal singing is
enough to enahnce any come-down!  Since I don't crackerjack all that often
anymore, I harldy watch it.

But it's on for 1/2 a day on sundays, then it's replaced by Jaam-E-Jamm
(Persian news, & music).

SF has it's bright moments!

From: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin )
Subject: Tapes of Chrysalis?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hello,

While at Chrysalis I noticed a Dat recorder hooked up and a bunch of 
tapes on it.  Apparently some recording might have taken place.  That 
doesn't mean it will be available to the public but if it is please, 
please, please let me know.  I am particulary interested in John 
Carel's set.  

Every dj that night kicked ass.  The party was perfect (I wouldn't 
expect less from gateway).  The people were awesome.  The vibe was 
awesome.  The location (minus robberies)  was great.  It was even what 
I would consider a near-by party coming from Sac.  Loved it!!

There has been talk in the past about worshipping dj's like rock-stars 
or something.  I don't know anything about that but for the second time 
(the first being Gateway's moonlight party)  John Carel has blown me 
away completely!  The dance floor was breaking down.  I myself had to 
sit for lack of energy.  Than the record Eternal Prayer was put on.  I 
have a compilation cd with this song and I hate it!  So when I heard 
the voice I just had to dance to it because I couldn't stand the song 
(don't ask me why).  But It was completely different.  It was much 
trancier and way less cheesy than the version I have.  Infact it might 
have just been the voice.  And things just took off!!!  Record after 
Record of insane music!  After a while I turned around in disbelief at 
what I was hearing and saw that the dance floor filled up again.  That 
guy is the Bomb dj!!

Thanks gateway for being true to the revolution.  I know why they do it 
and I know why others do it.  I know why I would do it and I know why 
others will do it.  The revolution of cultural evolution will grow.

love chris

I can understand Michael's disappointment, for I was there that night, not
on the dancefloor, but waiting in line. I was really looking forward to this
one, with such a strong DJ line up, but it's unfortunate that there 
wasn't enough space for everyone.... in fact it was way too small. This was
obvious from the ridiculously long line; my friends and I waited in line 
for an hour, and barely moved 5 feet! So we gathered our things together 
and left before the commotion started.  Needless to say, we were very 
disappointed with the whole situation.

personal comments.  Hopefully some of you had a good time :)
