From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 20 12:25:37 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA19202; Mon, 20 Nov 1995 12:25:37 -0800
Received: from ucscb.UCSC.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id MAA19174; Mon, 20 Nov 1995 12:25:19 -0800
Received: by ucscb.UCSC.EDU (5.65/1.34)
	id AA08512; Mon, 20 Nov 95 12:24:17 -0800
Date: Mon, 20 Nov 95 12:24:17 -0800
From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
Message-Id: <9511202024.AA08512@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Kundalini
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My story is the same as the others already posted.  I got there at
11, stood in line for two hours, got right to the door where I was
about to pay to get in, when somebody started shouting that Carlos
had to get through, so we all stepped aside to let him past... and
this group of close to thirty people pushed their way past everyone
to the very front, Carlos was nowhere.  One of my companions said in
a loud irritated voice, "What do you think you're doing?"  and a girl
looked back and said, "why not..."  and my companion said under
her breath, "wait like everyone else, stupid bitch..." and then a guy
who was with the group pushing their way turned around and was just about
ready to sock my friend... (an basically decent girl with an uncensored
mouth) tensions were just on the cracking point when we suddenly relaxed
and it became crystal clear to us that this was not what we wanted to be
a part of tonight.  So we wished them all a fabulous night and turned away.  
And that wasn't the first group of people who had just pushed through
the line to the front...  Well, all those people got in, they paid their
$20 and got asked to leave an hour later.  It's funny how when you build
up your expectation to a certain point, the reality you find is completely
different than your expectation.  I thought the year anniversary of 
Kundalini would be special, because I had such a good time at the first
one a year ago, but something was lurking in the background, something
I wasn't giving enough credit.  It's been festering and finally came
out this weekend, its long silence broken.  To the people behind Kundalini,
don't get too cocky.  As soon as you start ignoring the people that made
your parties great in the beginning, you will fail.  And that's what I felt
on Saturday night... someone's ego trip taken too far. All that 
expectation without the foundation to hold itself up.  Time to go
back to the basics and work on that foundation with a bit more care.
So I went to a friend's house, and had a great night visiting and just
talking to a bunch of new people.  No lasers and big sound systems,
just the beginnings of a nice new foundation.
For an even greater tommorow.
It was a special weekend after all.

life can be pretty damn cool.

-john.

--Boundary-1877627-0-0

this "space" (conveniently located across the street from my place) is 
actually the rehearsal studios for Beyond Race, the band that destroyed time 
and sound and body at burning man. they have parties there often, Beyond Race 
play at them occasionally. the crowd is usually interesting and the music too. 
i don't know if they intend to be listed as an "event". its more of a word of 
mouth thing usually. just drive by the entrance on Howard between 10th/11th 
and see if anything is going on. personally, i've stopped going to these 
parties as the door people are running this like a club ("7$, no you can't 
poke your head in and see if your friend is here") which i think is kind of 
lame and overpriced for a rent party. 
 
------> 
	aaron

Subject: Re: alien emotion

Precedence: bulk



My computer tells me that on Thu, 16 Nov 1995, ecto shared:

>         But isn't that the whole problem? Finding "emotion" and "mind" as
> two separate things in conflict? When ya look at yourself (and not
> specifically you kev! :) and see that "mind" "heart" and "body" are three
> manifestations of the same thing and all can act in unison, synergistically
> there is no conflict and everyone's happy! :)
>         brad

	Yes!  I believe this is so... several months ago I wrote a long 
post on a similar topic, entitled "Rhyme and Reason United," or 
something like that.  Science long ago determined that emotions don't 
literally come from the heart -- the heart pumps blood.  Now it is 
thought that conciousness, traditionally believed to originate in a place 
behind the forehead, in fact may be more widely dispersed.
	It is common to think of mind and emotion as being at odds with 
each other, but in a perfectly evolved person these traits would act in 
harmony.  Both are necessary, as emotional persons who do not think and 
thinking persons who do not feel are, to put it wryly, potholes on the 
road of human tranquility.
	
				*** Starchild ***

"Go placidly amidst the noise and haste..."
				-from the Desiderata
______________________________________________________________________________

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 14 Nov 1995 01:39:42 -0500
From: Brundelfly@aol.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: We miss you!

Hi all.  I hope you guys don't mind me just jumping on and off your list like
this, but I really miss the SF community, and I need to here first-hand how
things are going in the best scene in the country.    

I know it's hard to belive anyone would move away from the most beautiful
city to ever to be assembled, but because of reasons beyond my control I  had
to.   Last Jan. my beautiful wife, my daughter --who, by the way, was
concived the morning after the first "Dust bowl" 4th of July Gathering-- and
myself, reluctantly packed up our lives and moved to Texas.   Dallas/Ft.
Worth is ok, but after experiencing the joy's of "The City" for so long, this
place will never compare.

Someone please write us so we can be reminded of what this whole culture is
truly about.  We plan to make a trip "home" soon for some soul regeneration,
so some useful tips on anything that may have changed over the past year
would also be nice.  We have probably also met one or two of you, or at least
someone you know.  It sure would be nice to talk to an old friend from The
Bay Area from time-to-time without charging up the phone bill.
   
 Anyway, thanks for your time.  I'll leave you with a little advice.  Never
take the SF scene for granted.  Dispite it's ups and downs over the years,
it's still alive and well.  Many cities are curently struggling with things
long past for you.  Because of a few caring; dedicated and professional
promoters, as well as many talented; creative and hard working DJ's and
record producers, SF has become a legend within the scene and model for all
other's to follow.   Proof that no obstacle will stop all this as long as
there are people who truely care.  Keep it up, and enjoy...    






                                                                       Dylan,
Kelly and Akayna

Hi everybody,

I just got back from Mad at Bahia.  I liked it because of the beautiful 
way it's set up...dj table up on a raised bit with tables as well.  The 
dance floor was big enough and not too chaotic with people coming and 
going.  And the 
bartender was a beautiful woman with a magnificent smile.

  There were all 
kinds of tropical-themed doodads everywhere.  Such as lots of tall, 
frondy plants.  I really liked it a lot.  I get the impression that in 
other incarnations Bahia is probably as much fun as it was at MaD.  
I also liked the films they were playing above the dance floor opposite 
the dj.  Lots of flowers-in-motion on some sunny days, which elevated me 
out of my previous blahness state that comes from winter approaching.

I was in kind of a bad mood all day due to a disappointing cloning 
disaster (i cloned the wrong thing *shit!*) and so I really needed 
to be with mellow friendly people.

Jon Carrol was playing when I got there, and then somebody named Jason 
Santos, I think.  Where does he come from?  The music was good.  Lots of 
people were dancing and getting down.  The people there I guess were 
people like me who needed something fun but not too intense to pick us up 
out of the ordinairy boringness of beginning another week cycle of 
unnatural labors.

I think that if there are people on this list who haven't yet been to one 
of the parties that this would be a good place to start.  

Bye!

Ann

I tried something like that a couple of months ago.  It was supposed to be
liquid E.  It really sucked.  I was a bit afraid for my life to be honest.
It came on really fast and totally slammed me.  I could barely move.  I got
tunnel vision.  I felt as though I would pass out every time I stood up.
There was a period of time when I honestly felt that my life could go either
way....either end or continue....and if I wanted it to continue I had to
really focus and make it happen.  It did not feel good *at all*, and I would
not do it again, or recommend that anyone else do it.  A few of my friends
did it as well and had very similar bad experiences.  I would have been
really pissed had I paid for it....but it seems that I paid enough that night.

>while going through some police reports for a section I do once and a while
>for our campus papers, I came across the story of two girls who overdosed on
>something the report says they told their friends was "Frog", a liquid form
>of Ecstacy. Has anyone heard of this stuff? Is this an accurate description
>of the substance? How is it different, or similar, to "normal" Ecstacy.
>any info would be greatly appreciated
>thanks

At 12:09 PM 11/21/95 -0800, you wrote:
>Don't forget the Shitty sound system at 'AudioTech'.  That's what they
>needed... An audiotech-nician, and a new soundsystem.  How embarrasing.

Props to Shobhan for keeping it up in spite of all that. You could also
un-props her for not knowing when to give up on a losing battle, though. I
think the net effect was conducive to variety though, since people who came
for the fouronthefloor probably explored and discovered the jungle.

I highly rate the breaks basement they had at Audio Tech. Great sound, great
DJs. If anyone knows who the DJ before Jonah was, I would much appreciate
that info. It was really great to see how enthusiastic and supportive the
crowd was toward jungle.

All in all, I stayed from about 11-4 and was mucho fine with paying the US$5
for what seemed to be a rent party (renty?).

for everyone who was trying to get in touch with the president (and anyone
else in the whitehouse), here's a message i received today from some schmo.
peace jb
---------------------
Forwarded message:
From:	autoresponder@WhiteHouse
To:	Msjoel@aol.com
Date: 95-11-20 17:28:09 EST

    Thank you for writing to President Clinton via electronic
mail.  Since June 1993, whitehouse.gov has received over 685,000
messages from people all across the country and the world.  

    Because so many of you write, the President cannot
personally review each message.  The mail is first read by White
House Correspondence staff.  Your concerns, ideas, and
suggestions are carefully recorded and communicated to the
President weekly with a representative sampling of the mail.

     All of us at the White House are excited about the progress
of this historic project (be sure to check out the Web page as
described below!), and we look forward to future developments
(such as using email to respond to the content of your messages). 
Your continued interest and participation are very important to
us.

                       Sincerely,

                       Stephen K. Horn
                       Director, Presidential Email
                       The Office of Correspondence

P.S. Please read on - you may find the following information
useful.

--  This is the only electronic message you will receive from
whitehouse.gov.  No other message purporting to be from the
President or his staff with an address at whitehouse.gov is
authentic.  If you have received such a message, you have been
spoofed.

--  You will receive only one autoresponder message per day.

--  The only personal addresses at whitehouse.gov are the
following:

    President@whitehouse.gov
    Vice.President@whitehouse.gov
    First.Lady@whitehouse.gov

Please write to Mrs. Gore and other White House staff by regular
mail.  The address is:  

     The White House, Washington, D.C. 20500.

--   On October 20, 1994, President Clinton and Vice President
Gore opened a World Wide Web home page called "Welcome to the
White House:  An Interactive Citizens' Handbook" and it fast
became one of the more popular spots on the Web.  The White House
home page provides, among other things,  a single point of access
to all electronic government information on the Internet. 
"Welcome to the White House" can be accessed at:

               http://www.whitehouse.gov

--   White House documents and publications are available on the
World Wide Web (see above) and by email.  To receive instructions
on retrieving documents by email, please send a message to the
following address:

               publications@whitehouse.gov

In the body of your message, type "Send Info" (without quotes);
do not include other text (such as message headers or
signature lines (.sig files)).  The instructions will be sent to
you automatically.

****************************************************************
List of Clinton Administration Accomplishments (three documents
compose the whole):

    To:  publications@whitehouse.gov
    Message body:      send file 317571
                       send file 317573
                       send file 317575
****************************************************************

--   The White House Public Access Email FAQ (Frequently Asked
Questions) document is available at the following address.  The
FAQ, among other things, lists alternate sources of government
information, i.e., the Congressional email projects.  Send an
email message (no text necessary) to:

               faq@whitehouse.gov

(This FAQ address is an autoresponder only; any comment sent to
this address will not be acknowledged.)

At 2:24 PM 11/20/95, Starchild wrote:
>My computer tells me that on Thu, 16 Nov 1995, ecto shared:
>
>>         But isn't that the whole problem? Finding "emotion" and "mind" as
>> two separate things in conflict? When ya look at yourself (and not
>> specifically you kev! :) and see that "mind" "heart" and "body" are three
>> manifestations of the same thing and all can act in unison, synergistically
>> there is no conflict and everyone's happy! :)
>>         brad
>
>        Yes!  I believe this is so... several months ago I wrote a long
>post on a similar topic, entitled "Rhyme and Reason United," or
>something like that.  Science long ago determined that emotions don't
>literally come from the heart -- the heart pumps blood.  Now it is
>thought that conciousness, traditionally believed to originate in a place
>behind the forehead, in fact may be more widely dispersed.
>        It is common to think of mind and emotion as being at odds with
>each other, but in a perfectly evolved person these traits would act in
>harmony.  Both are necessary, as emotional persons who do not think and
>thinking persons who do not feel are, to put it wryly, potholes on the
>road of human tranquility.
>
>                                *** Starchild ***
>______________________________________________________________________________
>"Go placidly amidst the noise and haste..."
>                                -from the Desiderata
>______________________________________________________________________________

        Wow, that was amazingly cool and very true (imho) :) WHat i've been
thinking/realizing lately is that 'emotion' is something that (like
'intuition' which it's tied in to) is a non-linguistic perception of your
environment. THat is, you 'feel' a certain way because of information that
you are perceiving from your environment that is beyond the 5 senses and
also beyond rational, linguistic interpretation.  I think buddhists believe
that the mind is a 6th organ of sense and, along this line, maybe the
'heartmind' is something along these lines. THis would explain a lot of
inexplicable reactions to things "good vibes" "bad vibes" or whatever. I do
think though, that like our 'normal' 5 senses, there isn't any necessary
causal relationship between what we perceive and how we react, it's more
synergistic: we see something but at the same time we 'map' concepts on to
what we perceive.
        akk, time to stop thinking, my brain hurts.

        peace,

        brad the emotional aries }:)

        also, i have to give props to mark/cellardemon (from vrave) for a
lot of these ideas that he pushed into my head :)

>        6.  The guy doing sound did not know what he was doing.


No shit! and no wonder! 

Anyone who uses a home stereo amp, no matter what wattage, has never done
sound for any party before. At least not for one over 5 people outside of
their bedroom. Your nice receiver at home may be a multi hundred watt
monster, but it was not built to push all of that for hours and hours, it's
simply too much for a delicate component. Industrial strength amps are
required for a hassle free boogie.

eh

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

>        Wow, that was amazingly cool and very true (imho) :) WHat i've been
>thinking/realizing lately is that 'emotion' is something that (like
>'intuition' which it's tied in to) is a non-linguistic perception of your
>environment. THat is, you 'feel' a certain way because of information that
>you are perceiving from your environment that is beyond the 5 senses and
>also beyond rational, linguistic interpretation.  I think buddhists believe
>that the mind is a 6th organ of sense and, along this line, maybe the
>'heartmind' is something along these lines. THis would explain a lot of
>inexplicable reactions to things "good vibes" "bad vibes" or whatever. I do
>think though, that like our 'normal' 5 senses, there isn't any necessary
>causal relationship between what we perceive and how we react, it's more
>synergistic: we see something but at the same time we 'map' concepts on to
>what we perceive.

There is a really good book that is totally along these lines called "The
Logic of Sense." It's by a guy named Gilles Deleuze who was a figure in the
student movements of the late '60s. It's purple and I forget who the
publisher is, but it's available at City Lights, Kepler's and sometimes at
Barnes & Noble (go figure, but I got "be here now" there too). Check it.

eh

Tue, Nov 21, 1995, amyp@yosemite.examen.com wrote:

>Does anyone know who or have you heard of the following DJs:

>Josh Winks
>Colonel Abrams
>Barbara Tucker
>DJ Pierre
>Terence Parker

Well, Josh Wink has no "s" on the end of his name! He is a cute man from
Philly, and he has very long dreadlocks. He used to be quite the  friendly
guy, don't know about now, but I assume he still is. He also seems to be very
busy, with flying all over the world to d.j., making his own records on the
Sorted label, and writing articles for that pseudo raver mag, Project X. He
has been at Area 51 twice in the past year. He was *really* good. Oh, the
amazed looks of those little sf ravers.... he was good. And he remembered me,
so I was happy. Of course, how could he not? I used to chase him all over the
place mercilessly, I even gave him a bottle of Wink soda once. He was the
victim of my dj schmoozing for a while, but I gave up that vile practice. 

I know I've heard Pierre, but I can't remember where. (what a phat rhymer I
am, huh?) I've never heard of the rest of those people. But I haven't been
back East for a while. 

Have a super-fresh day!

MsPhink

        "Who are these DJ's" (Nov 21,  2:08pm)
References: <9511212208.277EB4@pongo.examen.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: amyp@yosemite.examen.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Who are these DJ's
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

OK, I'll give it a try :)

Josh Wink -- both a record producer and a DJ, he's from Philly, been
  around the block so to speak since the late 1980s.  I've heard he's
  a very good DJ.  Right now he's the king of the underground tracks
  with "Don't Laugh," "I Am Ready" and "Higher State of Consciousness"
  all creating beaucoup excitement in 1995.  I'm not big on any of 
  them, actually, but many of his other tracks are excellent and he
  mentioned one I particularly like, "Meditation Will Manifest," in
  an interview I saw recently.  Also check his excellent remix of
  Towa Tei's "Technova."  

Colonel Abrams -- As far as I know, he's basically a pop house singer.
  Very popular tracks in Europe and the east coast.  Not my style,
  I don't know very much more.

Barbara Tucker -- Also a pop house singer, but with real depth.  "Deep
  Inside" and "Beautiful People" are both in the classic SF house set
  tradition.  A great voice and serious talent.

DJ Pierre -- My admiration for this guy only grows year after year.
  He's been there since near the beginning for house, best known now
  for his distinctive "wild pitch" remix sound -- the one with the
  honking horns or train sounds that go on for three times the length
  of a regular track :)  But he's also an important figure from the
  early Chicago house and acid house days.  His "Sunshine" remix of
  Midi Rain with the "let your mind be your sun" vocal sample is another
  in a long string of classics he's done.  I'm playing the hell out of
  his Jeff Mills "Late Night" remix these days.  A lot of his stuff is
  samey, but that's the way in dance music, and his level of samey is
  well above the peaks most everyone else ever reaches.  Some of my
  friends think his Wicked set last year was the best house set ever
  played in SF, bar none.  DJ Pierre rules.  Nuff said.

Terence Parker -- Well, there was this kind of quiet guy standing over
  on the side at Record Time in Detroit when me and Robert Smith and
  John Courte were there a month ago.  Pretty soon Robert introduces me
  to . . . Terence Parker!  I don't know whether TP is a DJ or not
  (pretty much everyone who makes house music except Mike Banks seems
  to have tried at one time or another, whether or not they still do),
  but it doesn't matter to me.  Terence has put out some amazing tracks,
  only one of which, "The Question," is widely known (both for the original
  and a nearly identical K-Klass remix).  I'm particularly partial to
  "Stand Up for the Soul," myself.  Anyway, TP has put out tons of Detroit
  house over the last five years or more.  He has a raw, percussive style
  with gospel-influenced vocals, lots of piano chords and syncopated 
  meter, all of which are well in evidence on "The Question."  Some of his
  tracks are hard to listen to, since he experiments so much with sound
  and harmony.  A truly underappeciated producer, if you ask me.

That help?

  :)

phred

   Here it is, before I head out for T-giving. There might be more stuff
   this weekend - one party a night seems a little skimpy. But at least
   there's something promising every night. Organic probably has the
   longest, best track record of the lot.
   
   Last weekend sounded a bit tough - a couple busts and a robbery. So be
   careful out there and remember, there's no money back guarantees.


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

       90.1 (Stanford)

       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

You'd be better of just figuring out the simple mathematical formula he

sounds :) or getting Phuture "acid trax", which is by far the best thing 
he's ever made, problem is he made it exactly 10 years ago & IMHO he's 
only made about 10 good tracks in this time out of many hundreds.
-josh

'ello, 'ello!

        Did anyone else happen to see the "Weird TV" segment on Burning Man
Saturday night?  Weird TV is, er, well, a weird TV program on channel 2
Saturday latenights (around 2:00ish?)  They had interviews with some of the
organizers, Larry somebody and another guy(?) about how Burning Man
started, then they showed the incredible rain/hail/wind storms and the mud
frolicking that followed, the lighting ceremony, and some dude in a shark
car tearassin' around.  I had just gotten in so I was just tooo tired to
watch any more.  It was kewl to see some of it since I missed it, though 8(
Peace

At 12:03 AM 11/22/95, trose@violet.berkeley.edu wrote:
>> > DJ Pierre
>> One of THE Acid House originators and inventor of the "wild pitch" style
>>
>Do you know if he has any albums out...or whrer I can find some "wild

output for them. His remixes of the Joint Venture singles for them are
excellent. In addition to Wild Pitch stuff he's done some classic acid trax
as well, being involved in Phortune and Phuture to name a couple.

one continuous song :) from Midnight to Midnight to entice the Sun
to return.

I wasn't around this weekend, but my friend happened to be standing right
next to the cop/organizer interaction at the busted Kundalini party.  This
is how it went down:

When the *cop* said that it was fucked-up that they were taking people's
money knowing that they couldn't possibly have an unpermitted party of that
size in downtown Concord without it getting shut down, the guy running the
show said, "We all have to make money, you know."

I guess it's all about motives isn't it?

Saving my 20s for a worthier cause...

Tony

At 12:10 AM 11/22/95, trose@violet.berkeley.edu wrote:
>Hello out there,
>         I am beginning to try to work out how to use my computer
>(486dx2-66 8/540) running linux and win3.1 with a turtle beach sound cardto
>make some kick ass trance!
>I was woindering if anyone out there has any advice and particularly if
>you can tell me where to find (or share with me:))share some good
>software. thanks.
>-Trose (aka hierophant)

For really good sequencing software on the PC, I'd recommend you check out
Cakewalk Pro by Twelve Tone Systems.  It has a really good, intuitive,
interface and very nice features like groove quantizing which will allow
you to quantize a track according to a particular groove.  It comes with a
bunch of pre-set grooves and you can define your own as well.  Other
quantizing features allow you to synch up time and groove to other tracks
too.

I believe a related home page with demos can be found at:
http://www.isvr.soton.ac.uk/People/ccb/Cakewalk/Demos/

I wish you luck and much fun in your music making!

Peace

Tigger (Glenn)

strike me as suprising.  Kundalini started with a wonderful party one 
year ago and they have progressively gone downhill since.  They have 
given less and taken more with each party they have thrown.  The last one 
I went to was last spring way out there somewhere in a building on the 
fairgounds.  The line moved incredibly slow until 12:00 rolled around, 
then the price went up to $20 and amazingly enough the line began to move 
again.  I'm sad to see the end of a good party... but Kundalini is over.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 22 Nov 1995 00:05:12 -0800 (PST)
From: Matthew Corwine <mcorwine@u.washington.edu>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: 313-Digest V1 #132 (fwd)

spam spam spam...

*************************************************

Attn manufacturers, distributors, shippers
retailers, customers, fans of underground music.

We are currently facing a situation here in Detroit. 
Submerge is about to be right field in a new baseball stadium! 
We are located in one of the more rundown areas of Detroit - 
The Cass Corridor. Due to our cheap rent and unique location 
we and our customers have come to love our special spot 
(not to mention it was one of the few places we could afford). 
2030 as it is called is also the home of UR, Metroplex, Red Planet, 
Eddie Fowlkes, Juan Atkins and members of Parliament-Funkadelic. 
Developers from outside of the city have negotiated with city 
officials a deal in which our neighborhood chillingly 
called AREA 1 is slated for eminate destruction to clear 
the way for the new stadium which is scheduled to break 
ground in May 1996. Buildings are being razed as we speak! 
Its winter and many of these abandoned buildings are the only 
shelter available for our neighborhoods many homeless people. 
Being very pro-Detroit we always hoped and knew that blighted 
areas such as ours would eventually come back which is one of 
the reasons we stayed, but progress must come in 
a way that is fair to everyone.

Hopefully with your support we can get the city and the 
developers to see that there is more here than the decayed
buildings, drugs and crime. Hopefully they also see a 
neighborhood full of proud Vietnam vets too proud to accept 
handouts, perhaps they will see people who no matter how down 
on their luck still are able to share their food with someone 
less fortunate, perhaps they will see small business owners 
who refused the exodus to the safety and comfort of the 
suburbs and remained loyal to the city.

Hopefully the city and the developers will see that 
shelters need to be built and business kept in or close 
to their original locations. We at Submerge face and 
ironic problem - due to most of our hometown radio stations 
inability to play our records (even though the rest of the 
world does!!) this music and its affiliated artists producers 
and record labels although some of which are world famous 
mean absolutely nothing to our pre-programmed audiences 
here in Detroit and I am sure this will include Detroits 
city council. The only major press coverage our music ever 
got here was highly negative and associated with teen drug 
use at warehouse partys. This was very unfair press 
especially to the people built and survive from this music. 
I am hoping that anyone who appreciates what Detroit underground 
music has done for this world and what submerge is doing 
to keep the Spirit of truly independent Detroit record 
labels alive could write a brief 1pg. or less letter and 
fax it to the  #1+313+963+0213 please include your return 
address and also please mention the need for shelters as 
the homeless have no voice! 

We need these faxes or letters by 11-27-95 for our meeting with City Counsel.

Peace - The Unknown Writer - on behalf of Submerge

2030 GRANDVER, SUITE 101, DETROIT, MI 48226
PH   1+313+963+1025
FAX  1+313+963+0213


******************************

Yesterday I was down in SF and I picked up a cd at Virgin Records. Mainly
I was attracted to the "happily raving cats" on the cover (they continue
throughout the insert :) ), but it also listed tracks by the
LowSpirit/Mayday family (Marusha, Westbam, etc.), N-Trance, and thirteen
other groups. So I bought it and took it home. As soon as I put in the cd
player I knew why it was titled "Happy Rave 95"!  AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME
this is extremely happy hardcore which had me blissed ever since last
night. There is not one bad track on this one IMO and the happiness just
envelopes you completely. I got a few other new Cds but haven't had a
chance to listen to them yet (I'll post a review as soon as I have)
because of the utter powerfulness of HappyRave95. 

  Austin

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The main difference between home stereo amps and "professional"
PA amps rated at the same wattage, e.g. "100 watts per channel",
is mainly this:

PA amps are designed to be played at their maximum power output,
including going beyond into the land of Clipping and Distortion
(that "crunchy" sound), for extended periods of time without
failure, since everyone always demands more volume no matter
how loud the music already is.  They also incorporate special
"soft clipping" circuitry so that when they do go "into the
red", the distortion isn't as obnoxious.

Home amps, on the other hand, are designed for exact-fidelity
reproduction, usually at much quieter levels.  Therefore, the
electronics are not build to stand hours of overload, because
any home stereo user who hears their amp fuzzing out will just
turn it down.  There is also usually no overload light, as
most amps today are MUCH louder than the average home or
apartment will desire (or withstand).

This is why home amps often die when pressed into party usage:
people crank it up as loud as they can, into the overload
range, and the amp can't sustain the wattage and fries
itself, whereas a PA in that condition will cope just fine.

I have run several home parties off of home stereos and never
harmed the speakers or the amps: the key is to know what
an amp or speaker being pushed too hard sounds like, and to
back off reasonably if you hear it.

The trouble with house music is that the "overloaded PA" sound
is _so_ widespread and _so_ common that many people think that
the record actually sounds like that!  SJ Oasis, anyone?

Hope this lay explanation won't offend any of the techies.

// g

Subject: Re: Audio Tech

             <199511230818.AAA12730@jobe.shell.portal.com> 
Date: Thu, 23 Nov 95 13:32:47 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


First of all, there's a better chance that you'll fry your speakers
before you fry your home amp. In fact, a good way to fry your speakers
(especially your tweeters) is to run them with an underpowered amp that
is clipping and distoring. Of course, if you're running "club" (aka
horn loaded) speakers then there's a good chance they'll survive cuz
they're meant for that kind of abuse.

Second, if you get a power MOSFET (field effect transistor -- closest
you can get to a "solid state tube") amp, it will intrinsically prevent
itself from frying because MOSFETs don't have the problem of "beta
breakdown" that occurs in standard bipolar transistors, which is
essentially a heat-induced "positive feedback loop" in which the hotter
the transistor gets, the more current it lets pass through it, and it
eventually burns itself up. MOSFETs have a "negative feedback effect"
in which the hotter they get, the less current they allow to pass, and
therefore they tend to self-regulate their overheating behavior. Beta
breakdown induced overheating is typically how yer average (aka bipolar
transistor using) home amp will fry itself when put to "club" use....
Better (aka pro) bipolar txistor based amps have a heat sensor to
prevent this kind of problem. MOSFET amps don't really need 'em as long
as you've got reasonable heat sinks and air circulation. MOSFETs don't
really need soft clipping either since their distortion characteristics
are inherently "soft" (the MOSFET transfer function produces
even-harmonic distortion components, just like a vacuum tube), whereas
bipolar txistors have dissonant/harsh odd harmonic components when they
distort due a fractional exponential in the transfer function when you
overdrive them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Precedence: bulk


What do you all think about melatonin? it's a relatively new health-food
store supplement that is claimed to be the bodies natural "sleeping pill".
Claims are also made that it prevents effects of aging, and that it
increases sex drive in older people.

I tried one last night before going to sleep and indeed, I did sleep
very well (didn't wake up at all during the night), had more
interesting dreams than usual, and felt pretty fresh in the morning.

The claim is that it is a hormone produced by the pineal gland at
night and causes drowsiness.

Comments? Warnings?

PS: and is there an anti-melatonin for when you want to stay awake??

It's the overrated hype drug of the moment.  I tried it some time ago,
to see if promoting more restful sleep would give me more energy
during the day.  I actually felt pretty crappy the next day(on 3 and
then 1 mg).  I'm the same age as I would have been anyways :^), and as
for sex, well, I'm older, but not that older(though I'm getting older
every day)... :^(.  

My guess is you'd have to be past the melatonin drop off age to get
any use from it... e.g., when you don't sleep as deeply as you did in
your youth.  Assuming your laying off the caffeine, alcohol,  etc.
before bedtime.  And I wonder if you might start lowering your natural
output of melatonin as your tolerance grows?

Anyhoo, it's probably better to take one once in a while than benzos.
Sometimes it made me sleepy, sometimes not.  And it tends to wear off
in 4 hours(some people take a booster at this point).

YMMV, 

David

I've been doing some research on GHB (haven't tried it though).
Apparently the usual dose is about 1 g.  Too much for a pill, so it is
distributed as a solution.  It usually starts out as a powder.
Apparently its still easy to obtain overseas, someone is even selling
it mail order on Usenet (check the alt.drugs groups).

Subject: Freedom Submerged (Political)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.OSF.3.91l.951122192944.10070B@saul1.u.washington.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951124023620.18700E-100000@orion>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So Detroit's Submerge Records is about to lose their home to be replaced 
by a new ball park.

This phenomenon is not unique to Detroit.  City governments and other 
official entities routinely violate people's rights through what is 
called "eminant domain" -- it means they claim that in the name of 
the "public good" they have more right to your property than you do.

The ongoing People's Park controversy in Berkeley began with just such a 
use of eminant domain by the University of California, which tore down 
existing housing and forced people out of house and home in order to 
clear the land for student housing, which was subsequently never built 
because of local opposition to the University's heavy-handed tactics.

I foresee this same type action happening in the San Francisco's South of 
Market area in the future, possibly displacing venues and other members of 
the rave community, since this is an area often discussed as being ripe 
for redevelopment.

It is interesting to notice that eminant domain is almost always used in 
the poorer areas of town, where residents and merchants lack the power and 
resources to fight City Hall's destruction of their homes and businesses.

Needless to say, in a libertarian society, property rights violations 
like this would not be occuring.

Food for thought,
			 *** Starchild ***

			- - - - - - - - - -

I have no experience, to my knowledge, with GHB, but I know liquid E 
exists -- I've taken it, once.  I disbelieved it myself at first, having 
read a bunch about MDMA and not heard it mentioned once.  I'm not sure if 
it was the dose or what, but with the exception of the first time I took 
Exstasy, the time on liquid E was the most wonderful trip I've had in my 
life.  It was at a Full Moon party at Bonny Doon a couple years ago, and 
some very generous strangers shared it with me.  I'm reasonably sure the 
stuff was pure Exstasy -- even mixed with copious amounts of water, it 
had that incredibly bitter taste, and I got the jaw clenching, the 
overpowering feeling of love and oneness with the world and everyone in 
it, it could scarcely have been anything else.

Mmm, just thinking about it now is making me smile!

Big Hugzzz to you all,
				*** Starchild ***

On Thu, 23 Nov 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> 
> What do you all think about melatonin? it's a relatively new health-food
> store supplement that is claimed to be the bodies natural "sleeping pill".
> Claims are also made that it prevents effects of aging, and that it
> increases sex drive in older people.
> 
> I tried one last night before going to sleep and indeed, I did sleep
> very well (didn't wake up at all during the night), had more
> interesting dreams than usual, and felt pretty fresh in the morning.
> 
> The claim is that it is a hormone produced by the pineal gland at
> night and causes drowsiness.
> 
> Comments? Warnings?

Yeah, I've known about it and taken it before all the hype.  Some of the 
research seems to indicate that your pineal gland (the physical organ
that is associated with the "third eye") excretes melatonin while you
are asleep usually between the hours of 2 a.m. and 4 a.m. but guess
what!? That's prime ravin' time for many of us so our bodies don't
get to get their melatonin dose, compound this with the fact that as you get
older, you produce/excrete less and less, so this really is a good thing 
for you gray haired ravers out there.  I take it to help me sleep and to
help regulate my sleep cycle when I've done a weekend of hardcore raving.
(I got a day job now, and have to come to work before 4 pm these days :)

I've noticed if I take over 2.5 mcg I get drowsy in the morning though.

 
> PS: and is there an anti-melatonin for when you want to stay awake??


Yes, it's called meth but don't even go there :)

Thu, Nov 23, 1995, mayer@netcom.com wrote:

>What do you all think about melatonin? it's a relatively new >health-food
store supplement that is claimed to be the bodies >natural "sleeping pill".
Claims are also made that it prevents >effects of aging, and that it
increases sex drive in older >people.

I have been hearing a lot of reports in the media about melatonin. It seems
that the things it does best are: preventing jat lag and helping you to
sleep. Unless you have chronic insomnia, I really don't think you should be
taking it. I have been studying various systems of natural medicine on my own
for several years now. One thing I have learned is that the human body is a
very complex mechanism and it usually does a good job of regulating itself. 

Every few years there comes along some miracle supplement that has been
claimed to do everything except the dishes. For example, the claims on
melatonin about sex drive & reversal of aging are based on mice. Older and
younger mice had their pineal glands switched around. There haven't been any
studies done on humans that have substantiated these claims. Since melatonin
is a hormone, I wouldn't take it myself. Well.... maybe if I was in my 50's
or 60's I'd think about it. 

I think the best thing you can do for yourself is to eat good food, get some
exercise and plenty of rest. This keeps you younger than taking pills! ;-)
Not that I follow my own advice, but what the heck?

You can believe if the FDA thinks millions of people are taking melatonin,
they'll try to pull it off the market. Just like ma huang. The FDA is one
gov't organization I wouldn't mind seeing fall by the wayside! 

MsPhinko-stinko

At 1:55 AM 11/24/95, Starchild wrote:
>My computer tells me that on Wed, 22 Nov 1995, Tony Rotundo shared:
>
>> I wasn't around this weekend, but my friend happened to be standing right
>> next to the cop/organizer interaction at the busted Kundalini party.  This
>> is how it went down:
>>
>> When the *cop* said that it was fucked-up that they were taking people's
>> money knowing that they couldn't possibly have an unpermitted party of that
>> size in downtown Concord without it getting shut down, the guy running the
>> show said, "We all have to make money, you know."
>>
>> I guess it's all about motives isn't it?
>>
>> Saving my 20s for a worthier cause...
>>
>> Tony
>
>The cop definitely had a point, but still, seems to me that he was the
>pot calling the kettle black.  It's fucked up to shut down a party if
>it's not causing problems -- permit, shmermit.
>
>For liberty,
>                                *** Starchild ***

If you were there, you would have seen there *were* problems. Suburban
'gangsters' wearing Raiders parkas fighting in the street, the club was
*hopelessly* overcrowded and the fire marshall has a right to do something
about that.

Don't get me wrong, I am all for having parties in all kinds of places, but
when you operate inside the law by having your party in a restaurant like
this was, you have to abide by the laws that restaurants have to, including
max occupancies, fire exits, use permits, etc.

I really feel that in this case, it was a clear case of a sucky promoter
with a clear problem regarding morality. When you throw a party, you have a
trust or bond with your paying guests that you will deliver a good party to
them. This promoter clearly broke the trust of his guests by clearly not
delivering to them a party that was in the right sized space, etc.

I think that someone should post his name on SFR so that we can all stay
clear of his parties in the future. We deserve it, and so does he.

they'll be throwing a make-up party in the future.

me.  I'll see if I can get a satisfactory explanation next time I talk

busted  couldn't be forgiven (e.g. Progress, CDC's Chemsitry).

Organic:

  the party.  rather good.  when we got in the vibe wasn't quite in
place but carlos and tony worked it and then when jeno came on he tore
down the house with house.  it was nice throwing in "deep inside" 
which really got me going.  Simon played a very very nice coming down 
set and then the party ended at 5 am.

good party.  i just want to mention the afterwards also:

when out side i was waiting with deegroovy (veronica) and her friend
connie for some other friends when 2 of the palace security guards
parted the crowd holding a rather large guy bleeding from the head. 
appearently the person was drunk, but had also been beaten by the 
security guards causing the blood.  The cops arrived and the 
security guards blamed ignorance on how the bleeding occured.  The
cops then tried to scare everyone away and at one point while i was
crossing the street a cop told me to stop.  i was rather interested on
seeing what would happen next so i kept walking and the officer grabbed me
by the throat and pulled me to the curb, and after a few minutes holding
my id chastized me for not being my age (21) and told me to go home.  
  Im not saying that i didnt provoke a bit.  but allowing people to
hit someone in the head and throw him to the ground bleeding didn;t
see right.  also being a photojournalist i wasnt particularly happy
about not being able to see the events occuring.  Its the press's right
to me close to a scene as long as you are not interfering with the
process.

i donno.  the whole situation just doesn't see right to me.
especially after a fun party.
oh well.

doug ) ( dougie@netcom.com

Hi Everyone,

A while back I posted a request for travel tips regarding Spain and 
Paris. I just want to thank all of you who responded with your ideas, 
recommendations and enthusiasm. I've printed out your lists of clubs, 
stores, restaurants and tourist traps and plan to take them with me in 
just a few (!) weeks. Sorry not to have sent along my thanks before now, 
and sorry not to respond to each of you personally -- it's been a 
hectic and difficult time (a recent death in the family), but 
please know that I really appreciate your help!

A note on Kundalini -- 

I have a special place in my heart for this party because my boyfriend 
and I kissed for the first time at their first party last year at the 
Troc. We've been happily together ever since. I'm sorry to hear the party 
in Concord didn't go off, and sorry for those of you who got caught up in 
the maelstrom. Too bad the magic didn't happen this time.

Love,
Kathryn

Dear All;

	Recently saw a film directed by  Lars Von Trier, called the 
Kingdom. It would be great if you spoke Danish or Swedish, but us 
monoliquial American will have to deal with the sub-titles; which are 
unfortuately difficult to read at some points in the movie.

	However and I'm just gonna reprint this an excerpt or an excerpt 
from The New York Post review by Larry Worth:

	If Stanley Kubrick, David Lynch, Paddy Chayefsky, & Robert Altman 
were rolled into one, the reseult might be Lars von Trier.

	Denmark's answer to Twin Peaks! A comedy of the supernatural. Von 
Trier, with Wellesian graddiosity, flaunts a liberated cinematic 
imagination with nose thumbing glee.

		-Stephen Holden, The New York Times

	An unholy mix of hospital soap opera, saturday morning 
supernaturalism, genteel detective story & erotic intrique.

		-J. Hoberman, Village Voice

	You can find this film playing at the UC Berkeley. SO why do a 
movie review on a rave mailing list, ravers are international world 
citzens, so a review of a popular cool foreign film that appears to be doing 
well over in Europe, seems appropreiate.

	Flames Welcome, but make sure you check out the movie, it's 4.5 
hours long so make sure you stock up on cheaper candy before you go 
in, anyway....., see ya in space>>>>>>>______.........

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Nov 26 04:14:06 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id EAA14488; Sun, 26 Nov 1995 04:14:06 -0800
Received: from apollo.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id EAA14483; Sun, 26 Nov 1995 04:14:03 -0800
Received: (from star@localhost) by apollo.sfsu.edu (8.7.1/8.7.1) id EAA23338; Sun, 26 Nov 1995 04:13:49 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sun, 26 Nov 1995 04:13:49 -0800 (PST)
From: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: star@apollo
To: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Was Busting Kundalini Fair?
In-Reply-To: <v02130503acdbd9af3d8e@[157.22.222.111]>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951126030901.21820A-100000@apollo>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



My computer tells me that on Fri, 24 Nov 1995, Wayne D. Correia shared:

> If you were there, you would have seen there *were* problems. Suburban
> 'gangsters' wearing Raiders parkas fighting in the street, the club was
> *hopelessly* overcrowded and the fire marshall has a right to do something
> about that.
> 
> Don't get me wrong, I am all for having parties in all kinds of places, but
> when you operate inside the law by having your party in a restaurant like
> this was, you have to abide by the laws that restaurants have to, including
> max occupancies, fire exits, use permits, etc.
> 
> I really feel that in this case, it was a clear case of a sucky promoter
> with a clear problem regarding morality. When you throw a party, you have a
> trust or bond with your paying guests that you will deliver a good party to
> them. This promoter clearly broke the trust of his guests by clearly not
> delivering to them a party that was in the right sized space, etc.
> 
> I think that someone should post his name on SFR so that we can all stay
> clear of his parties in the future. We deserve it, and so does he.
> 

Dear Wayne,

	My first thought when I read this was to post a response saying 
"OK, you're right.  What you've said shows that they deserved to be shut 
down."  
	I was then going to go on to say (as I am saying now) that I wasn't 
aware of the overcrowding inside or fighting outside the Kundalini space, 
since these conditions weren't mentioned in others' posts about the bust, and 
as you correctly assume, I wasn't there, so I have no firsthand knowledge.
	After thinking about it a little bit more however, I decided that 
the situation still didn't justify the cops and the fire marshall 
shutting down the party.  It may seem strange to some of you reading 
this that I would favor allowing a party to continue when people are fighting 
and possibly getting hurt, and the space is so full of people that it poses a 
serious danger should a fire or other incident break out.  Bear with me, I'll 
try to explain.
	Imagine for a moment that we are near Daytona, Ohio, at the site 
of the recent talks on ending the conflict in Bosnia.  Imagine that due 
to the high-profile nature of the event, and the organizers perhaps 
having granted too many passes to the press and so forth, the space where 
the peace talks are being held is hopelessly overcrowded.  Furthermore, a 
scuffle has broken out in the street outside the hall between pro-Bosian and 
pro-Serb protestors.  Additionally complicating matters, it is discovered 
that the event being scheduled at the last minute made it impossible to comply 
with city regulations requiring a permit for an event of this size to be 
obtained one month in advance.
	Here we have a situation approximating what happened at 
Kundalini:  Overcrowding, through fault of the promoters; fighting among 
people at the site of the event, but not actually inside; and lack of a 
permit for reasons outside the promoters' control.
	Now can you see for one minute the Daytona cops and fire marshall 
shutting down the peace talks and just telling everybody to pack up and 
go home?  Hell no!!!  It would never happen.  So why do raves get shut 
down for the same offenses that other events get away with?  Two basic 
reasons:
	(1) Raves are not an "official" function.  Rave promoters can't 
afford to pay for the cops to provide adequate security from the get-go; 
in the case of Daytona, the local taxpayers probably footed the bill.  
The result is that for "official" events, the cops are part of the 
process; thus they have a stake in seeing that the event goes forward 
successfully.  At a rave, they arrive late in the game, with an 
antagonistic outlook.  Official events also never have to worry about 
having the proper permits, because the people throwing them are in effect 
the same people in charge of overseeing the distribution of permits (this 
is generalizing somewhat, but true in a broad sense.)
	(2) Raves are not seen as important or valuable community events 
the way peace talks, parades, festivals and the like are.  We know that 
they are just as important and valuable, but the cops and the authorities 
don't -- in fact the opposite:  They view them primarily as nuisances and 
potential causes of trouble.

	While we can't hope to change these realities overnight, we don't 
have to legitimatize among ourselves the inferior treatment we 
receive because we're not a part of the official elite, and we don't have
to accept implied condemnations of our values that we know are wrong.
	In the case of the fictional problems at the Daytona peace talks, 
police and fire officials would most likely have: (1) Broken up the 
fighting and dealt with the antagonists on an individual basis, instead 
of seeing them as representative of the event as a whole and resorting to 
"group punishment" by shutting it down; (2) Calmly and politely gone 
about getting some of the people inside to exit the building in order to 
alleviate the overcrowding, perhaps by making an announcement asking 
people who didn't have a pressing need to be inside to leave for the sake 
of preserving the safety of everyone else; and (3) Ignored the issue of the 
lack of a permit altogether.
	I am suggesting that all of the above could have (and should 
have) been done at Kundalini, and at numerous other parties busted on 
similar grounds.  None of this should be taken as a defense of the 
Kundalini promoters.  Like I said, I wasn't there, and I don't know 
the people involved.  What I am saying is that whatever mistakes the 
promoters may have made, including the question of their motives, is an 
entirely separate issue.

Part of your complete nutritious breakfast,

				*** Starchild ***
______________________________________________________________________________
"
______________________________________________________________________________


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Nov 26 09:53:29 1995

Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA28110; Sun, 26 Nov 1995 09:53:26 -0800
From: blkadder@value.net

In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951126030901.21820A-100000@apollo>

On Sun, 26 Nov 1995, Starchild wrote:
*SNIP*

> 	In the case of the fictional problems at the Daytona peace talks, 
> police and fire officials would most likely have: (1) Broken up the 
> fighting and dealt with the antagonists on an individual basis, instead 
> of seeing them as representative of the event as a whole and resorting to 
> "group punishment" by shutting it down; (2) Calmly and politely gone 
> about getting some of the people inside to exit the building in order to 
> alleviate the overcrowding, perhaps by making an announcement asking 
> people who didn't have a pressing need to be inside to leave for the sake 
> of preserving the safety of everyone else; and (3) Ignored the issue of the 
> lack of a permit altogether.
> 	I am suggesting that all of the above could have (and should 
> have) been done at Kundalini, and at numerous other parties busted on 
> similar grounds.  None of this should be taken as a defense of the 
> Kundalini promoters.  Like I said, I wasn't there, and I don't know 
> the people involved.  What I am saying is that whatever mistakes the 
> promoters may have made, including the question of their motives, is an 
> entirely separate issue.
> 
> Part of your complete nutritious breakfast,
> 
> 				*** Starchild ***

You know it never ceases to amaze me that no matter how fucked up or 
irresponsible a person/promotion group is, that there are always 
excuses.

1) The space was way too small for the number of people that were in the 
building. Since tickets were being sold at the door, I imagine it was 
very simple matter for Joe Doorguy to say "Yup, it's full in there," and 
pass the information along to the promoter(s). Shoving people in like 
cattle, combined with the comments to the police by the promoters(per 
Tony Rotundo) show the utter lack of respect for the participants,the 
space, and gives a good indication of what the promoter(s) motivation was/is.

2) It is not job of the police to be babysitters. A situation arose where 
there was fighting occuring outside of an overcrowed, unpermitted party.

To play devils' advocate for a moment, if I was a police officer 
dispatched to this area where there is a big fight going on, with 
hundreds of people hanging outside of a building pushing and shoving 
their way to get in, I would be inclined to remove the source of the 
crowds desire, that is, to get into that building. If the party had 
continued, the crowd would not have dispersed and the situation would 
remain a problem. Asking some of the people to leave is at the discretion 
of the police. When there is severe overcrowding, this is seldom an 
option. Remember there are several hundred of "them" and only a handful 
of police, in a dangerous situation. All the police have to go by in this 
situation was a brawl going on outside. Doesn't speak too well.... 

Having to have permits to throw a party sucks. For the most part it is just 
legalized extortion. Perhaps if the promoters were responsible the police 
could have overlooked the lack of permit(unlikely, but I have seen it 
happen SEVERAL times.) They weren't.  

If the promoters of Kundalini really wanted to make things right, they 
could have given refunds when people were leaving. Right now, the only 
people paying for their greed and disrespect are the people that paid 
their $20. Is that right?

                                              Black Adder

I tried GHB for the first time last night.  It was GREAT!  No side 
effects.  One dose lasts about an hour, you feel a little strange for 
about an hour after that, and then...back to normal.  E on the other 
hand, although also a great rush, makes me feel like shit the next day.  

I don't even feel tired today..raring to go!!  Try it!

Dear All;

	I went to Tribal Fucked lastnight at the Richmond Armory, right 
next to the Richmond police station. If the music wasn't so good I would 
have had an awful time, but it wasn't good enough to allow Tribal Bunk to 
rip me off again, never again.

	The Richmond police REGULARS, about 10 of them, mingled with the
crowd the entire night, like metal on metal.

	I love it when I see a milatary base being used to throw a rave, 
I wait inpatiently for the time when tanks around the world are used for 
stages to dance upon, and the bon fires are fueled by AK47 & M16A2 rifle 
butts.

	I'm very curious just how much it really cost Tribal Trash to throw 
a party at this venue, my Army friends tell me the place should have gone 
for no more than $1000 - $2000 for a night max. Yet I paid $20 for my 
ticket, and got no where near what I got from Vision for $9.00 less.

	The party was so vibeless that I saw Tribal Gunk staff walking 
around blowing whistles in a vain attempt trying to get the crowd hyped 
up, unfortuately that's all there was, hype, no substance.

	The only phang good about this party I can say is they handed out 
blow pops to people in line, thanks, but I can buy my own.

	If you went, you were ripped off, sorry Tribal Bunt, but this 
raver is not gonna let you do it, or should I say give it to me, again.

I have a couple of things on my mind.  First off a question, when parties
like Tribal Funk have professional cops patroling them, do they pay the cops?
I imagine that it might be part of the rental aggreement with the space, 
but it just seems so stupid to pay people who are there to bust up the 
spirit and the vibe.  Maybe, promoters that know that there are going to 
be cops at their parties should declare the parties are drug free in advance.
Basically, to warn people of the emminent danger of police.  I know 
several people who have been harrassed and shakin down by cops at parties
in such venues.  It can be scarry as shit and unless you know the letter 
of the law about possesion you can easily be intimidated into letting a 
cop search and seize your ass.
My moral delema is  that I want to see Banco de Gaia, but I do not want 
to support the troc.  Their "security" force has a well earned reputation 
for using Physical force to deal with  problems.  Besides Doug's Organic 
account, one of my female friends was slapped in the face by them and 
when the police came they said that person did not work at the club.
To boycott or not to boycot the troc?
tomcatt

well, i'm bummed that tribal funk wasn't much fun.  oh well.


one thing to think about:  the venues for throwing large raves are 
basically nonexistant these days.  since the tagging and damage at the 
richmond civic center, the last big venue aside from that place in 
oakland where they had cyberfest, there really have not been any places 
to throw big, above-ground raves anymore.

which is why i love littler parties so much...we just have to keep the 
community strong and vital and we can party and dance together well into 
the next century, if we stay true to ourselves.

personally i would NOT go to a $20 party unless i could get in for free.  
and i would gladly work the door, tape the party, or whatever- because it 
would give me something to do for a while and make me feel more connected 
to the event.  that part is hella fun.

love,

Ann

on wednesday, nov. 29 at 4:30pm there will be a rally and boom box party 
outside the Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant, protesting the police dept's 
delay in disciplining officers after the New Years Raid fiasco (and for 
only sending 6 officers to commission-level discipline) and FOR OUR RIGHT 
TO GATHER AND DANCE!

a little background: at 4:00am, Jan. 1, the SFPD and the State Alcohol 
BVeverage Control Bureau raided a private, peaceful AIDS benefit 
party/rave, beating and arresting guests, verbally abusing them with 
homophobic slurs, and confiscating thousands of dollars in donations and 
equipment, much of which has not been returned to this day.  And while 
the Office of Citizen Complaints (OCC), the city's civilian police 
oversight agency, sustained over 50 counts of misconduct against 21 
officers,m only 6 are being sent to the Police Commission for 
discipline.  (Chief Ribera can choose how he will discipline - or - the 
rest.) At least one of the officers involved,Sgt. Haggett, has a history 
of brutality, and has sicne killed an unarmed man in the Tenderloin.

Since the raid, the SFPD have kept up their tradition: police murder of 
African- Americans, harassment of youth, sex workers and homeless people, 
illegal cooperation with the INS, arrests of peacefu demonstrators, and 
continuing crackdowns on house and hip hop parties.

the rally wed will be a way for concerned people to voice our protest, 
connect with each other, and reassert our right to gather and dance.   we 
are encouraging people to bring boom boxes and radios, and will be 
transmitting house (Acieeeed!!!) via a transmitter.

the rally is from 4:30 to 5:30 and we are encouraging people to stay for 
the Police Commission meeting afterwards.

call Action for Police Accountability at 487-5437 for more information.

take care!
monicat

hours, I don't see why we have to wait 3 hours befor they turn on the 
light show (We danced (or stood) under simple black lights until 
then).

either.  The place had windows...all closed tight.  

Police walking around the place.  I want to be able to smoke pot 
openly. Not hide it like some criminal.

Truth is; you can't be sure about a even til it happens.  Thats what 
makes the more memorable times memorable.

2. Cooke CT; Cadden GA; Margolius KA.
     Autoerotic deaths: four cases.
   Pathology, 1994 Jul, 26(3):276-80.
       (UI:  95083282)

Abstract: We describe the circumstances and post mortem medical findings of 4
    unusual fatalities where death occurred during autoerotic practice. Three
    cases occurred in young to middle-aged men--hanging, electrocution and
    inhalation of a zucchini. The manner of death in each was accidental. The
    fourth case was an elderly man who died of ischemic heart disease,
    apparently whilst masturbating with a vacuum cleaner and a hair dryer.

Barbara Tucker is one of the promoters of Underground Network, who do the well known Wednesday night parties at the Sound Factory Bar in New York - that's the night that Little Louie Vega dj's there.  Out of this collaboration have come several house tracks produced by Little Louie with Tucker as the vocalist- the most well known is last year's "Beautiful People".  The newest single is "Stay Together", and if you like soulful NY house, it's a must have.  Little Louie played it at the last Wicked here in SF and kept it going for about 20 minutes - the crowd went off in a big way ...

just against blatant drug use at parties...

Didn't do any raving: I usually find big holiday weekends to be
hitormiss for finding parties with a decent vibe - mostly misses.

I got the Spiritual Trance CD, and it's good.  My interest in trance has
waned over the past year (though I keep a few Ethan tapes handy for
my fix.)  But I still get off on the Goa style, where rubbery synths are
allowed to carry the rhythm and the kick drums are less pounding: high
energy without the braindamage.

I bought it at BPM and so probably paid more for it than almost anyone
else ($25!). It says Mixed by Goa Gil, but unless his beat-matching
skills have recently increased from 0 to 100, I'd bet it
was mixed digitally.

Tuned into FLUX TV friday nite to see if DJ Keoki is as big an asshole
as everyone says he is.  Bigger, much bigger :(.  The show as a whole 
was very well put together with an intersting assortment of  videos and
interview segments.  I wish FLUX luck in getting a wider distribution.

So did anyone go to the Survival Research Labs (SRL) show?  Technological
entities built to destroy each other, as art, is OK by me.  Maybe
if warfare and murder was presented to us as an art form we wouldn't 
get so upset about it all the time.  Like those Blue Angels; they look
so silly just flying around making noise when they're supposed to be
blowing stuff up.  Give 'em to the SRL.

Speaking of technological entities; I know it's so *mainstream*, but
Toy Story was really great.  Just like the music we rave to - there's
so much more you can do when you reduce the role of humans in the
equation.   Two digital appendages up.  "To infinity and beyond!"

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

I just sent this review to Andrew T., but since you asked I'll send it to
the rest of the list:

it was ok. we got there a bit late so it was hard to find a spot where we
could see. we finally went up on the overpass where we could look down at
the event from above. it reminded me a bit of the final night at burning
man w/out the participatory feeling. much more of a sense of "show and
audience" - so it was alot less visceral.

dark, industrial music, lots of flamethrowers, a cool armored truck-thing
that seemed to be made from a streetsweeper, a big mardi gras like head
that eventually went up in flames like everything else. The most amusing
part for me was seeing this couple arriving home at the apt. building
accross the street from the event. Upon seeing what was going on, the woman
says to the man (in an angry tone), "That's it, I'm going BACK TO THE
OFFICE!!!!"

I came a way feeling that a good, old-fashioned, demolition derby would
have been more exciting, if not as "artistic".

cheers,
ek

I've taken that approach at last few parties I've been to, including the
last F&F, and found that the quality of the experience was not in any way
diminished. In fact, I found it to be quite exhilarating. Just the music,
the visuals, the great vibe being projected by the participants, and a
healthy dose of intense dancing provided the goods. In some ways I felt
more plugged into others at the party than when under the influence. I plan
to continue experimenting with this modus operandi...

Peace,
ek

Date: Mon, 27 Nov 1995 14:16:22 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: The Importance of Tribal Funk Sucking
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Would you have a cyber-quilt if two or more threads became interwoven?

Funny thing about things sucking.  I personally thought Tribal Funk SUCKED,
but that's only because it wiped me out and left me soaking in a hot bath
once I got home from it.  So I was bitter, but sweetly so. ;^)

My thoughts on TF:  By Tony

I very reluctantly went to Tribal Funk, and felt hypocritcal, because just
days before I said to you all that I was "Saving my 20s for a worthier
cause [than Kundalini]..."  Nonetheless I decided that I would give it the
benefit of my doubt, if not just benefit it with my $20.  I reminded myself
of the event held at the Richmond Civic Center about 8 months ago (Futur?)
that had great music, so I was focused more on that than any negative
vibrations I felt.  I had my negative-vibe shields honed and on full.  I
also made sure some friends would be there to share my angst should the
party suck, or rather, suck-bad.  ;^)

They frisked people at the door.  I guess if you're not carrying anything
(which I wasn't...well, really), it's nothing to worry about.  If you were
there to turn many people "on" then you would have cause for concern.  If I
went to do that (deal), I probably would've turned away before going in.  I
too have a problem with the whole frisking process (shows lack of trust),
but we didn't let that spoil our attitude.  We all got in unscathed.  As
for the line "that fucking frisking bullshit does not a good party make."
I guess it's better than someone getting shot, or a whole bunch of people
getting drunk.  So, I have to disagree.

Here's a logical gripe of the event:  "If you intend to
let that [frisking] happen don't throw the party, it does not start the
evening off good..."  How about this instead, if YOU see frisking at the
door...go home.

So someone wrote that they made you pour water out at the gate, but then
they let you keep the container and offered free water inside?  What are
you complaining about exactly?  Unless you had a bottle full of vodka (I'm
sure their motive for making people pour out their liquids was due to
smuggled alcohol) or mushroom tea or something, why be bitter?  Lack of
alcohol helped save the event most likely.

Yes there was a strong youth presence, but because there was no alcohol,
the majority of "attitudes" seemed in check.  Fred Thorton wrote that only
"10% of people dancing before midnight...[sic]" he very well may have been
at a different event, for we started dancing immediately, and we weren't
alone.  Weird how one person sees it differently than so many others.
Granted, maybe at another event, six weeks ago, when Dutch was spinning,
more people were dancing before midnight, but shit man, that's a pretty
tough comparison.  Comparisons are odious, anyway.  People danced and
danced hard, the whole night.

The sound was great, the music was great most of the time.  The lasers
didn't start until late, but I gotta laugh that Fred was upset about just
standing under black lights for three hours.  You know Fred, there was a
line of people standing under star light waiting to get in and enjoy the
event, rather than nit-pick it.  The lights can certainly add to a party,
but come on, are they so vital that you can't have fun without them?  I can
just imagine you standing there waiting for the laser to come on so you can
finally have a good time.  Hmmm?  And once they did get going, weren't they
fucking amazing!?

I heard people were in line for a while, but it was well controlled, and
the promoters did say very clearly on their VM that it would be
one-in/one-out when it got full.  In fact their voice mail was very forward
and clear as to price and what to expect.

It got hot, but there was a very welcomed outdoor chill area (npi), you
don't find that at all huge events, there were windows open in the
stairwells ( I saw them/stood by them Fred), and there was an upstairs
"viewing deck" that wasn't too hot.  What can you do about the heat?  They
had fans going as well.

The police were there, and I too have a sour taste for police being at a
party, but they hung out upstairs a lot telling people to put out smokes
which shouldn't have been smoked inside anyway.  I didn't see anyone get
busted.  I think there were ample areas where one could smoke-out without
getting hassled.  I saw quite a bit actually.

"I love it when I see a milatary base being used to throw a rave..."  B.
Darkness.  Seemed more like a high school gym than an armory.

I heard that the cops almost didn't let them have the party, sometime
around Wed., which is pretty late in the game, and in order to have it,
they had to hire cops.  To the tune of $4,500, but that's just what I
heard.  That's not a small amount to add to the budget two days prior to
the event.  There's no way in hell the venue went for $1,000 - $2,000
Brian!  No fucking way.

I won't harangue much longer.  The point is, I went with a bunch of friends
and we all had a great time.  We didn't let petty things get us down.  We
maintained high spirits and gave off lots of great energy.  The fact that
there were younger people there, well, had they been drunk maybe that would
have really sucked, but for the most part they weren't too bad.  But who
are you -- This person:  >And getting greif from
fucking kids, I HATE THAT, next time I see 13 & 14 year olds in the line I'm
leaving, it proves to me that you don't care about the party, YOU WANT THE
MONEY.< -- to be so fucking selfish!?  It's an open party pal, you gotta
deal with kids, adults, cops, promoters, and everyone else there.  You
would see it much different if you were 18.  Can you say "Generation gap?!"

It sounds to me like a handful of people went soly to pick the party apart.
Feel free, but I will say that it was well organized, had good sound, good
music, good lights and free fruit at the end.  For a party that size, you
have to expect security, heat, frisking, and lots of different people to
party with, if you can't deal with that, then I suggest you stay home.  I
was not at all disappointed and that made me very happy.

Thanks for not ripping me off...

Tony

P.S.  Brian D. I saw you there, and I must say, you looked very, very happy
dancing in the arms of a woman.  You certainly didn't look as upset as your
post would make one think. They were giving massages, thought of you then
too.  Thought that would make you happy that they were promoting
body-healing.  No?
