From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 27 14:50:00 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA09119; Mon, 27 Nov 1995 14:50:00 -0800
Received: from eagle.is.lmsc.lockheed.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA09114; Mon, 27 Nov 1995 14:49:55 -0800
Received: from sunfse.ese.lmsc.lockheed.com by eagle.is.lmsc.lockheed.com (8.6.11/DEC-Ultrix/4.3)
	id OAA06579; Mon, 27 Nov 1995 14:44:54 -0800
Received: from ifs2.ese.lmsc.lockheed.com by sunfse.ese.lmsc.lockheed.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA14867; Mon, 27 Nov 95 14:49:08 PST
Date: Mon, 27 Nov 95 14:49:08 PST
From: jimt@sunfse.ese.lmsc.lockheed.com (Jim S. Thompson)
Message-Id: <9511272249.AA14867@sunfse.ese.lmsc.lockheed.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: SRL Show Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	     I arrived at the SRL show site (Beal St & Folsom) at 7:30.
	There were about 50 people in line, within 15 minutes there were
	about 500.  I knew someone working the gate - she said there were
	3000 tickets for the event.  It looked like it pretty much sold 
	out as I overheard some of the ticket sellers say they had run out
	of tickets....
	     The site was really cool - at the base of a huge 
	embankment and between the base of the Bay Bridge and and an 
	old concrete street bridge.  The embankment had various  figures
	and a little house with a "Party" sign constructed on it.  The 
	flat area before the embankment was covered with the usual SRL
	suspects: about 20 large crawling machines, flamethrowing machines, 
	catapults and a huge paper machier torso and head that could be bent 
	and pivoted.  There were also several other animated paper mache 
	figures.  The site was illuminated with large banks of floodlamps.
	There were bleacher seats set up that could hold a thousand or more
	people and a steel pipe barricade to separate the audience from
	the machinery.
	    Promptly at 8 tickets went on sale and people were admitted.
	The show began right at 9 with all the animal-like crawling machines
	converging while various flame throwing machines provided the proper
	ambiance.  There were huge banks of speakers set up that emitted
	deafeningly LOUD ominous droning and roaring sounds with occasional 
	voice samples that sounded like clips from news broadcasts ("6 
	people were killed in an explosion today").  Huge plumes of smoke 
	would rise from some of the machines - especially this tremendous 
	flame thrower that looked like it was built from an industrial
	ventilation blower.  One person had this machine that would send
	showers of sparks about 100 feet into the air across the site -
	it looked like a high voltage cabinet that would charge up and 
	vaporize a piece of metal that was placed into a small drum that
	acted like a cannon barrel.  There were several machines that 
	were like small cannons and would shoot projectiles (some flaming)
	toward the figures on the embankment.  There was a large catapult
	that would fling entire bales of flaming hay toward the huge torso
	and head.  One very impressive machine was a spinning disk with rods 
	and vanes that would create a vertical vortex of air.  When ignited 
	fuel was introduced, it would create a flaming tornado.  Rather 
	impressive.
	    The show lasted a little under an hour, by the end of which
	the large torso/head figure, the "Party" house and various figures
	were reduced to smoldering rubble.  Now THAT's entertainment!



        jim thompson - CUBE ROOT FACT AXON INFO GRID DATA FATE

After reading all the post on tf I decided to put my 2 liras in.

I went there pretty much expecting an over-hyped event, my wonderfully warm
greeting was by a secruity guard " put your hands in the air" was the first
thing I heard before I was frisked, not a great first impretion!  But fuck
there was nothing else I could find on sat. and I was sapposed to meet up
with a verry nice girl there(she never showed).  We hooked up with some
nice fellas from Long Beach, got stoned, had to stash the pipe as 2 cops
rolled by commenting on how nice our crack smoke smelled( no, nobody was
smoking any crack, I guess they were more stupid then they looked and
did'nt seem to care anyway)  By ~5 I really got into it, most of the thugs
had left and there was a nice vibe till it ended at 8  DJ Dan kicked ass
with some breakbeat ~11-12. Does any on know who the live performance was
by? she brought the fuckin house down.  I could'nt belive it but by the
morning I was pretty intoit!  Would i prefer a smaller more underground
rave? hell yes, but unfortunately they seem to be getting scarce lately. 
By the way a few months ago i went to an out-of-sight,  it was at the small
brick place on howard, no lazers, no visuals, no special lighting just
MUSIC!!! and a mass frenzy of groovin-sweatin party people and it was
PERFECT!! thats really all you need-good music and good vibe.  Promoters
need to get back to basics! thats how it started in the first place.  Even
though for me TF was pretty good I could never go to one like that every
weekend the scene would really be played out fast.  In sum I was plesantly
suprised but I'll always prefere the underground.

P.S If the capcity of that lacal was 1500 which they said on the info line,
and it filled (which it did) thats-1500x20.00=$30,000  thats ALOT of moolah
where the fuck did it all go?

SEEya
Mark

I do have to agree, the vibes in line were pretty bad, and it took a 
bit to get things going, but once things got going, so did the vibes! I 
myself had a great time, although I called it an early evening at 3:30 
am thus missing the come-down set.  The cops that were wandering around 
didn't strike me as being too offensive (as cops go) compared to what 
it sounded like at Kundalini.  They just wandered around flashing their 
lights about every now and then, and I myself didn't see anybody get 
busted, and at least the party was allowed to continue!  Could have 
been way worse than it was.  And I did manage to find one sfraver 
there, purely by coincidence actually, no badges or anything else 
involved.  Very cool guy.  
By the way, after I went outside the party, while I was waiting for my 
ride, a fire engine drove up and parked for a while right out front.  
Does anybody know what this was about?  I missed the bleeding person, 
so the fire engine had left before that happened.  It roared up with 
lights flashing, and then just appeared to sit there for a while, and 
then disappeared.  Just wondering what that was all about.

Shawna

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Re: drugs/alcohol
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>On Mon, 27 Nov 1995, Brenda Brewer wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> I'd like to get some feedback from people out there who don't feel the
>> need to include drugs/alcohol as part of their raving experience.  just
>> curious.

I have been on the 'rave a week' plan for all summer. I took E nearly every
time I went out. Yes, I was having an awesome time(!), but I figured that I
would start to tone it down a bit and get back to work during the
fall/winter, so I have been going out sober since F&F and having a good
time not on drugs.

I went to Tribal Funk with the intention of taking E. When we got there at
around 11:30, I immediately started dancing my self into a frenzy, and I
was having a *great* time. But at around 2am I realized how exhausted my
body was from going to Organic Friday night, I decided that I would crash
pretty hard if I took E simply to stay dancing all the way though until
8am. (This would have most likely affected my being at SRL Sunday night I
figured).

So I decided it would be best not to take E just for the speedy effects.
(Unfortunately, this fatal decision to stay sober would later leave me
hopelessly out-of-phase from the drugged masses...)

Then, the last person (not yet on drugs) in the group I was with (who, by
the way, were all on drugs) told me (making me feel really stupid) "Don't
you realize that these parties are *designed* for taking drugs?!?!"

That one stopped me cold in my tracks.( Another in a long list of Saturday
night vibe-killers for me...)

Now ever since Saturday night around 2:00am I have been wholly consumed in
analyzing what I have been doing while raving all this time? If it really
is so drug-focused, I feel like my bubble's been burst!

Raving was a special, magical, spiritual event when I went out, and the
drugs always seemed secondary, although still important as a catalyst to
pass into the 'next dimension'.

I mean, when I was taking E, it was to turn a great party into an awesome,
magical, unforgettable experience. If I am *supposed* to take E to turn
something like Tribal Funk from what it was (all specific critique
withheld) into a great rave, and parties like Tribal Funk were indeed
*designed* for drug useage, maybe I should not be raving, as I never want
to go "to a place just to take drugs" called a rave much in the same way I
would not plan a vacation to Amsterdam just to "find a place to smoke
opium", etc. It's just TOO drug focused for my comfort.

Mind you, at TF, all my friends that thought it was an great party were all
on drugs. I had 'only' a good time, and I was in the 'not on drugs'
category. I never want drugs to be the #1 focus of a party or my life.

Don't worry, if what I've written sounds confusing, you should have been
inside my brain the last 36 hours while I have thought about all of this.

I hope I figure it out.

_____________________________________________________________________

San Francisco CA 94107    FAX: 415.826.6100      http://www.club.net/

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 27 18:16:02 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Re: Organic...bad vibe? ( w/ Tribal Funk and Trocadero tibits too)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 11:52 PM 11/26/95, Christopher Lawrenc Kawaja wrote:
>Uhhh...
>
>I don't want to sound spoilt or anything, but I went to Organic, and I
>was waiting in line, and the vibe I was getting was terrible.  Nobody was
>talking to anyone, and the whole attitude seemed really negative...I just
>left before the thing started.  Sorry.

The upside:

The first thing that made me think that there was hope for Organic is that
it was NOT AT THE TROCADERO. I have had parties there before, and as long
as it's not rave-related (mine was industrial/bondage related so they loved
me! Hee-Hee) :-) they are OK to deal with. But the punk management and the
punk security definitely seem to deplore and loathe the rave community and
the rave scene. When I was there the last three years every Wednesday for
Bondage-A-Go-Go, there was always adequate ventilation and free water. At
the last Organic, they *turneed off the air conditioning, took away the
free water, and charged $2+ for bottled water. The whole place was WAY
oversold and it was like a sauna there!!! As far as I can tell, the Troc
was saying "fuck you, ravers!" since the next night the A/C seemed to be
working OK again and the free water & cups had magically returned for a
punk show I was at.

Anyway, I went to Organic, and the first time we drove past it, I noticed
the high ganster-kidz to raver ratio, and I got a bad feeling. We parked
our cars and got in line anyway, and the people in line and BIG security
guards frisking at the door freaked me out. But we had our own group there
(Vince, Amy Starkey, et. al.) and decided that we'd have fun anyway!

Well, we did, and I'll tell ya' inside we spent all of our time dancing,
dancing, dancing. It was great! Carlos, Jeno, and Simon all played great
music and we even spent time dancing w/ Carlos behind the front speakers.
He is a maniac!

The downside:

THE PRICE (15.00) WAS NOT ON THE INFO LINE.

Water was $2.50. Gee thanks. And that was on top of $15.00 to get in to
what should have been a $10 party.

The security guards were searching everybody going in, and once we were in
the security was always underfoot, even walking THROUGH the dance floor
with their flashlights on. But to tell you the truth, none of the ravers
took them seriously, and we kinda got used to them. I started waving to
them as they walked by after a while.

That was the first party I have been to where I was FRISKED at the door,
and I am kinda feeling after that I don't WANT to go to a party where the
promoters actively attract the KIND of people that you HAVE to frisk going
into a party.

TRIBAL FUNK (partial):

Anyway, the same crap happened at Tribal Funk. Being frisked AGAIN at the
door there makes me want to tell the promoters of both parties to not sow
their promotional seed (flyers) so far and wide that they attract the kind
of customers that have to be frisked and begged 'not to tag'.

Tag? What the hell? Who do *we* even know that tags? Why are they coming to
raves? Should't they just stay home and defend their block from the rival
gangs? Do I have a bad attitude about this?

Now just think about it if we HAD to frisk you on your way into a Friends
and Family? What if we had to BEG you on the info lines not to tag the
walls with your gang crap when you were there? What's wrong wigh this
picture? Get it?

enough said,
-w

San Francisco CA 94107    FAX: 415.826.6100      http://www.club.net/

-------------
info from NW-RAVES:

From: DirkJan@aol.com
Date: Wed, 15 Nov 1995 15:13:20 -0500
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: EBN, Banco de Gaia info

EBN stands for "Emergency Broadcast Network"
(http://www.tvtrecords.com/bands/ebn.html). You might have seen their work in
the Electric Carnival tent of the Lollapalooza '94 tour where they had
several Macs running with their own midi-based video controller.
   EBN comes out of the heads of Joshua Pearson and Gardner Post who met at
the great artschool Rhode Island School of Design.
   EBN started in 1991 during the Persian Gulf War, exploring seemingly
random received information from cable-tv, music and other sounds, turning
them into high-energy music videos.
   Important part of their performance is throwing a visual and musical
information-overload at their audience. I haven't seen their show yet but
this is how the bands' press release describes EBN's multi-media sensory
assault: "Multiple video screens overflow with thousands of broadcast images
crushed into a high-speed image overload. "Host anchorperson" Josh Pearson
talks, raps, mumbles and screams (sometimes through a megaphone) as he
interacts with the video while standing on a huge robotic podium bristling
with TV monitors, lights, and lasers; EBN DJs and VJs cut and scratch sounds
and images live using turntable, video switchers, and Macintosh computers
running special new VideoSampler software."
   Their current CD, Telecommunication Breakdown (TVT Records), has audio and
video on it which can be played in both your CD player and (PC and Mac)
CD-rom drive. It also contains an interactive Macintosh only floppy disk with
images, liner notes, group history, lyrics, merchandising.

   Banco de Gaia is Toby Marks (UK), an ambient megalomaniac
(http://www.obsolete.com/~banco/ ). He has a training in jazz, bhangra and
electronic music. He loves to use exotic sounds, like on his album Maya
(Middle East) and his current Last Train to Lhasa (Tibet, China, Albania,
North Africa), mixed with hip-hop and house-beats. Sure, ethnocentric
dance-music is pretty en vogue nowadays, and cultural piracy can be
embarressingly painful. But fortunately,  Toby sincerely tries to raise
awareness and political support for the endangered Tibetan culture, by
showing way more respect for the original material than many of his less
gifted peers.


_____________________________________________________________________
Wayne D. Correia
900 Tennessee St.         TEL: 415.826.6000            wayne@club.net
San Francisco CA 94107    FAX: 415.826.6100      http://www.club.net/

Dear All;

	Where did all the money go, hmmm, know that's the ? of the hour,
and one that's also none of my bussiness, but I to am certainly curious.
Tony I most respectfully say, that I believe your wrong with regard to the
price of the venue, I had Army Reserve Personnel with me, they hated the
rave, and thought it was to much for an Army Building, Tony an Armory
Hall, in down town Richmond, THINK about it, where they have like 
Weddings, & Corporate Bankquets, cheap, cheap, cheap. But I encourage you 
to call them tomorroe as I am, just to give TF the benefit of the doubt, 
and just to see how much it costs really, please post your result as I will.

> and it filled (which it did) thats-1500x20.00=$30,000  thats ALOT of moolah

	If they had to pay $4,500 for the cops to be there just because
it's next to the police station, then TF, are fools!!! $4,500 could have
gone toward booking a really hot outta towner. They could have hired
Brinks or the Hells Angles for less. I'm not gonna support parties throw
by people who can't manage them properly, and having it end up costing the
scene more. Martin got the Fuckin Sound Factory for Vision, along with
some of SF's finest, and had 11 DJ's, and it was $11, before 11 o'clock.
How ccan you say this party was well managed. There where also arrests, at
least one I witnessed for drugs.

because they bring in a massage therapist doesn't make the party. Cruel
World does it all da time, and would you go to one of theirs? My happiness
at TF has everything to do with the fact, yes, that I was with the most
beautiful womyn in the world, no doubt there. However, that happiness has
nothing to do with TF or the rave, but everything to do with her = >. I don't
no why I'm not doublely pissed cause, I bought her ticket as well. SHe's
from Germany, and was very upset with the "negativity of the people who
attended, why is no one dancing, & no one seems to care", were just some
of her quotes for the night. 

	We had a good time no matter what in true raver form, but left 
only to find our car had been blocked in on 4 sides by those kind, loving 
respectful people you were talking about, with the Police & TF refusing 
to do anything about it, so me and 4 others sat their for 2 hours waiting 
for those people to leave, and guess what; we could get back in without 
paying, you guessed it, another $20/each @ 5AM.

friends like that who needs Cruel World. Well, I'm glad to see that 50% 
of the respondents seemed to have a good time, I really mean that. I'm 
sure TF did everything they could to throw a great party, less hireing a 
consultant for resource/greed management.

regard to the price of the venue for a night, which should be public info.

re: what wayne said

I think the terminology "these parties were designed to take drugs at" is 
the problem...from a strange perspective look at it in terms of a tribal 
setting.  Certain tribal evetns were designed to bring you closer to a 
trance/meditation state or a deity or yourself and often this was 
achieved by taking drugs.  A question you may ask yourself in this day 
and age since circumstance is nowhere near alike to tribal cultutres, is 
whether or not you think raves are designed for something?  I help 
organize raves because I realize the potential that danicng holds for 
self renewal and spiritual cleansing that society doesn't offer very 
often these days.  I have achieved thru drugs and not thru drugs so for 
me it is not a wquestion of whether the rave is designedto take drugs at 
but how I want to achieve what I think what raves are designed for.

love drenalin

ps sorry if this confused i'm trying to beat being timed out =)

All I can say is that it's just terrible to let one person's dumb 
opinion (in my dumb opinion!) about the existence of these parties to 
ruin your whole perspective on it.  I think it's quite sad that he sees 
them as just an excuse to do drugs.  I agree that it's pretty effective 
in creating a door to another dancier dimension, but he's obviously not 
seeing beyond that door, when there's so much more cool shit on the 
other side!  Don't let his near-sighted point of view change the way 
you feel about it all, I'm pretty new at all this (Organic was my first 
"Offical Rave"), but I've seen a lot of people in my time who seemed to 
think of life in general as an excuse to do drugs, with no sight to 
beyond it, and it's pretty pathetic.  Don't get me wrong, I thoroughly 
enjoy my drugs myself!  Had a killer time at Organic on E.  But it 
seems to me it's just common sense to know there's usually more than 
just the door there, and I think you know that, unlike that other guy.

>
>I have been on the 'rave a week' plan for all summer. I took E nearly 
every
>time I went out. Yes, I was having an awesome time(!), but I figured 
that I
>would start to tone it down a bit and get back to work during the
>fall/winter, so I have been going out sober since F&F and having a 
good
>time not on drugs.
>
>I went to Tribal Funk with the intention of taking E. When we got 
there at
>around 11:30, I immediately started dancing my self into a frenzy, and 
I
>was having a *great* time. But at around 2am I realized how exhausted 
my
>body was from going to Organic Friday night, I decided that I would 
crash
>pretty hard if I took E simply to stay dancing all the way though 
until
>8am. (This would have most likely affected my being at SRL Sunday 
night I
>figured).
>
>So I decided it would be best not to take E just for the speedy 
effects.

>hopelessly out-of-phase from the drugged masses...)

by

consumed in

really

the
>drugs always seemed secondary, although still important as a catalyst 
to
>pass into the 'next dimension'.
>
>I mean, when I was taking E, it was to turn a great party into an 
awesome,
>magical, unforgettable experience. If I am *supposed* to take E to 
turn
>something like Tribal Funk from what it was (all specific critique
>withheld) into a great rave, and parties like Tribal Funk were indeed

want

way I

Hi all.  I KNOW this is OLD news, but I have been lurking and feel I 
should contribute once in a while.  I too was at Chrysalis and it was 
overall a very POSITIVE experience for me.  It was my first "smaller" 
rave, as the last one I went to was a LARGE party at the San Diego Sports 
Arena (during the 4.0+ earthquake!) with SVEN VATH spinning as the 
headliner.  This Chrysalis was a COMPLETE 180 from the last one, in fact 
I am probably going to goto this one too.

The vibe was GREAT!  We got there at 1am and stayed til 7am, not that 
long but still I had a good time.  The Music was EXCELLENT- although I am 
too new to know WHO was spinning WHAT.  The smart lights were cool, but 
the lazers were something to be seen (ok, it wasn't LAZERIUM...).  With 
TWO large projection screens I found myself in a total trance with the 
music, and the chill room was a WARM friendly place.  However, I am a bit 
new so I didn't really see anyone I knew.  So, I hope to goto more 
parties like that in the future and get to meet some of you out there in 
net land...

THe fruit and candy were good ideas to have out there.  Good planning, as 
this was the first time I've been to one of these where RE-CHARGING will 
not cost you the price of a movie!

I am just wondering how some of you experienced ones out there managed to 
not get tired quickly.  Also, how do you get over the natural inhibitions 
of meeting a bunch of new people?  Perhaps as I get more familiar with 
the scene it will all fall into place...

Oh, but the way, I DID bring EARplugs...and do they ever help!!!

A bit about me:(intro)

22.  Graduated from San Francisco State (B.A. in Radio & Television, 
minor in Bus. Admin.).  This summer I worked as a camera operator for 
this Nickelodeon-type game show we taped at Great America.  This month, 
the job ended and I am now temping at Adaptec (and making MORE than I was 
previously!) while I find another TV/video production job...  Like 
concerts/live shows (Stone Roses, Catherine Wheel, 
Trashcan Sinatras, Chapterhouse, Course of Empire, Pixies, Northside, 
Wild Swans, Ocean Blue...Swervedriver and Bailter Space are some fave 
bands I like).  Also ski and am getting into surfing.  Like active 
lifestyle...

Computer: 100mhz Pentium w/ 16megs and 800meg HD, CD-ROM (ANY 
recommendations for GOOD games out there???  I KNOW of "Full Throttle" 
and "Descent"... 14.4K modem.  ANYONE know of where I can get a 28,8K for 
around $150???

The WEB page here is GREAT!  AWESOME job on the graphics!!!!
I will go there often!  

Well, sorry to have bored you to death!  So much for my .02

Austin wrote:
it also listed tracks by the
>LowSpirit/Mayday family (Marusha, Westbam, etc.), N-Trance, and thirteen
>other groups. So I bought it and took it home.
>this is extremely happy hardcore

i am fine with everyone having their own definitions of music ...i just
want to clear up what is commonly called happy hardcore..

happy hardcore (also called 4-beat) is a form of dance music from england
which came out of the old techno scene and the '92 breakbet scene...it has
a fast, usually breakbeat, and uses a lot of super sped up piano tunes and
women's vocals..it is typified by such acts as vibes, wishdokta, jimmy j
and cru-l-t, etc....labels include rmix, kniteforce, impact....dj's like
slipmatt, sy, vibes, dougal....just lettin you all know...for more info
check dj casper's jungle/happy hardcore page....there is a link on breaks
or email me for the location...

there is also ."happy gabber" which is different

the acts you are talking about are all german rave acts...usually under
"rave" or simply "techno" or "hardcore" (but they're not even really
considered that)

sorry to be anal..but i feel the need to clear this up

yes yes
 *the dj stareyes*

Sorry to jump into this so late...

What's "appropriate" for this list is a pretty broad subject - certainly, 
in my opinion, talking about san francisco city politics is fine, talking 
about timewave zero and 2012 is borderline but not wrong, etc.  it used 
to be a bigger issue for me, but then I started using better mail reading 
tools, which allowed me to do lots of nice sorting and threading and 
such.  I now read SFRaves mail about once every week or so - I just went 
through 350 messages in less than an hour.  I'd encourage other people to 
do the same. 

However, better mail filtering is no excuse for making sfraves noisier... 
please, before you decide to send a message, consider for a second that 
your message is duplicated and sent to (currently) 422 people's 
mailboxes.  

Finally, anyone who relies *solely* upon SFRaves for their social 
interactions and news reports and such are in my opinion asking too much 
from the list, and should consider, er, broadening their interest 
horizon.  Does a "virtual community" mean that membership is exclusive?  
I certainly hope not, and that's not why I created the list.

On Fri, 17 Nov 1995, Rob Jellinghaus wrote:
> Five years ago, sfraves itself wasn't nearly as hopping as it is now. 

ha!  5 years ago it was but a gleam in a young boy's 17-year-old eye.  :)

> Growth has its good side and its bad side.  I prefer to go with the 
> flow and learn to surf more efficiently, since all the newbies are as 
> entitled to this net--and to the ability to say what's on their 
> mind--as you or I were back in the day.

Well, that's sorta like saying all 15-year-olds are entitled to drive 
their cars any way they like on the public roads.  No... not if we care 
about preserving our "fine anarchy", to paraphrase Mark Pesce.

	Brian

My computer tells me that on Mon, 27 Nov 1995, Jim Trickett shared:

> At 10:24 PM 11/26/95 -0800, Fred Thornton wrote:
> >
> >Police walking around the place.  I want to be able to smoke pot 
> >openly. Not hide it like some criminal.
> 
> Am I reading this right?  You don't want to have to hide pot - an illegal
> drug - you want to be able to smoke it in the open?  A rave (especially a
> big one like TF) is a very public place...perhaps you might consider being a
> little more discreet?  Whatever your complaints about a party, I don't think
> not being able to smoke pot in the open should be among them.  And just to
> defer argument, I'm not against pot - I smoke it myself occasionally - I'm
> just against blatant drug use at parties...
> 
> Jim

Am *I* reading you right, Jim?  You don't think the potential for getting 
busted and thrown in jail for the simple act of smoking an herb you 
purchased honestly to increase your enjoyment of the evening should be a 
concern at parties?  

And are you really against blatant drug use at parties, or only illegal 
drug use?  What would you do if you saw someone guzzling coffee?  And if 
this isn't a problem, please explain exactly how pot is so much different?

Your bud,

Recently,  Brenda Brewer <shakti@teleport.com> asked:
> 
> I'd like to get some feedback from people out there who don't feel the 
> need to include drugs/alcohol as part of their raving experience.  just 
> curious...
> 
 Drugs: My normal rave mode is without the enhancement of illegal substances.
        Trances are shorter but more "special". I can chill out when I want
        to - some drugs keep a person hyper when rest is what's called for.

 Alcohol: If the event is in an establishment that normally is a bar or
          nightclub, then I usually buy one alcoholic drink to encourage the
          management - and I like a drink occasionally. While booze has
          some pain-reducing qualities , it also dulls my "vibe" for an
          hour or so.  

 That's my opinion - Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Wayne Wrote:

>I have been on the 'rave a week' plan for all summer. I took E nearly every
>time I went out. Yes, I was having an awesome time(!), but I figured that I
>would start to tone it down a bit and get back to work during the
>fall/winter, so I have been going out sober since F&F and having a good
>time not on drugs.
>
>I went to Tribal Funk with the intention of taking E. When we got there at
>around 11:30, I immediately started dancing my self into a frenzy, and I
>was having a *great* time. But at around 2am I realized how exhausted my
>body was from going to Organic Friday night, I decided that I would crash
>pretty hard if I took E simply to stay dancing all the way though until
>8am. (This would have most likely affected my being at SRL Sunday night I
>figured).
>
>So I decided it would be best not to take E just for the speedy effects.
>(Unfortunately, this fatal decision to stay sober would later leave me
>hopelessly out-of-phase from the drugged masses...)
>
>Then, the last person (not yet on drugs) in the group I was with (who, by
>the way, were all on drugs) told me (making me feel really stupid) "Don't
>you realize that these parties are *designed* for taking drugs?!?!"
>
>That one stopped me cold in my tracks.( Another in a long list of Saturday
>night vibe-killers for me...)
>
>Now ever since Saturday night around 2:00am I have been wholly consumed in
>analyzing what I have been doing while raving all this time? If it really
>is so drug-focused, I feel like my bubble's been burst!
>
>Raving was a special, magical, spiritual event when I went out, and the
>drugs always seemed secondary, although still important as a catalyst to
>pass into the 'next dimension'.


There are tribal cultures in which by way of initiation a person is given
some sort of drug substance and has a vision or see's the light or increases
his/her level of consciousness for a short time.  After the experience they
are expected to find out how to get back there on thier own, without the
drug.  If they can make it, then they get to go on to the next step and
repeat the process to the next level.  I believe in this methode myself.  I
believe that drugs can nock you out of your mundane existance and show you
something more....but then it's up to you.  The drug will only work to a
certain extent.  I've battled with this issue for a few years now, having
found the existance of higher states of consciousness through drugs, relying
on them to get me there, then being fucked by them for not figuring out that
it was up to me not them to get me there.  Sober experience have always been
more fulfilling, and seem to impact me more.  It's easy to deny somthing
magical if it was drug induced.  Al of this ofcourse is IMHO.

Rick

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Nov 28 10:17:09 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA06979; Tue, 28 Nov 1995 10:17:09 -0800

From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Message-Id: <199511281746.JAA25262@netcom20.netcom.com>
Subject: booze/drugs/nothing it's all good!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 28 Nov 1995 09:46:49 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2404      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I have had good times w/o use of anything.  I have had bad times w/o the 
use of anything.  Some folx I know use enhancers so that they need not 
see the ugliness that surrounds them.  I've heard as many reasons as 
excuses.  to me it's all good.  If you want to or if you want to avoid 
it, I see no difference.  What irks me however, are people , especially 
young first-timers, who are neither emotionally or mentally ready to use 
any form of drug.  It matters little, could be cofee, booze, or another 
psycho-stimulant/depressant.  Nothing is funnier/tragic than seeing some 
fool kid loose all marbles and jump at the turntables, or seeing people 
walk around talking to themselves in a deep hallucinatory state, or 
seeing people brush off bugs and shit that ain't really there, or seeing 
someone go apeshit and start swinging at fences.

At events I've been to (mostly these days 21+), shit is usually under 
control, although 21+ have thier stupid problems too like taking too much 
GHB (what is a little for some folx is plenty for others; tricky stuff) 
anfd having to go to the hospital for respitory arrest, or cardiac 
flutter/arrythmia.  Seeing older folx not know when enough is too much as 
they mix all kinds of drugs w/ booze and end up quite dead (like the guy 
a few years back at the End Up).

I say as long as you are educated, and make rational decisions about what 
you do/don't do, everything can end up just fine.

Things have changed from the old days:
It seems now people HAVE to crack-on to have a good time.  I know many 
don't, but many more do.  It's almost as if it's a pre-requisite to have 
a good time.  Before it was more of a communal thing, trying to catch a 
vibe spread it, and share it.  These days it seems like the drugs create 
a vibe instead of the music, and as such, you'll find lower energy levels 
at events where drugs are scarce.  Kinda sad, shit used to be used to 
augment, now either the music is so bad, or people are so jaded, that 
anything other than reality is a blessing.  Yes, I long for the old 
days.  I'm glad I was there for 'em.

Until they are brought back, I'm down with tha green.

Out,
John

BSP - Charlotte and I will be playing at Butterfly the second week of 
Dec.  It's on a Tues., stop by, have a beer (yes, it's 21+), and say 
hello.  Also get a chance to hear the Baroness stomp some hedz! (fyi- 
CHarlotte == Baroness).

There have been a couple different sfraves buttons and badges.  I think a
couple might still be floating around for those who are interested.

As for the End Up . . . *well* . . . A legendary place, of which I barely
know even the beginning of the legend.  My understanding is that it's
been one of the premier gathering spots for the gay community south of
Market for 20 years and maybe longer.  It supposedly "closed" earlier
this year but except for maybe a weekend or two they haven't missed a
beat.  I've only been there a couple of times but it's definitely a
unique place, right by the elevated freeway at 6th & Harrison.  

I'm sure there are plenty of people here on sfraves who really have the
stories about the End Up!

phred

TONIGHT!:

>                Silicon Valley SIGGRAPH November Meeting
>
>                     Pixar and Disney's 'Toy Story'
>
>        Rick Sayre, Ronen Barzel, Rich Quade, and  Hal Hickel, Pixar
>
>                    Tuesday, November 28, 1995
>                    Apple Auidtorium
>                    4 Infinite Loop
>                    Cupertino
>
>                    7:30 pm Networking & Socializing
>                    8:00 pm Meeting
>                    Admission free, open to all and to all ages!
>
>As Steve Jobs told us all in his keynote speech at SIGGRAPH '95 last
>summer in Los Angeles, 1995 is the 100th anniversary of the first
>moving picture.  1995 will be significant in motion picture history for
>a second reason.  The soon-to-be-released feature length movie, 'Toy
>Story', co-produced and animated by Pixar and Disney Studios is the
>first feature length film whose frames are 100% computer generated.
>Come to the SIGGRAPH meeting to hear from the principal developers how
>the movie was made and all about mind boggling facts such as: the
>number of gigabytes (terabytes?) of disk to store the animation frames,
>the hours (years?) of CPU time for generating them, and, of course,
>inside stories about how some of the magical effects were produced.
>
>
>Directions (for those of you in Santa Clara County):
>>From Highway 280, take the De Anza Boulevard off ramp south towards
>Cupertino.
>Turn left at Mariani.
>Turn left into the second driveway.
>The auditorium is in building 4, the second building on the right.
>
>For further information,
>call Domenic Allen at (408) 720-9669, ext. 7448. or domenic@acm.org
>http://www.best.com/~siggraph
>http://www.toystory.com

>>On Mon, 27 Nov 1995, Brenda Brewer wrote:
>>> I'd like to get some feedback from people out there who don't feel the
>>> need to include drugs/alcohol as part of their raving experience.  just
>>> curious.
> 
> In a galaxy, far far away - people use to go parties to experience good music.

	Once upon a time, people went to parties to be with people, in an
environment where no one was going to tell them their way of doing
whatever they were doing was evil and wrong (as long as one took care of
themselves and was open and kind). At that time and place, people went for
different reasons I would think, but I think the main pull of raves
thorughout the world (or at least the parties I am talking about), was the
music and a vibe which centered around the people who went and each
one of those people contributing what they could while pulling their own
weight in their community.
	Then somehow that all got fashionable and people started going to 
be seen and look cool and do the drugs they could find and the energy of 
the firt group got diluted a bit. Then more people started citing drug 
use as evil (illegal drug use I suppose) instead of the 
irresponsible/false behavior that accompanied use by many of this newer 
group of people. I do not think the focus of all raves was 
everlet's-go-eat-some-drugs (although I think some of the sound 
systems/promoters out there both in the past and in this day do have that 
attitude, but I think they are spin-offs of what I consider the 
underground party scene or festies, or whatever it is that I consider 
raves which happens to not be parties like Cool World and Funky Techno 
Tribe massives or Ghost tribe productions parties which charge $20 or 
gather the "cool" people).
	People go for all different reasons, they have and will. Why worry
about the evidence of problems and not complain about the problem
themselves if we are going to complain. If people dislike aspects of raves
such as people changing during the course of the night into huggable,
friendly humans (but then return to grumpy asshole in the morning) then
dislike the fact that some people abuse things (whether it be drugs or the
environment they are in) and not the things they abuse... 

dave

hey folks,
On the subject of haus/techno radio shows, I thought that I should mention
that my friend does a show on Thursday nights from10-whenever.
He does it on Radio Libre 103.3, Radio Libre is a pirate station in the 
Mission.  It is easiest to tune in to it in the mission but it does reach 
out into other hoods.  He is always looking for guests to come and play
or tapes that he can play.  He does not limit the show to dance music, so 
he is also interested in ambient/dub.  If anyone is interested in hooking 
up with him, send me something any I will get you his phone number.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Nov 28 15:04:03 1995

Received: from van-pm-0920.direct.ca (van-pm-0920.direct.ca [204.174.244.20]) by fun.direct.ca (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id OAA18149; Tue, 28 Nov 1995 14:58:13 -0800

X-Sender: ttricket@Direct.CA
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 28 Nov 1995 15:09:36 -0800
To: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
From: ttricket@Direct.CA (Jim Trickett)
Subject: Re: Tribal Plunk, or Plop, Fissle, ; Mixed = <
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 04:50 AM 11/28/95 -0800, Starchild wrote:
>
>Am *I* reading you right, Jim?  You don't think the potential for getting 
>busted and thrown in jail for the simple act of smoking an herb you 
>purchased honestly to increase your enjoyment of the evening should be a 
>concern at parties?  

Of course it's a concern!  But the fact that u know it's illegal and the
fact that there are police in sight should maybe guide your use of it.  I
don't see pot as a *necessity* when raving and I don't think anyone should
consider smoking pot at a party an inherent *right*.  

>And are you really against blatant drug use at parties, or only illegal 
>drug use?  What would you do if you saw someone guzzling coffee?  And if 
>this isn't a problem, please explain exactly how pot is so much different?

Good distinction...I'm against blatant, illegal drug use.  I think people
openly consuming drugs at raves only provides ammunition for those who would
put a stop to parties altogether.  No, I don't see guzzling coffee as a
problem, because coffee isn't illegal.  From the tone of your msg, you seem
to imply that I am against pot, which isn't true.  I think ppl should merely
be more discreet in their consumption of it (or indeed of any illegal
substance) in public, at a rave.  I know many, myself included, see raves as
an "oasis" of sorts from everyday problems, and like to augment their
experience with drugs, but the fact is everyone is still subject to the law
when they are in a rave.  One shouldn't *expect* and *demand* the _right_ to
smoke pot at a party - they should instead always be discreet about their
consumption or consume their drugs somewhere else...at least until laws get
changed and drugs become better tolerated by society in general, as in
Holland (or even as here in Vancouver, BC, where possession of small
quantities of pot won't be prosecuted)  

Jim
 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Happiness is merely the remission of pain.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Hello out there all in computerland,
    
    I went to MAD lastnight for the first time, and I just wanted to
say....MAD RULES!!  O.K, it's like this, have you ever had a dream where
your hanging out at a place.  Your not sure where you are, but your there
observing.  As you look out into a crowd people you sense warmth and energy.
Your eyes continue to look around and a freindly person comes over to share
their energy with you.  You don't know that person, or you do, it doesn't
seem to make a difference because your only in the moment, and in the momemt
one  can onlyfeel, not judge or remember.  You're a child, you're smiling,
you don't understand anything,... exept you have no desire to.  There is a
glow around everything.  Children.  You find yourself emerged with children.
They're playing, laughfing, dancing.  You start to run around and laugh.
There are no parents... no teachers...only children.

At 6:14 PM 11/27/95, Wayne D. Correia wrote:
>
>Now ever since Saturday night around 2:00am I have been wholly consumed in
>analyzing what I have been doing while raving all this time? If it really
>is so drug-focused, I feel like my bubble's been burst!
        Well, personally speaking, i think that rave culture and the use of
psychedelics (including E) have a symbiotic relationship. It wouldn't be
what it is without drugs (please don't flame me yet!). The rapid evolution
of this scene, and the way it focuses itself, the music, the clothing, the
ideas that are generated from within these 'places' are all influenced
greatly by those who do drugs. Now, that is not to say that one HAS to do
drugs. I know of many straight-edge people who are a lot more vibey and
'with it' than those who partake and this, i think is partially due to the
'contact high' effect and learning and communicating with those who are
on/have done drugs or maybe they're JUST BORN WAY COOL! :)
        Basically, it's a culture that is heavily influenced by the use of
some drugs, but it's not necessary to do drugs all the time to get the full
experience of it. Personally, the experience of doing E at a party for my
first time put the whole culture in a completely different light. Like,
"aha!" and this is a good thing, but not a path you have to take every
weekend. :)
        Remember: 'vibe' is something that is within you already that drugs
bring out, it's the 'easy' way, but there are other ways of tapping in to
that kind of energy :) Like Rick said, all of this is IMHO, hee hee.
        peace,
        brad

ps-->In general, when i look at my involvement with anything (raves, drugs,
people, technology, whatever) i ask whether it complexifies the connection
that i have both to others and to my 'higher self' or whether it or
*separates* my self from others or my 'good side' :) It's a tough call but
a good general rule that i do my best to follow.

From: mac <70730.2126@compuserve.com>

>Question one:  Has anybody ever heard of an S.F. place called the End 
>Up?  Had heard of it, wondered if it was any good, and what it was all 
>about.

well.. the End Up is sort of a mix of 2 places really... a place where one
"ends up" on a Sat/Sun morning...as well as a place where one can place
one's "end" up .. if u get my gist :)  As far as most ravers are concerned, I
suppose, it's a place to go to hang out with every other bugger that stayed
out the whole nite before, and drink Rolling Rocks (that's the best they have:)
and listen to deep house at 7AM.  However, at that time, besides fuckers like
me who look basically wrecked after a nite out.. u also have people who actually
get up at that time... looking fresh and wonderful.. . and venture down there to
spend the day dancing. (This is especially true on Sunday) Took me a long time 
to figure out why those people looked so damned good after a nite out, and we
all
looked so shitty... they had just gotten up!!

On a warm summer Sunday morning it's a heavenly place... albeit inhabited
by mostly devilish individuals. It has an outdoor patio, great door people,
ok music (good house), no vibe (a lot of speed merchants up since Thursday
morning :)
but whaddya want when the sun is shining in ur face and the music is 
pumping hard, and ur only half awake? Still a friendly place tho...

It also is one of the oldest gay bars in the city of SF and I believe the 
place where the wet jockey contest was invented :)  An interesting thing
to watch is its transformation from mostly straight crowd to gay crowd 
over the course of a Sunday morning/afternoon/evening (yeah... i've done a 
12 hour stint there after a rave :)

True story of an attempted pick-up at 6PM at the End Up of a straight
friend of mine:

"Wow... ur beautiful... are u gay or bi?"
"um.. do I have another choice ?"
"Ur straight? What u doing at a gay bar then?"
"sorry man, it was straight when I came here 12 hours ago :)"

Go there. There's history and more...

hugz :)

PS:

>Am *I* reading you right, Jim?  You don't think the potential for getting 
>busted and thrown in jail for the simple act of smoking an herb you 
>purchased honestly to increase your enjoyment of the evening should be a 
>concern at parties?  
>
>And are you really against blatant drug use at parties, or only illegal 
>drug use?  What would you do if you saw someone guzzling coffee?  And if 
>this isn't a problem, please explain exactly how pot is so much different?

I don't think the point is that drug use is right or wrong.  The point is
that it is illegal, regardless of if that is right or wrong.  The police
officers' jobs are to prevent people from breaking the law.  Even if they
think it's a shitty law (which I'm sure many of them do) it's still their
job to enforce it.  I think the fact that they knew that weed was there and
didn't confiscate it shows that they are at least trying to be relaxed about
it.  I know plenty of friends at home who had run-ins with the borderline
psychotic HBPD where they intimidated them a lot for posession, which
doesn't seem to be the case here.  In any case, Jim wasn't discussing the
moral issue, just the legal one.

Jake

BY YOUR COMMAND;

	The End Up is a place where the creatures of the night come to
gather as the ACURSED morning sun arises, along with those stupid little
noisey birds(god I hate them). In this dark place, you will find the most
narly bunch of freaks ever assembled(so freaky the sight of which would
make Rush Limbaub go immediately into full cardiac arrest), which include
the enternally SPUN raver(dats me), vampire, & vampiress, club kid(I want
to get one for X-Mas so I can walk it around on a leash at parties; you
can be the first adult on your block to own their very own SF Club Kid,
East Coast Model More Expensive; it dances better:), goth, punk, gangsta,
prep, leather boy, fag hag, drag queens calore, bull dikes, punk dikes,
bull punk dikes, political bull punk dikes(you get The general idea), an
occasional lipstick lesbian(wheres the honey), and even sometimes, the
dreaded clueless earthling. 

	These creatures can easially be identified by the following 
general appearance characteristics:

	1. Prefers useing a flashlight, & Wears dark sunglasses even in
the club. 

	2. If not wearing sunglasses, one can notice the extremely enlarged 
pupil of these creatures, being no less than the size of a quarter. NOTE; 
observation of the pupil size can easially be accomplished because these 
creatures eyelids are generally wide open.

	3. Occasionally these creatures can be identified by a mysterious 
white powder on there noses, accompanied by strange & frequent snorting 
sounds. NOTE: It is thought that this white powder is an indication that 
these creatures mite be rabid. Caution should be used approaching these 
creatures if one notices this white powder on their noses.

	4. However some of these creatures can be very friendly, touchy &
feelly, so much so that they want to come home with you, ack.

	But in general, the End Up is very much like this, so do go, and 
experience it; as most seasoned SFRavers have, just don't bring anyone home, 
from there, with you; hehe!!!, and above all, never tell your mother.

Well, I made a tape a few months back of CLUB mixes by some of my fave 
artists- and they were GOOD mixes for the most part.  Some of the tracks 
on my tape were: 

Mesmerize (CHAPTERHOUSE)- remix (lots of deep bass)
Sexuality (BILLY BRAGG)- London remix (very ravey/vigorous beats)
The Promise (WHEN IN ROME)- Colisium Club mix (KILLER off CD3-single!)
Planet Love (THE DYLANS)- Club mix (6:34 mix- ALL synth from Britt pop)
Infested! (COURSE OF EMPIRE)- Club mix (industrial hard beats)
That Way Again (SEVEN RED SEVEN)- Minus-4 Mercury mix (ravey/thumpy)
Still Thinking (SEVEN RED SEVEN)- "Thinking of You" cassingle club mix
So Many People (HUBERT KaH)- Extended Dance Mix- keeps the beat going...
Fools Gold (THE STONE ROSES)- 12" version of a Guy Called Gerald mix!! 
Answer Me (ANYTHING BOX)- Pumped V2.2 mix (vinyl thing...)
Where is Love and Happiness (ANYTHING BOX) Ultraviolet remix by TWITCH
Let There Be Light (MIKE OLDFIELD)- B.T.'s Pure Luminescence mix (13:49)

Ok.  So, I found myself really liking B.T.'s remix of the rather mellow 
MIKE OLDFIELD track from _Songs from Distant Earth_ (?) CD.  But this was 
a just INCREADIBLE mix!  Very DEEP!  Constantly progressing and 
re-shaping itself- and then letting you FLY!  Then, it slows down for a 
bit and then there's a MID-release type thing, SIMILAR to when everyone 
decides to CLAP THEIR HANDS to the beat during a DJ's set...  After that 
it just LAUNCHES into more techno-beats and just is overall 
INVIGORATING.  so, WHO is this guy?  Or Woman?   I REALLY like "B.T."'s 
stuff and want to know if MORE stuff is out there!????????

If ANYONE can help me out on WHO "B.T." is or TWITCH, let me know if they 
appear on any other albums//comps..etc.

been to (in 3 different countries, five differnt states) has been fuel
largly by chems.  Be it MDMA, MDA, LSD, DMT, psilibum, THC, or alcohol ect.

hearing people say that drugs are not an important part of the scene, and in
the same breath telling me what a killer time they had on E last week.

never given anyone shit because they were high or not!

To: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

BY YOUR COMMAND;

	Everyone has been asking this, it seems like latey?, What is a
raver or raving for that matter. This is how I define a raver. 

	A International/InterGallactic Citzen.

	Mission: To spread, awareness, peace, love, positivity, tolerance,
and all the beliefs we share; refered to as PLUR; through out the
universe. In order to combat the whole sale slaughter of human dignity & turn
around the negativity, which seems to permeate this grid we call Earth. 
	
			TAKE BACK THE GRID


IN MY OPINION, WHICH COMES AS A RESULT OF MY SOMETIME CONTINUED & MAINTAINED 
AWARENESS WHILE EXPERINCEING LIFE.........

	Experience & awareness bring about change in humanity, for humans
need to become aware of a problem or an issue before they can change it.
This process of becoming aware, whether in be an internal process like a
macrophage marking a substance found in the body body as foreign, and 
making other cells, like Killer T cells aware of it's exsistance. 

	This awareness process can be external like when you sit in a
classroom, or watch a movie, and something in the presentation touchs your
spirit. 

	Or it can be a combination of the two, for example a rave. Where
you've take a substance that affects your bodies internal homeostasis,
while you're being bombared by external taste, smell, sight, sound, & tactile
sensations. 

	Awareness is the key here, so as far as D&A go's, if these
substances or these experiences enhanced or created by them, make your
more aware of that light that shines from within you, that shines from
within me, that shines from within us all, then I am for these experiences, 
then I am for anything than enhances ones awareness.

	But on the other hand, if these substances & experiences blinds you
from seeing that light within yourself, leave them. Because if you can't
see it first within yourself, then you will never be able to see it in
others, and ignorance, hatred, & intolerance will prevail. 

	Why do so many of us refuse to acknowledge what we are, by
quickly give away all your power to a drug, sad. It's not the drug, it's
YOU, you make it happen, YOU are powerful, YOU are magic. Gods have come,
gods have gone; we exsist, we survive, by being aware, adaptable, & the
most survivable creatures on the planet. We have gone & continue to go
where no other creature could survive, not even a roach. For a time our
bodies defy chaos, this force that's constantly tearing everything down
around us & including us. You are walking magic, don't you see it?

	I see my parents bitter, and old, because they worked their lives
away, and worshipped a false god(limiting lifes experiences, almost hiding
from them). I will not allow myself to be 70, never having experienced
what it was like to climb a mountain, and then smoke a bowl, do E & dance
all night, <<<<<<blank, you fill in>>>>>...etc. When I'm old, and a 
younger person asked me about an event in my history, I want to be able 
to tell them that I was there, this is what happen, this is how it made 
me feel. Not, oh i was working, or oh I sorta remember reading about that 
stuff in the paper or seeing those folks on TV.

	Drugs, education, life itself, bring about experience & awareness. 
Your dead for an enternity(my beliefs), you have but a small window to
experience life in all it's states, forms, and environments, and if there
is something behond, you'll be armed with a lifetime of experiences, some 
even to extremes.

	This came off kinda preachy, I'm aware of this, let me just say,
that this was & continues to be my path of maintained awareness &
discovery. I beg your forgiveness if I've offended anyone, it was not my
intention. 

	Also, I may appear hippocritical to some, all I have in my defense
is nothing in life is black & white. There are days that my level of
awareness is very high, and the love just pores outta of me, and other
days where I'm blinded by my own pride, greed, excess, lust, & desire, and
my lack of awareness can lead me to sometimes hurting my brother & sister. 
You never really arrive at 100% love, or 100% evil, but rather always
oscillating around a point. It's sorta like in math when you try and
calculate the limit of f(x) = x as x approaches infinite, you never get
there, you can only approach it. 

	My intention was/is to add my defination of a raver to the many, share 
my thoughts, feelings, & experience in a hope that you will see the power 
the lies within YOU, not a drug.

	   Peace, Love & Happy Holidays From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 29 00:47:51 1995

Received: from EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU by EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU (PMDF V4.2-11 #5526) id
 <01HY79G2MX1O8Y5DXE@EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU>; Wed, 29 Nov 1995 03:47:27 EST
Date: 29-NOV-1995 03:09:04.35
Subject: Tribal Funk Q/A
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <01HY79G2MX1Q8Y5DXE@EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU>
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Many, many thanks to everyone who came out to Tribal Funk's Second Birthday
last saturday. From all the smiles we saw all night, we're sure that most
people had a great time and we had a great time putting it on.

>From the posts I have read, however, there seem to be a few questions and
rumors running amuck. Please feel free to contact me with any questions you
might have about the night, Tribal Funk, or our goal. We have always tried
to be completely open and honest about our parties. You may remember that
I posted our last newsletter to this list. In it I had written that  the
price of the party was going to be $15 before midnight. Because the police
called us on Wed. and charged us $4200 to have 8 police officers in the party
all night, we had to raise the admission price to cover our costs. We were
not happy about this. The armory is state property and therefore not subject
ot local jurisdiction. We had talked to the police 2 weeks before the party
and they said everyting was fine. But three days before the party, we were
in no position to argue the finer points of the legality of the police's
actions. However, the police behaved themselves very well. And by the end
of the night, the Srgt was telling us about a few locations in Richmond which
might be good places to hold future events. I want to thank everyone for
behaving themselves and putting forth a positive image that made the police
supportive of our event.

For those who had problems with regards to drugs at the party, we announced
on the voicemail that the police would be there and to be careful. We are
not able to provide a space which is exempt from the law. You choose to use
them at your own risk always.

We tried to alert everyone to everything they should have expected for the
night on the voicemail. We did not try to trick anyone.

The police decided at 12:30 that we had filled the hall to capacity and forbid
us to admit more people. People stood in line until nearly 3 am to get in.
We reduced the admission price to $10 for those who had to wait.

There were no tags whatsoever on Saturday night. We are really happy that
the scene has been policing itself. Thanks to all that didn't tag.

We frisked everyone who came to the party. If you didn't notice, the party
took place in the ghetto. It is not a safe neighborhood. We had a bunch of
locals come join us at the party. They were all great and we are glad they
came. Never the less, we would not risk allowing someone to bring a gun or
knife into the party. It is our responsibilty to provide a safe party and
we feel that frisking and searching bags is a necessary evil to provide that
safety.

Not allowing bottled water into the party was a policy enforced by the police.
If we had been allowed to control that, we would have allowed the water inside.
Nonetheless, there was free water inside. We appologize for the inconvienance.

The reason the laser and lights were still programming during the party was
because the light show, New Dimension Productions, arrived late and without
a power distro. We had to get Mark Wayne to go back to Concord and get another
so the lights would work. That meant that the laser and lights didn't get
power until 10:30. Also, we never turn on all our goodies at the beginning
of the night. We build everything up and are constantly changing what visual
effects are going. We feel that makes for a more interesting and dynamic
show. (The 20-watt laser was fucking amazing!!)

The final cost for the hall was just under $1500 but that does not include
many costs.

The party was very hot, but we rented fans to help ease the heat. We could
not open the windows because of the near-by neighbors. It would have allowed
to much noise to escape.

I think that answers most of the questions raised. If you have any more please
contact me. Its been a great two years. We've had a lot of fun. We hope everyone
else has too. We'll see you all at the next one. Keep Smiling.

Peace,
Colin

Everyone says that E is supposed to open you up to the Universe, etc. 
>From my own experience, that is true. Drugs give people the key to a 
door of perception that must unlocked before it can be ventured through.
I've often wondered if I would be able to have these types of experiences 
if that door had never been opened.

Many times I've had enlightening experiences while dancing. No drug could
ever come *close* to what I've experienced sober. It's much more intense
to be *high* on the energy at 3 am than to be high on something that's
going to make you depressed for the next two days. (IMHO)

I've done my share of partaking (and probably someone else's, too) and
probably will continue to do so in the future from time to time. On the
occasions when I don't, however, I often get tired and fall asleep for an
hour or two. But that's no sacrifice in comparison to what I'm gaining. 

There's nothing like having your everyday self ripped wide open for the
world to see and simultaneously being so full of energy you could burst. 

Being connected to the universal energy source without "static" is
indescribable. This specific type of connection, as far as I know, just
simply isn't possible in a drug-induced state. Buoyancy doesn't even cover
it. You feel like you're floating- like your feet are barely touching the
ground with the beats. That is more like like the definition of what
ecstasy is than Ecstasy could ever hope to be. :)

Sorry to go off like that, but I just had a vivid recollection of dancing
on saturday night at Burning Man... ahhh.
						lv, Alex
my $.0225 (inflation)



viva | Alexandra Crocket  | "Reality is anything            
plur | alex_c@scs.unr.edu |  you can get away with"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 29 08:28:18 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id IAA22957; Wed, 29 Nov 1995 08:28:18 -0800
Received: from hp1.online.apple.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id IAA22952; Wed, 29 Nov 1995 08:28:15 -0800
From: MVasey@eworld.com
Received: by hp1.online.apple.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id IAA15813; Wed, 29 Nov 1995 08:27:39 -0800
Date: Wed, 29 Nov 1995 08:27:39 -0800
Message-ID: <951129082734_19442136@hp1.online.apple.com>
To: Msjoel@aol.com
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: SRL boy/girl?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

joel' wrote:

>not to break this down on boy/girl lines, since i really liked the show, but
>i think it's another case of boys with toys, albeit really cool ones.

My first impression years ago at the first SRL show I saw was the same. It
was really cool and interesting but I kept getting this underlying feeling
that it was really just some big boys with some very interesting "toys". More
that just toys though, art as well as a statement about society and
technology...but mostly toys. Still my type of thing though and I've really
enjoyed the shows since the first one.

There is an overabundance of "boys" though, even though there were many women
involved in planning, producing, building, and operating the show. 

This show was the first SRL show I've been involved in. I worked with a woman
named Laurel. Laurel designed and built the "fighting guy" robots that were
hanging from an I-beam. I wrote the code that controlled them. My first trip
over to the SRL machine shop about two weeks before the show I expected to
find 5-10 "boys" working in some ultra-geeky machine shop. What I found was
about 20-40 people working on all sorts of projects for the show. There was
actually a good mix of people of all types... men, women, young, old,
techno-geeks (like me:), artists, etc. It seemed many of the machines were
individual or small group projects that would be incorporated into the show.
Not very structured at all, lots of freedom, and a good environment for
creative ideas. A very positive experience. I did not detect any elitism or
sexism or any other -ism...

But, the show itself does give a different impression. Too many guys in
machine shop suits w/remote controlls running in and around the machines.
Laurel and I sat near the audience attempting to control our robots (one of
which had been knocked off by the missle loader :(  ). I very much enjoyed
the show but if I must pick some nits they would be:

- I would prefer that they keep the show floor clear of as many "people" as
possible. The main offenders were the jump-suited robot controllers with
there remote-control boxes. This, I think, contributes to the "boys with
toys" experience many people go away with. I think this would also give the
robots/machines more of an autonomous look/feel. Keep it to machines and
props only.

-I would prefer that they keep the camera crews off the floor completely. I
know it probably added to the quality of the live internet feed but it was
very distracting. I just reviewed several videos people made from the
audience and its amazing how in every shot there were several camera people
in the way...

I hope I get a chance to help out again, and I encourage anyone (especially
more females) with some good ideas or skills to contact Mark Pauline and
volunteer. He seems to be very open to all sorts of ideas/peoples.

peace,
martin

quoth Brenda Brewer <shakti@teleport.com>
>I'd like to get some feedback from people out there who don't feel the
>need to include drugs/alcohol as part of their raving experience.

I don't do alchohol or other drugs, I go to raves, I dance, I trance, I hug
and cuddle, I feal the love around me, I have a great time, I ride my
motorcycle home without risk of DUI or extreme liklyhood of death and I
wake up the next day feeling good. Very little of this would be the case if
I were to use drugs, you see,  I don't get this, getting a little high
bullshit. When I get loaded, it's all or nothing, full on, double vision
drunk, passing out, loud and obnoxious, numb to the world, to high to feel
the vibe or any thing else, damn near puking my guts out but somehow saving
that for the hangover that lats all day the next day.  I'm having way more
fun clean and sober, not that I didn't have some fun loaded, just less fun
and the problems really sucked.

If asked, I would explain, that I was fine, everything under control, I'm
not not an adict, why just look the brand of beer I'm drinking, $6.50 a
sixer,  class stuff, not like the $2.89 a 12 pack shit that adicts drink.
Yup I'm just fine, I'm shit faced drunk, on 4 hits of acid, and stoned into
stupidity, but I'm fine, it's those nasty crank users who have a problem.

Besides, not doing drugs leaves me money for important stuff, like records
and motorcycle maintenance.

Michael Standish    DoD#732               standish@c2.org     CBR600F
2 wheels good, 4 wheels bad               510.525.FILM     (525.3456)

	Thank you for your uncompromising honesty, however, I still feel

to protect & to serve, thanks. Word will now travel in law enforcement
(brother cop) as well as the lawless that raves, & ravers are EASY
targets!!!!! Thanks for selling us out, what will our price be next time

or Friend's & Family, for cheap, Sometimes in the process of creating
something wonderful you must go back to your roots to see where you left
your true path. Just a sincere thought, but then who am I trying to tell
you how you should manage your parties, then again I got socked for
$40.00. 

On 29 Nov 1995 CDUWE@EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU wrote:

> I posted our last newsletter to this list. In it I had written that  the
> price of the party was going to be $15 before midnight. Because the police
> called us on Wed. and charged us $4200 to have 8 police officers in the party
> all night, we had to raise the admission price to cover our costs. We were
> not happy about this. The armory is state property and therefore not subject
> ot local jurisdiction. We had talked to the police 2 weeks before the party
> and they said everyting was fine. But three days before the party, we were
> in no position to argue the finer points of the legality of the police's
> actions. However, the police behaved themselves very well. And by the end
> of the night, the Srgt was telling us about a few locations in Richmond which
> might be good places to hold future events. I want to thank everyone for
> behaving themselves and putting forth a positive image that made the police
> supportive of our event.
> 
> For those who had problems with regards to drugs at the party, we announced
> on the voicemail that the police would be there and to be careful. We are
> not able to provide a space which is exempt from the law. You choose to use
> them at your own risk always.
> 
> We tried to alert everyone to everything they should have expected for the
> night on the voicemail. We did not try to trick anyone.
> 
> The police decided at 12:30 that we had filled the hall to capacity and forbid
> us to admit more people. People stood in line until nearly 3 am to get in.
> We reduced the admission price to $10 for those who had to wait.
> 
> There were no tags whatsoever on Saturday night. We are really happy that
> the scene has been policing itself. Thanks to all that didn't tag.
> 
> We frisked everyone who came to the party. If you didn't notice, the party
> took place in the ghetto. It is not a safe neighborhood. We had a bunch of
> locals come join us at the party. They were all great and we are glad they
> came. Never the less, we would not risk allowing someone to bring a gun or
> knife into the party. It is our responsibilty to provide a safe party and
> we feel that frisking and searching bags is a necessary evil to provide that
> safety.
> 
> Not allowing bottled water into the party was a policy enforced by the police.
> If we had been allowed to control that, we would have allowed the water inside.
> Nonetheless, there was free water inside. We appologize for the inconvienance.
> 
> The reason the laser and lights were still programming during the party was
> because the light show, New Dimension Productions, arrived late and without
> a power distro. We had to get Mark Wayne to go back to Concord and get another
> so the lights would work. That meant that the laser and lights didn't get
> power until 10:30. Also, we never turn on all our goodies at the beginning
> of the night. We build everything up and are constantly changing what visual
> effects are going. We feel that makes for a more interesting and dynamic
> show. (The 20-watt laser was fucking amazing!!)
> 
> The final cost for the hall was just under $1500 but that does not include
> many costs.
> 
> The party was very hot, but we rented fans to help ease the heat. We could
> not open the windows because of the near-by neighbors. It would have allowed
> to much noise to escape.
> 
> I think that answers most of the questions raised. If you have any more please
> contact me. Its been a great two years. We've had a lot of fun. We hope everyone
> else has too. We'll see you all at the next one. Keep Smiling.

Subject: Re: drugs/alcohol
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

1) Wayne is not allowed to leave us.  He's far too cool, and Vince would
look weird without him.

2) After reading all the posts on this, here's my personal synthesis.  For
me, the drugs are totally optional.  One of the greatest times I had at a
rave was an Organic in the Park, and I was totally sober.  In fact, all of
the most amazing, spiritual events of my life, with one noteable exception
(but I believe that actually happened _in spite_ of the drugs), all happened
when I was sober.  When I was driving to LA this summer with my
friend/soulmate/ other half Tiesha, she told me this story about going to
Crater Lake in the middle of the night and seeing this huge body of
undisturbed water perfectly reflecting the sky above, and how it was the
most amazing thing she'd ever seen.  I can think of a lot of personal
experiences that were similar.  And when I think of the times I've felt most
connected with people, they also happened when I was sober.  I can
specifically think of a party I went to in high school where I ended up
spending the night there with about 25 other people, only about two or three
of whom I knew, and we all ended up as best friends.  

Go on a hike in the middle of nowhere with a few of your best friends
sometime and you'll see what I mean.  Personally, I think that any feelings
you have on drugs you can have when you're sober, too (at least I can).  And
ultimately, that's better because it all comes from you.  It's amazing what
the human mind can do, and people usually underestimate that power.  I mean,
think about how most people act on E.  What's preventing them from acting
that way normally?  Nothing, except themselves.  Sure, you may get some cool
visual and aural effects when you're high, but that's not the reason most
people I've talked to do them.  It's for the mental affects, the way you
percieve things.  Well, it's totally possible to percieve things that way
all the time if you just make the effort and stop thinking that the drugs
are responsible for your behaviour.  Ultimately, it's all you.


Jake

Brian-
I have some advice for you. Some of us had fun at Tribal Funk. Some of us did
not. Let it die!

I had a great time at that party, only to find posts by you and others have
totally screwed up my lovely memories of it. I am trying to turn every rave I
go to into a positive experience, even if it looks somewhat sketchy from the
start. 

And no, I don't agree with you that every rave I go to should be low budget
like FnF. That would be boring. FnF was a great rave, but it was not ALL
THAT. That light show at Tribal Funk was PHAT. I have never seen anything
like it in SF. The music was excellent also. Maybe Tribal Funk was not the
rave for you, but we all knew what to expect from the phone message! We also
knew that it would be a big budget rave. If you don't like those kind of
raves, you don't have to go to them. But don't go and then come back & tell
us all how it sucked. 

This is not just directed at you now, but I am sick of all these cry-baby
ravers who post negative comments after every event they go to. I am SORRY if
the events don't live up to your expectations, but I don't care! (Kundalini
was an exception of course, but it didn't even happen). I can just picture
some folks who can't wait to go home and start composing messages about how
this or that sucked. What a buzzkill, people. I am sick of all the negative
comments about these awful rave promoters who are out to rip us all off and
steal our money. W/o the promoters, there would be no scene! How about some
positive comments sometimes? There is a ton of negative energy on this list.
Ironically, the same people who do the most complaining post messages about
being positive. What's up with that? All of the messages I read every day
trashing the scene & the people do nothing for my enchancement of any event I
go to. 

As my friends used to say to me: "Just shut up and dance."

MsPhink
