> 	Thank you for your uncompromising honesty, however, I still feel
> ripped off, and will ****never***** be attending another one of your
> parties. I feel you should never have given that money to the police, you
> opened up our scene to nothing more than petty extortion, from those sworn
> to protect & to serve, thanks. Word will now travel in law enforcement
> (brother cop) as well as the lawless that raves, & ravers are EASY
> targets!!!!! Thanks for selling us out, what will our price be next time 
> $8000.00, $10,000.00 where will it end.
> 
Brian, This is not the first time the scene has been the victim of extortion
nor will it be the last.  Would you rather that Tribal Funk politely
cancelled their party, so that we could sit here and complain about how inept
Tribal Funk is for losing their space? The fact of the matter is that the
police do not trust the rave scene.  Isn't Richmond part of Alameda County,
whose leaders are still in shock from the Cool World incident, who were
threatening to outlaw all forms of all night dance parties... It's true
that Cool World isn't representative of the rest of the scene but who
knows that except for us?  How will anyone learn?  We have to take
responsibility for things like Cool World and show the police that we
have much more to offer than that... this means that we probably will
have to party with them for a while.  We will have to keep paying them
off for a while.  It'll be hard, but we and the scene will survive and
the end result will be more trust on both sides.  Tribal Funk isn't the
enemy... that distrust on BOTH sides is.  Tribal Funk has thrown a lot
of good parties, and it may seem like they're detiorating or turning on
us but they're not.  Our scene is growing by leaps and bounds and 
confronting new parts of society that it hasn't had to face yet... 
thousands of young kids who grew up with gangsta images and their concerned
parents who are afraid of the violent world that threatens these kids...
That's a lot of fear and mistrust to deal with... but Tribal Funk and
the rest of us are dealing with it, working with it and growing more
and more together with every encounter.  Some encounters work better than
others.  But the net result is that of steady growth. Throwing a
massive on Thanksgiving weekend is harder than it looks, you get a lot
of strays and a lot of attention.  I think Tribal Funk is doing fine.

> 	Some advice, tell Hollywood Dog to stay in LA(there's penty of
> hungry, excellent light/laser tallent right here), tell the expensive LA
> DJ's to stay there as well, and try and throw great parties like Gateway
> or Friend's & Family, for cheap, Sometimes in the process of creating
> something wonderful you must go back to your roots to see where you left
> your true path. Just a sincere thought, but then who am I trying to tell
> you how you should manage your parties, then again I got socked for
> $40.00. 
> 
I don't get it.  One week everyone's complaining that all the DJs here
sound the same and blessed be the promotors that bring in the out of town
DJs for the special nights... and then on a big weekend like Thanksgiving
you're complaining that there were out of town DJs.  Gateway and Friend's
and Family parties are great, but serve an entirely different purpose, and
I don't think should be compared.  If Friend's and Family had thrown a
openly public massive on Thanksgiving I'm sure they would have to charge
more than $5.  Big parties play a very important role in our scene.  
and just because it can be harder for us to have fun at them doesn't mean
they are our enemy.  It just means we need to open our hearts just a
little more to start accomodating everyone.

and you didn't get socked for $40.  You should know that big parties
run the risk of costing you $20 and the risk that you will be exposed
to forces unexpected that will keep you from having the most fabulous
night of your life.  I've found that taking that risk pays for itself
in one way or another, just not always in the way I expected.  You
gave up your money of your own free will... if you don't feel it was
justified then never go to another Tribal Funk again, take that lesson
in exchange for your $40.  Only I hope that at some level you see that
you weren't really unknowingly cheated or abused.  We all have to take 
responsibility for our actions in order to free ourselves...

As for myself, I'm looking forward to the next Tribal Funk.

and remember, if life never sucked, we'd never notice how
fucking beautiful it is.

regards,
-john.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

When I have been previously been critical of parties (with the exception of
Kundalini), I was not dropping a bunch of negative comments onto SFRaves
for the purpose of killing the promoter, or the party. I usually just want
to go to a better party next time, and quite often, SFRaves is the closest
thing to a feedback loop many promoters have to find out how to improve
their parties the next time they throw one. I also think that a lot of
promoters can learn from the lessons of their peers by paying attention to
what people say about other promoter's parties on SFRaves for the prupose
of improving things or incorporating good feedback for even their own
parties.

I've seen comments about Tribal Funk go both ways. Some people may have
misconstrued my words when I very briefly spoke earlier (in other threads)
about Tribal Funk. I never, ever said that it sucked, but here are some of
my suggestions on how to improve things to make it even better, and also
what I liked about the party even the way it was.

--
Tribal Funk was not perfect.
--
It cost $20 due to law enforcement. I don't like paying $20 for a party.
Maybe it's in my mind. I used to have a problem with $15 parties, but I
have learned to live with it when the parties are great or it's obvious
that the money was spent really well. I would be happy to pay $0-$10 for
'okay' parties and $15 for 'great' parties indefinitely, but unless there's
something really extraordinary to cause it, I would appreciate it greatly
if parties could cost $15 or less. There are some things that cause the
party to cost more. For instance, if you are flying in some really big guns
from somewhere that cost a *lot* to hire and transport or, like in this
specific case, the law enforcement 'problem' caused the party to cost more
at the last minute, and that's just the way that it is.

As a promoter, there's not much you can do about 'the law enforcement
problem' when your use permits' validity is at the hands of the local
police chief and he has a bunch of officers that would be glad to take your
profits in the form of overtime, 'working' at your party, against your
will, as a condition of your permit.

Yes, I was bummed at the aforementioned high law enforcement presence, but
I am beginning to live with the fact that this will probably continue to be
the trend at the larger parties. I am not bummed *because they were there*.
I don't mind seeing a lot of cops. They are my friends. My father was a cop
for 25 years. But as a responsible, non-dangerous, non-tagging, non-violent
raver, I just don't want to have to pay extra for them if possible.

The downside to the 'law enforcement problem' here is that the extra
charges pushed the promoter's venue costs up from $1500 to nearly $6000.
That's quite a cost hike, and of course, the promoters have no choice but
to pass it on to the consumers. It's not Tribal Funk's problem if they got
screwed into hiring a bunch of cops as a condition of their use permit.
It's just unfortunate for all that it happened.

In fact, regular clubs in San Jose all get screwed this way, every night
they are open past midnight. They are *forced* to hire off-duty San Jose
police officers to stand around outside their clubs (and even totally
mellow coffee houses!) to 'protect the peace' or their use permit will
either not be issued or just plain revoked! The way a club owner finds out
about this is when they go to apply for their use permit in San Jose they
get a call from someone in the police department 'downtown' telling them
about all these officers that are looking for overtime pay and that their
permits will be issued sooner/at all if the club owner will employ these
off-duty cops! San Jose has also passed laws that completely outlaw all
dancing past 2:00am, even for 21+ clubs and venues! Now *that's* an
unfriendly town!

At Tribal Funk (and any other parties that area *required* to hire police)
the real bummer is that most all the cops did was stand around in uniform
all night and talk to each other, while you and I (and the promoters) paid,
and paid, and paid. I would have rather the extra $5 bought us a Doc Martin
[or fill in the name of your favorite big-gun out of town DJ] for the
night, etc., etc. or the party could have just cost the planned $15. But
that's the way it was, and once explained, it makes perfect sense why it
was $20.

It was pretty hot and humid. This was my first party in a big concrete gym
(or a big concrete gym called an 'armory', in this case). I am used to
dedicated dance venues like King Street, etc. that are better prepared to
hold hundreds of sweaty dancers, etc. Because this place is not really
designed to hold 1500 sweaty dancers, it was pretty warm and humid inside.
Sometimes getting all sweaty while dancing feels great -- you know, like
you're dancing harder or something, but eventually you just want to be
dryer and cooler in the long run. The fans placed around the building were
welcome additions, but it was still pretty hot and wet in there. I don't
think that the heat was a problem, but the humidity was. This happens, and
I am used to being in a room full of sweaty dancers, but I would never say
no to some good old A/C or fresh air.

There was no ambient area. More important to me personally was there was no
ambient room, or even at least a big enough area full of w/ soft seating to
hold all the people that wanted chill out. I've gotten used to the idea of
having a soft, and if lucky, ambient music filled area to hang out in when
I get too tired to dance. So when I was really, really tired, there was
really no where to go. Since it was in one big concrete room, not much
could be done to fix that. The main area was kinda hard (concrete and
all...) The outside area was there, but totally dark, and too cold and wet
(dewpoint, ya' know) later in the night to really hang around for too long.
I would go from soaking myself inside from dancing to drying myself outside
and then go back inside again to be warm. Maybe that area could have had a
couple of lights and heaters to keep the chill off the air?  Maybe a
chill-out tent in that other parking lot area where the generators were? It
looked pretty big out there when I peeked my head out the door by the
women's bathroom that led to the inside parking lot. Having a comfortable
place to 'get away from it all' is a *really* nice thing to have when you
have a bunch of tired ravers that need somewhere to crash for a while. Just
a suggestion.

--
Tribal Funk was great:
--
It was consistently probably the best music I have heard at a rave all
year. From the time we got there around 11:30pm, and all the way until 8am,
the music was really, really, really good. I am *still* kicking myself for
not having the energy (either via a good night's sleep the night before or
via stimulants) to stay awake *all night* to take advantage of that music!

I would like to know who played in what order so I can get it all straight
in my mind. I think it went Utopia (xx:xx-11:30) [before we got there],
Tony (11:30-1:30), Dan (1:30-3:30), Trance (3:30-5:30), Garth/Jeno combo
(5:30-8:00).

Tony's, Dan's and Trance's sets were great! The relentless slamming beats
during Dan and Trance's sets were to die for! I want to hear those guys
again soon! Somewhere in between two of the sets was that house singer,
too, but I was outside when that happened. The Garth/Jeno combo was the
first time I have ever seen two DJ's tag-team a set at a rave.

I would definitely buy mix tapes of the entire night's music if available.

The visuals and the lasers were also totally cool. It seems that people are
finally starting to more consistently spend money on 'extras' like lasers
which definitely make a party feel more deluxe and complete. I would
consider them required party ingredients, much like the sound system and
the DJ's are. It definitely gives a party a much bigger presence.

I also got to spend time with some SF Raves people I never met before like
Robert Smith, who I talked to for over an hour, and RAFONE (including
RAFONE belt buckle, so we can remember who he is!) and I saw a other people
I knew, too.

--
Aside from any other critique, everybody agreed that the music and lasers
were both top notch.

With all said, Tribal Funk's definitely on course for putting on good
parties. They obviously learned quite a bit that night and I am sure those
insights will be incorporated into future events.

Yes, I would go to another Tribal Funk.
--

_____________________________________________________________________
Wayne D. Correia
900 Tennessee St.         TEL: 415.826.6000            wayne@club.net
San Francisco CA 94107    FAX: 415.826.6100      http://www.club.net/
_____________________________________________________________________

Precedence: bulk

Richmond is in Contra Costa County.  Despite it's perceived
conservatism, CCC seems to be the only place allowing large raves
these days.  Richmond is doing it because they need the money-they're
one of the poorest bay area cities.  It's a minor inconvenience to
them for the $$$.  I'm glad to see their starting to have a more
sympathetic, or should I say, less antagonistic attitude toward
parties.  

There's an enlightening article in today's Tribune about the Cool
World "incident" in which police were caught off-guard by the size of
the party and the noise from an outdoor soundsystem.  Apparently the
city of Oakland, who permitted the party, didn't know or care about
the size of the party or the noise until people complained.  If
promoters are are going to stay above ground, they'll have to
communicate and coordinate with the authorities better.

The upshot of the article was that city officials were asleep at the
wheel, and that the promoters took advantage of their lack of
attention to detail.  If they can get the "juice" in city hall, I
wouldn't be surprised to see them back in Oakland.

Best quote(Kenni Ski, Cool World):"Cyberfest is not a free love,
youth-oriented, drug and alcohol fest reminscent of the '60's.
Sorry."

Apology accepted.

David

> You are welcome, I hope the info was helpful. . :)
>Also a little  suggestion to all that are listening: 
>The best thing to do if you or your friends are dissatisfied with what the
scene is producing, consider creating your own events.
>It is the only way to change what you dont like and try your own ideas.Also
It  might make you moore sympathetic to what producers and promoters go
through to throw a party. They are usually required to hire security cops as
part of an rental agreement, and not because they prefer to. The vibe that
is created at smaller parties I find much more enjoyable due to the fact
that the people throwing them arent in it for the money, but just to throw a
good party. Also I find the people who seek out the smaller more intamate
functions are more into the old spirit and vibe that seems to be getting
more and more absent at the mainstream parties.Remember a 20 dollar charge
dosent mean a better party, just more greed and less of the true spirit of
the rave.
>
> one of the hole in the wall parties that i had the best times at
>- anyone remember Scrambled  on sunday mornings, Quite a regular fallowing.
BOY those were the days. It was made possible by the the boys from Renegade
Jon "the Mac", and the  Sean Murray. It was a vintage party, lots of smiling
faces and always a good time. Jon is in Atlanta , Georgia and Sean is
working with Progress these days, Scrambled held its last party months ago,
but I hope I get to see them work together  again. They were dedicated to
the old shool way.Mabey they will get together to throw 420 again this year,
If you hear of it come April I suggest you attend. These boys threw a good
one last year, Beautiful location , beautiful people  and a beautiful
feeling.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 29 20:34:30 1995

	id UAA21217; Wed, 29 Nov 1995 20:33:39 -0800
Date: Wed, 29 Nov 1995 20:33:39 -0800
Message-Id: <199511300433.UAA21217@ix4.ix.netcom.com>
From: scary@ix.netcom.com (Gary Burns )
Subject: Playing at the moment...
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk


	For thanksgiving I spent a few days with family in LA. By pure
	chance, I stumbled across a great record store - StreetSounds, 
	somewhere in West Hollywood.

	The staff were friendly, attitude free, the listening stations
	looked top notch, and although I didn't have much time to flip
	around, the record selection looked really good. 

	Anyway, as I had little time or money, I decided to pick up a
	couple of tapes - lots of DJ's I'd never heard, or even heard 
	of. 

	Marques Wyatt, the Vocal experience - you could guess by the 
	name, nice house, well mixed, nice mellow music.

	Christopher Lawrence. This one's labelled Contact, and you can 
	feel the aliens taking notice when you play it. Acid/Trance
	Techno material, nifty mixing, *great* records, one of the 
	best tapes I've heard since arriving here.

	Don't know if you can pick these up in SF, but they're both 
	worth the money if you like that type of music (which is 
	saying a lot, given the price of tapes...)

	Keep it tidy,
	Gary

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 29 22:13:23 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA06964; Wed, 29 Nov 1995 22:13:23 -0800
Received: from dons.ac.usfca.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id WAA06956; Wed, 29 Nov 1995 22:13:19 -0800
Message-Id: <199511300613.WAA06956@taz.hyperreal.com>
Date: Wed, 29 Nov 95 22:09:22 PST
X-Sender: lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Matthew D. P. K. Lanier)
Subject: is sfraves rave related?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-
i haven't had a chance to go to a decent party since semtember.  i'd like
all of you who gripe to remember how lucky you are to be in san francisco.
we have one of the best vibes around.  vibes ebb and flow.  maybe we're in a
down time.  that happens with cycles.  
if the party you're at isn't up to your standards, you have two choices.
1)accept it as part of the cycle that every scene, religious group,
community etc goes through and try to make the best of it.  make sure that
you are not one of the people dragging the vibe down, and maybe you'll just
find yourself enjoying it after a while.  or 2) go home and cry that all the
world is against you.  i find option #1 much more preferable.

so, to the people who are distressed about our scene, remember who is the
scene: it is not external, we are the scene.  if you do not like, that you
work to change it.  don't ask other people to.  this external locus of
control crap annoys me.

peace, love, and annoyance-

matt

p.s. i love you all, and hope to see you at whatever great rave i find
myself at this friday.  we are the scene: it does not exist outside of us.

mdplk


matthew d. p. k. lanier
vox 415-666-5659

"Peace within us, peace over us, peace under our feet.
peace behind us, peace around us, let all around us be peace."
     - David Haas

Subject: why I like MAD, some more
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 29 Nov 1995 22:42:26 -0800 (PST)
In-Reply-To: <199511290036.QAA10535@slip-1.slip.net> from "Illumin8" at Nov 28, 95 04:36:11 pm

Precedence: bulk

Hello everybody,

MAD, like last week, had magic.  Yippee! it looks like we've got a place to
hang-out and be with friends that you wouldn't normally see.  Such as 
Victor, moving here from Detroit & who is on this list, maybe?
 
As well as due to who's doing MAD, the magic might also be due to its
being in a Brazilian place. Brazilians are accustomed to having fun,
you know.  Unlike so many people in the US who suffer from having been 
raised Puritans, without even knowing it.  

It was so much fun to scoot around on that nice little dancefloor, the
music at just the right volume for enjoyment.  I appreciated that MAD
was 18 and above.  One suggestion to the door personnel:  marking those 
of us who can drink with nothing more than a black magic marker "X" is 
really NOT enforcing the liquor laws.  Is this a private joke or have you 
simply not had the time to snag a MAD stamp?  Don't tempt me to bring 
along a Sharpie from the lab. <|--- a mo bio in joke that maybe one other 
person on this list will get but probably won't think is very funny...)

Regarding the vibe:  there was just enough attitude 
there to be interesting. In low doses attitude is essential.  It's the 
tension that keeps you walking upright when you want to curl up into a 
little ball, sometimes.  Long live attitude.

Here's a little tidbit for you:  one night a week Bahia Cabana hosts a 
70's disco funk night.  the flyer encourages you to dress as either a 
"pimp" or a "ho."  Ahem.  My own Puritan attitude rises up and slaps my 
face.  Yikes!

Love,

Ann 


PS Miss Mona Love may just be getting a new job at a soon-to-be-announced 
coffee shop.  Please let's think good thoughts for Miss Mona so that she 
will no longer have to rely on the kindness of friends and strangers 
quite so much and will start getting the kind of renumeration for her 
good deeds that pays the bills.  render unto ceasar, the landlord, and 
all that.  and, of course, Pac Bell.

I found this website that allows you to search through newsgroups.  I typed
'analog synthesizers' and got 27000 hits.  
     http://dejanews2.dejanews.com/cgi-bin/nph-dnquery

  You also might want to check out Keyboard magazine I've seen some emulated
analog synths that can use MIDI.
  
                  good luck.

Hi-
	On a totally non-rave related note: 

	We have two rooms for rent in a six bedroom house in the 
Elmwood/Rockridge area of Berkeley/ North Oakland. (Near 
Alcatraz/College intersection)   We have a shared kitchen, living room, 
deck,  laundry machines, and off street parking.   BART is about a ten 
minute walk, the freeway is a couple of minutes by car, and UC campus is 
about 15 minutes by bike.  The place is also wheelchair accessible.

	The first bedroom is carpeted, it has its own entrance, and a 
half-bath.   $335/month + $490 deposit.

	The second bedroom is smaller, but very liveable, and has a 
hardwood floor.   $280/month + $350 deposit.

	Your housemates will be 4 males (potentially 4 males & 1 female).  Two 
of us are ravers, and everyone is friendly. 

	We would like to fill the rooms immediately, i.e. December 1 or 
sooner.  If this interests you, or someone you know, please either contact 
me or pass the word on.  Come check it out. 

				Dave
				Voice:  (510) 654-1755
				E:  chicken@uclink.berkeley.edu

Date: Thu, 30 Nov 1995 09:52:29 PST
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9510308177.AA817754054@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: darrele@netcom.com (Darrel Etter), sfraves@hyperreal.com,
        shawna-@ix.netcom.com
Subject: End-Up
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     Mac pegs the End-Up perfectly :)  One of the first places I discovered 
     in the 80's, it still has alot of charm, raunch, and +/-vibe along 
     w/the regulars who make it a comfortable haunt for me.  Sundays are 
     usually the best time to come down, lounge, see who's done whatever 
     the night before, and/or go off (again?).  It's still tweeky at times 
     but it always pumps wailing divas and alot more ;)  I will say, 
     though, that it's not everyone's cup of tea.
     
     Recently (the past few of months), it's gone through some changes 
     w/r/t management, drumming, keeping the sliding doors closed, "noise 
     complaints", and 86'ing people for the day...it's not like it used to 
     be, but then again, I love it 'cause it's always changing.  I think 
     the worse time for some of us ravers there is when the "Melrose Place" 
     crowd kicks in on the afternoons.
     
     Darrel asks about the End-Up sign which is still hanging.  When 
     there's other gigs going on, the promoters often put other signs up 
     over it (e.g., Sugar on Fridays) so don't fret, you can see your 
     regular sign still there sans mom's kitchen.
     
     So Shawna, I encourage you to check it out as well as other venues.  
     It takes a while to find what you want from the scene and where you 
     want to add your loving vibe.  
     
     Hope to meet you sometime!
     
     Diane  :)

The calendar has phattened up after Thanksgiving.  XNTRK has a good lineup
for friday night, and Wicked and the EBN/Banco de Gaia show should be a
good bet for Saturday night.  For the budget-conscious, try the Top on
Friday, Vanilla Fudge on Saturday, MAD on Monday and Come/Unity on Wednesday.
See you next week...

P.S.- Subscription and unsubscription info is at the bottom, as usual.

Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, December 1st - Nomad Interactive presents _XNTRK _
   Celebrate love, unity, brotherhood, community, culture, individuality,
   dance.
   DJs Carlos, Dutch, Tony, Jeno, Galen, Solar. Funkcentric Environmental
   Relaxation Zone by East Coast's Oracle. 415.675.5605 415.541.5646
   408.236.3398 916.484.4213

   rooms. 1434 Howard St. $8.

   Auzerais, San Jose

   Your Mama. The Oddball Lounge, 76 MInna St. 415.495.2851.

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)

       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)

       KMEL.

       Davis.

       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Nov 30 15:53:12 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA23325; Thu, 30 Nov 1995 15:53:12 -0800
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id PAA23316; Thu, 30 Nov 1995 15:53:07 -0800
Received: from psychoactive.com by ultima.org; Thu, 30 Nov 95 15:57 PST
X-Sender: tic-tac@mail.ultima.org
Message-Id: <v02120d02ace3e52b0b3d@[140.174.184.128]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Length: 1207
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 30 Nov 1995 15:59:24 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tic-tac@psychoactive.com (Joe Rice)
Subject: GHB redux
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This week's SF Weekly has a feature on GHB that attempts to be balanced and
provide an overview of the drug's users. It tends to focus on it's use as a
disinhibitor and sex enhancing agent, but mentions its club scene use as
well.

A couple things stood out:

3/4 of those admitted to emergency rooms under the influence of GHB had
also consumed other drugs, such as alcohol or CNS depressants, which will
act synergistically to increase the drug's effects.

This drug is unlike any other that I know of in that small doses have a
simulant effect, while larger doses act as a depressant or even an
anesthetic. The margin between a stimulant and depressant dose is slim.

At any rate, it's a decent article and basically supports the adage that
one should be know what they're doing before they do it.

Joe

>From: scary@ix.netcom.com (Gary Burns )

>
>        For thanksgiving I spent a few days with family in LA. By pure
>        chance, I stumbled across a great record store - StreetSounds,
>        somewhere in West Hollywood.
>
>        The staff were friendly, attitude free, the listening stations
>        looked top notch, and although I didn't have much time to flip
>        around, the record selection looked really good.
>
>        Anyway, as I had little time or money, I decided to pick up a
>        couple of tapes - lots of DJ's I'd never heard, or even heard
>        of.
>
>        Marques Wyatt, the Vocal experience - you could guess by the
>        name, nice house, well mixed, nice mellow music.
>
>        Christopher Lawrence. This one's labelled Contact, and you can
>        feel the aliens taking notice when you play it. Acid/Trance
>        Techno material, nifty mixing, *great* records, one of the
>        best tapes I've heard since arriving here.
>
>        Don't know if you can pick these up in SF, but they're both
>        worth the money if you like that type of music (which is
>        saying a lot, given the price of tapes...)
>
>        Keep it tidy,
>        Gary
For all you LA transplants like myself...also check out PRIME CUTS(right up
the street from street sounds)This is probrably the fattest record store in
LA(they have it all)I remember when Doc used to work there and....also DMC
and Beat-Non-Stop(steve Loria's shop)kick ass too DMC is pretty cheap and
stock House/TEchno oldies but goodies(a lot of nice re-issues too)Beat-Non
Stop has alot o stuff but it's pricey.in two weeks I will post my review of
Dr. Freecloud's Mixing Lab(I'm going on a pilgrimage)ME and a couple o
friends are headed for the city of Angles for an OPeration..(long Live Ron
D. Core!!)
>

On Wed, 29 Nov 1995, RAF*ONE wrote:

>         okay so I finally turned 21...I'm all set to goto those previously
> forbidden parties...now a couple o qquestions...
>         1.Is Wicked the same great party it was a couple
	  o years ago?or a CLUB..

It is still a great party, although the Wicked's of yesteryear were truly
LEGENDARY! Maybe one day they will return to that level of glory but
I don't think it can be achieved within the confines of any club.

>         2.how much is the cover charge?
It is $15 but since it's your birthday, I will comp you +1


>         3.What is the generL VIBE AT A WICKED PARTY?
Well I can only speak for myself, traditionally Wicked is about House Music
(in all of its forms and manifestations)  We strive to attain and 
maintain a  certain level of consciousness or vibe at the party, it's 
hard to explain but the metaphor I like to think of is that of "building
a House", it may take the most part of the evening to lay the foundation,
which is important, it's hard to put into works but the party has to reach
a certain critical mass before it can go to the next level, this is not
just a function of the DJ, or, the music they are playing, it is an 
alchemical mix of the DJ, music, venue, and most of all THE PARTY GOERS
and what they bring with them.  If you bring a lot of spectator energy
(which has been happening lately) they that's what you get, if you bring
a lot of participatory energy then that's what you get.

Wicked's tend to be on the "freaky" side, and I mean this in everything
good about the word, the party has always had and encouraged a sort of
pan-sexual atmosphere and the most amazingly exotic looking men and women
often turn up at Wicked's.

It's also about out of your head dancing, hard beats that pull you deep 
into the vibe of house and try to maintain you there for a long time after
the party.


for more info check out http://www.wicked.com
